SP.L: Ha, ha, ha. Ile pledge that: and then Ile tell you a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Well said friend; up with tha, and then out with thy secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: I will friend. And tother two friends, here's upon the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.P: I hope he will shew us a way, out of the bottom of his bowl to find his Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: This fellow was happily found.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: This was an excellent draught.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.P: But the seeret, friend, out with that, you must keep no secrets amongst friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.P: It might prove a shrew'd matter against my mis∣chevious Master as it may be handled.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Hang him cullion, that would turn thee away.
Wee'l help thee to handle it, fear it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Heark you then all friends. Shall I out with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: What else.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.P: Ile first take tother cup, and then out with't al∣together—And now it comes—If my Mistress do bring him home a bastard, she's but even with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: He has one I warrant. Has he cadzooks?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.P: That he has by this most delicate drink. But it is the Arsivarsiest Aufe that ever crept into the world. Sure some Goblin got it for him; or chang'd it in the neast, thats certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: I vow thou utterest brave things. Is't a boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.P: It has gone for a boy in short coats and long coats this seaven and twenty years.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: An Idiote is it.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.P: Yes: A very natural; and goes a thissen; and looks as old as I do too. And I think if my beard were off, I could be like him: I have taken great pains to practise his speech and action to make my self merry with him in the countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Where is he kept, friend, where is he kept.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.P: In the further side of Norfolk, where you must never see him. Tis now a dozen years since his father saw him, and then he compounded for a sum of mony with an old man, one Hulverhead, to keep him for his life time; and he never to hear of him. But I saw him within these three moneths. We hearken after him, as land-sick heirs do after their fathers, in hope to hear of his end at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.P: But heark you, friend, if your beard were off, could you be like him think you? What if you cut it off, and to him for a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Pray thee hold thy peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: My beard, friend, no: My beard's my honour.
Hair is an ornament of honour upon man or woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.P: Come, come; I know what we will do with him. Mun, knock him down with the other cup. We'l lay him to sleep; but yet watch and keep him betwixt hawk and buzzard as he is, till we make excellent sport with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hey ho. I am very sleepy.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: See he jooks already. Boy shew us a private room.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: This way, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Down, Plumpton▪parke, &c.
SP.STAGE: They lead Buz. out, and he sings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Indeed you were unkind to turn away
M maid (poor harmless maid) whose innocent mirth
Was the best chear your house afforded me.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: I am sorry sister, trust me, truly sorry,
And knew I which way to recover her
With my best care I would. Yet, give me leave,
I saw her overbold; and overheard her
Say, she foresaw that Arthur my sole enemy
Should be your husband. Ile marry you to death first.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Now you fly out again.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Your pardon again your sister,
And for your satisfaction I will strive
To oversway my passion. How now Arnold,
Me thinks I read good newes upon thy face.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: The best, Sir, I can tell is, the old Jew
Quicksands has lost his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: She is not dead,

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Tis not so well for him: for if she were
He then might overtake her though she were
Gone to the devil. But she's run away:
But to what corner of the earth, or under
Whose bed to find her is not to be thought.
It has rais'd such a laughter in the town
Among the Gallants—!

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: And do you laugh too?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Yes; and if you do not out-laugh all men
That hear the joyful newes, tis too good for you.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: I am too merciful, I kill thee not.
Out of my doors, thou villain, reprobate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Hold, Pray Sir, hold.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Never while I have power to lift a hand
Against thee, mischievous Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy
SP.L: Is not this passion, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Forbear, sister.
This is a cause turns patience into fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Arnold, forbear his sight.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: And my house too.
Or villain, look to die, oft as I see thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: Turn'd out o doors! A dainty frantick humour
In a young Master! Good enough for me though;
Because tis proper to old serving-men
To be so serv'd. What course now must I take?
I am too old to seek out a new Master.
I will not beg, because Ile crosse the proverb
That runs upon old serving creatures; stealing
I have no minde to: Tis a hanging matter.
Wit and invention help me with some shift
To help a cast-off now at a dead lift.
Sweet fortune hear my suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Why how now, Arnold! What, at thy devotion?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Ile tell you in your ear, sir, I dare trust you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vi.
SP.L: Could earthly man have dreamt this Rafcal
Whose Letchery, to all our thinking, was
Nothing but greedy Avarice and cosonage,
Could have been all this while a conceal'd whoremaster,
To have a Bastard of so many years
Nursled i'th' Countrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Note the punishments
That haunt the Miscreant for his black misdeeds;
That his base off-spring proves a natural Ideot;
Next that his wife, by whom he might had comfort
In progeny, though of some others getting,
Should with her light heels make him heavie-headed
By running of her Countrey! And lastly that
The blinded wretch should cast his servant off,
Who was the cover of his villany,
To shew us (that can have no mercy on him)
The way to plague him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: What do'st laugh at?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: To think how nimble the poor uzzard is
To be reveng'd on's Master; How he has Shap'd himself;
Cut off his beard, and practis'd all the postures
To act the Changeling bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Could we light
Upon some quaint old fellow now, could match him
To play the clown that brings him up to town,
Our company were full, and we were ready
To put our project into present action.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Gentlemen, we are fitted: take this man w'ye
He is the onely man I would have sought,
To give our project life. I'le trust thee Arnold,
And trust thou me, thou shalt get pieces by't;
Besides, Ile piece thee to thy Master again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: That clinches Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Go follow your directions.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: Come away then.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Sweet mirth thou art my Mistress. I could serve thee.
And shake the thought off of all woman kind
But that old wonts are hardly lest. A man
That's enter'd in his youth, and throughly salted
In documents of women, hardly leaves
While reins or brains will last him: Tis my case.
Yet mirth, when women fail, brings sweet incounters
That tickle up a man above their sphear:
They dull, but mirth revives a man: who's here,
The solitary musing man, cal'd Arthur,
Posses'd with seriours vanity; Mirth to me!
The world is full: I cannot peep my head forth
But I meet mirth in every corner: Ha!
Sure some old runt with a splay-foot has crost him!
Hold up thy head man; what dost seek? thy grave?
I would scarse trust you with a piece of earth
You would chuse to lye in though; if some plump Mistriss
Or a deft Lass were set before your search.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: How vainly this man talks!

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Gid ye good den forsooth.
How vainly this man talks! speak but truth now,
Does not thy thought now run upon a Wench?
I never look'd so but mine stood that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: 'Tis all your glory that; and to make boast
Of the variety that serves your lust:
Yet not to know what woman you love best.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Not I cadzooks, but all alike to me,
Since I put off my Wench I kept at Livory:
But of their use I think I have had my share,
And have lov'd every one best of living women;
A dead one I nere coveted, that's my comfort:
But of all ages that are pressable;
From sixteen unto sixty; and of all complections
From the white flaxen to the tawney-Moor;
And of all statures between Dwarf and Giants;
Of all conditions, from the Doxie to the Dowsabel.
Of all opinions, I will not say Religious:
(For what make they with any?) and of all
Features and shapes, from the huckle-back'd Bum-creeper,
To the streight spiny Shop-maid in St. Martins.
Briefly, all sorts and sizes I have tasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: And thinkst thou hast done well in't!

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: As well as I could with the worst of'em tho'l say't.
Few men come after me that mend my work.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: But thou nere thinkst of punishments to come;
Thou dream'st not of diseases, poverty,
The loss of sense or member, or the cross
(Common to such loose livers) an ill marriage;
A hell on earth to scourge thy conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Yes, when I marry, let me have a wife
To have no mercy on me; let the fate
Of a stale dovting Batchelor fall upon me;
Let me have Quicksands curse, to take a Wife
Will run away next day, and prostitute
Her self to all the world before her Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Nay, that will be too good: If I foresee
Any thing in thy marriage destiny,
'Twil be to take a thing that has been common
To th'world before, and live with thee perforce
To thy perpetual torment.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Close that point.
I cannot marry. Will you be merry, Arthur?
I have such things to tell thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: No, I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Pray thee come closer to me. What has crost thee?
Is thy suppos'd slain father come again,
To dispossess thee for another life time?
Or has thy valiant sister beaten thee? Tell me.
It shall go no further.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Let your valiant wit
And jocound humor be suppos'd no warrant
For you t'abuse your friends by.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Why didst tell me of marrying then? But I
Have done. And now pray speak what troubles you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: I care not if I do: For 'twill be Town talk.
My Sister on a private discontent
Betwixt her self and me hath left my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Gone quite away?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Yes, And I know not whither.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Beyond Sea sure to sight with th'Air, that took
Her fathers last breath into't. Went she alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: No, No; My man's gone with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Who, the fellow
That brags on's back so; the stiff strong chin'd Rascal?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Even he.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: The devil is in these young Tits,
And wildfire in their Cruppers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Let me charm you,
By all our friendship, you nor speak nor hear
An ill construction of her act in this,
I know her thoughts are noble; and my wo
Is swoln unto that fulness, that th' addition
But of word in scorn would blow me up
Into a cloud of wild distemper'd fury
Over the heads of all whose looser breath
Dare raise a wind to break me. Then I fall
A sodain storm of ruin on you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: I know not how to laugh at this: It comes
So near my pitty. But ile to my Griggs
Again; And there will find new mirth to stretch
And laugh, like tickled wenches, hand ore head.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: How does my habit and my arms become me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Too well to be a woman, manly Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: Wher's the pistol you provided for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Here Mistress and a good one.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: Tis too long.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: No Lady would wish a shorter. If it were
'T would bear no charge, or carry nothing hotne.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: Ile try what I can do. Thou think'st me valiant.
I'm sure I have often felt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: All the virago's that are found in story,
Penthesilea and Symaramis
Were no such handy strikers as your self:
But they had another stroke, could you but find it,
Then you were excellent. I could teach it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: I dare not understand thee yet. Be sure
As you respect my honour, or your life
That you continue constant to my trust,
And so thou canst not know how much Ile love thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: There is a hope as good, now, as a promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: Here at this Inne abide, and wait my coming
Be careful of my guildings: Be not seen
Abroad for fear my brother may surprise you.
Ther's money for you; and ere that be spent
Tis like I shall return.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Best stars attend you,
Mars arm thee all the day; and Venus light
Thee home into these amorous arms at night.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Be chear'd my love; help to bear up the joy,
That I conceive by thy concealed Beauty,
Thy rich imprison'd beauty, whose inranchisement
Is now at hand, and shall shine forth again
In its admired glory. I am rapt
Above the sphear of common joy and wonder
In the effects of this our quaint complot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: In the mean time, though you take pleasure in't,
My name has dearly suffered.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: But thine honor
Shall, in the vindication of thy name,
When envy and detraction are struck dumb
Gain an eternal memory with vertue;
When the discountenanc'd wits of all my jierers
Shall hang their heads, and fall like leaves in Autumn.
O how I laugh to hear the cozen'd people
As I pass on the streets abuse themselves
By idle questions and false reports.
As thus: good morrow Master Quicksands; pray
How fares your beauteous bedfellow? says another
I hear she's not at home. A third sayes no:
He saw her yesterday at the still-yard
With such a Gallant, sowsing their dry'd tongues
In Rhemish, Deal, and Back-rag: Then a fourth
Sayes he knowes all her haunts and Meetings
At Bridgfoot, Bear, the Tunnes, the Cats, the Squirels;
Where, when, and in what company to find her,
But that he scornes to do poor me the favour:
Because a light piece is too good for me.
While a fifth youth with counterfeit shew of pity,
Meets, and bewails my case, and saies he knowes
A Lord that must be nameless keeps my wife
In an inchanted Castle two miles West
Upon the River side: but all conclude—

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: That you are a monstrous cuckold, and deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Knowing my safety, then, and their foul errors,
Have I not cause to laugh? Yes, in abundance.
Now note my plot, the height of my invention
I have already given out to some,
That I have certain knowledge you are dead,
And have had private burial in the countrey;
At which my shame, not grief, forbad my presence:
Yet some way to make known unto the world
A husbands duty, I resolve to make
A certain kind of feast, which shall advance
My joy above the reach of spight or chance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: May I partake, Sir, of your rich conceit?

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: To morrow night expires your limited moneth
Of vow'd virginity; It shall be such a night;
In which I mean thy beauty shall break forth
And dazle with amazement even to death
Those my malicious enemies, that rejoyc'd
In thy suppos'd escape, and my vexation.
I will envite 'hem all to such a feast
As shall fetch blushes from the boldest guest;
I have the first course ready—

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: And if I
Fail in the second, blame my houswifery.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Away, some body comes; I guess of them
That have jeer'd me, whom I must jeer again.
Gallants y'are welcom. I was sending for ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: To give us that we come for?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: What may that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Trifles you have o ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Of yours, my Masters?

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Yes, you have in mortgage
Three-score pound Land of mine inheritance.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: And my Annuity of a hundred Marks.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: And Jewels, Watches, Plate, and cloaths of mine,
Pawn'd for four hundred pound. Will you restore all?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: You know all these were forfeited long since,
Yet I'le come roundly to you, Gentlemen.
Ha'you brought my moneys, and my interest?

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: No surely. But we'le come as roundly to you
As moneyless Gentlemen can. You know
Good Offices are ready money Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: But have you Offices to sell, good Sirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: We mean to do you Offices worth your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: As how, I pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Marry, Sir, as thus;
We'le help you to a man that has a friend—

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: That knows a party, that can go to the house—

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Where a Gentleman dwelt, that knew a Scholar

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: That was exceeding wel acquainted with a Traveler

SP.SPEAKER: Vi.
SP.L: That made report of a great Magician beyond the Seas.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: That might ha'been as likely as any man in all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: To have helpt you to your wife again.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: You are the merriest mates that ere I cop'd withal.
But to be serious Gentlemen, I am satisfied
Concerning my lost Wife. She has made even
With me and all the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: What is she dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Dead, Dead: And therefore as men use to mourn
For kind and loving wives, and call their friends
Their choicest friends unto a solemn banquet
Serv'd out with sighs and sadness, while the widowers
Blubber, and bath in tears (which they do seem
To wring out of their fingers ends and noses)
And after all the demure ceremony.
Are subject to be thought dissemblers, I
(To avoid the scandal of Hypocresie,
Because 'tis plain she lov'd me not) invite
You and your like that lov'd her and not me,
To see me in the pride of my rejoycings,
You shall find entertainment worth your company,
And that let me intreat to morrow night.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: You shall ha'mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: To morrow night say you.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Yes gallants: fail not, as you wish to view
Your mortgages and pawns again. Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: We came to jear the Jew, and he jears us.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: How glad the raschal is for his Wives death.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: An honest man could not have had such luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: He has some further end in't, could we guess it,
Then a meer merriment for his dead wives niddance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: Perhaps he has got a new Wife, and intends
To make a funeral and a Marriage feast
In one to hedge in charges.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: He'il be hang'd rather then marry again.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Zooks would he had some devilish jealous hilding,
'Twould be a rare addition to his mirth,
For us to bring our antick in betwixt'em
Of his changling Bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: How ere we'll grace his feast with our presentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: When's the Buzzard?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: We left him with his foster father, Arnold,
Bsy at rehearsal practising their parts.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: They shall be perfect by to morrow night.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: If not unto our profit, our delight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Brother be comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Let not the name
Or empty sound of comfort mix with th'air
That must invade these ears: They are not capable,
Or, if they be, they dare not, for themselves,
Give the conveyance of a sillable
Into my heart, that speak not grief or sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Be griev'd then, Ile grieve with you: For each sigh
You waste for Millicents untimely death
Ile spend a tear for your as fruitless sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: That's most unsutable; y'are no company
For me to grieve with if you grieve for me;
Take the same cause with me; you are no friend
Or sister else of mine. It is enough
To set the world a weeping!

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: So it is;
All but the stony part of't.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Now you are right. Her husband's of that part;
He cannot weep by nature: But Ile find
A way by art in Chymistry to melt him.
At least extract some drops. But do you weep
Indeed for Millicent? What, all these tears?

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: All for your love.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: She is my love indeed; and was my wife.
But for the empty name of marriage onely,
But now she's yours for ever. You enjoy her.
In her fair blessed memory; in her goodness,
And all that has prepar'd her way for glory.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Let me embrace thee sister. How I reverence
Any fair honour that is done to her,
Now thou shalt weep no more: Thou hast given me com∣fort
In shewing me how she's mine. And tears indeed
Are all too weak a sacrifice for her
But such as the heart weeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Sit down brother.
Sing boy the mornful song I bad you practise.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Call you this mournful. Tis a wanton air.
Go y'are a naughty child indeed, Ile whip you
If you give voice unto such notes,

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: I know not brother how you like the air,
But in my mind the words are sad, Pray read'em.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: They are sad indeed▪ How now my boy, dost weep?
I am not angry now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: I do not weep,
Sir, for my self. But ther's a youth without
(A handsome youth) whose sorrow works in me:
He sayes he wants a service, and seeks yours.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Dost thou not know him▪

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: No: but I pity him.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: O, good boy, that canst weep for a strangers misery!
The sweetness of thy dear compassion
Even melts me too. What does he say he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Tis that Sir, that will grieve you when you hear it.
He is a poor kinsman to the gentlewoman
Lately deceas'd that you so lov'd and mourn for.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: And dost thou let him stay without so long?
Merciless Villain! run and fetch him quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: O brother—

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Sister, can I be too zealous
In such a cause as this? For heark you, sister,

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: There was no way like this to get within'em,
Now courage keep true touch with me. Ile vex
Your cunning and unnatural purpose, brother,
If I do nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Sir, here's the youth?

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: A lovely one he is, and wondrous like her,
O let me run and clasp him; hang about him,
And yoak him to me with a thousand kisses!
I shall be troublesome and heavy to thee,
With the pleas'd waight of my incessant love.
Youth of a happy kindred, which foreruns
A happy fortune ever. Pray thee, sister,
Is he not very like her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: If I durst
I would now say, this were the better beauty,
For it resembles Arthurs.

SP.SPEAKER: The,
SP.L: I'st not her face? you do not mind me sister:

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Hers was a good one once, and this is now.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Why sister, you were wont to take delight
In any comfort that belong'd to me;
And help to carry my joyes sweetly: now
You keep no constant course with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: This man
Melts me—alas, Sir, I am a poor boy.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: What, and allied to her? impossible!
Where ere thou liv'st her name's a fortune to thee.
Her memory amongst good men sets thee up;
It is a word that commands all in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: This snare was not well laid. I fear my self.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Live my companion; my especial sweet one,
My brother and my bedfellow thou shalt be.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: By lakin but I must not, though I find
But weak matter against it.—This my courage!

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: She took from earth, how kind is heaven, how good
To send me yet, a joy so near in blood!
Good noble youth, if there be any more
Distres'd of you, that claims aliance with her
Though a far off; deal freely; let me know it,
Give me their sad names; Ile seek'em out,
And like a good great man, in memory humble
Nere cease until I plant'em all in fortunes,
And see'em grow about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: I hear of none, my self excepted, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Thou shalt have all my care then, all my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: What make I here? I shall undo my self.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Yet note him sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: I ther's the mark my malice chiefly aims at;
But then, he stands so near, I wound him too.
I feel that must not be. Art must be shewen here.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Come, you shall kiss him for me, and bid him welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: You are most welcome, Sir, and were her name
To which you are allied, a stranger here,
Yet, Sir, believe me, you in those fair eyes
Bring your own welcome with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: Never came Malice 'mong so sweet a people.
It knowes not how to look, nor I on them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Let not your gentle modesty make you seem
Ungentle to us, by turning so away.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: That's well said sister, but he will and shall
Be bolder with us, ere we part.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: I shall too much I fear.—

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Come gentle blessing,
Let not a misery be thought on here,
(If ever any were so rude to touch thee)
Between us we'll divide the comfort of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: I have heard thy story often, and with pitty
As often thought upon't, and that the father,
Of my best lov'd Theophilus, together with
His, then, friend Master Meanwell (who have since
Become each others deathsman astis thought)
By suits in Law wrought the sad overthrow
Of thy poor Fathers fortune; by which means,
Poor Gentleman he was enforc'd to leave
His native Country to seek forrain meanes
To maintain life.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Or rather to meet death.
For since his traval, which is now six years,
I never heard of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Much pittiful!

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: So is your story, Mistress unto me.
But let us dry our eyes; and know we must not
Stick in the mire of pitty; but with labour
Work our delivery: yours is now at hand
If you set will and brain to't. But my honor
(If a poor wench may speak so) is so crack'd
Within the ring, as 'twill be hardly solder'd
By any art. If on that wicked fellow,
That struck me into such a desperate hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: He will be here to night, and all the crew
And this must be the night of my delivery,
I am prevented else for ever, wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Be sure, among the guests, that you make choise
Of the most civil one to be your convoy,
And then let me alone to act your Mores part.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Peace, he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Ile to my shift then.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Wher's my hidden beauty?
That shall this night be glorious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: I but wait the good hour
For my deliverance out of this obscurity.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Tis at hand.
So are my guests. See some of'em are enter'd.
O my blith friend, Master Nathaniel, welcome.
And Master Arthur Meanwell as I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Yes, Sir, a Gentleman late posses'd with sadnes,
Whom I had much a do to draw along
To be partaker more of your mirth then chear.
You say here shall be mirth. How now, what's that?
Ha'vou a black coney berry in your house?

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Stay Catelina. Nay, she may be seen.
For know, Sirs, I am mortified to beauty
Since my wives death. I will not keep a face
Better then this under my roof I ha'sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: You were too rash, Sir, in that oath, if I
Mav be allowed to speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Tis done and past, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: If I be not taken with yon'd funeral face,
And her two eyes the scutcheons, would I were whipt now.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: Suppose your friends should wish you to a match
Prosperous in wealth and honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Ile hear of none, nor you if you speak so.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: Sir, I ha'done.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: It is the handsom'st Rogue
I have ere seen yet of a deed of darkness;
Tawney and russet faces I have dealt with,
But never came so deep in blackness yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Come hither Catelyna. You shall see, Sir,
What a brave wench she shall be made anon
And when she dances how you shall admire her.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: Will you have dancing here to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Yes I have borrowed other Moors of Merchants
That trade in Barbary, whence I had mine own here,
And you shall see their way and skill in dancing.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: He keeps this Rie-loaf for his own white white tooth
With confidence none will cheat him of a bit;
Ile have a sliver though I loose my whittle.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Here take this key, twill lead thee to those orna∣ments
That deck'd thy mistress lately. Use her casket,
And with the sparklingst of her jewels shine;
Flame like a midnight beacon with that face,
Or a pitch'd ship a fire; the streamers glowing
And the keel mourning, (how I shall rejoyce
At these prepostrous splendours) get thee glorious;
Be like a running fire-work in my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: He sets me more a fire at her. Well old stick breech
If I do chance to clap your Barbary buttock
In all her bravery, and get a snatch
In an odd corner, or the dark to night
To mend your chear, and you hereafter hear on't,
Say there are as good stomacks as your own,
Hist, Negro, hist.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: No fee, O no, I darea notta.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Why, why—pish—pox I love thee,

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: O no de fine white Zentilmanna
Cannot a love a the black a thing a.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Cadzooks the best of all wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Mill.
SP.L: O take—a heed—a my mastra see—a.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: When we are alone, then wilt thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Then I shall speak a more a.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: And Ile not lose the Moor-a for more then I
Will speak-a.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: I muse the rest of my invited Gallants
Come not away.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Zooks the old angry justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: How comes it Sir, to pass, that such a newes
Is spread about the town? is my Neece dead,
And you prepar'd to mirth Sir, hah?
Is this the entertainment I must find
To welcome me to town?

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: She is not dead, Sir. But take you no notice
You shall have instantly an entertainment, that
Shall fill you all with wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Sure he is mad;
Or do you understand his meaning sirs?
Or how or where his wife died?

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: I know nothing;
But give me leave to fear, by his wild humor,
He's guilty of her death; therefore I hope
Hee'l hang himself anon before us all
To raise the mirth he speaks of.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: Fie upon you.
Yet trust me, sir, there have been large constructions,
And strong presumptions, that the ill made match
Betwixt her youthful beauty and his covetous age;
Between her sweetness and his frowardness
Was the unhappy means of her destruction;
And you that gave strength to that ill tied knot
Do suffer sharply in the worlds opinion,
While she, sweet virgin, has its general pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Pray what have you been to her? I nere found you
Appear a suiter to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: I nere saw her,
Nor ever should have sought her, Sir; For she
Was onely love to my sworne enemy,
On whom yet (were she living and in my gift
Rather a thousand times I would bestow her
Then on that man that had, and could not know her.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: I have done ill; and wish I could redeem
This act with half my estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: This Devels bird,
This Moor runs more and more still in my mind.
O are you come? And ha'you brought your scene
Of Mirth along with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: Yes, and our actors
Are here at hand: But we perceive much business
First to be set a foot. Here's Revels towards.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: A daunce of furies or of Blackamores
Is practising within;

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋin.
SP.L: But first there is to be some odd collation
In stead of supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Cheap enough I warrant,
But saw you not a Moor-hen there amongst'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: A pretty little Rogue, most richly deck'd
With pearls, chains and jewels. She is queen
Of the Nights triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: If you hnce to spy me
Take her aside, say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Thou wilt filch
Some of her jewels perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Ile draw a lot
For the best jewel she wears. But mum my Masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Enter the house pray Gentlemen: I am ready
Now with your entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Wee'l follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Nw for six penny custards, a pipkin of bak'd
Pears, three sawcers of stew'd prunes, a groats worth
Of strong ale, and two peniworth of Gingerbread.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: If she does live (as he bears me in hand
She is not dead) Ile tell you briefly, Sir,
If all the law bodily and ghostly,
And all the conscience too, that I can purchase
With all the wealth I have can take her from him,
I will recover her, and then bestow her
(If you refuse her) on your so you speak of,
(whose right she is indeed) rather then he
Shall hold her longer. Now mine eyes are open'd.
Will you walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: I pray excuse me, Sir,
SP.STAGE: Exi, Enter Mili. white. fac'd & in her ovvn habit.
SP.L: I cannot fit my self to mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Your pleasure.
Mil. Have I with patience waited for this ou,
And does fear check me now? I'le break through all,
And trust my self with yon'd mildeGentleman.
He cannot but be noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: A goodly creature!
The Rooms illumin'd with her; yet her look
Sad, and cheek pale, as if a sorrow suck'd it.
Hovv came she in? What is she? I am fear▪struck.
Tis some unresting shaddow. Or, if not,
What makes a thing so glorious in this house,
The master being an enemy to beauty?
She modestly makes to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Noble Sir,—

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: Speaks too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: If ever you durst own a goodness,
Now crown it by an act of honour and mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: Speak quickly; lose no time then: say, what are you?
You look like one that should not be delai'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: I am th'unfortunate woman of this house,
To all mens thoughts at rest. This is the face
On which the Hell of jealousie abus'd
The hand of Heaven, to fright the world withall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Were you the seeming Moor was here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: The same;
And onely to your secresie and pitty
I have ventur'd to appear my self again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: What's to be done? Pray speak, and tis perform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: In trust and Manhood Sir, I would commit
A great charge to you, even my life and honor
To free me from this den of misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: A blessed tasque! But when you are freed Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: I would desire Sir, then to be convei'd.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Whither? to whom? speak quickly: why do you stoop?

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Pray let that rest. I will relieve your trouble
When I am freed from hence, and use some others.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: Nay, that were cruelty. As you love goodness tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Why dare you bear me Sir, to one you hate.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.L: What's that, if you love? Tis your peace I wait on.
I look upon your service, not mine own.
Were he the mortall'st enemy flesh bred up
To you I must be noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: You profess—

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: By all that's good and gracious, I will die
Ere I forsake you, and not set you safe
Within those walls you seek.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Then, as we pass
Ile tell you where they stand, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: You shall grace me.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT 4. SCENE 5.
DIV3.STAGE: Quick sands. Testy. Nath. Vincent. Edmond.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Now to our Revels. Sit ye, sit ye gallants
Whilst, Uncle, you shall see how I'le requite
The masque they lent me on my wedding night.
Twas but lent Gentlemen, your masque of horns,
And all the private jears and publick scorns
Y'have cast upon me since. Now you shall see
How Ile return them; and remarried be.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: I hope he'l marry his Moor to anger us.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Ile give her something with her, if I catch her,
And't be but in the cole-house.
SP.STAGE: Florish enter Inductor like a Moor leading Phil∣lis (black and) gorge∣ously deck't with jewels.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Attend Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: The Queen of Ethiop dreampt upon a night
Her black womb should bring forth a virgin white.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: She told her king; he told thereof his Peeres.
Till this white dream fil'd their black heads with fears:

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: A whorson blockheads.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: Blackheads I sai'd. Ile come to you anon

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: He puts the blockheads on'hem grosly.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Brave impudent rogue. He made the speeches last year
Before my Lord Marquess of Fleet Conduit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: Till this white dream fil'd their blackheads with fear,
For tis no better then a Prodegy
To have white children in a black countrey.
So 'twas decreed that if the child prov'd white,
It should be made away. O cruel spight!
The Queen cry'd out, and was delivered
Of child black as you see: Yet Wizards sed
That if this damsel liv'd married to be
To a white man, she should be white as he.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: The moral is, If Quicksands marry her,
Her face shall be white as his conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: The careful Queen, conclusion for to try,
Sent her to merry England charily
(The fairest Nation man yet ever saw)
To take a husband; such as I shall draw,
Being an Aegyptian Prophet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Draw me, and ile hang thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: Now I come to you, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Now mark my Jeeres.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: You must not have her: For I find by your hand
You have forfeited the mortgage of your land.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Pox o'your Palmistrie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.L: Now me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: Nor you: For here I plainly see
You have sold and spent your lifes Annuity.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: The devil take him, made thee a soothsayer.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: I find from whence your skill comes. Yet take me
For thy little Princess of darknesse, and if
I rub her not as white as another can
Let me be hung up with her for a new
Sign of the labour in vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: Nor you, sir: For
Te onely sute you wear smels of the chest
That holds in Limbo Lavender all your rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Would his brains were in thy belly that keeps the key on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ind.
SP.L: This is the worthy man, whose wealth and wit,
To make a white one, must the black mark hit.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Your jeers are answer'd, gallants. Now your dance.
SP.STAGE: Enter the rest of the Moors. They Dance an Antique in which they use action of Mockery and derision to the three Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: We applaud your devise, and you'l give me leave
To take your black bride here, forth in a daunce.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: With all my heart, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Musick, play a Galliard,
You know what you promised me, Bullis.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: But howa can ita be donea.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: How I am taken with the elevation of her nostrils.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Play a little quicker—Heark you—if I lead you
A dance to a couch or a bed side, will you follow me?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: I will doa my besta.
SP.STAGE: Nat. daunces vily. Quicks. & Tes. laughs & looks off.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: So, so; quick Musick, quick.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: O ougly! call you this dauncing; ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Do you laugh at me.
SP.STAGE: Enter Arnold like a Countrey man, and Buz. like a changling, and as they enter, exit Nat. with Phil. the Musick still playing.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: By your leave Gentlefolks.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: O brave, o brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: How now.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: What are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hack ye there, hack ye there,
O brave pipes. Hack ye there.
SP.STAGE: He sings and dan∣ces and spins with a Rock & spindle.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: What are you men or devils?

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: You are advis'd enough: Sir, if you please
But to be short, I'le shew you I am a Norfolk man,
And my name is John Hulverhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: Hold thy peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: You cannot hear o'chat side it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I know thee not, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: But you know my brother Matthew Hulverhead
Deceas'd, with whom you plac'd this simple child of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I plac't no childe in Norfolk nor Suffolk nor any
Folk I—say thou mistookst me: Ile reward thee. Go.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: I cannot hear o'that ear neither, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: What's the matter, Mr. Quicksands?

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Ha'you any more jeeres to put upon us? what are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Get you out of my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: I may not till I be righted. I come for right, and
I will have right, or the best of the Citie shall
Hear on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: I swear the Rascals act it handsomly.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: What art thou fellow? What dost thou seek?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Tell that Gentleman: He is an upright Majestrate
And will see thee righted.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.P: I am a poor Norfolk man, sir. And I come to ease myself of a charge, by putting off a childe nat'ral to the natual father here.

SP.SPEAKER: Quic.
SP.L: My child! Am I his father? Darst thou speak it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: Be not asham'd on't, sir: You are not the first grave and wise Citizen that has got an ideot.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Here's good stuff towards.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha—with a Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: How should I get him. I was never married till this moneth.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: How does other bawdy Batchelors get children?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz
SP.L: With a hay toodle loodle loodle loo, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Have you been a bastard-getter and marry my Neece.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Now it works.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Ie teach you to get a bastard, sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: He needs none o'your skill it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Well, Gentlemen, to take your wonder off,
I will lay truth before you.
For a poor servant that I had, I undertook and paid
For keeping of an ideot.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Who, your man Buzzard?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Even he.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: 'Tis like this is the child. But for a certain sum
Which I did pay, 'twas articled, that I should nere be
Troubled with it more.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Now what say you to that Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: 'Tis not denyed Sir, There was such agreement,
But now he is another kind of charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Why, he gets something towards his living me thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Yes, he has learn'd to thrip among the Mothers;
But Sir, withal, to do more harm then good by't,
And that's the charge I speak of: we are not bound
To keep your child, and your childes children too.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: Sir, by his cunning at the Rock,
And twirling of his spindle on the Thrip-skins,
He has fetch'd up the bellies of sixteen
Of his Thrip-sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle, loodle, loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Is't possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: So well he takes after his father here it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Take heed o'that friend: you heard him say it was his mans child.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: He sha'not fright me with that, though it be
A great mans part to turn over his bastards
To his servants. I am none of his hirelings, nor
His Tenants I. But I know what I say; and I know
What I come about; and not without advise; And you
May know, that Norfolk is not without as knavish
Councel, as another County may be. Let his man Buz.
Be brought forth, and see what he will say to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Wretch that I was to put away that fellow!
But stay! where is my wife? my wife, my wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: What say you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: My Moor I would say. Which way went my Moor?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.P: Your Ethiopian Princess.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: is gone to dance with her in private, because you laught him out of countenance here.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Mischief on mischief! worse and worse I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: What do you fear, why stare you? Are you frantick?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I must have wits and fits, my fancies and fegaries.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Your jeers upon poor Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: How do you feel your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: Ask your father blessing Timsy.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: Upon your knees man.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Upon all my knees. A—ah. Hay toodle loodle.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: What was't to you, you slaves?
SP.STAGE: Enter Nat. & Phillis pul'd in by the Moors.
SP.L: Must you be peeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: What's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: What was't to you, ye Rascals?

SP.SPEAKER: Moor.
SP.P: It is to us Sir, We were hir'd to dance and to speak speeches; and to do the Gentleman true service in his house: And we will not see his house made a baudy house, and make no speech o'that.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: What is the business?

SP.SPEAKER: Moor.
SP.P: Marry Sir a naughty business. This Gentleman has committed a deed of darkness with your Moor, Sir; We all saw it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: What deed of darkness? speak it plainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Moor.
SP.L: Darkness or lightness; call it which you will.
They have lyen together; made this same a baudy house;
How will you have it?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Undone, most wretched. O, I am confounded.
I see no art can keep a woman honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: I love her, and will justifie my Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: And I the best of any man on earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Thou speakest good English now.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: O Ruine, ruine, ruine—

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Why take you on so, for an ougly feind?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: She is my wife, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: How Sir, your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: In conceit you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I say my lawful wife; your Neece; and so dis∣guis'd
By me on purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: I said he was mad before, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Now I applaud my act, 'twas sweet and brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I'le be divorc'd before a Court in publique.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Now will I use Authority and skill.
Friends, guard the doors. None shall depart the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Mun. Vin. Content, content.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: Shall I, Sir, and my charge stay too?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Oh—

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Marry Sir, shall you.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: I fear we shall be smoak'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: No, no, fear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: You know your Chamber huswife. I'le wait o'your Master
To night. We will not part until to morrow day,
Justice and Law lights every one his way.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Is this your merry night, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Oh—oh—oh—o—

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: Why roar you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: It is the Cuckolds howle. A common cry about the City.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Oh o—Buz. Hay toodle loodle, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: Now my good Host, since you have been our friend
And onely councel keeper in our absence,
To you, before we visit our own houses
We'le render a relation of our journey,
And what the motive was that drew us forth.
'Tis true, we did pretend a deadly quarrel
At a great bowling match upon Black-heath;
Went off; took horse; and several wayes, forecast
To meet at Dover, where we met good friends,
And in one Barque past over into France:
Here 'twas suppos'd to fight, like fashion followers
That thither flie, as if no sand but theirs
Could dry up English blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Now, by the way,
Suppose that supposition had been true,
And the supposed deaths of you, and you
Had mov'd your sons to combate in earnest,
And both been kil'd indeed, as you in jest,
Where had been then your witty subtilty,
My noble Meanwell, and my brave Rashly?
Ha! have I twight ye there?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Thou keepst thy humor still my running Host.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: My humor was, nor is, nor must be lost:
But, to the question, was it wisely done,
When each of you might so have lost a son?

LG.L: We had no fear of that Sir, by the Rule,
The common Rule o'th'world. Where do you find
Sons that have lives and Lands, will venture both
For their dead Fathers that are gone and car'd for?
Nor was it onely to make tryal of
What husbands they would be; how spend, or save;
How mannage, or destroy; how one or both
Might play the Tyrants over their poor Tenants,
Yet fall by Prodigality into th'Compters:
And then the dead by pulling off a Beard,
After a little chiding and some whyning,
To set the living on their legs again,
And take 'em into favour; pish, old play-plots.
No Sir, our business runs another course;
Know you this Gentleman yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Nor yet, nor yet;
Best wits may have bad memories; I forget.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: It is my part to speak. Mine Host, y'have known me,
My name is Winloss; a poor Gentleman,
Yet richer, by my liberty, then I was
For six years space, till these good Gentlemen
In charity redeem'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Master Winloss!
I thought I could as soon forgot my Chriss-Cross,
Yet (pardon me) you have been six years gone,
And all of them in prison saving one,
In Dunkerk as I weene.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: It is most true;
And that from thence these Gentlemen redeem'd me
At their own charge, by paying five hundred pound,
Which was my Ransom.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: 'Tis a rare example.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Worthy brass tables, and a pen of steel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: No more good neighbour Winloss. What we did
Was to discharge our conscience of a burden
Got (and 'twas all we got) by your undoing,
In a sad suit at Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: I do remember;
And, without ruine I'le tell you, That sad cause,
In which you join'd against him, overthrew him
And all his Family: But this worthy act
Of yours in his enlargement, crowns your piety,
And puts him in a way of better Fortune,
Then his first tottering estate could promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Shut up that point. You have heard no ill, you say,
Among our sons and daughters in our absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Not any Sir at all. But, Mr. Winloss,
You that have past so many sorrows, can
(I make no doubt) here one with manly patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Tis of my daughter Phillis! Is she dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Tis well and't be no worse with her: I fear
She's gone the tother way of all flesh, do you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Why dost thou tell him this?

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: To have him right
His daughters wrong upon that wicked beast
That has seduc'd her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Who is't? canst thou tell?

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Even the Rank-rider of the town, Sir, one
Master Nathaniel Banelasse, if you know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: He has my sons acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: And mine's too.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: You may be proud on', if they scape his doctrine.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: But does he keep my daughter to his lust?

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: No, Sir, tis worse then so. He has cast her off
To the common, as tis fear'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Owretchedness!

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: How cam'st thou by this knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Sir, Ile tell you.
I have, i'th'house, a guest, was once your man,
And serv'd your son, since you went ore I'm sure on'c,
Though now he has got a young spark to his Master,
That has a brace of gueldings in my stable;
And lusty ones they are. That's by the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: But to the point, I pray thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: Sir, the young gallant is abroad, the man
Scults closs i'th'ouse here, and has done these two dayes
Spending his time with me in drink and talk.
Most of his talk runs upon wenches mainly;
And who loves who, and who keeps home, and so forth;
And he told me the tale that I tell you
Twixt Banelasse and your done and undone daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Mine host—cry mercy Gentlemen—

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: Nay, nay, come on.

SP.SPEAKER: Host.
SP.L: I told you he was very shy to be seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: My old master alive again? and he that he kil'd too?

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: Whom do you serve? was I so ill a master,
That, in my absence, you forsook my children?
Or how have they misus'd you? Why dost look
So like an apprehended thief? I fear
Thou serv'st some robber, or some murderer,
Or art become thy self one. If the Devil
Have so possess'd thee, strive to turn him out:
He add my prayers to help thee. Whats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: O honor'd master! Ile keep nothing from you.
There is an act of horror now on foot,
Upon revenge of your supposed murder,
Of which to stand and tell the circumstance,
Would wast the time and hinder the prevention
Of your sons murder, and your daughters ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: O fearful!

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Let not your amazement drown
Your reason in delay; your sudden hast
Was never so requir'd as now. Stay not
To ask my why, or whither. As ye go
I shall inform ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Go, we follow thee.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT. 5. SCENE 2.
DIV3.STAGE: Dionysia as before in mans habit, sword and pistol.
DIV3.L: What a fierce conflict twixt revenge and love,
Like an unnatural civil war, now rages
In my perplexed breast. There, fight it out;
To it Pel-mel my thoughts. The battel's hot.
Now for the day! revenge begins to stagger,
And her destracted Army at an instant
Ruted and put to flight. All conquering love,
Thou hast got the victory; and now I sue
(Like a rent kingdom by self-opposite thoughts)
Unto thy soveraignty, to be the liege-right.
Take me to thy protection, kingly love,
And having captivated my revenge,
O, play not now the Tyrant. A firm hope
Perswades me no: But when I shall
Reveal my self I shall obtain Theophilus love.
Which now is ten times sweeter in my thought
Then my revenge was, when 'twas first begot.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: What, still alone? we have been seeking thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: O 'tis the service that I ow you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Indeed you are too pensive: two whole dayes
And nights among us, and no more familiar?
SP.STAGE: Ent. Ar. in his false beard, eading in Mil. veil'd. Pages they stand a∣loofe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: May I crave your name, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: That's to little purpose,
My business is the thing—yonder's the star!
What young Gentleman is that your Mistris arm
Appears so courteous too?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: One she thinks well on Sir,
No matter for his name, as you said, neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: He seems some well grac'd suitor. 'Tis my fear,
If he should now—I must be just however.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Sir, a Gentleman desires to speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Dost thou not know his name?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: He will not tell it Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: You treacherous boy, do you bring you know not whom?
O 'tis the Gentleman I was so bound to, Sister:
The welcom'st man alive; Thanks my good boy.
What's she he brings in veil'd, and this way leads?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Sir, though I am still a stranger in my visit,
To works of gentleness, I am partly known.
There (if you chance t'enquire of me hereafter
(When I shall more deserve your inquisition)
I may be found, if not exact in service,
A least a poor pretender in my wishes:
And so presenting this white gift, (more modest
Then the most secret duty of mans friendship
Can ever be) I take my leave—

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: This man
Would breed, at every time ht's seen, a wonder!
Sir, leave me not thus lost: let me once know you,
And what this mystery means? This bears a shape
I may not entertain: I have set my vow
Against all woman kinde, since Heaven was married
To my first love; and must not willingly
Discover a temptation with mine own hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: How shie and nice we are to meet our happinesse!
Like dying wretches, 'raid to go to rest.
Because you shall be guilty of no breach
I'le ope the Casket for you.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Blesse me, it is—
Warm, so Love cherish me and comfortable.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: O death, my hopes are blasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: How is it with you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Might a man credit his own sences now
This were my Millicent. How think you, sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Indeed I am so, my Theophilus.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: She lives, and he is lost to me for ever,
I shall be straight discover'd too. False Love
Thou hast dealt loosely with me; And Revenge
I re-invoke thy nobler spirit: Now
Possesse me wholly; let it not be thought
I came and went off idly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Sir, something troubles you. See your kinswoman
My brother stands intranc'd too; Brother, brother▪
Noble Lady, speak to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: I was in my discovery too sudden.
Strong rapture of his joy transmutes him—Sir,
Be not so wonder-struck; or, if you be,
Let me conjure you by the love you bore me,
Rturn unto your self again. Let not
A wandring thought fly from you, to examine
From whence, or how I came: If I be welcome
I am your own and Millicent.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: And in that
So blest a treasure, that the wealth and strength
Of all the world shall never purchace from me.
Heaven may be pleas'd again to take thee, but
Ile hold so fast, that wee'll go hand in hand;
Besides, I hope his mercy will not part us.
But where's the man now more desir'd then ever
That brought you hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: You ask in vain for him.
I can resolve you all; but for the present
He will be known to none.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: This is a cruel goodness: To put thankfulness
Out of all action. Sirah, how went he?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: I know not, Sir, he vanish'd sodainly.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Vanish'd! good Lucy help to hold her fast
She may not vanish too. Spirits are subtle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: This was my fear. Will you have patience,
And fit but in this chair while I relate my story.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Ile be as calm in my extreamest deeps
As is the couch where a sweet conscience sleeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: Tis now determinate as fate; and so
At the whole cluster of'em. Bless me ha!
SP.STAGE: As Dionisia presents her pistol. Enter. Rash. Mean. Win. Rafe. Arthur.
SP.L: My father living! Then the cause is dead
Of my revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: What is he kill'd out right.
Or els but hurt? Theophilus! my boy!
Dead, past recovery. Stay the murdress there.
Look you, Sir, to her. I suspect your son too
Is not without a hand in't by the hast
We met him in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: He is not hurt at all
My honour'd father, as I desire your blessing,
But stricken with an extasie of joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Look up my boy. How dost?here's none but friends.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: Sure, sure w'are all then in Elisium
Where all are friends and fill'd with equal joy.
Earth can have no felicity like this.
If thisbe any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Thou canst not see nothing,
Look well about thee man.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: I see, I feel, I hear and know ye all:
But who knowes what he knowes, sees, feels, or hears?
Tis not an age for man to know himself in.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: He is not mad I know by that.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: If I know any thing, you are my father—

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Thou art a wise child.

SP.SPEAKER: The.
SP.L: And I beseech your blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Thou hast it. Millicont, I have heard your story,
And Lucy, you betwixt you sooth his fancy,
He will be well anon. Keep'em company Arthur,
And Lucy, bid him welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: More then life, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: You Dionysia would be chid a little;
But, Sir, let me intreat her parden

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: Dry your eyes: you have it.
Go instantly resume your sexes habit,
And with the rest be ready, if we call ye
To Quicsands house. The rumour of our coming
Already calls us thither to be assistant
To justice Testy in a pondrous difference.

SP.SPEAKER: Kash.
SP.L: How does he now?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: He's fallen into a slumber.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: In with him all I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar. &c.
SP.L: He shall have all our cares.
SP.STAGE: Exit with The. in the chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Come my friend Meanwell. Now to Quick-sands cause,
To keep it out of wrangling lawyers jawes.
The face of danger is almost made clean
And may conclude all in a comick scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Come, we will hear this cause try'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: See the Judges
Have tane their seats, while we stand here for evidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: My worthy friends, y'are come unto a cause
As rare, as was your unexpected coming
From the supposed grave—

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: To th' point I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: How quick you are! Good Mr. Rashly, know
(Though I crav'd your assistance) onely I
Supply the chief place in Authority.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: And much good do'c you. I have other business—
Your Neece Sir was too good for my poor son.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: Nay Gentlemen, we came to end
A business: Pray begin no new one first.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Well Sir, I ha'done.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: Pray Sir fall to the question.

SP.SPEAKER: Test.
SP.L: Bring in the parties.
The first branch of the question rises here
If Quicksands wife, my Neece, be dead or living
Speak Gentlemen. What can you say to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Quicksands affirm'd to us, that she was dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Edm.
SP.L: Though, since in a destracted passion
He sayes she lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: She lives, and is that strumpet,
From whom I sue to be divorc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: That Moor, there?
Did you wed her since your fair wives decease?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Tha same is she, and all the wives I had
That black is but an artificial tincture
Laid by my jealousie upon her face.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: This is most strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Braver and braver still,
I aim'd but at a cloud and clasp'd a June,
Will you be onely mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: I have sworn it ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Then I am made for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Test.
SP.L: Remove her, and let instant tryal be made
To take the blackness off.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Then if her shame,
And my firm truth appear not, punish me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: However, your consent to be divorc'd
From Millicent is irrecoverable.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Before you all, Ile forfeit my estate
If ere I re-accept her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Then she's free.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Now Mr. Banelass—

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Now for the honour of Wenchers.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Your fact is manifested and confest.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: In fewest words it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Are you content
To take this woman now in question,
If she be found no Moor to be your Wife,
In holy marriage to restore her honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Or else, before you all, let me be torn
To pieces; having first those dearest members,
In which I have most delighted, daub'd with honey▪

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: This protestation
Is clear, without respect of portion, now,
Or that she is my Neece: For you must know
She is no Neece of mine that could transgress
In that leane kind: Nor must she ever look
For favour at my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: I am content, to take her as she is,
Not as your Neece, but as his counterfeit servant,
Hoping he'le give me with her all about her.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: My chains, and Jewels, worth a thousand pounds,
I'le pay it for my folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: 'Twil be twice
The price of my pawn'd goods. I'le put the rest
Up for your jeers past on my friends and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: You are agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: To take her with all faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: I take you at your word.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Hah—

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Hell and her changes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Lead by the hope of justice, I am bold
To fix here fast, here to repair my ruins.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: The devil looks ten times worse with a white face,
Give me it black again.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Are we not one, you know from the beginning?

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Get thee from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Sirrah you have your suit and your desert,
'Tis your best part to pass it patiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: 'Tis Winloss daughter; we have found the error.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I am confounded here. Where is my Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: I, that's the point must now be urg'd. The Law
Asks her at your hands. Answer me, where is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I am at my joys end, and my wits together.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: You have brought her fame in question: Tis re∣veng'd
Now you are in both for her life and honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Seak villain, Murderer, where is my Neece?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I have snar'd my self exceeding cunningly;
That quean there knows.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Take heed, Sir, what you say,
If she must be my wife. Hands off I pray,
These are my goods she wears. Give me'em, Phil.
For fear he snatch, Ile put'em in my pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Sweet heart, my own will hold'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Sweet heart already! we are soon familiar.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: You know we are no strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Well Mr. Quicksands: because you cannot answer
(To put you by the fear of halter-stretching)
Since y'have ingag'd your word and whole estate
To be divorc'd: And you good Mr. Testy,
I you'l be willing yet that my poor son
To wed your Neece, as I shall find it lawful,
Ile undertake her safe recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: I have in heart given her your son already.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: And he has her already.
SP.STAGE: Ent. The. Mil. Ar. Lu. Dio. Winloss.
SP.L: As for example, see Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: See, see, the heaven that I am justly fallen from,
O may I yet find favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: Never here.
Hadst thou not given thy faith to a divorce,
On forfeiture of thine estate, which thou
Dost hold more precious; or couldst now redeem
That great ingagement; and then multiply
Thy past estate into a tenfold sum.
Make me inheritrix of all; and last assure me
To die within a week, Ile not re-marry thee:
Adulterate beast, that brok'st thy former wedlock
In thy base lust with that thy servant there.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: What a pox no, I tro—My wife that must be?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: 'Twas your own doing, to put me to my shifts.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: The devil shift you, then you will be sure
Of change enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: O shame unto my blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: I will henceforward councel all my friends
To wed their whores at first, before they go
Out o'their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: How can you answer this?

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I utterly deny't upon my oath.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: So do I, and safely for any act.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: That's well agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: It was but in attempt, I told my Mistriss,
Had it been done, sure I should nere have spoke on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Those are the councels women can onely keep.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Nothing in act I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.L: In him 'twas foul enough though.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: O hateful vice in age.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: 'Tis an old vice grown in him from his youth,
Of which bring forth for proof his bastard there.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: I fear we shall be whipt for counterfeits;
My long coats have a grudging of the lash.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: I see my old Masters face again, and I will
Fear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Then Ile bear up again—
Hay diddy daddy, come play with the Baby
Dindle dandle on thy knee, and give him a penny,
And a new coat, o ho—

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: My grief and shame is endless.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: Let not grief master you, Mr. Quicksands.

SP.SPEAKER: Ed.
SP.L: We are your friends, and pitty your afflictions.
What will you give us now and we'le release you
For ever of this changling charge of yours?

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: And prove he's not your bastard. Speak now roundly.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I'le cancel both your mortgages.

SP.SPEAKER: Vin.
SP.L: A match. Now look you Sir, your quandam servant,
All but the beard he wore; for loss of which
We'le recompence him.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: O Buzzard, Buzzard, Buzzard.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: O Master, Master, Master. Your servant and no bastard,
Nor father of your Ideot in Norfolk,
He's there, and well Sir, I heard lately of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: How couldst thou use me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: How could you turn me away so?

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha. Come hither Buzzard. Thou shalt not want a Mster.

SP.SPEAKER: Arn.
SP.L: Nor I, I hope, while my old Master lives. Y'are welcome home Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: And thou to me my good old servant Arnold.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: Well fare a misery of a mans own seeking;
A tough one too will hold him tack to's end,
This comes with wiving at hreescore and three;
Would doating fools were all serv'd so for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: To shut up all: Theophilus, take my Neece,
We'll shortly find a Lawfull course to marry ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: I will take care for't. Arthur, take my daughtr well bestow'd.
With a glad fathers blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mea.
SP.L: And mine with it, wishing my daughter were as

SP.SPEAKER: Dio.
SP.L: Sir take no thought for me, till my strict life
(By making man, and the world meer strangers to me,
In expiation of my late transgression
Gainst maiden modesty) shall render me
Some way deserving th'honour of a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Rash.
SP.L: Spoke like a good new woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: How now! do you look squemish on your fortune,
Sir her's a Gentleman shall maintain her blood
As worthy as your own till you defile it,
Tis best you cleanse it again.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Cadzooks I will—
Forgiv'me for swearing, and turn Precisian, ad pray
I'che nose that all my brethren whoremasters spend no worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: My father—

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: O my child.

SP.SPEAKER: Nat.
SP.L: Though Mr. Quickssands made a Mock-marriage with his English Moor,
Ile not mock thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Tes.
SP.L: Enough, euough. I hope all pleas'd at last
But Master Quick-sands here.

SP.SPEAKER: Qui.
SP.L: I yeeld to fortune with an humble knee,
If you be pleas'd, your pleasure shall please me.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: Now let me be a modost undertaker
For us the players, the play and the play-maker:
If we have faild in speech or Action, we
Must crave a pardon; If the Commedy
Either in mirth, or matter be not right,
As 'twas intended unto your delight,
The Poet in hope of favour doth submit
Ʋnto your censure both himself and it,
Wishing that as y'are judges in the cause
You judge but by the antient Comick Lawes.
Not by their course who in this latter age
Have sown such pleasing errors on the stage,
Which he no more will chuse to imitate
Then they to fly from truth, and run the State.
But whether I avail, you have seen the play,
And all that in defence the Poet can say
Is, that he cannot mend it by a jest
I'th Epilogue exceeding all the rest;
To send you off upon a champing bit,
More then the scenes afforded of his wit:
Nor studies he the Art to have it said
He sculks behind the hangings as affraid
Of a hard censure, or pretend to brag
Here's all your money again brought in i'th bag
If you applaud not, when before the word
'Twas parcel'd out upon the shearing-board.
Such are fine helps; but are not practised yet
By our plain Poet who cannot forget
His wonted modesty, and humble way
For him and us, and his yet doubtful play,
Which, if receiv'd or but allow'd by you,
We and the play are yours, the Poet too.

DIV1.P: THE Love-sick Court OR THE Ambitious Politique.
A COMEDY
Written by Richard Brome:

P.HI: Nil mea, ceu mos est, commendes carmina curo

DIV1.P: LONDON, Printed by J. T. for A. C. and are to be sold by Henry Broom, at the Gun in Ivie-lane, 1658.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: A little wit, lesse learning, no Poetry
This Play-maker dares boast: Tis his modesty.
For though his labours have not found least grace,
It puffs not him up or in minde or face,
Which makes him rather in the Art disclame
Bold License, then to arrogate a Name;
Yet to the wit, the scholler, and the Poet,
Such as the Play is, we must dare to show it
Our judgements to but too: And without fear
Of giving least offence to any ear.
If you finde pleasure in't, we boasting none,
Nor you nor we lose by' expectation.
Sometimes at poor mens boards the curious finde
'Mongst homely fare, some unexpected dish,
Which at great Tables they may want and wish:
If in this slight Collation you will binde
Ʋs to believe you' have pleasd your pallats here,
Pray bring your friends w'you next, you know your cheor.

DIV1.HEAD: Drammatis Personae.

LIST.ITEM: King of Thessaly.
Philargus, the Prince, supposed Son of the late slain General.
Stratocles a Politician.
Philocles, A young Nobleman son of the late General, and twin with Philargus.
Euphalus, A Gentleman belonging to the King.
Geron, A curious Coxcomb and a Schollar.
Matho, A villain, servant to Stratocles.
Tersulus, A Taylor, servant to Philargus.
Ʋarillus, A Barbar, servant to Philocles.
Eudina, The Princesse.
Themile, Philocles Mother.
Placilla, Her Daughter.
Garula, An old Midwife.
Doris, Themilis Waiting-woman.
4. Rusticks.

DIV1.P: The Scene THESSALY.

SP.SPEAKER: DIs.
SP.L: Good morrow my good Lord. How fares the King?

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: More sick in mind then body, by th'opinion,
(Not onely of the skilful Doctors, but) of all
That come about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I that have not seen him
Since he was sick, can guess, then at the cause
Of his distemper. He is sick o'th'subject;
Th'unquiet Commons fill his head and breast
With their impertinent discontents and strife.
The peace that his good care has kept'hem in
For many years, still feeding them with plenty,
Hath, like ore pampered steeds that throw their Masters,
Set them at war with him. O misery of kings!
His vertue breeds their vices; and his goodness
Pulls all their ills upon him. He has been
Too long too lenetive: A thousand heads
(Or say a hundred, or but ten) cut off
Of the most gross ones, the prime, leading heads
Of theirs a moneth since, had preserv'd him better
Then all his doctors pills can purge him now.

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: You are too sharp Disanius. There's a means,
As milde as other of the Kings clear Acts,
In agitation now, shall reconcile
All to a common peace no doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What's that Justinius?

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: Stay: Here comes Stratocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I fear, in that
Ambitious pate lies the combustable stuff
Of all this late commotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Why is man
Prescrib'd on earth to imitate the Gods,
But to come nearest them in power and action?
That is to be a King! That onely thought
Fills this capacious breast. A King or nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: He's deep in meditation.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: On no good.
It is some divellish waking dream affects him.
I'le put him out—And as I was about
To say my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: What? when Disanius?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: About a moneth since,
It stick still in my jaws. Be not ambitious,
Affect not popularity. 'Tis the most
Notable break-neck in a kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: In whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I know to whom I speak; would Stratocles
As well knew who he is, and what he does:
It would be better for him. Thank me not,
I wish it for the king and kingdoms good,
Not yours I do assure you, my great Lord;
Yet mine own Peer, if you forget me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: You take your time Sir to make me your mirth.
A time may come—

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: When you may be my King,
And then up goes Disanius. Is't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Yes, upto Court, to be king Stratocles fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: The Court now priviledges thee, or I would change
A cuffe with your great Souldier-ship and popular great∣ness
With clowns and Citizens, and Gentry, sprung
By their late peaceful wealth, out of their dongue.
But let'em thank our pious King, not you
That claim (as merit for your service done)
Their loves and voices.

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: Cease my Lords this strife.
The King may hear on't, whose perplexities
Already are too grievous. Pray be silent,
The king approaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Wee'll attend his entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.STAGE: Upon those terms they are come then, Eupathus?

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Four of the chief in the commotion,
Upon the ingagement of my faith, that you
Had past your kingly word for their return
In safety, I have brought to Court, who wait
Your present will and pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Bring'em in.
Disanius, welcome. I thought well to send for you
To take a Councellors part of my late cares
Into your consideration.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I attend
Your Highness pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Nearer good Disanius.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Do you deal in secret king? The Commons sent for
To their examination, and this old
Antagonist of mine cal'd to confront me,
And I prepar'd by no intelligence
To fit me for th'incounter? Let'em come.
I must not be deny'd to stand as fair
In competition for the Crown as any man
The King himself elects for his successor;
The people are mine own thro' all his parts:
He may command their knees, but I their hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Stratocles, Justinius, Disanius sit.
My lords, altho'our Lawes of Thessaly
To you, as well as to our self, are known,
And all our customs, yet for orders sake
I shall lay open one to you. That is, when
A king deceaseth without issue male
(As I unfortunately must) the Commons
Are to elect their King, provided that
He be of noble blood, a sculdier, and one
That has done publick service for the Crown—

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: That makes for me.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Or else the son of some
Great General slain in battel for his countrey
(As my Adrastus was.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: O my brave brother!

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Twenty years sorrow for that Souldiers loss
Has not worn out his memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Your grace
Forgets not then Souldiers of fresher fame.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Some other time to boast good Stratocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Twere good youl'd hear the king—A general,
Or a Generals son may be elected. There
Your Majesty left.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Or if the sonless King
Yet has a daughter, and he match her in
His life time to a husband that is noble,
He stands immediate heir unto the Crown
Against all contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
