Swain heads of Thessaly (the King has known us)
And here we came to lay our heads together
For good of common wealth. Here at the verge
Of this adjoyning Thicket is our Bower
Of consultation; and from thence (regardful
Ever with eye and ear for common good)
We saw a beard pull'd off; and heard that mouth,
(Which now is dumb) open a plot, unlike
The pittiful complint he made to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: But saw you not some passages before?
Of his attempt upon our lives?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: Good Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Rus.
SP.L: No we came in but then. Those are enough
To hang the man, and turn his Lord out of
Our Countrey favour: If we find he has
That plot upon the body of the Princess
Of Rape and Murder. He can be no King
For us: for, sirrah, we have wives and daughters.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: Stand close. See who comes here.

SP.SPEAKER: Stra.
SP.L: So, now go back my friends. There's some reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Thanks to the noble bounteous Stratocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Srat.
SP.L: Lady your tears are bootless.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: Help ye Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Your cries as unavailable. The Gods
(To whom your friendly foolish lovers
Have sacrific'd each other) have given you up
To me the onely worthy of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: No they are both sublim'd into one star,
Yet of a double influence, that shall
Strike death into thy purposes, and give
Me light by which t'ascend with them to live
After my present death.
SP.STAGE: She offers to kill her self with a knife, he holds her.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Your hast to death shall not prevent my lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: She must outlive thy Lust and the false Traytor

SP.SPEAKER: Rus.
SP.L: Hold, hold, disarm, but kill him not.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Rus.
SP.L: Wee'll keep him tame.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: You have ods o'me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: I am in heaven already.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Live wonder of the heavens, a star on earth
Out shining theirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: What a short journey 'tis
For heavenly minds to reach unto the Gods!

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Btray'd!

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: No not betray'd. Y'are but well meet my Lord,
But that's our Gentlen ess more then your deserving.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Am I become the shame and scorn of pesants.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: Or if you'l ha't betray'd, then blame your own
Overmuch policy and want of Beasts
To carry it to Market. We nere lay
More burthen on a Asse, then he can bear
Here in the countrey: what is done at court
We know not. Here perhaps is one can tell,
Know you this bearded Satyre?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Coward, slave,
Thy faintness hath betray'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Math.
SP.L: No, 'twas ods,
Such as men meet that sight against the Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: The fellow has some Grace; he weeps: But come
Princess and Princes, what is now your pleasure
We do unto these men?

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: For me, I have learn'd
By mine own sufferings in my afflictions
To be compassionate. I wish their pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: That mercy wounds me deeper with remorse
Then all my lost designs, and their derision
Have done with indignation.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: There is some hope these yet may prove new men.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: Lord Stratocles,
Those wounds that pierce the heart with true contrition
Do bring the precious balm in'em that cures it.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: We wish yours may be such.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: And that this shame
May guard you innocent of future blame.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Rus.
SP.L: Here's sweetness upon sweetness.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: Now it remains, that we advise our selves,
Brethren of Tempe, that since these delinquents
Are fallen into our hands, that we discharge
Our Countrey loyalty with discretion,
And not release him from our power, but by
The power above us. (that's the kings) wee'l wait
On you to court. On you for your new loves,
And you for old acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: I'le acquaint my father with your care,
He shall be witness of our bringing in
The ambitious Politick trapt in his own gin.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Bereft of all my joyes and hopes at once!
Is there no comort, nor no counsel left me?
Why stand you gazing thus with sealed lips?
Where is your counsell now, which you are wont
In trifling matters to pour out in plenty?
Now, in the peril of my life and state
I cannot get a word. Give me my daughter,
Or take my Kingdom too. Where is she? Tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: All we can say or hear is, she was taken
Out of her private walks by violent hands,
Onely we guesse the master of the plot
Was Stratocles, who now is missing in the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: He ask'd my leave to leave the Court, and had it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Twas a fit glosse for his fowl treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: But what ha' you said for her recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: We have dispatch't a hundred several posts
To every coast and angle of your Kingdom:
No way of finding her is left unsought.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Could we finde Stratocles, she might be found.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Stil upon him? Where's Philocles? where's Philargus?
They are missing too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis▪
SP.L: Hell has not in't a thought
That can detract their honours.

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: Yet a Rumor
Is spread about the Court; they are gone to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: 'Gainst whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: Against themselves. Nay more, that they
Have fought, and both are slain.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: You may as soon
Believe the Artick and Antartick poles
Can meet it opposition, amidst
The firmament, and jointly in a fall
Extinguish both their lights in Neptunes bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Whence springs this Rumor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Stratocles is the head
We may be confident; and his men the pipes
That have dispers't it.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Stil you judge Stratocles.
What purpose can he have in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: O my sister
Has heard the news too. Weep not tender sister,
Your sons are safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Yes they are with the Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And, had they tane Eudina with them too,
My doubts and fears were over, well as yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Here's one that makes a face, an ugly one,
And would weep too, had she but moisture in her.
How now! Whose Mare's dead, Garrula? Take thy bottle
And turn that into tears. Or dost thou wring
Thy face because that's dry? Gi'mee't, I'le fill it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: My son, oh, oh my son is at deaths door.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: And is death so unkind to keep it shut
Against him? Out upon him churle.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: My liege
And Madam (it shall out) you might have sav'd
My sons life in your servants love, whose scorn
Will be his death, except the King divert it,
And I shall tell him what you know I know—

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: O me undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: And open such a secret
Unto his majesty—

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yet forbear me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: Do you slight me in the care of my sons life?
Do you scorn my secret too, that may be worth
More then your kingdom to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Away old fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: Now you shall never know't.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: For thy good wil
The king would thank thee, in offering at some mirth
To cool his grief, but that it is too hot
Yet to be touch'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: Indeed you do not well
To move the King, or to perplex the Lady
Now in their sorrows fulness.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: What's their sorrow
To mine? My sons a dying.

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: Her sons are dead,
And the Kings daughter lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: But I pray, say,
Is my Lord Philocles and Philargus dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Jus.
SP.L: 'Tis said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: Then I say my son shall live.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: And so wilt thou while thou canst lift thy bottle
To that old Mazer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: Hem! A hem! a ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Do you rejoyce, and shew the rotten half tooth
You have left that they are dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: No I rejoyce
That the advancement that the giglet gap'd for
In one of their fine followers is lost,
In hope of which she scorn'd my son. But now
He shall scorn her and live.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Out envious trot

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: Ile comfort him with the newes.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: away you Hag,
Here comes one merry look.

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: Joy to the king.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Well said, speak up and home good

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: Your daughter's safe return'd so is your son, Madam,
For which you are to thank the Gods: This is
Their true relation.
SP.STAGE: He gives the King a paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Where is Stratocles?

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: Caught in the snares of his foul treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Bravely and honestly spoken Eupathus.

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: And by their hands whose voices he had once
For his election.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What his country heads?

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: They all turn head upon him now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Brave heads
Observe my judgement now, my king: Those heads
I will so souse in our best Greekish Wines,
That they shall be such heads! O heads, heads, heads!

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I do approve your judgment good Disanius,
But wish you not insult ore mans dejection.
We find that Stracocles is much Penetent
And troubled at his trespass.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: A halter still him
For an ambitious hypocritical Traytor.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The time for my Eudina's match draws near,
And I no longer will attend on fortune,
I have decreed it past recal, regardless
Whether against the oracle, or with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Yet am I consident in your assertion
You priests of Delphos.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Hee'l bestow her yet
On Stratocles, if she stand longer doubtful
In a fair choise.

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: Fear not my Lord. That doubt
Your Countrey heads will clear. He has lost them
For ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: O brave heads! I will so ring
Their ears with jewels of praises and preferment
That they shall glare like direful comets at him.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: One she shall chuse of them: If not, I'le put
A third upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: With your pardon Sir,
Why are you (for I find it is so) stronger
For Philocles?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No reason urges me;
And yet I find an inclination in me
That pleads for him. I can perceive you too,
Are partial towards Philargus. Can you yield
A reason for't?

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Yes, Sir, he is my eldest.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Alas, But not an hour. Well, I'le remit
My power propounding, and accept
Her choice of either, made within the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: I, there my hopes do anchor; else they were
Certain of Ship-wrack: yet the perillous waves
My vessel rides on seems so many graves.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Brother, and friend, I'm deaf to all deswasion.
I charge you by Eudina's love, our friendship,
And (if there be) ought that you hold more sacred,
Move not to alter my fix'd resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: That resolution's mine; And I conjure you
By the self-same respects, and all that are
Or may be hollowed, to let me depart.
I will remove but for some few daies journey
Whence you shall duly hear from me. But rather
I'le travail to th' Antipodes, then here
Linger the vain impediment of your joyes
In your Eudina.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Travel's my design.
Eudina must be yours. She is a bliss
Which heaven created for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Can a bliss
Be purchas'd with your absence? No: 'Twil torture
Equally in fruition as in want.
Were it a Kingdom onely, we could part it
Without the quarrel of the Thebean brothers;
Or, were it heaven it self, Castor and Pollux
Should have our imitation. But Eudina
Is onely indivisible.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Add to it this,
Their sentence is erroneous, that deny
Partition to the soul: For ours do witness,
Friendship can give her a division,
And make reciprocal community
Of all her faculties. But still Eudyna
Is indivisible. Why name I her,
Whom to forget must be my onely tasque?
Brother adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: 'Tis I that must take leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Is it even so?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: I fear we are prevented.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Nephews, why left you so the presence? I
May justly fear you were ill advis'd in it.
The King expects your quick return, and will not
Let pass this peremptory day, set down
For matching of his daughter; to preserve
Life, State, or Kingdom. Have you a purpose,
First having beg'd that villain Stratocles pardon,
To give him up your interest in the Princess?
The Kingdom too, to boot? will you compel
The King to give him all?

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Not so good Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What do you less in flying from the presence,
When that affair is now in agitation?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Uncle, you saw withal the great destraction
We left the Princess in. How when she look'd
Upon Philargus, she inclin'd to him;
And when on me to me; when on us both
How extasied she fell!

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: A strong necessity
There is that one of us absent.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Therefore
You both flie off to travel several wayes!
Come, let me tell you your courtesie is foolish,
And you unworthy to have such a fortune
Hang like a pregnant cloud over your heads
Ready to be dissolv'd in showres upon you,
While your own madness conjures up a wind
To blow't away.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Uncle, you are unjust,
I would remove to let that golden showre
Light upon Philocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: I upon Philargus.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I could even swadle'em both for a brace of Babyes.
Your folly makes me mad: will you return
Yet to the presence, both of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Uncle, you know
To be both there, is neither to be there,
But to breed more perplexity in Eudyna.
Pray take Philargus.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Nephew, come, be wise:
It is a crown that Courts you; and the name
Of friend, or Brother ought to stand aloof,
And know a distance, where such dignity
Is tendred. Take your opportunity,
I find you coming, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Philarg.
SP.L: I pray take Philocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I'le take him for the wiser man then. Nephew,
Come, and embrace your fortune, and forget not
To thank the Gods your Brother has no more wit.
A Kingdom and a beauteous bed▪fellow
(There Nephew, there!) Do not those bare a sound
'Bove friend and Brother, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: not in mine ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What frost has ceiz'd their blood, & brains, which neither
Beauty nor dignity can thaw? Go travel.
What stay you for? young Gentlemen sometimes
Wait for a gale of gold to blow'em out
O'th'harbour; Stratocles will furnish you,
And thank you more then for his forfeit life.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Stratocles can gain nothing by my abscence,
While her Philargus stayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Philarg.
SP.L: No, nor by mine,
While Philocles remains.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis
SP.L: Shall I make a motion,
Will one of you remain?

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: One must and shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Then yield to take your lots for't. (I will make'em)
As you respect my love; your mothers life;
The kingdoms good; Eudynas love and life,
Let it be so. Pause not upon't, but do't.
See, here's ink and paper. I am inspir'd,
Apollo, with thy wisdom. Love.—and friendship.
See, here's a pass for one, and a plantation
For tother. Love and friendship Gentlemen.
Love shall abide at home, and friendship walk,
According to the custom of the world.
Let it be so. ▪Come study not, but draw,
I'le draw upon ye both else.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Friendship for me then.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: See here I have it brother. And yours is love.
My love be prosperous to you. My horse, my horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: All's ready, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: In the first place then bring
A parting cup, that by the grapes Elizar
As Jove by Acheron, I may protest
My constancy and zeal unto my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: And now's my time to act thy purpose, Doris.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Kick not your heels against the Gods, Philargus,
It is most evidently their decree
That you abide and Philocles remove.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: I do obey my Lot. And noblest brother.
Be you as free in love, as I from envy.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: But how can you forgo that equal interest
You have with me in Thessaly, and Eudina?

SP.SPEAKER: Diss.
SP.L: Why should that trouble you? you see he does
Forgo't; and is a going. Would he were gone once.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Can love allow't?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Variety of objects
Like Nails abandon one a nother. So
May I, by novelties of Travail, lose
The thought of Love; and chearfully return
Both hers and yours in a more just relation.
SP.STAGE: Enter Varil∣lus with a bowl of wine.
SP.L: Give me the bowl. Now brother to that love
You owe the fair Eudina, unto which
I give th'addition of mine own, and all
The joves that ere I wish'd my self and her,
And to that friendship, which nor Time, nor absence
Shall ever end or alter.
SP.STAGE: He drinks and gives Varillus the bowl.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: Now the service that may redeem my faults
Is to be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Give it me full, Varillus.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: I'le give you more then you expect by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: You have the victory in friendship, brother,
Who, by your resolute absence will inforce
And drive me to a happiness; wherein
I must not cease, in all the strength of prayers
Of sacrifice, and vowes; in all my goods
Of fortune, mind and body to be yours:
Which that you may return to repossess
With the more speed, this health to auspicate
And expedite your travails.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: They are done
Already if my Pothecaries skill fail not.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: With this embrace my brother, and my last
Of present ceremony, I now wish you
In th'arms of your Eudina—
And may my better part of soul, which now
I leave in trust with you, by you be breath'd
Into her breast; that she may lively find
She has my love in yours; and that in you
She has us both.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: So, so, enough. Ha'ye done yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: How is it with you brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Philarg.
SP.L: As it is
With souls that leave the world in peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: For shame
Leave womanish ceremony. Will you part
Before it be too late?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Too soon I fear.
Philargus! Brother! Friend! Ye Gods, how comes this?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What is he dead? I see then how it comes.
You or your man, or both ha'poyson'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: No, 'twas my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Thou wilt not go out o'th'world
With a lie i'thy mouth? Speak yet again,

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: He has said well for me already,

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Gone, past recovery, but he shall not pass
Without my company.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Wilt thou die mad too?
SP.STAGE: He offers to kill himself. Dis. snatch∣eth his sword away.
SP.L: Come, Sir, let go your whiblin. He has yet
Some breath. Run for Physitians—No, Sir, stay.
I will not quit you so. I can read guilty lines
Palpably on this villans visnomy.
Is there no more i'th'house? some help here! ho!
Nephew forbear. As you will have me think
SP.STAGE: Philocles of∣fers again to kill him∣self.
SP.L: You guiltless of your brothers blood, forbear.
How am I tortur'd! Ho! Philargus; rub him,
Rub him, he may live yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: O that the world
Might be so happy!

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: So, well said: A box
Or two in kindness will not do amiss.
Stir not you sirrah. O, Sir, you lay hold
On that same traytor.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: I'le not stir my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I'le hold you to your word, Sir, run, Sir, you
And fetch Physitians.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: O my Lord, fallen dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Stay but to look upon him, and I'le swear
Thou art his murderer. Fetch the Kings Physitians,
If not to cure him; yet to rip the cause
Out of his sodain death. I guess they'l finde
Your handy-work in's maw.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: You heard him say
It was himself that did it. I am clear'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: My Lord, the King, impatient of your stay,
Has sent .

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What has he sent. Has he sent means
To call this man from death, or that from falling
After him into th'grave?

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: O heavy spectacle!

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: But, come I will not cry tho'. Pray assist me,
In with this body, Charity commands
When griev'd necessity intreats your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: My Rustici amici, your Councel and
Your vertue have restor'd me. And tis true
As Wholom said the good Antisthenes
Vertue is armour 'gainst the very fates.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: We told you for your good, good Mr. Geron,
Fond love became you not.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Rus.
SP.L: It sat upon your coat like burs or bryars
Stuck in the hindlocks of our fleecy sheep;
Who shake their heads; figgle, and writh their tayls,
And bleat for woe; sprinkle the ground behind'em
Sometimes I wisse: Twould make one laugh and pitty'em
And all at once, but all remediless.
Til we with helping wit and hands release'em

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: A wise man then in love is like a sheep
l'th' bryars. As Whilome said

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Rus.
SP.L: But (by the way)
What was that Whilome, Sir, you speak much of him,
But what was he pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: An ancient Britain, whom I have affected
As idly as my love. But I'le forget it
And use that word no more. The clowns have found me.

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Rus.
SP.L: But will you now proceed upon your plot
For th'honour of Tempe plains, and Tempe swains.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: You can all dance.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Rus.
SP.L: After our countrey guise.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Rus.
SP.L: Like so many light horses.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: So can our wives
Who have follow'd us up to Court we thank'em
Pray Juno we get them honestly home again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: There is no doubt. However fear you nothing
As why—Tis hard to leave off an old custom.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Rus.
SP.L: The why was out, but lome stuck in your teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: Tis well it did so. You can dance you say.
A dance I have projected for the Princess
Who ever marries her it shall serve. As why—

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: Again 'twas eene a comming.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: You are as quick as why—

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Rus.
SP.L: And there again.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Rus.
SP.L: Nay we are heads, I tell you Master Geron,
And should have wit; and shew't we can i' th'countrey,
In the head vein, though hear at Court, like courtiers
We'll shew it in our heels. Pray therefore on.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: On, let us then to practise. King and court
Shall see, to crown their joyes, some countrey sport.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No answer, no return? Must I intreat,
Yet have my undeserved favours slighted?

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Yet, Sir, your Kingly patience.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Stupid folly
'Twere longer to attend. My vow is past
And register'd in heaven; the minute is
Athand, that calls down thonder on me, which
No tear, or prayers can mollifie or aver',
If I upon so long deliheration
Shall falsifie. So, call in Stratocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: O my dread father. Yet one hours patience
Till Eupathus or Disanius return.
One short, short hour: I may not live so long.
His wife you nam'd; though you may force me take him.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: I'le leave that to the Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: They will forgive. Give them your imitation
In mercy, as in power on earth. I know Disanius
Went not in vain to call'em to your presence.
And him that he brings first into this room
O Philocles or Philargus I will take,
Though he precede the other but one foot,
I have it by inspiration from the Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: You are full of dreams.

SP.SPEAKER: Thym.
SP.L: This cannot, Sir, be long
In tryal. King Yet I am not bound to wait
On those ingrateful men. O Stratocles,
You have from your late Errors, which your then
Head-strong ambition hurried and cast you in
With that humility purg'd your self, that I
Conceive you now a temperate Man; and am
Instructed by the clemency of the Gods
To cherish and reward your vertue. Therefore
From their divine appointment, as my hands—

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: (O mighty, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Dare not to disobey me)
Receive Eudina.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Royal King and Master,
Mistake not so the pleasure of the Gods.
My forfeit life you have forgiven me:
Your Kingly power and grace might do it. You
Have given it freely: but I took't with caution,
By future service to make good your gift:
But for my forfeit love to fair Eudina,
And my lost honor to the twin-born brothers,
There can be no redemption, if I add
By acceptation of your bounteous offer
A second trespass, greater then the former.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Do you refuse her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: In hope shee'l plead
My pardon to your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: The Gods have wrought
Effectually for me.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Strangely, unexpected
Are you become a suppliant Placilla?

SP.SPEAKER: Pla.
SP.L: In the behalf, Sir, of your loyal subjects,
The Swains of Tempe.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I expected, rather,
News from your unkind brothers. See Justinius,
The Commons, rather then I shall bestow
My daughter upon Stratocles, do beseech me
To take a further time.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Y'are happy, Sir,
In his refusal and in their request.
They are fair predictions of ensuing joyes
To you, your daughter, and the Kingdom, If
I may be worthy to divine so much.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: How ere thy divination proves, thy wish
Is worth our thanks. And we may have
Glad tidings presently. Now Eupathus
Where is Disanius, Philocles, and Philargus?
Why come they not?

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: They are all at hand my liege.
This paper may excuse their stay.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: O do
They plead excuse then?

SP.SPEAKER: Thym.
SP.L: I am full of fears.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: And I of sodain joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Plac.
SP.L: Pray all be well.
The King has struck his breast, and seems perplext.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Justinius, Stratocles, read here this Paper.
Go Eupathus, and let them enter. Stay.
Yet go, bring them in their prescribed manner.
I'le send the woman off, whose sodain grief
May be a bar to our proceedings. Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: I fear that Garrula has detected me.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: I must intreat a while your absence, Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: May I presume to ask your reason, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: My will has been above your question. Pray,
Let me request you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: I know obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: And go Placilla, send old Garrula to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Now tis most evident. O mighty, Sir,
Conceive not worse of me then Garrula.
Let us appear together.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: What means this?

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: You may be pleas'd to hear me first.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Pray pull not
More weight upon your breast then you can bear,
By your impertinent stay. Go I command you.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: I must obey. However tis too late
To change the resolution of my fate.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: I have not known her thus. I fear destraction
Fore-runs the voice of grief, as to prevent it.
Heaven knowes I call'd for Garrula, but to send her
With best directions to prepare and arm
Her tender soul against the sting of sorrow
Before it should approach her. But Eudina
You must be valliant; and not let the sight
Of death in others shake your confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: How means your majesty?

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Suppose that both
Your fatal lovers, Philocles and Philargus
Slept in the caves of death.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: I should not live then;

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Suppose his desteny had cut off one,
And, in him, all the impediments, that crost
You in th' enjoying of the other, say
Which could you wish surviver? But you have
Declar'd your constant purpose to possess
The first Disanius brings into this presence.
Come; one is dead. There is a strict necessity
You know it. Now collect your Reason: For 'tis not
Your passion for the dead; nor your dislike
Of Stratocles; no though my subjects yeeld you
A longer time, shall make me tempt the Gods
SP.STAGE: Recorders. Ent. Disanius be∣fore a herse. Phi∣locles after. Varil∣lus manacled and led by Tersuus. Euputhus supports Philocles, as ready to sink with grief.
SP.L: By breaking of my vow. Be stedfast then,
As you respect a father; and take courage.
See Philocles lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud
SP.L: Philargus then
Is brought in dead beore him by Disanius;
And unto him the first to be brought in
My faith was vow'd; and he is now my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: What being dead? Could you affect'em so
Equally, both alive, that you forbore
To chuse, because you could not have'em both;
And now seek onely him cannot be had?
SP.STAGE: The herse set down. Eudinae kneels to it. Philo. kneels
SP.L: What Love, what madness call you this? good Gods,
Throw not your wrath upon me in destruction on the other

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Nor let your passion Master you great, sir, side,
As sodain grief does her. But give a little
Scope to her sorrow. Shee will soon return
And meet her Reason in obedience
To your desires.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I thank thee good Justinius.
SP.STAGE: During which Disanius &c. discourse with the King. Di∣sanius seems to acquaint the King with the manner of Philargus death, pointing at Varillus. The King seems much troubled; but at the end of the song, (as by the Kings appointment Disanius rais∣eth Philocles, and Justinius raiseth Eudina, and bring them to the King while Eupathus with the At∣tendants go forth with the herse, the Recorders play∣ing. which done,

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Your virgin tears and vowes ore your lost love
I did attend with pardon, my Eudina,
I hope you are now compliant to my will.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Grieve not your father Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: I ha'done;
And as the Gods direct him to command me,
I must and will obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: So that's well said.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The Gods have pleas'd Eudina to determine
Your doubtful choice, reserving Philocles
Unto your love without competitor:
Therefore it now remains that he be taken
Into your liking; whom I have decreed
My successor.

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: His merits are above
Me and this land; In which what interest
My birth hath given me I resign to him.
Onely let me beseech a further respite.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: For what? the celebration? I consent;
But for the contract, this imediate hour
Shall see it knit beyond all dissolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I that I thirst to see.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Give me your hands.
Yours Philocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Why give you not your hand,
Dare you not trust the King with't? should he now
Shew a jades trick and flie back.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: I beseech
Under your highness Pardon, yet, a respite.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: More respits yet? Was ever hopeful match
Driven so round about?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Why this delay?

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: My brothers blood cries in me for your justice
Which must be executed on his murderer
Before I safely can, or dare possess
His interest in the faith of fair Eudina.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: O, is that all? that may be soon dispatch'd.
Come forwards Poysoner. Good your Majesty,
For expedition, make me his judge,
And hangman too (I care not) rather then
Suffer this match hang o'the tenters thus.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Has he confes'd the fact?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Yes, yes to me.
I beat it out of him. Quickly good King.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Your patience good Disanius Sirrah speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: It was my act. But may your mercy look
Upon my love in it unto my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Your Lord shall be your jdge then.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: I ad∣judge him
To sharp but lingring tortures (for his death
Alone can yeeld no satisfaction)
Tortures that may draw in, by his confession,
As accessaries with him, all the homicides
That are i'th' Kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: A hard matter that.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Nor can I think his onely brain and hands
Compos'd the poyson.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Hang him, hee's a Barber,
And uses Aqua fortis, oyl of Vitriol,
Mercury, and such like, to cleanse his Rasors.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: 'Tis good that you Varillus clear your conscience
And, if you had confederates in the fact,
Give up their names.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: Varillus, I suspect
Doris joyn'd hand with you in my Lords death.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What's that you mutter?

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: It shall out my Lord;
The handmaid Doris put him on't; I know't
By what she said to us both we being her lovers.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: The Taylor proves an honest man: because
He cannot have the wench himself, he'll hang her.

SP.SPEAKER: Var.
SP.L: Of her I had the poyson, tis confest.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: O that whore. King. Find her and drag her hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Where's my Philargus? Give me yet his body,
That with a mothers tears I may imbalm it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: You have heard the wosul newes then; but my sister
Could grief recal Philargus, we would weep
A second deluge for his reparation;
Renew his breath by sighing, and awake him,
With grones out of his Sepulchre.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Already
Have you inter'd him then? you made strange hast.
Was it your subtlety to send me hence,
Fearing my cries might have reviv'd him, king?
And so again delay'd your daughters marriage?
I have enough to cross it yet Philargus

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Destraction sure.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: My fear foresaw't.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: You are deceiv'd, for from my depth of sorow,
Through this thick film o tears, I can perceive
You are about to joyn the hands and faiths
Of Philocles and Eudina,

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Is not that
Enough to dry your tears, and shew, you that
The Gods were rather merciful in leaving
This son, then rigorous in taking other?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Or would you now, cause you have lost Philargus,
Kill Philocles too by crossing of this contract?

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: It is the pleasure of the Gods I cross it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Of devils it is. What can she mean? Go sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: King by your leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: What sayes old suckbottle now?

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Nay I am here before you Garrula,
And now will tell the long hid secret for you.
And if I erre in it, disprove me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: Tell't then.
My faltring tongue will fail me. I can hear tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: This contract must not be.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: You then must yeeld
More reason then I find you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Your self
Can never make it. You will sooner joyn
The Wolfe and Lamb. Falcon and Dove together.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: No trifling I command you Thymele.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: If you be serious, Mother, hold us not
In this suspence.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Let not the royal blood
Of Thessaly be stain'd with an incestuous match.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: She sayes right. They are both your lawful chil∣dren
By your own vertuous Queen now in—Elisium.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: What dreams are these of your distemperd heads,

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: This is no dream or fable. But unfain'd
As truth it self: Which with your gracious leave
I shall demonstrate, humbly craving pardon
For my so long concealment, as I'le yeeld
Due reason for it.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Freely speak, you have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: You may remember in your civil wars,
(Those cruel warres, as I may justly stile' em)
In which my husband fell—

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: O my brave brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: When open Rebels and domestick Traytors
Pursu'd your Crown and life; your gracious Queen
To have been brought to bed; and was beleev'd
To have miscarried by an abortive birth.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: True: In her flight she was constrain'd to take
A neighbouring cottage; and use the help
Of the Swains wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.
SP.L: That swain-ess was my self,
Though my deserts have glorified me since:
And by my help (and somewhat of the Gods)
She then made you the Father of that Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Take up thy bottle—Sister, speak you on.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Th'affrighted queen (yet wise in that extremity)
Suspecting that the innocence of her babe
Born to a Kingdom, could not be secur'd
In those combustions from apparent danger,
Sent him to me in private, then in travel
Of my Philargus—Charging me to fain
A second labour, with the Midwifes aid,
For Philocles: I did, and was reputed
Mother of both.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: I cannot think our Queen
Would keep us ignorant of so good a Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: I mov'd her oft to tell you. But she answer'd,
All is not sound, There's danger, yet; And when
After Eudyna's birth she felt her self
At point of death, she strictly did enjoyn
Me and this woman, onely conscious with her,
By oath of which she had prepar'd this copy
In her own hand, to keep it silent, till
Philocles should be able to secure
Himself from treachery; or that your terme
Of life expiring, or some accident
Of no lesse consequence requir'd detection.
For further proof—

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: My joy forbids more questioning
Give me my lesh and blood into my bosome.
Thrice happy Fathers if your Children were
Borne to you thus of perfect Age. But where
Is now a Match for my Eudina. I
Have here a successor.
SP.STAGE: A shout within and crying Philargus, Philargus. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Hah! Voyces i'th Ayre that cry Philargus?

SP.SPEAKER: Eud.
SP.L: Voyces that do tell me, I must follow him
Up to the heavens, and there be married to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Des.
SP.L: Here's the She-Devil now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: You need not pull me
For that mans love, I laid thy Lord to sleep:
Had I lov'd thee best, then his Lord had slept.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: How does he sleep? speak impudent baggage, how?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: How? With a powder, Sir, which my own father
A skilful pothecary prepar'd; who, if
Philargus dye, shall hang with us for Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Yes, But now the perils past.
See, if he sleep, tis walking.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Ha! Philargus.
Or but the shade; the spirit of my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Be not amaz'd, as at an apparition.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Doth my son live? O then I have enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Come hither. come hither you three. I will dis∣charge
The scene of you▪ Thy love unto thy Lord
(Though somewhat unadvisedly imploy'd)
Deserves reward; Ile see it given thee,
Thy Lord and King shall thank thee: take thy wench,
She has love in her wit, and wit in her anger.
I like the luck of things; that ill intents
Should bring forth good events. Thy faithfulness
To thy Lord too was happy. Go, I▪le see you
All royally rewarded. How now Geron?

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: My Lord I see here's joy towards, as why—

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: 'Slife, stand not Whiloming now man:but be brief.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: Cry mercy. I had left it. But my Lord
To celebrate the flowing joyes in Court,
I and my Countrey heads have fram'd a Masque,
Rather an antick dance, rather a countrey toy,
Rather a Rustick round; rather a—

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Hoy day!
Thy Rather's worse then thy Whilom. Dost know
What time o'day 'tis.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: Tis a rural thing
To be presented at the Princess wedding
And, if you think it meet, I will induce
The practise of it presently. As why—

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Go fetch the heads and heels, I'le stay the King,
To see and laugh at'em. That's grace enough.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Philargus you have much to know; the which
We will Eudina tell you, now shee's yours.
Receive her and our blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Were I dead
(As I was thought to be) your name pronounc'd
Over my grave, beyond all Necromancy,
Would call fresh blood into my veins again;
Strengthen my nerves, to break the Iron gates
Of death; and force my joyful spirit from
Th' Elisian Paradise to live with you.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: You shall not be a looser Thymele:
Philocles shall be yours, and in exchange
Placilla mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: To me my beauteous spouse
Thou art as Juno to her Jupiter,
Sister and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Thy.
SP.L: Your highness may be pleas'd
Now at so happy leasure to perpend
The Oracle; which truly hath effected
Each word of the prediction.

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Who can repeat the answer, I ha'lost it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: I have it.
Contend not for the jewel, which
Ere long shall both of you inrich.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: Eudina does so: me in a dear sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Philar.
SP.L: Me in a Peerless wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Pursue your fortune: for 'tis she
Shall make ye what you seem to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Philoc.
SP.L: She has done that too: For now indeed w'are brothers

SP.SPEAKER: King
SP.L: Apollo thou hast fill'd us all with joy,
But has our joy already fill'd our Court
With Musick?

SP.SPEAKER: Dis.
SP.L: Will your Majesty yet sit
And see the practise of a presentation,
Against the Marriages by your Swains of Tempe
With thanks; and give it all the grace we may?

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.L: From Tempe plains, the Tempe Swains
SP.STAGE: Enter Geron and the Swains and Nymphs for the dance.

L.HI: With Dance and Song do hither throng

SP.SPEAKER: Gar.

L.HI: O there, look there, Madam my Son, and all

SP.L: My old Temperian Neighbours.

L.HI: We cannot hope in all our scope,
To gain much praise for skill,
But it shall be enough, if ye

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My thanks to all.

SP.SPEAKER: All
SP.L: Heaven bless your Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thanks to Apollo. Let his temple be
The place of our solemnity. His Altars
Let them be laden with Arabian spices;
Let his Priests lead, in a devout procession,
The horned Sacrifice, mantled with Ghirlonds
And we (our Temples crown'd with Laurel) follow
With Musick, sounding Hymen and Apollo.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGƲE.
DIV1.L: Tis not the Poets art, nor all that we
By life of Action can present unt'ye
Can justly make us to presume a Play
Is good till you approv't: which that you may
It cannot mis-become us, since our gains
Come by your favour more then all our pains.
Thus to submit us unto your commands
And humbly ask that favour at your hands.

DIV1.P: THE WEEDING OF THE COVENT-GARDEN.
Or the Middlesex-JƲSTICE OF Peace.
A POSTHUME of RICHARD BROME, An Ingenious Servant, and Imitator of his Master, that famously Renowned Poet Ben. Johnson.

P.HI:
Aut prodesse solent, aut delectare Poetae.
Dramatis Personae.

DIV1.P: LONDON, Printed for Andrew Crook, and are to be sold at the Green Dragon in St. Pauls Church-yard: And Henry Broom at the Gun in Ivy-lane. 1658.

DIV1.HEAD: Upon AGLAƲRA printed in Folio.
DIV1.L: Br this large Margent did the Poet mean
To have a Comment writ upon his Scene?
Or is it that the Ladies, who ne're look
On any but a Poeme or Play-book,
May, in each page, have space to scribble down
When such a Lord, or Fashion comes to Town.
As Swaines in Almanacks account do keep,
When their Cow calv'd, and when they bought their sheep?
Ink is the life of Paper: 'tis meet then,
That this which scap'd the Press should feel the Pen.
A Room with one side furnish'd, or a face
Painted half-way, is but a faire disgrace.
This great voluminous Pamphlet may be said
To be like one that hath more haire then head;
More excrement then body. Trees, which sprout
With broadest leaves, have still the smallest fruit.
When I saw so much white, I did begin
To think Aglaura either did lie in,
Or else took Pennance. Never did I see
(unlesse in Bills dasht In the Chancerie).
So little in so much; as if the feet
Of Poetry, like Law, were sold by th'sheet.
If this new fashion should but last one yeare,
Poets, as Clerks, would make our paper dear.
Doth not the Artist erre, and blast his fame
That sets out pictures lesser then the frame?
Was ever Chamberlaine so mad, to dare
To lodge a childe in the great Bed at Ware?
Aglaura wold please better, did she lie
I'th' narrow bounds of an Epitomie.
Pieces that are weav'd of the finest twist,
(As Silk and Plush) have still more stuffe then list.
She, that in Persian habit made great brags,
Degenerates in this excesse of rags;
Who, by her Giant-bulk this only gaines,
Perchance in Libraries to hang in chaines.
Tis not in Book, as Cloth; we never say
Make London-measure, when we buy a Play:
But rather have them pair'd: Those leaves be faire
To the judicious, which more spotted are.
Give me the sociable Pocket-books.
These empty Folio's only please the Cooks.

DIV1.HEAD: A SONG.
DIV1.L: A Way with all grief and give us more sack.
'Tis that which we love, let love have no lack.
Nor sorrow, nor care can crosse our delights,
Nor witches, nor goblins, nor Buttery sprights,
Tho' the candles burne dimme while we can do thus,
We'll scorn to flie them: but we'll make them flie us.
Old Sack, and old Songs, and a merry old crew
Will fright away Sprights, when the ground looks blew.

DIV1.HEAD: A PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: HE that could never boast, nor seek the way,
To prepare friends to magnifie his Play,
Nor raile at's Auditory for unjust,
If they not lik't it nor was so mistrust.
Ful ever in himself, that he besought
Preapprobation though they lik't it not.
Nor ever had the luck to have his name
Clap't up above this merit. Nor the shame
To be cried down below it. He this night
Your faire and free Attention does invite.
Only he prays no prejudice be brought
By any that before-hand wish it nought.
And that ye all be pleas'd to heare and see,
With Candor suiting his Integritie.
That for the Writer. Something we must say,
Now in defence of us, and of the Play
We shall present no Scandal or Abuse,
To vertue or to honour. Nor traduce
Person of worth. Nor point at the disgrace
Of any one residing in the Place,
On which our Scene is laid, nor any Action shew,
Of thing has there been done, for ought we know.
Though it be probable that such have been.
But if some vicious persons be brought in.
As no new Buildings, nor the strongest hold
Can keep ou Rats and Vermine bad and bold.
Let not the sight of such be ill endur'd;
All sores are seen and search't before th' are cur'd.
As Ruffian, Bawd, and the licentious crew,
Too apt to pester Scituations new.

DIV1.HEAD: Another Prologue.
DIV1.L: 'Tis not amisse ere we begin our Play,
T' intreat you, that you take the same surveigh
Into your fancie, as our Poet took,
Of Covent-Garden, when he wrote his Book.
Some ten years since, when it was grown with weeds.
Not set, as now it is, with Noble Seeds.
Which make the Garden glorious. And much
Our Poet craves and hopes you will not grutch
It him, that since so happily his Pen
Foretold its faire emprovement, and that men
Of worth and honour should renown the place.
The Play may still retain its former grace.

DIV1.HEAD: To my LORD of Newcastle, on his PLAY called THE VARIETY. He having commanded to give him my true o∣pinion of it.
DIV1.L: I Could not think these seven yeares, but that I
In part a Poet was, and so might lie,
By the Poetick Licence. But I finde
Now I am none, and strictly am confin'd
To truth, if therefore I subpaena'd were
Before the Court of Chancerie to swear.
Or if from thence I should be higher sent,
And on my life unto a Parliament
Of wit and judgement, there to certifie
What I could say of your VARIETY:
I would depose each Scene appear'd to me
An Act of wit, each Act a Comedy,
And all was such, to all that understood,
As knowing Johnson, swore By God 'twas good.

LIST.ITEM: Rooksbill, a great Builder in Covent-Garden.
Crossewill, a Countrey Gentleman, Lodger in his Buildings.
Cockbrain, a Justice of Peace, the Weeder of the Garden.
Mun Clotpoll, a foolish Gull.
Driblow, Captain of the Philoblathici.
Belt, Crossewills Servant.
Ralph, Dorcas Servant.
Pig, Damaris Servant.

LIST.HEAD: Women Actors.
LIST.ITEM: Lucie, Rooksbills daughter.
Katharine, Crossewills daughter.
Dorcas, alias Damaris, Croswills Neece.
Margerie Howlet, a Bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I Marry Sir! This is something like! These appear like Buildings! Here's Architecture exprest in∣deed! It is a most sightly scitua∣tion, and fit for Gentry and Nobility.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: When it is all finished, doubtlesse it will be handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P:
It will be glorious: and yond magnificent Peece, the Piazzo, will excel that at Venice, by hear∣say, (I ne're travell'd). A hearty blessing on their braines, honours, and wealths, that are Projectors, Furtherers, and Performers of such great works. And now I come to you Mr. Rookesbill: I like your Rowe of houses most incomparably. Your money never
shone so on your Counting-boards, as in those Stru∣ctures.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: I have pil'd up a Leash of thousand pounds in walls and windows there.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: It will all come again with large en∣crease.

And better is your money thus let out on red and white, then upon black and white, I say. You can∣not think how I am taken with that Rowe! How even and straight they are! And so are all indeed. The Surveyor (what e're he was) has manifested himself the Master of his great Art. How he has wedded strength to beauty; state to uniformity; commodi∣ousnesse with perspicuity! All, all as't should be!

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: If all were as well tenanted and inhabited by worthy persons.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Phew; that will follow. What new Planta∣tion was ever peopled with the better sort at first; nay, commonly, the lewdest blades, and naughty∣packs are either necessitated to 'hem, or else do prove the most forward venturers. Is not lime and hair the first in all your foundations? do we not soile or dung our lands, before we sowe or plant any thing that's good in 'hem? And do not weeds creep up first in all Gardens? and why not then in this? which never was a Garden until now; and which will be the Gar∣den of Gardens, I foresee't. And for the weeds in it, let me alone for the weeding of them out. And so as my Reverend Ancestor Justice Adam Overdoe, was wont to say, In Heavens name and the Kings, and for the good of the Common-wealth I will go a∣bout it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P:
I would a few more of the Worshipful here∣abouts, (whether they be in Commission or not) were as well minded that way as you are Sir; we should
then have all sweet and clean, and that quickly too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I have thought upon a way for't, Mr. Rooks∣bill: and I will pursue it, viz. to finde out all the enormities, yet be my selfe unspied: whereby I will tread out the spark of impiety, whilest it is yet a spark and not a flame; and break the egge of a mis∣chief, whilest it is yet an egge and not a Cockatrice. Then doubt not of worthy tenants for your houses Mr. Rooksbill.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, your best furtherance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I had a letter bur last night from a worthy friend, a West-countrey Gentleman, that is, now coming up with his family to live in Town here; and desire is to inhabit in these buildings. He was to lie at Hammersmith last night, and requested an early meeting of me this morning here, to assist him in the taking of a house. It is my businesse hither; for he could never do't himselfe. He has the oldest touchy, wrangling humour.—But in a harmlesse way; for he hurts no body, and pleases himself in it. His children have all the trouble of it, that do anger him in obeying him sometimes. You will know him anon. I mean, he shall be your Tenant. And luckily he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: It is not enough you tell me of obedience. Or that you are obedient. But I will be obeyed in my own way. Do you see—

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: My noble friend Mr. Croswill, right happi∣ly met.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Your troublesome friend Mr. Cockbrayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P:
No trouble at all, Sir, though I have pre∣vented
yours in finding a fit house for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: You ha' not ha' you, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Actum est Mr. Croswill. But Civility par∣don me, Is not this your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: All the Shee-things I have: and would I were well rid of her too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Sweet Mrs. Katherine, Welcome—Mr. Gabriel, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Gabriel Croswill is my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: But where's your younger sonne Mihill? There's a spark!

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: A Spark! A dunce I fear by this time like his brother Sheepshead there.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Gabriel is my proper name.

SP.SPEAKER: Gros.
SP.P: I have not seen him this Twelve-moneth, since I chamber'd him a Student here in Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: In town, and I not know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: He knows not yet of my coming neither, nor shall not, till I steal upon him; and if I finde him mopish like his brother, I know what I will doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Have you not heard from him lately?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Yes, often by his letters, lesse I could reade more comfort in 'hem. I fear he's turn'd Precisian, for all his Epistles end with Amen; and the-matter of 'hem is such as if he could teach me to ask him blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: A comfortable hearing of a young man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
Is it so Sir? but I'le new mould him if it be so.—I'le tell you Mr. Cockbrayne; never was such a father so crost in his children. They will not obey me in my way. I grant, they do things that other fathers would rejoyce at. But I will be obeyed in my own way, dee see. Here's my eldest sonne. Mark how he stands, as if he had learn't a posture at Knights-bridge
spittle as we came aloug while-eare. He was not only borne without wit, but with an obstinate re∣solution, never to have any. I mean, such wit as might become a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Was that resolution borne in him think you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: It could never grow up in him still as it does else. When I would have him take his horse, and follow the dogs, and associate Gentlemen, in hawk∣ing, hunting, or such like exercises, he'l run you a foot five mile another way, to meet the brethren of the separation, at such exercises as I never sent him to (I am sure) on worky dayes. And whereas most Gentlemen run into other mens books, in hands that they care not who reades, he has a book of his own Short-writing in his pocket, of such stuffe as is fit for no mans reading indeed but his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Surely Sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Sure you are an Asse. Hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: You are my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: What comfort should I have, were my son such.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: And he has nothing but hang'd the head, as you see now, ever since Holiday sports were cried up in the Countrey. And but for that, and to talk with some of the silenc'd Pastors here in town about it, I should not have drawn him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: I would I could change a sonne w' you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What kinde of thing is thy sonne? ha! dost thou look like one that could have a sonne fit for me to father, ha? And yet the best take both, and t' please you at all adventures, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: I am sure there cannot be a worse, or more debauch'd reprobate then mine is living.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
And is the devil too good a Master for
him, think'st thou, ha? Wherein can I deserve so ill at thy hands, fellow, whate're thou art, that thou should'st wish me comber'd with a worse burden, when thou hearest me complain of this, ha? What is this fellow that you dare know him, Friend Cock∣brayn? I will not dwell within three parishes of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: My tenant! Blesse me from him. I had ra∣ther all my Rents were Bawdy houses.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Think nothing of his words, he'll forget all instantly. The best natur'd man living.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Dost thou stand like a son now that hears his father abus'd, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I am praying for the conversion of the young man he speaks of.

SP.SPEAKER: Coek.
SP.P: Well said, Mr. Gabriel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: But by the way, where's your sonne Antho∣ny? have you not heard of him yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Never since he forsook me, on the discon∣tent he took, in that he might not marry your daugh∣ret there. And where he lives, or whether he lives or not, I know not. I hope your davghter is a comfort to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Yes, in keeping her chamber whole weeks together, fullenning upon her Samplery breech-work, when I was in hope she would have made me a Grand∣father ere now. But she has a humour, forsooth, since we put your son by her, to make me a match-broker, her marriage-Maker; when I tell you friend, there has been so many untoward matches of Pa∣rents making, that I have sworn she shall make her own choice, though it be of one I hate. Make me her match-maker! Must I obey her, or she me, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I wish, with teares, my sonne had had her now.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Wherein Sir, (under correction do I disobey you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: In that very word, under correction, thou dis∣obey'st me. Are you to be under correction at these yeares? ha! If I ha' not already taught you manners beyond the help of correction, go, seek a wiser father to mend 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Yet give me leave, dear Sir, in my ex∣cuse.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Leave out correction then.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: If I were forward as many Maidens are,
To wish a husband, must I not be sought?
I never was a Gadder: and my Mother,
Before she dy'd, adjur'd me to be none.
I hope you'll give me leave to keep your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: La there again! How subtly she seeks dominion over me! No, huswife, No; you keep no house of mine. I'll nestle you no longer under my wing. Are you not fledge; I'll have you fly out I, as other mens daughters do; and keep a house of your own if you can find it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: We had a kinswoman flew out too late∣ly, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What tell'st thou me of her; wise-acres? Can they not flie out a little, but they must turne arrant vvhores, ha? Tell me of your kinswoman? 'Tis true, she was my Neece; she vvent to't a little afore her time? some tvvo years since, and so fled from Re∣ligion; and is turn'd Turk, vve fear. And vvhat of that in your precisiancial vvisdom? I have such children as no man has. But (as I vvas saying,) vvould ye top me husvvife, ha! Look you, novv I chide her, she sayes nothing. Is this obedience, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Perhaps, I might unfortunately cast my affecti∣on on a man that vvould refuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: That man I vvould desire to knovv; shevv me that man; see if I svvinge him not dares slight my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Still the old humour, self-vvill'd, crosse, and touchie; but suddainly reconcil'd. Come, Mr. Cros∣wil, to the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Oh, you told me of a house you had found for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Yes Sir. And here's the Landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Does he look, or go like one could let a house vvorthy of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Sir, vve have able Builders here, that vvill not carry least shevv of their buildings on their backs. This is a rich sufficient man, I assure you, and my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I cry him heartily mercy, and embrace him. And novv I note you better, you look like Thrift it self.
SP.STAGE: Enter Dorcas above upon a Bellconie. Gabriel gazes at her. Dorcas is habited like a Curtizan of Venice.
SP.P: I cannot think you vvill throvv avvay your houses at a cast. You have a sonne, perhaps, that may, by the commendations you gave of him. Lets see your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Come avvay Mr. Gabriel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Come Sir, vvhat do you gape ad shake the head at there? I'll lay my life he has spied the little Crosse upon the nevv Church yond, and is at defiance vvith it. Sirrah, I vvill make you honour the first syllable of my name. My name is Will. Croswill, and I vvill have my humour. Let those that talk of me for it, speak their pleasure, I vvill do mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I shall obey you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Novv you are in the right. You shall indeed. I'll make your heart ake else, dee see.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P:
But truly I vvas looking at that Image; that
painted idolatrous image yonder, as I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O heresie! It is some Lady, or Gentlewo∣man standing upon her Bellconey.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Her Bellconey? Where is it? I can spy from her foot to her face, yet I can see no Bellconey she has.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: What a Knave's this: That's the Bellconey she stands on, that which jets out so on the forepart of the house; every house here has one of 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: 'Tis very good; I like the jetting out of the forepart very well; it is a gallant fashion indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I guess what she is, what ere I have said. O Justice look to thine office.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Come now to this house, and then to my son Mihil, the Spark you spoke of. And if I find him cross too, I'le cross him: Let him look to't▪ Dee see.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I'le see you hous'd; and then about my pro∣ject, which is for weeding of this hopeful Garden. Ex. omnes.
SP.STAGE: Gabriel stayes last looking up at her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.L: Why should not we in England use that free∣dome
The famous Curtezans have in Italy:
We have the art, and know the Theory
To allure and catch the wandring eyes of Lovers;
Yea, and their hearts too: but our stricter Lawes
Forbids the publique practise, our desires
Are high as theirs; our wills as apt and forward;
Our wits as ripe, our beauties more attractive;
Or Travellers are shrewd lyars. Where's the let?
Only in bashful coward custome, that
Stoops i'the shoulders, and submits the neck
To bondage of Authority; to these Lawes,
That men of feeble age and weaker eye-sight
Have fram'd to bar their sons from youthful pleasures.
Possets and Cawdels on their queasie stomacks,
Whilst I fly out in brave rebellion;
And offer, at the least, to break these shackles
That holds our legs together: And begin
A fashion, which pursu'd by Cyprian Dames,
May perswade Justice to allow our Games.
Who knows? I'le try. Francisca bring my Lute.
SP.STAGE: while she is tuning her Lute: Enter Nich. Rookesbill, Anthony in a false beard, Clotpoll.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Troth I have a great mind to be one of the Philoblathici, a Brother of the Blade and Battoon, as you translate it; now ye have beat it into my head: But I fear I shall never come on and off handsomely. I have mettal enough methinks, but I know not how methinks to put it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: We'l help you out with it, and set it flying for you never doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Obotts, you mean my money mettal, I mean my valour mettal I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Peace, heark.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: T'other flyes fast enough already.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Pox on ye peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: O most melodious.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Most odious, Did you say? It is methinks most odoriferous.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: What new devise can this be? Look!

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: She is vanisht. Is't not the Mountebanks Wife that was here; and now come again to play some new merry tricks by herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: A botts on't, I never saw that Mountebank; they say, he brought the first resort into this new plan∣tation, and sow'd so much seed of Knavery and Co∣zenage here, that 'tis fear'd 'twill never out.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Nay but this creature: What can she be?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And then again, he drew such flocks of idle people to him, that the Players, they say, curst him abhominably.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant,
SP.P: Thou ever talk'st of the wrong matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Cry mercy Brothers of the Blade and Bat∣toune: Do you think if I give my endeavour to it, I shall ever learn to roar and carry it as you do, that have it naturally, as you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Yes, as we'll beat it into you. But this wo∣man, this musical woman, that set her self out to show so, I would be satisfied in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And she be as able as she seems, she has in her to satisfie you, and you were a Brother of ten Blades, and ten Battounes.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I vow—Peace. I'le battoune thy teeth into thy tongue else; she bears a stately presence. Thou never saw'st her before: Didst thou Toney?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: No; but I heard an inkling at the Paris Tavern last night of a She-Gallant-that had travelled France and Italy; and that she would—

SP.SPEAKER: (Clot.
SP.P: Battoun thy teeth into thy tongue.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Plant some of her forraign collections, the fruits of her travels, in this Garden here, to try how they would grow or thrive on English earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Young Pig was speaking of such a one to me, and that she was a Mumper.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: What's that a Sister of the Scabberd, brother of the Blade?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Come, come; we'l in, we'l in; 'tis one of our fathers buildings; I'le see the Inhabitants. Some money Clot. furnish I say, and quickly.—I vow—

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: You shall, you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: What shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Vow twice before you have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I vow, and I vow again, I'le coyn thy brains.—

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Hold, hold, take your powl money; I thought I would have my will; and the word I look-for, I'le coyn thy brains.—

I do not love to give my money for nothing, I have a volume of words here, the worst of 'hem is as good as a blow; and then I save my Crown whole half a dozen times a day, by half a crown a time, there's half in half sav'd by that.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Come let's appear civil, till we have our en∣trance, and then as occasion serves—
Who would you speak withal?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Your Mistress, little one.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Do you know her Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: No; but I would know her, that's the busi∣ness: I mean the musical Gentlewoman that was fidling, and so many in the What-doe-call't een now.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: What-doe-call her Sir, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: What-doe-call her; 'tis not come to that yet, prethee let me see and speak with her first.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: You are dispos'd I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: What should we do here else?

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.P: You wont thrust in upon a body whether one will or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant. Nic.
SP.P: Away you Monkey.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.P: O me, What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: O my brave Philoblathici.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: What's the matter the Girl cryes out so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.P: I know not: I fear some rude company, some of the wild crew are broke into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Within. Whether would you go, you wont rob the house will ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Will ye be quiet Whiskin?

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.P: O me 'tis so: Hell's broke loose; this comes of your new fingle-fangle fashion, your prepostrous Italian way forsooth: would I could have kept my old way of pots and pipes, and my Strong-water course for customers: The very first twang of your fiddle guts has broke all, and conjur'd a legion of de∣vils among us.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Nay, there's but a Leash of us. How now?
Who have we here? Are these the far travel'd Ladies?
O thou party perpale, or rather parboild Bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What shall I do? Dam. Out alass; sure they are devils indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Art thou travel'd cross the Seas from the Bankside hither, old Countess of Codpiece-row?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Party perpale and parboild Bawd.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: And is this the Damsel that has been in France and Italy? Clot. Codpiece-row.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Peace ye roaring Scabs: I'le besworn she supt at Paris Tavern last night, and lay not long ago at the Venice by Whitefryers Dock.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Prethee what is she Madge?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: A civil Gentlewoman you see she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: She has none of the best faces: but is she war∣rantable; I have not had a civil night these three moneths.

SP.SPEAKER: Madge.
SP.P: Nor none are like to have here, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: O Madge how I do long thy thing to ding didle ding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: O Nick, I am not in the humour, no more is she to be o'the merry pin now; I am sure her case is too lamentable. But if you will all sit down, I'le give you a bottle of wine, and we'l relate her story to you, so you will be civil. Nic. Well for once, I care not if we be.
SP.STAGE: A Table bottle, light, and Tobacco stales.
SP.P: Let us set to't then; sit down brother Toney, sit down Gentlewoman, we shall know your name a∣non, I hope it will fall in your story; sit down Clot∣poll.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: You will call me brother Clotpoll too when I have taken my oath, and paid my entrance into the faternity of the Blade and the Battoun.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: 'Tis like we shall. Now Lady of the Stygian Lake, thou black infernal Madge, begin the dismal story, whilst I begin the bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: This Gentlewoman whose name is Damyris.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Damyris stay. Her nick-name then is Dammy, so we may call her when we grow familiar: and to begin that familiarity, Dammy here's to you.—drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: And what's your nick-name I pray Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Nick: only Nick, Madge there knows it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Then I believe your name is Nicholas.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I vow-witty. Yes Dammy, and my Sirname is Rookesbill, and so is my Fathers too: and what do you make o'that?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Nothing not I Sir: sure this is he.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: And I would he were nothing, so I had all he has: I must have tother glass to wash him out of my mouth, he furs it worse then Mondongas Tobacco. Here old Madge, and to all the birds that shall won∣der at thy howletship, when thou rid'st in an Ivy-bush, call'd a Cart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Well mad Nick, I'le pledge thee in hope to see as many flutter about the tree, that thou shalt clime backwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: A pox thou wilt be stifled with Offal and Car∣ret leaves before that day.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Fie, fie, what talk's this? 'tis he I am consi∣dent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: These are our ordinary complements, we wish no harm.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: No Dammy I vow, not I to any breathing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: But your Father Nick.—Is he that Rookes∣bill.—

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: But my Fathet; Pox rot ye, why do ye put me in mind of him again, he sticks i'my throat, now I'le wash him a little further.—Here Brother Toney

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Gramercy Brother Nick.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And to all the brothers that are, and are to be of the Blade and the Battoun.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: There said you well Clotpoll: Here 'tis—

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: I would but have asked you whether your Father were that Rookesbill that is call'd the great Builder.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P:
Yes marry is it he forsooth; he has built I know not how many houses hereabout, though he goes Dammy as if he were not worth a groat; and all his cloaths I vow are not worth this hilt, except those he wears, and prayes for fair weather in, on my Lord Mayors Day; and you are his Tenant, though perhaps you know it not, and may be mine; therefore use me well: for this house and the rest I hope will be mine, as well as I can hope he is mortal, of which I must confess I have been in some doubt, though now I hope again, he will be the first shall lay his bones i'the new Church, though the Church-yard be too good
for him before 'tis consecrated. So give me the to-the cup, for now he offends my stomack. Here's to thee now Clotpoll.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And to all the Sisters of the Scabberd Bro∣ther in Election. Dee hear, Pray talk of his father no more, for the next brings him to the belly-work, and then he'll drink him quite through him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: And so we shall have a foul house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: No he shall stick there. Now to the story Gentlewoman, 'twas that we sate for.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I to the story, I vow I had almost forgot it; and I am the worst at Sack in a morning: Dear Dam∣my to the story.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Good Sir my heart's too full to utter't.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Troth and my head's too full to hear it: But I'le go out and quarrel with some body to settle my brains, then go down to Mich. Crossewill to put him in mind of our meeting to day; then if you will meet me at the Goat at Dinner, wee'll have it all at large.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Will you be there indeed Sir, I would speak with you seriously.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Dammy if I be not, may my father out live me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: We both here promise you he shall be there by noon.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: 'Lady, 'tis sworn by Blade and by Battoun.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: This will be the bravest discovery for Mihill, the new Italian Bona Roba Catsoe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Why so sad on the suddain Niece.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: But do you think hee'll come as he has pro∣mis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: He never breaks a promise with any of us' though he fail all the honest part o'the world: But I trust you are not taken with the Ruffian, you'll nere get penny by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I prethee peace, I care not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: But Mystris, rhere is a Gallant now below, a Gingle boy indeed, that has his pockets full of, crowns that chide for vent. Shall I call him up to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I will see no man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: How's that? I hope you jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Indeed, I hope you jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: You will not hinder the house, I hope. Marry heigh. This were a humour and 'twould last. Go fetch him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I'le flie then out at window. Nay, by this steel 'tis true.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What's the matter? have I got a mad wo∣man into the house. What do you go about to break me the first day of your coming, before you have han∣sell'd a Couch or a Bedside in't. Were you but now all o'th heigh to set your self out for a signe with your fiddle cum twang, and promise such wonders, for∣sooth, and will not now be seen. Pray what's the Riddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I'll tell thee all anon. Prithie excuse me. I know thy share of his sins bounty would not come to thus much, take it, I give it thee. And prithee let me be honest till I have a mince to be otherwise, and I'le hinder thee nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Md.
SP.P: Well, I'le dismisse the Gallant, and send you, Sirrah, for another wench. I'le have Besse Bufflehead again. This kicksy wincy Giddibrain will spoil all I'le no more Italian tricks.—
SP.L: Thus some have by the phrensie of despair
Fumously run into the sea to throw
Their wretched bodies, but when come near
They saw the billows rise, heard Boreas blow,
And horrid death appearing on the Maine,
A sudden fear hath sent them back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: NAy, but honest Shoomaker; thy honest price.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: I tell you intruth, Sir, 'tis as good a boot as e∣ver you pull'd on in your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: A little too streight, I doubt. What do you think o' my boots honest Tailor.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: They do exceeding handsomely, never trust me Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Never fear it Tailor, you shall trust me, and please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: You are pleasant Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: And what do you think of my suite Shooma∣ker? can you say as much for the Tailor as he for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: A very neat suite, Sir, and becomes you ex∣cellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Honest men both, and hold together; one would little think you were so near neighbours. Well, you, have fitted me both, I must confesse. But how I shall fit you, now there's the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: There's but one way for than and please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: With paying us our money Sit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P:
Still both in a tale, I can not but commend your neighbourhood, I muse my Laundresse stayes,
I sent her three or foure wayes for moneys. But do not you stay for that. I have wayes enough to pay you. I have ploughes a going that you dream not of.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: No indeed, Sir, we dream of nothing but ready money, sleeping or waking.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I shall be rich enough ne're fear't. I have a venter in the new soap businesse man.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: We are but servants, Sir. And our Ma∣sters themselves have no faith, in flippery pro∣jects.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: Besides, the women begin to grumble a∣gainst that slippery project shrewdly, and, 'tis feard, will mutinie sho tly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Burlakin, and they may prove more trouble∣some then a commotion of Sailors.
O welcome, Laundresse, where's the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Laun.
SP.P: Not a penny of money, Sir, can I get. But here's one come to town has brought you enough, and you can have grace to finger it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Who's that I prithee.

SP.SPEAKER: Laun.
SP.P: Your father, your father Sir. I met his man by great chance, who told me his Master meanes to steal upon you presently, and take you as he findes you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P:
Is he come up with his crosse tricks. I head he was to come. And that he meanes to live here altogether. He has had an aime these dozen years to live in town here, but never was fully bent on't un∣til the Proclamation of restraint spurr'd him up. 'Tis such a Crossewill. Well, he is my father, and I am utterly undone if thou help'st me not now at a pinch, at a pinch, dear Laundresse. Go borrow me a Gown,
and some foure or five Law-books? for, I protest, mine are in Duck-lane. Nay, trudge, sweet Laun∣dresse, trudge.— Ex. Laun. Honest Tailor and Shoemaker convey your selves away quietly, and I'll pay you to morrow, as I am a Gentleman:

SP.SPEAKER: Shoe.
SP.P: As I am a Shoemaker, and that's a kinde of a Centleman, you know, I'll not stirre till I have my money, I am not an Asse Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: No body sayes thou art.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoe.
SP.P: I have had too many such tricks put upon me i' my dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: A trick! as I hope for money it is no trick.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoe.
SP.P: Well Sir, trick or no trick. I must have my money or my boots, and that's plain dealing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: A pox o'th' boots, so my legs were out of 'hem. Would they were i'thy throat, spurres and all, you will not out.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoe.
SP.P: No marry will we not.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Well-said Shoomaker, I commend thee, thou hast a better heart then I, though my stomack's good.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: O well said, my good Laundresse. How am I bound to thee; yet all this wo'not do't Laundresse. Thou must bestir thy stumps a little further, and bor∣row me a couple of Gownes more for these Rascals here that will not away.

SP.SPEAKER: Laun.
SP.P: How! wo'not away? And they were well serv'd, they would be thrust out of doors for saucie companions. Your Masters would not put a Gentle∣man to his trumps thus.

SP.SPEAKER: M;.
SP.P:
Nay, svveet Laundresse, restrain thy tongue, and stretch thy feet. A couple of Govvns, good
