Laundresse, and forget not caps. Ex. If I do novv furnish you like Civil Lavvyers, and you do not keep your countenances; if ever you do but peep in at the Hall-door at Christmas to see the revels, I'le have you set i'th' stocks for this beleeve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: If you do, Sir, I may hap be even vvith you before the year comes about, and set you in our stocks for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: But will you make Lawyers of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Have you a minde to have your money you unbelieving Rascals.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoc.
SP.P: I see your drift, and hope you'll prove an honest Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Thou hast some hope, though no faith nor trust in any man.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoe.
SP.P: Alas, Sir, our Masters sit at grear rents, and keep great families.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I cry you mercy, they are remov'd into the nevv plantation here, where, they say, are a tribe of Infidel-tradesmen, that have made a Law vvithin your selves to put no trust in Gentlemen. But beare your selves handsomely here you vvere best. I am acquainted vvith a crevv that haunts about your ha∣bitations, vvith whom I will joyne, and so batter your windows one of these nights else.—O welcom, Laundresse, how doest thou toile for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Laun.
SP.P: Your fathers talking, as I am a woman, be∣low.—As thou art a woman below, well-said. Come on with these Gownes, and lets see how yow'll look. If we had time, the Shoomaker should wash his face; but seeing there is no remedy; pull the cap in your eyes, and good enongh. Now Laun∣dresse, set us stooles, and leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Laun.
SP.P: I hear him coming up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P:
Now let him come, we are ready for him. Shoomaker, keep your hand underneath the
book, that the pitch do not discover you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: I warrant you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: And Taylor, be sure you have no Needle on your sleeve, nor thread about your neck.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: I warrant you too for me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi:
SP.P: He's enrred.
SP.STAGE: Enter Croswill, Belt, and stand aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Remitter, I say, is where a man hath two titles, that is to say, one of an elder, the other of a later. And he cometh to the land by the later title; yet the Law adjudgeth him to be in by the force of the elder title. If the tenant in the taile discontinee the taile, and after he diseaseth his dis∣continue, and so dieth seised, whereby the tenants descend to their issue, as to his Cousin inheritable by force of the taile. In this case the tenants descend, who have right by force of the taile, a Remitter in the taile taken for that in the Law, shall put and ad∣judge him to be in by force of descent. Pox on ye, speak something good or bad, somewhat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: The Remitter, you say, is seised i'th' tail.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Excellent Shoomaker, I say so, and again, I say, that if the tenant in the taile in feoffe his son, or his Cousin, inheritable by force of the taile, the which sonne or cousin at the time of the feoffment is within age, and after the tenant in the taile dierh, this is a Remitter to the heire in the taile to whom the feoffment is made, now Taylor.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Think you so, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Look either Fitzherbert, Perkins, or Dier, and you shall finde it in the second part of Richard Cordelyon. So much for Remitter. Novv I'll put a plain home-spun case, as a man may say, vvhich vve call a moot-case.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: I pray do Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Some father might take joy of such a sonne novv. This takes not me. No, this is not my vvay.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: The case is this
pull up your grounds closer and behang'd, you are a Tailor, and you: a Shoomaker.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: And you owe us money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I put the case, I do, to you for a suit of clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: And to you for a paire of boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: True.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I have broke my day with you both. Sup∣pose so.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: Very well, we do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: You clap a Sergeant o' my back. I put in bail, remove it, and carry it up into the upper Court, with habeas-Corpus; bring it down again into the lower Court with procedendo; then take it from thence, and bring it into the Chancery with a Cer∣tiorari; I; and if you look not to t, bring it out of the Chancery again, and thus will I keep you from your money till your suite and your boots be worne out before you recover penny of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sho.
SP.P: Sly'd but you shall not, your father shall know all first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: S'foot Shoomaker wilt thou be an Asse. I do but put a case, Have you not feen it tried.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Yes, very often.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P:
Away with books. Away with Law. Away with madnesse. I, God blesse thee, and make thee his servant, and defend thee from Law, I say. Take up these books, sarrah, and carry them presently into Pauls Church-yard dee see, and change them all for Histo∣ries, as pleasant as profitable; Arthur of Britain,
Primalion of Greece, Amadis of Gaul, and such like de see.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I hope he do's but jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: And do you heare, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: I Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Get Bells work, and you can, into the bar∣gain.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Which Bell, Sir? Adam Bell, with Clim 'th' Clough, and William of Cloudesley.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Adam Bell you Asse? Valiant Bell that kill'd the Dragon.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: You mean St. George.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Sir Jolthead, do I not. I'le teach you to chop logick, vvith me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Sfoot, how shall I answer my borrow'd books? Stay Belt. Pray Sir, do not change my books.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Sir, Sir, I will change them and you too: Did I leave thee here to learn fashions and manners, that thou mightst carry thy self like a Gentleman, and dost thou wast thy brains in learning a language that I understand not a word of? ha! I had been as good have brought thee up among the wild Irish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Why alass Sir, Had I not better keep my self within my Chamber, at my Studie, then be rioting a∣broad, wasting both money and time, which is more precious then money? if you did know the inconve∣nience of company, you would rather incourage and commend my retir'd life, then any wayes dehort me from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Why Sir did not I keep companie think you when I was young? Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Ml.
SP.P: Yes Sir; but the times are much alter'd, and youth more corrupted now, they did not drink and wench in those dayes, but nay, o 'tis abominable in these.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
Why this is that I fear'd, the boyes turning
meacock too, after his elder brother, 'twas time to look to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nich.
SP.P: Why Croswill Mich. What, not up yet and behang'd. Or ha ye a wench a bed wye. Is this keep∣ing your home. Mihil runs to the door and holds it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Sfoot the Rogue Rooksbil and his crew, I fear'd as much.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Break open the door, let me come to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Forbear, or behang'd, you will undo me, my father's here. I'll meet you anon as I am honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Your father's a Clowterdepouch. Nay, I will come then, what Madamoiselle do you call fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: You would not believe me. Pray be civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: 'Tis so, we will Cry mercy, you are busie, we will not moote to day then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I hope you may excuse me, I'le be w'ye a∣non.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Come to the Goat Capricorne. We have the bravest new discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: How now! what are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: They are Gentlemen of my standing, Sir, that have a little over-studied themselves, and are some∣what—.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Mad; are they not? And so will you be shortly, if you follow these courses. Mooting do they call it? you shall moote nor mute here no long∣er. Therefore on with your cloak and sword, follow me to the Tavern and leave me such long-tail'd com∣pany as these are, for I do not like them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: No more do I, Sir, if I knew how to be rid of 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I think thou hast ne're a sword, hast thou, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Yes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Where is it, Sir, let me se't Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: 'Tis here, under mybed, Sir.—Reach it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Why there's a Lawyers trick right, make his weapon companion with his Pisse-pot. Fie, fie, here's a tool indeed. There's money, Sir, buy you a good one, one with the Mathematical hilt as they terme it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: It would do better in Mathematical books▪ Sir, offer me no money, pray Sir, but for books.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Go to, you are a peevish Jack, do not pro∣voke me: do not you owe me obedience? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Yes Sir, I acknowledge it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: 'Tis good you do. Well, take that money; and put your selfe into cloathes befitting your rank, Do so. And let me see you, squirting about without a weapon, like an Attorneys Clerk in Tearm-time, and I'l weapon you, What, shall I have a Noddie of you. This frets him to the liver. Go to, never hang the head for the matter. For I tell thee I will have it so, and herein be knowen what I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: You are known sufficiently for your crosse humour already; in which I'll try you if I can make you double this money, for this will not serve my turne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What have you told it after me, you had best weigh it too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: No Sir, but I have computed that for my pre¦sent use, here is too much by halfe, pray Sir, take halfe back.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Bodie o' me, what a perverse knave is this, to crosse me thus! Is there too much, say you? ha

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Yes truly, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Let me see't. Go thy wayes, take thy mu∣sty books, and rhy rustie whittle here again. And take your foolish plodding dunci-coxcomely course, till I look after you again. Come away sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Sfoot, who's the Gull now? Taylor, Shoo∣maker, you may go pawn your Gownes for any mo∣ney I am like to have.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoo.
SP.P: We have all played the Lavvyers to pret∣ty purpose, in pleading all this while for nothing. Well sir, to avoid further trouble, I am content to withdravv my action, that is, pull off your boots a∣gain, and be jogging.

SP.SPEAKER: Tayl.
SP.P: And for my part, sir, I can do no lesse then take you by default and non-suit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Very good Lavvyers both, Is my father quite gone Belt?

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Gone in a tempest of high displeasure, sir: And has sent you here all the money he had about him; and bids you refuse it if you dare, 'tis above tvvice the summe he offered you before; but good sir, do not refuse it. He svvears he vvill try vvhe∣ther you or he shall have his vvill. Take heed you crosse him not too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Well at thy request, because thou shalt not have anger for carrying it back again, I vvill accept.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: I thank you Sir. Consider, he's your fa∣ther, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P:
I do most Reverend Belt. and vvould be loth to crosse him, although I may as much in taking his money as refusing it, for ought I knovv, for thou knovv'st 'tis his custome to crosse me, and the rest
of his children in all we do, to try and urge his obe∣dience; 'tis an odde way: therefore to help my self I seem to covet the things that I hate, and he pulls them from me; and makes shew of loathing the things I covet, and he hurles them doubly at me, as now in this money.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Are you so crafty?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Yes, but do thou put it in his head, and I'le pick out thy braines.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: You never knew an old Serving-man treache∣rous to his young Master: what? to the hopes o'th' house; you will be heire, that's questionlesse: for to your comfort, your elder brother growes every day more fool then the other. But now the rest of the message is, that you make haste, and come to my Master to the Goat in Covent-Garden, where he dines with his new Landlord to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: He has taken a house then.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: O, a most delicate one, vvith a curious Belconee and all belonging to't most stately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: At the Goat does he dine, sayest thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: My crevv are gone thither too. Pray Mars vve fall not foule of one another. Well, go thy vvay, present my duty to him, I'le follovv presentlie. Tell him I took his money vvith much unvvilling∣nesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: As Lavvyers do their fees. Let me alone sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Well Tailor and Shoomaker; you have put me to't, but here's your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoo.
SP.P: 'Twas for that we did put you to't Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Let's see your biil Tailor

SP.SPEAKER: Tai.
SP.P: Here 'tis, sir, as ready as a Watchmans.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P:
Then good vvords vvill passe it, 7 li. 4. sh. tell your money; yours is 14 sh. boots and Galloshes.
There 'tis and 12. d. to drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoo.
SP.P: I thank your vvorship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Are you right Tailor.

SP.SPEAKER: Tai.
SP.P: Yes and please you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: There's a shilling for you too, to spend in bread.

SP.SPEAKER: Shoo.
SP.P: He knows both our diets. We'll make bold to take leave of your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Not so bold as I'm glad I'm too well rid of you, most courteous Gentlemen.

To see what money can do; that can change mens manners, alter their conditions: how tempestuous the slaves were without it. O thou powerful metal! what authority is in thee! Thou art the Key to all mens mouthes. With thee a man may lock up the jawes of an informer, and without thee he cannot the lips of a Lawyer.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. II.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Crossewill, Rookesbill, Gabriel, Kathe∣rine, Lucy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Down boy, and bid the Cook hasten din∣ner.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: What will you please to drink in the mean time, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I will not drink in the mean time, sir, Get you gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: A fine old humorous Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
Hold up your head, Sirrah, and leave your precise folly. I'll leave you to the wilde world else, dee see. Is the name of a Tavern so odious to you? Ha. Your brother has vext me sufficiently alreadie, and perhaps he'll refuse to come too! If he dares let him. Welcome Mr. Rooksbil, welcom Landlord, and your faire daughter, welcome pretty one. Trust
me a pretty one indeed, pray be acquainted with my daughter there. In your Maiden-company, I hope she will not think the Tavern such a bugs neast as she did. I had much ado to draw my rebellious chil∣dren to the Tavern after me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: And truly, sir, 'tis the first to my knowledge that e're my daughter came into.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: All in good time, she may encrease in ver∣tue. But if it be a fault, (as i' my conscience in his thought it is a great transgression) my unsetlednesse, and unprovidednesse else, where or how to entertain a friend, or feed my selfe, may well excuse us all, dee see.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: O Sir, I cannot enough admire that vertue in your sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: It is a vice, as much a vice or more, as is your sonnes, your cast-aways as you call him, that sucks no other aie, then that of Tavernes, Tap∣houses, Brothels, and such like. I would their ex∣tream qualities could meet each other at half-way, and so mingle their superfluities of humour unto a mean betwixt 'hem. It might render them both al∣lowable subjects, where now the one's a firedrake in the aire, and t'other a mandrake in the earth, both mis∣chievous, see how he stands like a mole-catcher. What dirty dogged humour vvas I in vvhen I got him troe?

SP.SPEAKER: Rookes.
SP.P: Hovve're his carriage seems distasteful un∣to you, I could afford (vvith your allovvance, to make conditions of estate agreeable) to give all that is mine to him vvith my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
What a mechanick slave is this, to thank a sonne of mine, hovve're I under-rate him, a fit mate to mingle blood vvith his moore-ditch breed. True, his estate is great, I understand it, but of all foule I love not Moor-hens. Such another motion
vvould stir me to roare him dovvn the tavern∣stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Rooks.
SP.P: What do you think on't sirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Heaven grant me patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Rooks.
SP.P: Will you consider of it Master Crosse∣will.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I was never so put to't. I wish we had a stickler. I muse that Master Cockbrayne stayes thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Rooks.
SP.P: You do not mind my motion sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Uds precious I minde nothing, I am so crost in mind thar I can minde nothing, nor I will minde nothing, dee see. Why comes not Mr. Cockbrayue, Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rooks.
SP.P: Yet you minde him it seems. But he, sir, cannot come, and desires you to hold him excus'd. He's gone about some special undertaking, for the good of the Common-wealth, he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Fart for his undertaking; all the world is bent to crosse me. What is my young Master come? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: My young Master Mr. Mihil will be here presently, he said he would follow me at heeles, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: And why not come before you, sir. Does he not think that I have waited long enough, sir? sure I'll crosse some body under that knaves pate of yours, d'y'fee.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Thus when any body angers him, I am sure to hear on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: So now my spleen is a little palliated, let me speak with you Mr. Rooksbill. Get you down, Sir∣rah; and bring me word, dinner is not ready, and I'll give you as much more, d'ye see.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: That's his way to his stomach.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: And is your brother that your father sayes is so ungracious, so well acquainted with my brother Mihil, say you.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Oh all in all, he's not so familiar with any man, if Mihil Croswill be your brother, as 'tis mani∣fest.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I would not that my father knew it, for all I can expect from him but his blessing, but does your father know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: No, I would not he should mistrust it for all he has, blessing and all; and now that I have found you love your brother fo well, I will make over my reason and my counsel in trust with you, hoping you will not wrong that trust.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: If I do, may the due price of treachery be my reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I love your brother, Lady, and he loves me. The only good act that ever my brother did, was to bring us acquainted, and is indeed all that he has to live on. For I do succour him with many a stolne peece for the felicitie he brought me in your brothers love. Now, my father, whose irreconcileable hate has for e∣ver discarded my brother, should he but dream of their acquaintance, would poison all my hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: But let me ask you, is there an hope betwixt you and my brother ever to come together?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Yes, and a way he has fort, which I under∣stand not yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Trust me, I pity you both, your case is very dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Love's above all adventures, the more hard the atchievement is, the sweeter the reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I like her spirit well.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: You Sir, come hither, what is hammering in your head now?
Is't not some Synodical question to put unto the brethren, concerning Whitsonales and Maygames? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Surely sir, I was premeditating a fit thanks∣giving to be rendred before meat in. Tavernes, accord∣ing to the present occasion which the time and place ad∣ministreth, and that as the spirit shall enable me, shall be delivered before you in due season.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I am glad I know your minde; for that trick, my zealous sonne, you shall come in at half-dinner, like a Chafing-dish of coales, when the sawce is cold, to make use of the heat of your spirit; d ye see. I love not meat twice drest.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Good sir, put the Proposition to him, that I made my affection to him, urges it more and more, I never was so taken with a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: But what's that to your daughter? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: The same affection governes her, she is not mine else.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros
SP.P: Well, hold your peace, and was that your spi∣ritual meditation?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Yes, verily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Come Sir, at this Gentlemans request I will now put a question to you concerning the flesh. What, think you of yond Virgin there his daughter? can you affect her so well as to wish her to be your wedded wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: You mean, elpoused in holy Matrimony.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Yes, I mean so.

P.HI: hum hum hum Psalm tune. How happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: But do thou say, yes verily to that, and as I hope to have peace in my grave. I'll break the Kings peace on thy pate presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: It is a weighty question, and requires due pre∣meditation in a religious answer, pray give me leave to take advice—

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: What sayes he, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: He sayes he will talk with a cunning man a∣bout her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Sure you mistake him, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vint.
SP.P: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Will. Harry, Zachary.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Zachary is a good name.

SP.SPEAKER: Vint.
SP.P: Where are you? he (rings the bell) shew up into the Phoenix. Is the Checque empty?

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Hoyday, here's a din.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: A pottle of Canarie to the Dolphin, score.

SP.SPEAKER: Vint.
SP.P: Y' are welcome, Gentlemen, take up the lil∣lie-pot.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Half a dozen of clean pipes and a candle for the Elcphant. They take their own Tobaccho.

SP.SPEAKER: Vint,
SP.P: Whose room do they foul Sirrah, Harry, Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Do Elephants take Tobaccho?

SP.SPEAKER: Vint.
SP.P: Carry up a Jordan for the Maidenhead, and a quart of white muskadine for the blew Bore.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Now me thinks, the muskadine for tht Maidenhead, and the Jordan for the Bore were better.
Knock aboue, and a pot thrown. Why boyes, draw∣er, rogues, take up, (below) By and by, by and by, (above) Wine, Tobaccho.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What variety of noises is here? and all excel∣lent ill sounds. (Above) Call up the Fidlers, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Such cries as these went forth before the deso∣lation of the great City.
O prophane tinkling the cymbals of Satan; that tickle the care with vanity, to lift up the mind to lewd∣nesse. Mine eares shall be that of the Adder against the Song of the Serpent.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: O rare, in a young man!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I will roare out aloud to drown your Incan∣tations. Yea, I will set out a throat even as the beast that belloweth.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Most happy youth!

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Hold your peace, Sirrah, or I'le make you bel∣low for something.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Sfoot-back, Nick to your own room. Thy father's here too, as I breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: My Lucie too, as I live. How the devil got they acquainted? Sure he's his Landlord 'Tis so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Dare you come, sir, you should have stayed now till you had been sent for.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Verily, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Are you at your Verilies too? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: But for dipleasing you, I had rather have graz'd on Littletons Commons, or ha' fasted this fourt∣night, then come for my repast into this Wildernesse; but you will ha' it so

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: You are in the right Sir, I'le have it so in∣deed, I'le know why I shall not else. What do you know no bodie here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I crie them mercie, my good brother,—and my loving sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: But what vertuous men has this man to his sons, and how they thrive in grace against his will, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: What Gentlewoman is this of your acquaint∣ance, Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: 'Tis well dissembled brother, but I know your cunning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Have you betray'd me?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Mum Mr. Mihil, mum.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: By and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: What devil art thou that roarest in mine eare so.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Hold, I beseech you, I come to wait upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What, with a By and by, that strikes into my head as sharp as a Stellatto.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: I come to tell you, sir, that your table's co∣vered in a fairer Room, and more private, your meat is ready to go up, and all in a readinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Now thou art an honest fellow, there's a couple of shillings for thee. Have us out of thy windmil here, I prithee, and thy By and by's.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Captain Driblow, Clotpoll, Nick, Anthony, Drawer, A Table, Pot and Glasses.
DIV3.P: GO Sirrah, make your reckoning for our din∣ner. Leave us this wine, and come when we call you. We have businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: I shall, sir, by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Well, sir, you will be of both you say, the Blade and the Battoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Of both, sir, by all meanes, both Philoblathi∣cus and Philobatticus, I. I'le now have all that be∣longs to your order, or all my money again, that's for a certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Your money again? loe you there. You bring me a fit man, Gentlemen to be sworn, do you not? that talks of money again, when 'tis a main Article in the Oath, never to look for money again, once disfinger'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: You will not spoil all now 'tis come so far? will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Well sir, when I have my Oath, and that I am sworn one of you. I'le do as you do, and care as little for money as he that has least.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Well, to the Oath then, for both the Bsade and the Battoon you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I by all meanes, Captain, for both. S'lid the Battoon may stick to me, when the Blade may flie out o'th' Hilts.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Yes, to the Brokers.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Lay your hands on these Hilts, sir. The Ar∣ticles that you depose unto are these, To be true and faithful unto the whole Fraternity of the Blade and the Battoon, and to every member thereof.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: As ever faithful member was.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: That at no time, wittingly or ignorantly, drunk or sober, you reveal or make discovery of the Brother, or a member of the Brotherhood, of his lodg∣ing, haunts, or by-walks, to any Creditor, Officer, Sut∣ler, or such like dangerous or suspitious person.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I defie them all.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: That if any of the Brotherhood be in re∣straint or distresse by imprisonment, sicknesse, or whatsoever engagement, you make his case your own, and your purse and your travel his; and that if a bro∣ther die or finish his dayes, by end timely or untimelie, by Surfet, Sword, or Law. You wear the sable order of the Riband in remembrance of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: A convenient cheap way of mourning.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P:
That your purse and weapon to the utmost
of your strength, be on all occasions drawn to the as∣sistance or defence of a Brother or Brothers friend, be it he, be it she.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I understand you, and shall be as forward to fight for a She-friend, as ever the best man in the mir∣rour of Knighthood was for an honest woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: That you be ever at deadly defiance with all such people, as Protections are directed to in Parlia∣ment, and that you watch all occasions to prevent or rescue Gentlemen from the gripes of the Law brissons. That you may thereby endear your selfe into noble society, and drink the juice of the Varlets labours for your officious intrusions.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And that will go down bravely.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You must rank your self so much the better man, by how much the more drink you are able to purchase at others costs.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cupt.
SP.P: You are to let no man take wall of you, but such as you suppose will either beat you or lend you money.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Better and better still.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: The rest of your duties for brevity sake you shall finde specified in that copy of your Order. Kiss the book.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I'le swear to them whatsoever they be.
So, now I am a Blade, and of a better Rowe then those of Tytere tu, or Oatmeal hoe, and so an health to our Fraternity, and in chief to our Noble Captain Driblow.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick. Ant.
SP.P: Agreed, Agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Now are you to practise or exercise your qua∣lity on the next you meet that is not of the Brother∣hood.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Are you one of the Brotherhood sir, of the Philoblathici.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I had else lost much sir, I have paid all dues be∣longing to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: So have I as I hope to gain honour by't 40 li. thick at least; yet I have this left, please you command the half sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Another time, your reckoning is not yet paid perhaps.
SP.STAGE: [Clot. puts his money in his pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: 'Tis the first money of mine that was refus'd since my coming to Town. I shall save infinitely.
I see now that I am sworn. How would I swear to get by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Take heed of that, Come hither son.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: How have you screwed this youth up into this humour, that was such a dry miserable Clown but two dayes since.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: The old way, by watching of him, and keep∣ing him high-flown a mattet of fourty eight houres to∣gether.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Men are apt to beleeve strange fancies in their liquour, and to entertain new opinions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I have fastned three or foure cups upon my precise brother. I would 'twere as many pottles, so it would convert him into the right way of good fel∣lowship.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vvould vve could see him, to try vvhat good vve could do upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Perhaps vve might convert him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: He's above still vvith the old men. I stole from him, but to see if your Italick Mystresse vvere come yet. Your Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: No, she comes anon; but is my affliction a∣bove still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Thy father? yes

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Ptithee do not call him my father less he took better courses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: And so is thy Sister; the little Rogue looks so squeamishly on me, and I on her, as we had never seen before; but the foolish Ape out of a present affecti∣on she has taken to my Sister, has discovered to her the whole discourse of our love, and my familiarity with thee, which were enough to spoile all, if it were discovered to the old folkes, befote my cards were play'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Well, remember Mr. Mihil, you have pro∣mised me half, if the old dogged fellow give her all, and you marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Thou canst not doubt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick
SP.P: You know I can spoile all when I list, but to shew my countenance in your cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Such is your vertue, Sir. Well, I'le up to 'em again before I be mist; and when they part, I am for you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: I have given you all the rudimenrs, and my most fatherly advices withal.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And the last is that I should not swear, how make you that good? I thought now I was sworne into this Brotherhood, I might have sworne what, and as much as I would.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: That's most unnecessary, for look you son, the best, and even the leudest of my sons do forbear it, not out of conscience, but for very good ends; and in stead of an Oath furnish the mouth with some af∣fected Protestation. As I am honest, it is so. I am no honest man if it be not. Ud take me, if I lie to you. Nev'rgo, nev'rstirre, l vow, and such like.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Or never credit me or let me never be trusted.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: O take heed of that, that may be spoken in so ill an houre, that you may run out of reputati∣on, and never be trusted indeed; the other will gaine you credit, and bring you into good and civil estimati∣on with your Hostesses; and make 'em terme you a faire conditioned Gentleman if he had it; and truly I never heard worse word come out of his mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Nev'r-go, nev'r-stir, I vow. l'le have, I vow then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I vow, but you shall not, that's mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot
SP.P: Cann't you lend it me now and then brother? I'le have, I swear then, and come as nigh swearing as I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I swear but you must not, that's mine you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I protest then, I'le have I protest, that's a Ci∣ty-word, and best to cozen with.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Come boyes, fall to some practice, Let me see about at the new French balls, sprung out of the old English vapours

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I protest come on. I'le make a third man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Whose man are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Whose man is not to be asked, nor scarce whose subject, now he is of our Brotherhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Yes, by your favour he may ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I ask no favour, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: That may be granted.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: You can grant nothing in this kinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I vow he may grant any thing of any kinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I swear, I neither can, nor will grant that.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: That, I protest, may bear exception in∣deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Exceptions amongst us? nay, then I vow.—

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I swear.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And I protest—

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Part faire my boyes; 'tis very well per∣form'd; now drink a round to qualifie this bout.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Agreed on all parts.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Look upon me ye Common-wealths men now, like a State-Surgeon, while I search and try
SP.L: The ulcerous coare of foule enormitie.
These are a parcel of those venomous weeds,
That ranklie pester this faire Garden-plot.
Whose boisterous growth is such, that I must use
More policie then strength to reach their root,
And hoist them up at once.
This is my way to get within 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: So, 'tis gone round.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I muse these Mumpers come not.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Best send a boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Drawer, ha! where be those Rascalls? (Within) By and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Are you one of 'em, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I am one that has the favour of the house, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: To intrude into Gentlemens privacies? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: To seek a poor living and 't please you, by picking up the crums of your liberalitie, for the use of my rare qualities.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: And what's your qualitie?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: It is to speak or sing ex tempore upon any Theame, that your fancie or the present occasion shall administer.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Can you drink before you lay your lips to't

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O my weak eye-sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Or can you eate a crust without chawing, made of the Flower of Battoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O good Gentlemen, forbear, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: The flower of Battoon. I protest a good jest, and 'twas mine own before I was aware, for he had the Maidenhead or first-blow of my Battoon. Nay, it shall down.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I will not yet desist; but suffer private affli∣ction with a Romane resolution for the publike wel∣fare, with full assurance that my fortitude shall at last get within 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: You are not satisfied, i seems, you Rascal, get you gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Phew! beat not the poor fellow so.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Let me come to him again, and flesh my self upon him. I will not only flesh my self, but tire up∣on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Enough, enough, good Gentlemen, you have beaten me enough of conscience. Was ever good Pa∣triot so rudely handled? but the end crowns all.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Forbear him sons. What canst thou be, that canst not be satisfied with beating? speak, art a man or a Ghost?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I have been, Sir, a man, and of my hands, howe're misfortune humbles me under your man∣hoods. But I have seen the face of warre, and serv'd in the Low-countreys, though I say't, on both sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Then 'tis impossible this fellow can be beat out of countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mick.
SP.P: We'll leave him in his qualiry for that con∣stant vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Sure, 'tis Fenner or his Ghost. He was a ri∣ming souldier. Look, do his eyes stand right?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: They had a dish e'ne now, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Of sack, 'tis true here, take another, and wash the inside of your Throat. And let us hear your pipes in their right tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Give me a Theam Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: The praise of sack. Sing the praise of sack.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Let it be of the Blade.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And the Battoon, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Do you call, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, I will have sack.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: T'other quart of Canarie? you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Are your eares so quick? I vow, I'le dull 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Anon, anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I say, a song of Sack.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: I, let it be of Sack.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Now you pump, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: No, sir, but think of a tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: If he can pump us up a spring of Sack, we'll keep him, and break half the Vintners in Town.
SP.STAGE: (Song. Now B. and Clot. askes Gabriel, Are you a bother. They fall in the burthen.)

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, well-said.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I swear, 'twas well.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I protest the best that I have heard in this kind. I wonder at his ability. I prithee, art not ac∣quainted with my two Poetical Drury-lane Writers? the Cobler and the Tapster.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: No sir, not I, I work not their way. What I do is ex tempore after the Theme given.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: But they run quite before you. Their Works are in print sometimes▪ and ready to be sung about streets, of men that are hang'd before they come to the Gallowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: But did not Mihil say he would come again.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I marvel at his stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I, and the Mumpers, when come they? I long to see the Sisters, now I am a brother sworn and entred.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: O here comes news. How now pig?

SP.SPEAKER: Pig.
SP.P: You must all presentlie to the Paris Tavern.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Must? at whose suit!

SP.SPEAKER: Pig.
SP.P: Mr. Mihil bade me tell you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Is he gone from hence?

SP.SPEAKER: Pig.
SP.P: He is, and all his gone and dispersed.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Then the old Jew my father's gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Pig.
SP.P: Only there's one delicate demure Gentleman with Mr. Mihil. travell'd along with him towards Pa∣ris. I believe he meanes to make a mouth of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: O, 'tis his precise brother. But vvhere's thy Mystresse, and Madama Damaris? that they come not.

SP.SPEAKER: Pig.
SP.P: They desire to meet you there too, 'tis more private.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Avvay vve'll follovv thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Pig, hovv does thy father Hog, the Turkie Merchant?

SP.SPEAKER: Pig.
SP.P: I am in haste, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Why Turkie Merchant?

SP.SPEAKER: Pig.
SP.P: Because he trades in nothing but Turkie commodities; Egges and Concubines; 'tvvere vvell to geld him, and send him to the Grand Seignior, to vvait in his Seraglio.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Thou hast such a vvit in this Clotpoll of thine. The Reckoning Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Here, here, Sir; here's your bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Let see the summe. What is't Drawer? 40. sh. and 3. d. Si, your dinner, and what you had since, in all, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt,
SP.P: 'Tis very reasonable, Commend me to thy Master. Son Clotpoll pay't. It is your duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Yes, for my Brothership.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Boyes, I must leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: 40. sh. for foure mens dinners, note that, yet he sayes 'tis reasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Good Captain, He was ever the fairest Reckoner, though he has never the luck to pay any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Fare you well, father.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: When we have further occasion, we'll re∣pair to your lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: At Bloomesbury. Father, I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Bloomsbury? good, I note it.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Sirrah, look to the second Article of your Oath.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Against discovery of lodgings, haunts, or by-walks, I am warn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Look that you be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: 40. sh. and 3. d. you'l bate the 3. d. will you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: We'll not much stand for that Sir, though our Master sits at deare rent.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Give me your two peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Pray let me see the bill before you pay it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Well, I can hold it then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Bread and beer, 1. sh. 4. d. I do not think we four could eat 3. d. of bread, and for my part, I drank but two glasses of beer.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: And I but one, Ivow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And my father and I but one betwixt us, I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Ha' you no men below?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Below the earth doest mean? I am sure we have none above-ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: I know not, Gentlemen, there's so much reckon'd at the bar, and you please you may see it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Nay, an't be at the bar, it stands for Law. Well, wine 5 sh. 9. d. I think we had no lesse. A Shoulder of Mutton stuff't with Oysters 8. sh. that cost your Master very near ten groats, a brace of Par∣tridge 5. sh. a couple of Cocks 4. sh. 6. d. a dozen of Larks 20. d. Anchovis 6. sh. I swear but a Sawcer full.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: I'le be sworne they are so much reckon'd in the Kitchn.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: All's law, I tell you, all's law in Tavernes. But I hope there will be a law for you one o'these dayes. Then is their Fruit and Cheese, Tobaccho, Fire, and I know not what, is't right cast.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: There is more hope of that young man, then of all the rest, indeed it is a sore abuse, another verie weed in the city. I do note that also.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Sirrah, before you have your money, fetch me a glasse of Beere. But canst thou sing this upon a∣ny subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Any sir, any, an't be till midnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: But you have strange helps to your inventi∣on. I did note the rolling o' th' eye, and rubbing your Brows sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: So did I, I protest, and therefore, I tell you what. If he can sing such another Song, and look stedfastly the while upon any thing, and hold his hands behind him. I'le give him half a crown; if not, he shall ha' nothing for tother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Agreed Gentlemen, give me your Theme.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: You shall give it him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: And withal, watch him if he stir hand or eye, especially the eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I will I protest, and set mine eye against his, that he shall not twink, but I'le perceive it, and lay him o're the pare.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Well Sir, your Theme.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: In praise of the Battoon, and if you misse it you shall be sure on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: You'll help me with the burthen, Gentle∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Yes, yes, for the more grace of the Song.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Take you no care for that. Set your eyes and begin.

LG.L: To prove the Battoon the most noble to be.
Of all other weapons observe his degree,
In Field to be Leader of all other Armes,
To conquest and honour, through hazard and harms.
The Gallant and Peasant, the Lord and the Lowne.
Must move by the motion of the Leaders Battoon.
O give me the Battoon.
The Pike and the Halbert are subject to it.
The Ensigne, the Partizan, all must submit,
To advance, or retire, fall back, or come on.
As they are directed by the Leaders Battoon.
Then it is to the Souldier the greatest Renown,
To purchase by service to bear the Battoon.
O give me the Battoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Marry, and take it Sir, why do you stare a∣bout? though you have broke Covenant, I have not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Where be the Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Ha! they are not gone, I hope, where be my brothers Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Gone sir, and have sent me to you for the reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I protest you jest, do you not? I gave 'em the full summe, and all the money I had, I protest, I swear, I vow, now they are not here, I may make bold with their words. They have my money, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: If you have no money, pray leave a pawne, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Take him there, put him in a cage, and let him sing it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: We know him not, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clat.
SP.P: No? he said he had the favour of the house to sing to Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I feare I shall be discovered, sir, I can give your worship credit for a peece till you come to your lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Protest, thou art generous; nay, I know where to finde'em; and thou shalt go with me to 'em, we will not part now, wee'll shoune 'em. I vow, (the words out) here, I'le leave my sword for t'other peece.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Your sword will not serve, sir, I doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Take my coat too, a friend and a Battoon is better then a coat and a sword at all times.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.L: I am glad my feare is over. And after all my sufferings, if at last
Cock braine crow not these roaring Lions down,
Let him be balladed about the Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Let me now bid you welcome to my fathers house, where till your own be fitted, though my father keep too private a family to expresse large entertain∣ment, yet I hope at worst you shall ha' convenient lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Indeed, I am glad that my father yielded to your fathers friendly request in it; and the more, in regard he is so hard to be entreated to any thing; but especially for your societies sake, sweet Sister. In∣deed I'le call you Sister alwayes, and I hope you shall be shortly in my brother Mihils right.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I have laid open my heart to you, which in∣deed is his, but your father, I feare, will never be wonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Why you would not have him too, Sister, would you?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: His consent I would, and my fathers, I hope, would easily be wrought. You saw he was willing your other brother should have me at the first sight, meerly for his reservednesse, and Mihil methought carried himself as civil to day as he; I mean, as ci∣villy for a Gentleman, that should not look like one fathers of the Dutch Church at five and twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: He was put to't to day. The noise of the Tavern had almost wrought his zeale ino fury, it is scarce out of my head yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: But you were about to tell me how he first fell into this veine, this vanity indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I'le tell you now, and in that something worth your observation.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I will observe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P:
My father has an humour, not to like any thing at first, nor accept best courtesies of friends,
though presently he findes 'em most commodious to him; things that he knows not how to be without, and oftentimes desires with the same breath the things he vilisied, and scorn'd them the last syllable he spake before. You saw when your father offered him the use of his house here, till his own be furnished, he cried, hah are all the houses in the Town yours Sir; and yet presently entreated for't, and thanked him.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: That shews the best nature, they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: But that is seldome attended by the best fortune. Nay, in us, I mean, his children, he will like nothing, no, not those actions which he him∣self cannot deny are vertuous; he will crosse us in all we do, as if there were no other way to shew his power over our obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: 'Tis a strange fatherly care.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Now, note the punishment that followes it. There's not a chile he has, hough we all know what we do, that make any conscience of crossing him, we have so much of his good nature in us.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: And that's as odde a duty in children.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I must confesse it is a stubbornnesse.

Yet for the most part we do nothing, but that which most Parents would allow in their children: and now for my brother Gabriel, with whom I must bring in the story of another Kinswoman of ours, my father had at home with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: So.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Nay, mark, I pray you, as I would entreat an Auditorie, if I now were a Poet to mark the Plot, and several points of my play, that they might not say when 'tis done, they understood not this or that, or how such a part came in or went out, because they did not observe the passages.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Well on, I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P:
My brother Gabriel, when he was a boy, nay,
till within these two yeares, vvas the wildest unta∣med thing that the countrey could possibly hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: So he is still for ought I know, for I think no man of his Religion in his wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I mean in outvvard conversation, he vvas the Ring-leader of all the youthful Frie, to Faires, to Wakes, to May-games, footbal-matches, any thing that had but noise and tumult in it; then he was Captain of the young train-band, and exercised the youth of tvventy parishes in martial discipline. O he did love to imitate a souldier the best,—and so in every thing, that there vvas not an handsom maid in an whole County could be quiet for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: He may be good at that sport still, for there is almost none of his sect holds any other game lavvful.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Yet did he bear the civillest aud the best or∣dered affection to our Kinsvvoman I spake of.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Yes, I remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: So loving to her person, so tender of her ho∣nour that nothing but too near affinity of blood could have kept them asunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: And she did love him as vvell!

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: O dearly, vertuously vvell; but my father fearing vvhat youth in heat of blood might do, re∣moves my brother Gabriel from home into the ser∣vice of a Reverend Bishop to follovv good ex∣amples.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: But he learned not to be a Puritane there I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P:
You shall hear, Sister, soon after came a Gal∣lant into the countrey from London here, and as vve after found, a Citizens sonne, though he shevved like a Lord there. Briefly, he grevv acquainted vvith my brother Mihil. Then vvoo'd and vvonne my
Cousin so secretly, my father never suspected, nor he nor I e're knevv vvhose son he vvas, nor of vvhat occupation my old lord his father vvas; but he pro∣mis'd her marriage, clap't her, you may guesse vvhere, and so like the slippery Trojan left her.

SP.SPEAKER: Euc.
SP.P: O divellish Rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: And foolish creature, she vvho soon repented it, and vvith her shame is fled to vvhat part of the vvorld vve knovv not.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: In truth 'tis pitiful, that villain vvould be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Novv upon this, my poor brother that lov'd her so, fell into discontent, forsook his lord, and vvould have left the Land, but that he vvas prevented and brought home.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: And ever since he has been thus religious.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Thus obstinate, for I think verily he does it but to crosse my father, for sending him out of the vvay vvhen the mischief vvas done.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I vvill not then beleeve 'tis Religion in any of the gang of 'em, but meer vvilful affectation. But vvhy, or vvherein do you or Mihil. crosse your fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I tell you Sister vve must. He is so crosse him∣self, that vve shall never get any thing of him that we desire, but by desiring the contrary.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Why then do you desire him to get you an hus∣band?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Because he should get me none. O Sister, both he and Mr. Cockbrayne, can vvish novv that I had had his son.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: There's another youth novv gone on love's pilgrimage, e're since your father crosthim in your love not to be heard of.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Hush! the old men.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: In good truth sir, I am taken with your con∣versation. I like it now exceeding well.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I'm glad it pleases you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: 'Tis very faire and friendly, I finde we shall accord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I am glad I have it for you Sir, I pray, make bold with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rok.
SP.P: Then pray sir, let me urge my motion a little further to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros,
SP.P: What is't? you cannot utter it so easily as I shall grant it, out with it man.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: That you will be pleased to accept my daugh∣ter for either of your sons, your youngest if you please, now I have seen him, I'le give him with her presently, either in hand a thousand pound, and five hundred pound a childe as fast as he can get 'em. And all I shall die seiz'd of.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What a Dogbolt is this to think that I should get a childe for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: I hope you do think well on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Pray love he does. I hope so too.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I mark his Answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I could finde in my heart to ask his good-will my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: And that were a sure way to go without it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: How say you, sir, is't a match?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I will not stay a minute in thy house, though I lie in the street fort.
Huswife, I'le sort you with ftter companions, Come, follow me quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Haven blesse me and my childe too from matching with such a disposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Truly, sir, I long'd to be out o th' house be∣fore.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Before you came in it did you not? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: These new walls do so stink of the lime me∣thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Marry fough, Gooddie Foyst.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: There can be no healthie dwelling in 'em this twelve-moneth yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Are you so tender bodied?

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Even please your selves then where you can like better, and you shall please me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Why you will not thrust me out of your house, will you? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: There's no such haste, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Indeed there is not, nor will I out for all your haste neither. I'le have look to my bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: With all my heart, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: But no more of your idle motions, if you love your ease in your house, your n here.
Here's a letter, sir, from Mr. Cockbrayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Is the earer paid, or give him that an't please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Some body has anger'd him, and I must suffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I sent you to seek my sons, good sir, have you found 'em? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: I cannot finde 'em sir. They went out of the Tavern together, they say, and I have been at Mr. Mihils chamber, and there they are not. I went to the Tavern again, and there they were not. hen I beat all the rest o'th' bushes, in this four est of foo es and mad men, and cannot finde em I, where e're they be.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
Sirrah, go finde em me where e're they be, a∣ny where, or no where, finde 'em, and finde 'em
quickly; I'le finde 'em in your Cockscombe else, d' ye see! and bring my sons Sanctity home before it be dark, lest he take up his lodging in a Church-porch; and charge Mr. Mihil that he come not to me till I send for him. Here's danger i'th' house. There was a match-motion indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Good sir, either like my house well, or be pleas'd to please your self with some better.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Pray Sir, be quiet in your house, lest I send you out of it to seek another. Let me see my cham∣ber.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: He must have his way, I see.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bettie, Frank, with swords drawn make fast the doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Bett.
SP.L: NAy, you perpetual Pusse, I'le fetch him out of the very bowels of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: He never came so deep himself yet with all that he could do, and I scorne the threatning of a She Marmaset.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: (Within) why Bettie, Frank, you mankinde Carions you. I vow, open the door, will you both kill one another, and cozen the Hangman of his fees?

SP.SPEAKER: Bett.
SP.P: Thou hadst been better have bit off the dugs of thy Damme, thou pin-buttock Jade thou, than have snapt a bit of mine from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Here's that shall stay your stomack better then the bit you snarle for. Thou greedy Brach thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: (Within) why wenches, are ye wild? break open the doores.

SP.SPEAKER: Bett.
SP.P: That I could split that divellish tongue of thine!

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I have as good a spight at as ill a member about thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Hold, what's the devil in ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Are ye so sharp-set ye Amazonian Trulls?

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Let me but make one passe at her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Pray let me go, and let her come.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Can no blunter tooles then these serve to take down your furies?

SP.SPEAKER: Bett.
SP.P: Let me come but within nailes reach of het.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Let me but try the strength of my teeth upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.L: As Hector 'twixt the hosts of Greece and Troy,
When Paris and the Spartane King should end
Their nine yeares warres, held up his brazen lance.
In signal, that both Armies should surcease,
And hear him speak. So let me crave your audience.
Dear Bettie be advis'd, and Frank, forbear
Thy thirst of Sisters blood. Whilest I rip up
The folly of your strife. Your cases both
Have been laid open to me. You contend
For love of a lewd Citizen, that sleights,
Nay more, disdaines, nay more, desies you both.
Tony can tell, Mun Clotpoll also knows
The words he spake, that you were both poor whores,
Not poor alone, but foule infectious harlots.
And that he wears your mark with pain and sorrow,
Hopelesse to claw them off. With constant purpose
Never to see you more, unlesse to greet.
Your bumpin buttocks with revengeful feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Did he say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: And must we two fall out for such a slander∣ous Villain?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: No, agree, agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Busse and be friends. Busse, or I'le baste ye both, I vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Come Sister we'll be in for ever now.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: For my part, Sister, sure I was not out with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: But did he say he would kick us?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Lo here, the man that dares it not deny.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: But do ye hear, Gentlemen. I hope you will use me kindlier then so.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Than how, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Then to win all my money, and leave me at stake for the reckoning. Pray do you pay the Drawer for me, though I pay it you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: What is it Drawer?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: The Gentlewomen and he had 14. sh. in before you came.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: 'Tis a plain case, your cloak must answer it at the bar, Sir. Drawer, away with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Nay, but Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, do but look after it, till we be gone, and these shall claw thine eyes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Well sir, I hope this quarter will not be al∣wayes lawlesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Do you grumble? Mr. Cffelesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I vow you shall have cues.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Yes, that you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Cuts and slashes too before we part, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: You will not murder me, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Damosels forbear; and you, forbear your noise. I vow, I'le slit your wistle else. You shall give him due correction civilly, and we will make him take it civilly. Sit you down Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: What will you do with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, mum.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: O, are ye here! was it a brotherly trick do ye think, to leave me to pay one reckoning twice? or did I think never to be made a mouth more, after I had paid my swearing dinner, and am I now a greater mouth then e're I was?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Mum, hold your tongue still in your mouth, lest I halifax it with your teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Halifax my tongue. And listen to a businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Do yon know this man?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Yes, the City mouth we had tother night.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: These are the Sisters that his lavish tongue so lewdly did deprave.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I cry them heartily mercy Are you of the sweet Sisterhood? I hope to know you all, all the pretty Mumpers in the berrie here, before I have done. 'Tis true, I protest, he spake words of you, that such flesh and blood could not bear. He could not have spoken worse of mutton of a groat a quarter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: And were we so fond to fight for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: But now we'll both be revenged upon the flesh of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Pray let me speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: No, they shall beat you first. And mark me well. Do thou but stir an hand or foot, or raise a voice that may be heard to the next room, well cut thy weasand. Now wenches take your course.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Nay, you slave, we'll mark you for a Sheep∣biter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: We'll teach you how to scandalize.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Have I given you that you cannot claw off, you Mungrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Rare, I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: There, there.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: We'll claw thine eares off rather.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: O brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O out-rage, most insufferable, all this goes into my black book.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: To him Bettie, at him Frank; there whores, there.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Fie, fie, forbear, enough, too much in con∣science.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: That young man has some pity yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I swear you shall no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Alas, good Gentlemen, it is enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, do you prate? you shall have as much. Come, take the Chaire, Sir, the breeches shall bait him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O good Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, they shall. To him and claw him, I'le clapperclaw your sides else

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O me! what mean you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bett.
SP.P: Heyday! his beard comes off.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: And his head too What rotten scab is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I protest, they have pulled my pieced brother in pieces here.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, some disguiz'd villain, and but for do∣ing the State so good service, we would hang him pre∣sently without examination.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I know him. And you shall not touch him. Best is, he knows nor me. Good Heaven, what Brain∣trick has possest him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, what canst thou be?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Come, 'tis an honest fellow, that is only a∣sham'd to run so base a course for his living in his own face. Poor man, I warrant his feare threatens his breeches shrewdly. But let's away, and quickly, our stay is dangerous. Come, we forgot Mich. Croswil and the wenches.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Come all away then, Sirrah, thank this Gentleman, and pray for him at the end of your Songs hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Farewel, friend Peece. I'le know you better now, before you have't again.
SP.STAGE: Ex. omnes but Cock. and Cit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: What monsters in mankinde? what hell-hounds are they? only as Ovid feign'd among the Getes. A friend at need, I with a friend was blest, Whom I may gratifie, and plague the rest. How is it with you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: O, I am very sore.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Indeed you are sorely handled. This may warne you out of such caterwaling company. You look like one more civil. And in hope you will be so, I'le bring you to a Barber.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Alas, my Cloke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: I'le help you to that too, so you with me, Will in an honest plot Assistant be.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: O Sir, in any thing, and thank you too, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: A Paris ill ya ben veni- Here's no bush at this door, but good wine rides post upon't, I mean, the sign-post. Boy, get you down, and if Nick Rooksbill, or any of his company ask for me, bring 'em up, d'ye hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: I will, I will, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: You are welcome to Paris brother Gabriel.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: It is neverthelesse a Tavern, brother Mihil, and you promised and covenanted with me at the last house of noise and noisomnesse, that you would not lead me to any more Tavernes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Lead you brother? men use to be led from Tavernes sometimes. You saw I did not lead you nor bring you to any that was more a Tavern then the last, nor so much neither; for here is no Bush you saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: 'Twas that betrayed and entrapped me: but let us yet forsake it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Pray let us drink first brother. By your leave here's to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: One glasse-full more is the most that I can bear. My head is very full, and laboureth with that I have had already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: There Sir, I'le undertake one good fellow, that has but just as much Religion as will serve an honest mans turne, will bear more wine then ten of these gid∣dy-braind Puritanes, their heads are so full of whim∣seys.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: 'Tis mighty headie, mighty headie, and truly I cannot but think that the over much abuse of these out-landish liquors, have bred so many errours in the Romish Church.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Indeed brother, there is too much abuse made of such good creatures. Wine in it self is good, you will grant, though the excesse be nought; and Ta∣vernes are not contemptible, so the company be good.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: It is most true, we finde that holy men have gone to Tavernes, and made good use of 'em upon their Peregrinations.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P:
And cannot men be content to take now and
then a cup, and discourse of good things by the way. As thus. Brother, here's a remembrance (if she be li∣ving, and have not lost her honour) to our Cousin Dore as.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: O that kinswoman of ours. She was the dear∣est losse that e're fell from our house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Pledge her, good brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I do—

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: I hope 'twill maudlenize him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: But have you never seen that miscreant that wrong'd her, since he did that same, they say you knew him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Alas, suppose I had, what could be done? she's lost we see. What good could she receive by any course against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: It had been good to have humbled him, though into the knowledge of his Transression. And of himself for his soules good, either by course of Law, or else in case of necessity, where the Law promiseth no releefe, by your own right hand you might have smote him, smote him with great force, yea, smote him unto the earth, until he had prayed that the evil might be taken from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: This is their way of loving enemies, to bear 'em into goodnesse. Well, brother, I may meet with him again, and then I know what to do. If he knew him as I do now, what a religious combate were here like to be at Nicks coming.
Sir, here's a Gentlewoman asks for Mr. Rooks∣bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: The travell'd Gallant, is't not.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Yes sir, and the old black party, her Land lady with her. But they ask for no body but him, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Say he is here by all meanes, and bring 'em up.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Women! pray brother lets avoid the place, let us flie it. What should we do with women in a Ta∣vern?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: No harme assure your selfe, cannot we go∣vern ourselves?
SP.STAGE: Enter Dorcas and Madge, and start back.

SP.SPEAKER: Nay,
SP.P: Lady, stay, he will be here presently, that you look for.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I will not glance an eye toward tempta∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I am amaz'd sure, I have seen this face, howe're your habit and the course of time may give't another seeming.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: Good Angels, help my thoughts and memo∣ry. It is my Kinsman Mihil. What's the other that hides his face, so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Do you turn away?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: It is my Cousin Gabriel, strangely altered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Come hither you. Ile make a little bold with you. Thou that hast been a concealer of more sins in womens actions, then thou hast grizled hairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: Sure I will speak to him, he alwayes lov'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Reveale a truth to me on my demand, now instanrly, without premeditation. I'le cut thy tongue out else.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What's here to do? do you think I am a devil? that you make such conjurations over me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I think thou art as true a servant of his as any Bawd can be. But he now if thou darest. How long have you known that Gentlewoman? and what do you know by her?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Here's a stirre about nothing. I know no∣thing by her, not . Nor whether she has any thing or nothing, that a woman should have by the re∣port of knowledge of man, woman or beast, not I. She came to me but this morning, with a purpose to set me up in my new house as I hoped. But she has taken a course to make it honestly spoken of already, to my utter undoing, but she never comes within my doors again, as I hope to thrive by my Trade here∣after.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: Pray look upon me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Was she so resolutely bent, and so soon al∣tered?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Upon the very first fight of the very first man that came into my house, the very first houre of my setting up in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: What man was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: A shame take him, your roaring friend, Nick. I think she is enamoured of him, or of something she guesses he has; and would faine play the honest woman with him, that never played honest man with woman in his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: 'Tis she, and 'tis most wonderful.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: If you knew who I were, you would not be so strange to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: And here she comes me a hunting after him, like a fondling, whilest halfe a dozen peeces might ha' been gotten at home by this time, aud she have had the halfes of it in her purse by this time; if she would have done, as I thought, she would have done by this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Alas, poor Howlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: I sent whooping after the best guest that haunt my house, to have taken the first fruits of her conversation, and she would not see a man of 'em, to my undoing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Well leave thy hooting, Madge, and hold thy peace. thou shalt get by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Yes, I shall get a good name shortly, and this geare hold, and turn begger, I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Pray sir, but one word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Speak to her, brother, 'tis our Cousin Dor∣cas.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Will you abuse me too? is she not lost?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: And will not you give her leave to be found again? his wine and her sudden apprehension works on him at once. Cousin, I'le speak to you, though I confesse the miracle of our meeting thus ama∣zes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: O Cousins both. As ye are Gentlemen, and of that noble stock, whose meer remembrance, when he was given up, and at the brink of desperate folly, stroke that reverend fear into my soul, that hath pre∣serv'd my honour from further falling. Lend me now your aide, to vindicate that honour by that man, that threw me in the way of losse and ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: All shall be well, good Cousin, you shall have both hands and hearts to re-estate you in him. So that in fact you have not wrong'd that ho∣nour, since he forsook you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: On my soule I have not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Infants then shall be pardoned. Brother speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: You were wont still to be my loving'st Cou∣sin.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: What a strange dream has wine wrought in my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.L: I hope it will work out his superfluous zeale.
And render him civil Christian again.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: It is no dream, good Cousin, you are awake,
And I, that Dorcas, for whom you have wish't

Affinity of blood might be dispen'd with. And you
to be my choice. So well you lov'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: And will above my life affect you still. But you must leave these gauds and prophane dres∣sings.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Bawds did he say? how comes he to know me troe?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.L: How came my Cousin Gabriel thus tran∣slated.
Out of gay cloathes long haire, and lofty spirit,
Stout and brave action, manly carriage;
Into so strict a Reformation?
Where is the martial humour he was wont so to affect.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: His purity and your disgrace fell on you both about a time, I faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Do you swear by your FAITH?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: He's falling back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Some more wine. You will drink with our
Cousin, brother, will you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: What wine is't, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Yes, in a cup of sincere love.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: What other wine you please, Gentlemen, we have none such ith' house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Of the same we had, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: Call not for wine for us, Cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Assuredly, we are no prophane wine-bibbers, not we.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Modest, and well-spoken verily, she should be a Sister or a Matron.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Yes, yes, we'll all drink for the good o'th' house.
'Tis upon putting down, they say, and more o'th neighbours. But Cousin, he knew you not to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: No, nor dreams of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: And the old one knowes nothing, does she.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: No, by no meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: She can bewray nothing then. My brother knows not him. I only do for his faire Sisters fake, of which you may hear more hereafter; in the mean, bear your selfe faire and free, as if you knew him not, and I'le work him to your end, never fear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: You are a noble Spokesman.
SP.STAGE: [Bawd and Gabriel confer devoutly the while.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Truly, you speak most edifyingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Well-said, give it to my brother. Drink to our Cousin, Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I will, and to that vertuous Matron, whose care of her, I hope, tends unto good edification.—Truly the wine is good, and I was something thirsty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Best drink again then, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I will follow your motherly advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: 'Twill work, anon, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: And you have travell'd Cousin. I may sup∣pose you brought this well-disposed Gentlewoman from Amsterdam with you. And this unto your wel∣come, hoping I shall be informed by you how the two zealous brethren thrive there? that broke in St. Hellens.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Of that or any thing sir, pray drink again, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: You Jade you, hold your tongue.
SP.STAGE: Enter Nick, Anthony, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: O, are ye here Gallants! I made all the haste I co, but was stayed, I vow, by the bravest sport, baiting of a fellow or two with our Pusse-cats here. I could e'ne sind in my heart to marry 'em both for their valours.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: Those words are daggers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I pray dissemble your passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: What? are you acquainted already?

SP.SPEAKER: Mich.
SP.P: Did not I tell thee she was a brave Ma∣dona?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: How long have you had acquaintance with her, Nick?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Never saw her before this morning, I, stand∣ing upon her Belconee.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Truly Cousin, I think 'twas you that I saw to day too, standing upon a Bellconee.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.L: You spell very modestly, sir. Your brother
I take it. But did you call her Cousin, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Yes sir, she is my Cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: 'Twill out too soon. Why Nick, thou know∣est these kinde of creatures call and are called Cou∣sins commonly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Yes, in their tribe. But I thought he had been too holy for them. But Dammy—

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: O fearfully prophane!

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: You said you had a storie to relate, of dire misfortune. and of unquoth hearing. I come to hear your story, what stop you your eares at? sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I dare not speak it but in thy reproof. Thou swearest Gee o Dee, Dee am thee, as I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow thou liest, I call'd her Dammy, be∣cause her name is Damyris,

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I say thou liest, her name is Dorcas, which was the name of an holy woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Shall we have things and things? I vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: This vvill spoil all. Brother, I pray for∣bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I may not forbear, I am moved for to smite him; yea, vvith often stripes to smite him; my zeal∣ous wrath is kindled, and he shall flie before me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: Let me entreat you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet. Frank.
SP.P: What furie's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Great Damboys shrink, and give a little ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I will pursue him in mine indignation.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: O me!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: And beat him into Potsheards.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Now he has bang'd the Pitcher, he may do any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Pray, brother, be perswaded.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: A brother to be so controuled?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: You sir, put up your Steel-stick.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I desire but to know first, if he be a bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Yes marry is he, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Sir, I am satisfied. So let him live.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Pray give me leave to ask you, do these men take part with the brethren?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
