SP.P: Yes, and are brothers a little disguiz'd, but for some ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Some State-occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Meer Intelligencers, to collect up such and such observations, for a great Separatist that is now writing a book against playing at Barlibreak, moulding of Cocklebread, and such like prophane exercises.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Truly such exercises are prophane exercises, that bear the denomination of good things ordained for mans use, as Barley, Cockles, and Bread are such things to be made sports and play-games? I pray you let me see these brethren again, to make my atone∣ment with them. And are those Sisters too, that were wih them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P:
O, most notorious ones, and are as equally disguiz'd to be as rank Spies as the other. S'lid man, and they should be taken for such as they are, they would be cut off presently. They came in this
mad humour to be merry with you for my sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Pray let 'em come again, I shall not be well until I have rendred satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: You must do as they do then, or they will think you are a Spie upon them.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I will be as merry as they, let wine be given unto us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: More wine, Boy, and bid 'em all come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Alas, Cousin, let him drink no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Fear nothing, Cousin, it shall be for his good and yours, as I will order it.
SP.STAGE: Enter Nick. Anthonie, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank, Drawer with wine

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: All welcome, not any repetition, but begin a new

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I will begin it, two glasses: it shall be a faith∣ful Salutation to all the Brothers and Sisters of—

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: The Blade and the Scabberd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: It shall go round.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I'le swear you do not well to let him drink so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Well said civil Roarer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Let it go round, go to, you are a wag. I know what you mean by the Blade and the Scabberd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Who could have thought this had been such a brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Nay, who could have thought you had been of the brethren.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Brethren sir, we are the Brothers.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Yea, the disguiz'd ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: How? disguiz'd ones?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P:
Do not crosse him again. If thou doest, and I do not maul thee. Yes, brother, these are vertu∣ous
men howe're they seeeme.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, I have so much vertue as to rebuke thee for lying. But we are brethren, sir, and as fa∣ctious as you, though we differ in the Grounds; for you, sir, defie Orders, and so do we; you of the Church, we of the Civil Magistrate; many of us speak i'th' nose, as you do; you out of humility of spirit, we by the wantonnesse of the flesh; now in de∣votion we go beyond you, for you will not kneel to a ghostly father, and we do to a carnal Mystresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I'le stop your mouth, you said you came to be merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Yes, I vow, and brought Fidlers along, but they must play i'th' next room, for here's one breaks all the Fiddles that come in his reach. Come fir, will you drink, dance, and do as we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I'le drink, I'le dance, I'le kisse, or do any thing, any living thing with any of you that is Bro∣ther or Sister. Sweet-heart let me feel thy Co∣ney.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.L: I now he's in. Play Fidlers. Dance.
All bravely performed, admirably well done, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, thou art a brother after my own heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Women.
SP.P: We cannot commend you enough, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: This done in civil fort among our selves, I hope, will prove no scandal to a brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: 'Twill prove an honour to our faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I thirst to do it honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Give him some wine, he thirsts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Thou little dapper thing, thou, hold thy peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Thou seest he can scarce stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: No, my religious brethren, no more wine.
Enough's a feast, and little doth suffice.
SP.P:
I thirst to do some honour to our cause. To lead
forth legions to fight a battel 'gainst our. malignant adversaries.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Such an employment now would make me famous, for my sufficiency of Att in Armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, this man has hidden things in him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: He has as brave a warlike spirit, man, before his precise humour tainted it, as ever breath'd in Hector.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow then, a good orderly diet of nothing but sack for a week together, would revive it in him, and bring it to good again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I hope, 'tis done already.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: How do you, sit?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I feare some Jesuitical fumes have invaded my Brain pan. All me thinks goes whirley, whir∣ley, whirley.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Best lie down upon a bed. Drawer!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Souldiers must not be curious. A Bench or a∣ny thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: The Gentleman may have a bed here, an't please you. But sir, there's an old angry Gentleman below, that asks for you, and by all description for that mortified Gentleman. And will by all meanes presse into your room here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: It is my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: O me! What shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Md. Bet. Fran.
SP.P: We shall be all clap't up.

SP.SPEAKER: M.
SP.P: Fear nothing, veile your face a little; Who is with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: No body but his old Servingman, that it seems discover'd you. You may put this Gentleman into this inner room, and keep the Key your selfe. I know not what charge he has about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Admirable honest fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: And you may tell your father he is gone, for he is gone you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow. a wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Now if you'll be civil, I may bring him up to you, if not, because he is your father, we'll thrust him out of doors, an't please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Notable rascal, well sir, let him up. I know how to fit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: But this delays my businesse, Cousin, and will, I fear, frustrate my hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Nor hinder any thing, I'le warrant thee, he's thine. Play Fidlers, t'other dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Will you! protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: You are not wilde?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Come Wenches, if he venture in his fathers sight, shame take us and we blush.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross. Belt.
SP.P: And I had not sold all my land to live upon my money in Town here, out of danger or the Statute, I would give thee a Copihold for this dis∣covery.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: I thank your worship, and truly 'tis a good∣ly sight, me thinks, an't please your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: I'm glad it likes you. Heigh, excellent good again. Heigh, Heigh, what an happinesse may fathers boast, that can bring their children up to this. (Dance ended) I cry ye mercy, Gentlemen all. Ha! I am so∣ry I interrupted your serious private occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Would you speak with any here, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: It is my father, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Tny father? hold thy peace; dar'st thou use thy father thus? to spend thy time thus! ha! Is this place fit for the son of a Geatleman of quality? ha! why doest not answer me, does this company sort with thy reputation? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Sir, the company.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Hold thy peace, I say, or are these exerci∣ses allowable for a Gentleman, that ever said or heard Grace at his fathers Table? answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: An't please you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Hold thy peace when I bid thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: The company, sir, offends not you, I hope; you see the worst of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: In good time, sir, you are the distracted Gentlemen, I take it, that ask't him if he would moot to night? Is this your mooting? do you put cases to your VVenches, or they to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow thy father talkes too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Which are the better Lawyers? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: But that you are his father, sit, and an old man, and he an honest young Gentleman, and our friend, we would tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: I thank you for him, yes truly, heartily; and for your good opinion of him, heartily. Pray keep him amongst you while ye have him, for I'e ha no more to say to him, I. Is your Invectives against drinking, wenching, and the abomination of the times come to this? is this your spending of time more pretious then money? is it you that knows not what to do with money but to buy books; and were drawn with such unwillingnesse to a Tavern? ha! you shall graze upon Littletons Commons, or eat nothing but books, an't please you, for any exhibition thou e∣ver get'st from me—And in that faith thou hast lost a father. Come sir, you have brought me to a goodly sight here; would any Villain but thy selfe have shewed his Master light to see so much woe! Thy Coxscombe shall yet pay fot't.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: O sir, O.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: This was your trim sight, was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: O.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: But well remembred. Pray where's your bro∣ther? my son I would say; for I know no brother or father thou hast. Where is Gabriel?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: He is not here, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Did you not tell me, Sirrah, he was here?

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: I told you then too much. I feel it here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: He was here, sir, but he is gone, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: So, so, he's lost. He must be cried, or we shall never finde him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I'le warrant you, I'le find him yet to night, sir. Pray Gentlemen pay you the Reckoning, I'le wait upon my father home.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Was that spoke like a son of mine? must o∣thers pay your reckoning, and I in place; take that, and do not make me mad. And why should you home with me? I pray, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Because sir, it grows dark, and 'tis the worst way as it is about the town; so many odde holes a man may slip into; pray take me with you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Pray take no care for me, sir, and let the way be as it is. Do not think me worse at it in the dark then your self, I beseech you. But you talk't of the Reckoning, pray let not the want of money for that hinder the search of your brother. There's towards your paines for that; and so for a farewel to you and your friends here, till I hear thou keepest better company, let me hear no more of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: There was no way to get this money, and be rid of him, but to offer him my service He would have driven me out before him else. But come, let's see my brother that went to sleep in so warlike a Passion. I hope he'll wake in a better.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Mun Clotpoll, thou art dull.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: No, I protest, but struck with admiration at the old Blades humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Come, Dammy and the rest, be merry. I vow, we'll sup together, and so at last hear all thy dis∣mal story.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.L: I mean he shall, and such an Audit make,
As shall restore her honour from the stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P:
WHat has this Coxscombe Cockbrayne writ me here? That he desires his ab∣sence be excus'd. What have I to do with him? when I send for him, let him come to me. That he is up∣on a point of discovery in a most excellent project for the weeding of this Garden? what Garden? what project? A project he says here for the good of the Republike, Repudding. This fellow has in stead of braines, a Cob-web in his Noddle, with little strawes, feathers, and wings of dead Butterflies hanging in it, that having motion by his aery fancie, there dance and keep a Racket; 'tis to teach women silence, or some such foolish impossibility. He is ambitious to be call'd into authority by notice taken of some spe∣cial service he is able to do the tate aforehand. But what great service he is able to do it, or which way to undertake it, falls not in the reach of my imaginati∣on. But good Mr. Croswill, by your favour now, what reason have you to slight or wrangle at this man? this honest Cockbrayne? that has alwayes been a con∣stant friend to you, and officious in many good wayes, and is a Gentleman, not only of good descent and e∣state, but of a good disposition. And you two, Mr. Crossewill, by your leave, have alwayes agreed like
neighbours children. I, the divel was in't, and now he vexes me again; we agreed in one point so well, that we have undone a couple of our children by it, and hindred the getting of I know not how many more. His son and my daughter should have married. And on a sndden he and I both consented to a dislike of the match and broke it, and have both repented it an hundred times since. We agree very wel in that point; and now is his son irrecoverably lost, and my daughter resolutely bent to be an Ape-leader in Limbo. But whats all this to the affliction I suffer in my sons now? that one of them from a riotous boy. should grow into a Puritanical Woodcock; and the tother from a civil well-qualified fellow, turn'd absolute Ruffian. There, there, I there's the devil in't. I could beat my selfe for getting such children.
See, see, my Master for want of other company fal∣len out with himself, and it please you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: It does not please me, nor thou pleasest me, nor any thing pleases me. The world's bent to crosse me, and thou shalt feel it.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: O good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Is it not so, sir, was not that dunce Gabriel, a most notorious wilde thing

Before he steer'd a Religious course? but then he run so full a saile, that he pass'd and was beyond the line of Religion before he was aware; and as he passed it un∣der the torrid Zone of Zeale, the Calenture took him o'the pate, that he is mad with it, and as far beyond Religion now as it is to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Sir, there's hope that he may he fetch't halfe way back again, by your fatherly advicement, and be∣come a sound man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: And then was not Mihil so civil, that he made me even sick to see him. And now is he flowen out as far into rior t'other way.

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: But he, sir, will appear a present comfort to you, he is reclaim'd already; you shall never see such a Reformation in a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What's this you tell me? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: He has cast off his long-curl'd haire and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.L: He had been better have cut his head off.
Where is he!

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: Below sir, and a Gentlewoman with him, but very much afraid to appear to you. I never saw a man so timoursome.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Do you think it fit I should go down to him, or he come up to me, fir, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Belt.
SP.P: I'le fetch him, here's a life!

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: I charg'd he should not come at this house too, for feare he might be catch'd with this mecha∣nick fellows daughter, though her portion be around one. And let him take heed he look not at her.
Blesse me! what changeling is this? he's in his Brothers cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Sir,—Sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Would you speak with any here, sir, do you know me. I know not you, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: The sense of your late displeasure, sir, has so humbled me into the knowledge of my self, that on the wings of true obedience, I flew after you to make a childes submission at your feet, to crave your pardon for my riotous transgression, and to ask your bles∣sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
A delicate speech, pray take it for fashion-sake.
But if I know how to look towards thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Pray sir, bestow it really upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: God blesse thee, I say, and so much many honest men bestow daily on sons that are none of their own, if thou beest mine, how camest thou thus like a fellow that had narrowly scap't the Pillorie, and brag'd in the publication of his eares? not an hair left to hide them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: To shew my readinesse to reform my life, sir. And yet a willingnesse withal to live, as well, as civilly, in which I am in all humility to preferre a suit to you. You know, sir, I am but a younger bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What will this come to?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Here is a widow, sir, a Gentlewoman of great estate, and of a well-known life. Antient she is, and has had husbands. How many?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Foure truly, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Foure sir, I would not lie. Of which the worst spoke well of her on's death-bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What's that to me or thee? come to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I have all wo'd and wonne her, sir, and crave but your good-will to marry her. I have brought a Church-man and a Kinsman to give her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Why so, what needs two words then? do you think I can deny you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: If he does grant it, 'tis the first request that e're he granted in his life. Sure the old Match-ma∣ker the devil thinks I am in earnest to marry this beast. And puts a readinesse in his hand to for∣ward it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Widow, you are welcome. Why call you not your Priest? or tarry sir, let me question you but a little, Do you think seriously you love this wi∣dow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Better then many men love their wives, I am perswaded.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: 'Tis very well, what children have you wi∣dow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Never had any, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Very well still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.P: Nor ever like to have any, fir, thats the com∣fort. We shall live at the lesse charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Thou art a covetous and a preposterous Knave. Wouldest thou bury up thy youth in barren ground? doest seek after wealth, and not after issue? doest love to feed on other mens leavings? or travel only in a beaten path? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: A man goes certainest on his journey so, sir, and lesse trouble it is you know to go in at a great gate, then a narrow wicket.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: You have said enough, sir, and delight to crosse me; but I'le crosse you for once, and lay a crosse upon you, shall perhaps carry you to your grave. Go, fetch your Priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I'le face it as far as I dare. I hope I shall have the grace to pull my hand from the book when it comes so far.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Widow, you are resolv'd to have him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Before all men i'th' world by your fair leave, 1.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: You shall not have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Without your free consent, I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: I am resolv'd I'le do't. And 'twill be the best crosse trick that e're I did in my life. Pray let me speak in some more private wirh you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: If I but 'scape Bridewell, I care not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P:
Now Tonie, she's thine own, Now Sister Kate;
he's thine. The Priest has pronounc't it. I say, A∣men to't. And heaven give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Now you have done the best brotherly office that ever made a Sister happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: And the friendliest to a friend. We have been casting for it, Sweet, this Twelve-moneth, and Heaven pardon me. I vow'd never to take acquaint∣ance of my Father, till 'twere effected. Although I know of late he has been willing.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: And so is mine, I know, but yet he swore, that I should match my self before he knew't, or I should never marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: You'll finde him of another minde towards me, and force me into wedlock presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: You have ta'ne the likeliest course that could be. But what is your disguiz'd woman, Bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: What you shall never know, Sister, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Come sir, I have broken off the match with your widow; and she's content to leave you as she found you. And now take me this pretty, simpring, plump-lip't, ruddie-cheek't, white-neck't, long-fin∣ger'd Virgin in hand, or I will swindge you, Sirrah, look to't. If you cannot live civilly with a young wife, you cannot but be mad with an old, I think. Be∣sides, she's a friends daughter of mine, and prepar'd by her discreet father here to love you. Come, and kisse her, quickly, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I cannot do't for all the wealth in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Kisse a Maid I never saw above twice in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: He will have me think him a bastard, do I what I can. Canst thou see a Maid twice, and not kisse her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Yes, twenty times, sir, and not kisse her, or if once, not above, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: But you shall kisse her above and below, sir, and in every room o'th' house, sir, before you part. Stand faire pretty one.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I know not how to do't.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: You were not best let me instruct you. I can be angry too.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: His back side's towards me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Turne your self, Sirrah, or I'le turne you. Go to, bend your body a little and be hang'd. So, now come your way, and say after your little Sir John here, I Mihil take thee, Lucie, &c. As learning shall enable him to proceed without book.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Pray let'em do it in the next chamber, they are too bashful afore us. There are witnesses enough. Go all in, I pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Widow, will you give me leave to obey my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: With all my heart, and say Amen to the marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: I think I shall have my will at last upon one of my rebellious off-spring.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: And now, pray give me leave sir, to let you know how happy I do hold my selfe in this marriage. I did like this Son better then the other before. And now I like him better then I did at my former view of him, by some Reformation that I do observe in him. And I do not a little rejoyce in the honour I may have to call you brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P:
That very word brother out of his mouth, has turn'd my stomack. I must pull all in pieces again. And yet let me see these young bloods when they
are set on't; if they do not marry, they will do worse. Let em e'ne go on now.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: You may easily conceive, sir, what a com∣fort it will be unto me, that I now growing old, and having (I give praise for't,) wealth enough, and no childe that I make account of but this one daughter, may, before I die, see Grandchildren that I may have by her sufficiently provided for, be they more or lesse in number, they may have enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: There he is again, he calls my Grand-chil∣dren that shall be, his Grand-children. Am I a Gentleman, and can hear this? if it be not too late, I'le spoile the getting of your Grand-children.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Heaven give you joy. Heaven give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: What, are you married?

SP.SPEAKER: Pars.
SP.P: I do pronounce them man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Mad. Kat. And we are witnesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Crosse.
SP.P: What remedy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih. Luc.
SP.P: We are, and crave your blessings.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross. Rook.
SP.P: All blessings be upon you, (all sa∣lute).

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: But you, sir, Mr. Bridegroom.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I'le only gratifie the Minister.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Do so, and pay him well, it is, perhaps, for the dearest fault that e're thou didst.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: There's for your paines, sir. Madge, there's for you. Enough to purchase thee a Licence to sell Ale, Tobaccho, and Strong-water again in Godpiece-Rowe, for here will be no dwelling for thee, I see that.

Now, brother Anthonie, go you all back to the com∣pany we left, and see that my Instructions be followed
concerning my brother Gabriel, Nick, and his Dam∣mie,

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: All, all.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Shall he go from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Yes, but you shall follow him presently, trust to me Sister. Go, take no leave of 'em. I'le bring 'em upon you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Are you at leisure now, sir, to tell me of your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Yes, to my grief, sir, praying you may have patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: To your grief, sir, he is not dead then? Younger brothers seldome grieve for their Elders death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Pray bear it as you may, sir I left him in an heavy plight. And let me speak it with sorrow, he lay speechlesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Alack-a day, good Gentleman, my son in-law, perhaps, is heire already.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: And hast thou been here all this while fooling or wiving (all's a matter) & left thy brother in danger? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: He's well attended, sir, and look't unto. Nor would I wish you see his weak estate.
It can but grieve you, sir, my wife and sister, toge∣ther with my self, will go. Or if
It please my father Rooksbill here, because his power in this quarter is available.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Co, shew the way. I'le go in person, I. My son's my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Nay, pray sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Yes, 'cause you have a wife, you shall con∣troul me. Will you go on, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Well, I'le bring you to him, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What was your widow, sir, she stunk of Aqua∣vitae, fearfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: I'le tell thee as we go. Kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: What a drunken sot was I, that knew thee not all this while? I vow, thy story pities me. I'le marry thee, and turne thee to thy friends, for I am sure I have none that will keep thee for my sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: I ask no further satisfaction of you, then to be honested by marriage. I'le work for a poor li∣ving.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Prithee Mun seek me a Priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: I have no acquaintance in their function, I.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorc.
SP.P: My Cousin Mihil said he would bring or send one.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: There's no starting, that Mihil has a fist o∣ver me. I vow, and thou wert not his Kinswoman, thou should to the Common yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Father, how come you hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Did not the company send for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, not we.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: The City-mouth, that peck't us at my lodging last night, came to me with an abominable scratch't face, and warn'd me on a businesse hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I smell some trick.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Some treacherie upon the brotherhood, per∣haps.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Timorous thing! what in our own Quar∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: If you doubt any thing, 'tis best remove.
The fellow was sorely handled.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I would but see the carcass of authority prance in our Quarter, and we not cut his legs off. Wel∣come Tonie, what hast thou brought the word here to passe for the Reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Come, you must make a wedding-night on't Nick, Mihil will go no lesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: My Vow is pass'd, and before you, sir, I con∣firm it. This is my wife. Anon, you shall perform the holy Ceremony,

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: 'Tis well, pray sir, retire your self to the next room there a while, and stay you with him, Lady.
But what do you with Gabriel? Is it not time to wake him yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: 'Tis now upon the point, h'as slept two houres.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Father, you'll see a brave experiment upon a Gentleman that has been a youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: And of the Philoblathici, as we are now.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: And since was grown one of the reformed, and we are now in practice to retrive, and bring him back to his first condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Have you followed all Mihils directions?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Hitherto we have. First, you saw he was laid defunct in Sack, next in his sleep, we have accou∣tred him in martial ab liments, and now we mean to wake him with alarmes shall affright the silly humour out of him, and render him his warlike faculty, or our Art failes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Where be the Wenches?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: The Sisters of the Scabberd, there's the sport on't. They have their parts to play upon him too. But for his drink now when he wakes, you said you would have a bottle of the womans what do you call't yonder? the Medea.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: What? the charm'd liquor that Medea brew'd to make old father Aeson young again?
Must that renew his youthful spirit in him?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: No, Sack will do bette. When he wakes he will be very dry, then a quart-draught of good Ca∣narie will so screw him up. 'Tis time 'twere now in practice. So, softly, softly. We must but halfe wake him at first.
SP.STAGE: A Bed put forth, Gabriel on it, Bettie and Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: O some small drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Here, drink it off, sir, (Drinks) Dum and Trumpet. An Alarm.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Surpriz'd by th' enemie, whilest we have plaid the Sluggard in our Tents.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Nick. Clot.
SP.P: Hold Captain, hold, we are your souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Y'are Mutineers, and have disturb'd my rest. And I'le do Martial Justice on you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I vow, hold, are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Know you not discipline? or are you growen rebellious in the Camp. I'le teach you war∣fare.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You have conjur'd a fury into him to beat us into fitters.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: My pate bleeds for't; I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I'le make you know command.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Noble Commander, hold thy furious hand, and heare thy souldiers speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: What have we women for our Martial Mu∣sick?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: None but the She-Trumpet, a neighbour here, and her Sister, that was Drum-maor to my Coun∣trey-Amazons, that pull'd up the Inclosures to lie all in Common.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Is the enemy i'th' field?

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Upon their march, Captain, and we your of∣ficers: But rows'd you up to be in readinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P:
You are my Lieutenant, you my Ancient, and you two my Sergeants; and you must know the Com∣mander
you serve under, to be none of those Letter-carriers that know not so much as the termes of dis∣cipline, what a Flanker is, Nor a Raveling is. Nor a Petarre is. Nor a Curtain is. Nor a Bulwark is. Nor a Bastile is. Nor a Counterscarp is. Nor a Casemate is. A Gabion is: Nor any left word of fortification. How can such fresh-water Captains command?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Right noble Colonel. He shall be our Co∣lonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: One souldier made up of Sack, is worth as many as would drink a fresh water river dry.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I knew, men of abilities should at last be put in action.
SP.L: Valiant men and wise,
Are only fit for weighty enterprise.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: O noble Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: What would an upstart Militaster now, That knew no rudiments of discipline, nor Art of warre, do in a sudden service? or say, when I know how to have my Ordnance planted here, my Cavalrie mount∣ed here, my Battery-discoveer on such a point, my Trenches cut thus, my Mine carried thus, my Gabi∣ons rais'd thus. Here my Parapet, there my Pallisadoe o'th'top of that. The enemie made saltable six hun∣dred paces there. And I draw out my Musketeers to flank 'em in their Trenches here, while my Pikes and Targeteers advance to the breach there. What would Captain, my Lords man, or Sergeant-major, my Ladies Kinsman, sent in by honourable favour, do or say in such an expedition?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Braver and braver still.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: This goes beyond the Blade and the Bat∣toon.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P:
Or how would their braines lie in their breeches, when the able Captain leads up his men in the Head of a Troop bravely, charges with his shot,
makes a stand with his Pikes, does execution with his Sword, the Cannon playing, the Drum beating, the Shot thumping, the Ensignes waving, the Armes clashing, the Aire rending, Dust and Smoke clouding, Blood raining. And then to bring up such a Division to fight, make good such a Ground, relieve such a Squadron, fetch off such a losse, r'enforce the Ranks that are broken. March on, Come off. Beat the Bessognes that lie hid in the Carriages. O the renown∣ed life of a worthy Commander.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Sound Drum and Trumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: A Colonel, a Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Whither hast thou brought me? does thy brother lie speechlesse in this house? ha! what in the name of tumult can these be?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Pray sit, attend, you will be pleased a∣non.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: A still march now. So, I have lost a great ma∣ny of my men. But courage yet, you poor remainder of my scatter'd Troops. Stand. Qni vala. An Am∣buscado of the enemy. Alarme. Lieutenant, charge in with your Shot. Now Gentlemen, for the honour of Covent-Garden, make a stand with your Pikes; in to the short sword; well fought, take Prisoners. Sound a Retreat now. Faire, faire i'th' coming off. So, 'twas bravely perform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Must we not fall to rifling now, Colo∣nel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Part faire on all sides, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: What's this, a vision, sure I do aile some∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Is't possible it is thou? art thou run mad as far as hell the tother way now.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.L: My wicked, caitiffe, reprobate son is here too.
Pray let me flee, I am but a dead man else.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: You shall receive no harm, sir Lay by your Armes my Masters. I bring none but friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: I hou canst not make that good, my father's there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih
SP.P: I'le make him friends with thee. Go and di patch within.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I'le see it done, and take our new made Brides with us for witnesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook
SP.P: Has his shame yet taught him to shunne my sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: And shall returne him instantly your com∣fort.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Unpossible, unpossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Attend the event.

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: I rather thought I should have found you, sir, disputing with the Pastors, and the Elders; yet to say truth, this is the better madnesse. What can this mean? how came he thus translated? what Charmes, or what Inchantments are upon him?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: What Babel was a building in my braines?
But now it turnes, and I can recollect
The knowledge of a father, brother, Sister.
And that a thousand vain imaginations,
Like scatterings of light things upon the earth,
Rushes, loose leaves, sprigs, straws, and dust
Contracted by a whirlwinde, were blowen up,
And lodg'd in the rich Seat of Contemplation,
Usurping there the room of vertuous thoughts.
Honour awake me from this Lethargie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What can those women that appear like furies be in this action?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: They were but us'd as properties to give new motion to his mortified condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P:
I know not what to say to any thing; there
is some Spell upon me too. My anger has forsook me. What are those men that bear a countenance. As if they stood indifferently affected to Bedlam and Bride-well.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.L: Meaning by us, sir. If our sight offend you,
Know we are men that dare forbear the place.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: I son, let's go, our stay is dangerous.
They look like Peace-maintainers, well fall off.

SP.SPEAKER: Vint.
SP.P: O tarry, Gentlemen, we are all undone else. If you make not your peace before you stir, both you and I must suffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Vint.
SP.P: The Magistrates and Officers with their Bill-men have ta'ne us by surprise. They are i'th' house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bett.
SP.P: O me! the blew Gown Colledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Wheels and whips. I feel what we must go to. Did not I say our stay was dangerous?

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Did not I say there was some subtile pra∣ctice upon the Philoblatici? and that we were betrayed hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Vint.
SP.P: There's no escaping forth. And Gentlemen, It will but breed more scandal on my house, and the whole plantation here, if now you make rebellious up∣roar. Yield your weapons, and welcome Justice but like subjects new, and peace will follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: But where's Nick? where's Tonie?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: They shall yield up their weapons. So do you.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Yes yes, 'tis best.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P: Shall we, sir, shall we?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Yes sir, you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Clot.
SP.P:
So, sir, I will then, not the Blade alone. But
for your more security, the Battoon, There see my Armes forth coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Say they shall have faire welcom, What are they married?
SP.STAGE: Enter Nick. Dorcas, Ant. Kat. Luc.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Yes, as fast as troth and holy words can binde 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.L: 'Tis well. Now sir, let me entreat your favour.
'Tis my first suit to you since I was your son,
That before others entrances distract our troubled
Scoene, these may be reconcil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nick.
SP.P: Even unto the earth, sir, and humbled with as true a penitence, as son can be for wronging of a father, I beg your pardon and blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Give it him, Brother Rooksbill, I dare say 'twill make him a good man.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: Heaven make him so. My blessing and my prayers shall not be wanting.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What? my Neece Dorcas made an honest wo∣man?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Was that the man that wrong'd my Cousin Dorcas?

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: Yes, and has now made ample recompence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Here they are altogether, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P:
Lay hands on all. First, on that old Ruffian, the Incendiarie, that sets the youthful bloods on fire here with his Infernal discipline. Next, take his sons, there's one, that young Blade there, Have I now got within ye, Gentlemen? will you have Songs ex temporc? know ye me now? a ha! I'le be can'd the
Weeder of this Garden. Take up those She weeds there. I have the rank one here. I took her stragling in my Round e'ne now.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: My Tenant, I take it, Mrs. Margerie How∣let.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Your widow sir, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: But for a shift sir, now you know my aim.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: O good your worship, as you came of a wo∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Peace Circes, cease thy charmes. What clu∣ster have we here now. O here's another of the sons of noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Rook.
SP.P: That's my son now, sir, by your leave, and I'le baile him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: What Mr. Rooksbil, are you here? what wo∣man's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: My Neece, sir, his sons wife. And I'le baile her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: What Mr. Croswill, you among this Ginge too?
How will you 'scape commitment?

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: Why, Mr. Cockbrayne? how his braines crow now?

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Who's here? your daughters too? but what are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I hope they'l prove my sons, and be indiffe∣rent men in time, sir, by that time their haire may grow, or be reduc't to an indifferent length.

SP.SPEAKER: Mih.
SP.P: That's done on me already, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Now he looks as like a Rogue as e're he did again.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: And sir, for me, now that my Cousin is resto∣red, and the wilde fury of my wine abated.
I do you the obedience of a son, acknowledging my former formal habit was more of stubbornnesse then true devotion. For which I beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: There's more deceit under these half Foot∣balls, then in whole Pudding-bags. Well boyes, be you indifferent sons, neither too hot nor too cold. I have found a fault in myself, I confesse. I will re∣form it, and be an indifferent father.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O here's the man I sought, whom, I confess, I am half sorry to commit with the rest, because I found him civiller.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Hoping you will not stake that good opinion, I'le now come nearer to you. And since here is such a convention of love and joy. I hope my offering of a sons true duty may sinde I dulgencie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: What? my son Antonie?

SP.SPEAKER: Cross.
SP.P: How? how? your son that should have had my daughter? Come hither Kate, now if thou lov'st him, take him. Are you content, friend Cock∣brayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: O sir, most happily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Why run you not together?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: It is too late, or needlesse now for me to marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Is't come to that? and if I do not swindge him—.Are you too good, sir, for my daugh∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: I do not say so, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Huswife, do you like him?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: No more then he does me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Get you together, or I'le swaddle you both into one, you perverse fooles.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Sir, the truth is, we are married already.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: 'Tis so, indeed, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Heyday! who am I trow? how durst you do it vvithout my consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I had your consent, sir, you commanded me to take my choice in vvhom I pleas'd, before you vvould take notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I cannot abide this vvrangling. Give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Joy and my blessing on you. Why I knovv not vvhom to commit novv.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: You have done the Common-wealth a special piece of service the vvhile vvith your State-braines. But let us make a night of this, I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Sir, the parties have given me satisfaction, and I am content they be releas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: There's an honest fellovv novv, and looks like one that vvould be beaten every day for ready money. Go novv, vvhile ye are vvell, and be seen no more in this Precinct.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Never and't please your vvorships, never.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.L: 'Tvvas built for no such vermine. Hence avvay.
And may the place be purg'd so every day.
'Tis no unvvorthy member may be found,
To pester or to vilifie this ground.
That as it vvas intended, it may be
A Scoene for Vertue and Nobilitie.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: TIs not the Poets Art, nor all that we
By life of Action can present on't, ye
Can or ought make us to presume a Play
Is good, 'tis you approve't. Which that you may
It cannot misbecome us, since our gaines
Come by your favour, more then all our paines.
Thus to submit us unto your commands.
And humbly ask the favour at your hands.

DIV1.HEAD: Another.
DIV1.L: 'Tis done. And now that Poets can divine,
Observe with what Nobility doth shine
Faire Covent-Garden. And as that improves,
May we finde like Improvement in your Loves.

DIV1.P: THE NEW ACADEMY, Or, the NEW Exchange.
By RICHARD BROME.
LONDON, Printed or Andrew Crook, at the Green Dragon in Saint auls Church-yard: And Henry Brome at the Gun in Ivy-lane. 1658.

LIST.HEAD: The Actors Names.
LIST.ITEM: Sir Swithin Whimlby, a melancholy Widower. Suitor to the Lady Nestlecock.
Old Matchil, a Merchant that married his Maid. Gabri∣alla's Guardian.
Young Matchil his sonne.
Old Lafoy a French Gentleman, Guardian to young Matchil.
Young F. Lafoy his sonne.
Mr. Hardyman, Captain Valentines Father-in-law. Han∣nah's father.
Strigood, half brother to Matchil.
Valentine Askal, son-in-law to Hardiman. Hannah's half-brother.
Erasmus a young Gentleman, his Companion and Friend.
Cash, Matchils Prentice.
Nehemiah Nestlecock, a foolish Gentleman, the Ladies sonne.
Ephraim, the Lady Nestlecocks Servant.
Rafe Camelion an uxorious Citizen.

LIST.HEAD: VVomen.
LIST.ITEM: Ladie Nestlecock, a fond Mother.
Mrs. Blithe Tripshort, Sir Swithin Whimlbies Neece.
Hannah, Camelions wife, Captain Hardimans daughter.
Maudlin, Matchils Maid and Wife.

DIV1.HEAD: THE NEW ACADEMY, OR, THE NEW EXCHANGE.

DIV2.HEAD: Act. I.
DIV2.P: IS this the entertainment you promis'd me in the Jovial Mer∣chants house? Is this the great interest you have in his huge hos∣pitality? when by half an hours attendance and intreats, we can∣not obtain the sight of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: I wonder at it; Sure some strange disaster has suddenly befallen him. He was, last night the merriest man alive, drank healthes; told tales; sung Catches; Trowle the Bowle; Tosse the Cannykin; and what not! and all for joy, that his sonne, he said, was upon his returne, whom he has not seen these dozen years, since he sent him a little Lad into France, to be bred there.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P:
I heard he did so; and that in lieu, by way of
Exchange, he brings up the daughter of the Parisien that breeds his sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: But is that daughter so exquisite a creature, as is this Merchant Matchills own whom you so much extoll?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: They are both so equally handsome, and ver∣tuous, that, be their dowries so, and their consents alike, I'll take my choice of crosse and pile for either, with such a friend as thou art.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Troth, and that's friendly spoken, Mus.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: It is so Val. yet not with some policie do I wish thee a fortune: for, insooth. young Gentleman, though I like your person, and some of your qualities, yet by reason of your wants, I finde you something heavy on my purse-strings; and my selfe scarce able to supply you. And, if we faile of good matches, I must even turne you over shortly to the hopes you hoast of in your City-Mystresses and Tradesmens wives—.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Peace, prythee hold thy peace.
Friend Cash! Is your Master, Mr. Matchill yet at leisure be seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.P: He much desires, sir, to be held excus'd. 'Tis true that he invited you. His dinner's ready; and his heart welcomes you. But he has met with an unhap∣py newes to day.—

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I feard some ill. What is the mat∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.P: His only sonne, whom he of late expect∣ed home out of France, we hear, is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: His daughter will prove a bouncing match then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.P: That's the impression the heavy newes makes in you, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: Come, let's go.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.P: Nay, Gentlemen, although my Masters sud∣den sadnesse shuts him from you. His meat and wine are ready. There are some good company in his Par∣lour too, Pray stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Are his faire daughter, and the French-borne
Damsel there to be seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.P: Both. Pray be pleas'd to enter.
I hope his passionate fit e're you have din'd will be past over. He is not wont to suffer long under the hand of sorrow.
SP.L: 'Tis like that you shall see him ere you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: In that faire hope we'll enter and fall to.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: 'Tis like you shall fall short though of your aim
At my young Mystresse, who by this black newes,
Becomes my Masters heire, and so the white
That all the gallant suiters of the City
And Court will level their keen shafts at. Where
Are mine own hopes then, that stood as faire
In competition for her, love as any,
When the great noise of her inheritance,
Shall drown each Lovers tongue, that cannot say,
It is a Lords at least, I rather wish
The young man had not did.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: Where's my Boykin? my Friskoe? my De∣light? my Cash? by what better name can I call thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.P: O me! Master Strigood, what make you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I come to comfort my brother in his sor∣row.
His sonne is dead, they say. Ha! Is't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: And he is almost dead with sorrow: Back sir.
The sight of you, that are his sole vexation, will make him mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: That is my way to cure him.
Madnesse drowns grief in any man.—Probatum.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Good Mr. Strigood depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Good Mr. Cash, and Mr. Matchils man.
I'll see your Master. What! deny his brother?
His nowne natural brother? By the surer side too
We tumbled in one Pannier; though we had
Two Rippiers, Sweet sir, I am the elder too
Strigood was in my mother before Matchill
Therefore, because I have spent an estate
And he has got-one, must not I maintain
My self the better man?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Yes: if you had the wherewithal.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Sir, you had been as good ha' held your tongue.
Lend me some money Cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I have no money, sir, but what's my Ma∣sters.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Whose money, sir, was that you played last night.
Among the Knights and Braveries at the ordinary?
Gold by the handfuls, Cash! Lend me two pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Speak lower, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Lend me three pieces, Cash.
Before I speak too loud, whose money's that
You use to weare abroad at Feasts and Revels
In silver lace and satten; though you wait
At home in simple Serge, or broad-cloth, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Be not so loud, I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Lend me five pieces.
I shall grow louder else. Who payes your Barber?
I mean not for your Prentice pig-hair'd cut
Your weare at home here; but your Periwigs;
Your locks and Lady-ware that dangle in 'em,
Like straws in the bush natural of a Bedlem?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: What mean you Mr. Strygood.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I mean ten pieces now; I'll go no lesse. Do not I know your haunts?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: You may; you train'd one to 'em

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Do not I know your our leaps, and vagaries?
Your tiring houses, where you shift your self,
Your privy lodgings, for your trunks and punks?
Your midnight walks and meetings? Come, the money.
And, heark thee, though thou modest my brother by't.
I'll keep thy councel: thou shalt finde me yertuous.
I want, he gives me nothing; and thou canst not
Do him better service, then relieve his brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash:
SP.L: I am in; and must, to hide my old faults, do
Like an ill Painter, lawbe 'em o're with new.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Quickly. I shall grow loud again else Cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Sir, I am in your hands, here are ten pieces.
I hope you will not think my Master for▪.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: No; no for all he has that comes through thy hands.
My nimble Cash; and from his I am sure,
Though I were starving, I should finger nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Will you go now?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: I'll see him e're I go,
And dine, if there be meat i'th' house. What eate's
Are there within 'll draw a knife amon 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: This desperate old Russian, would undo me,
But he hopes to waste his brother by me.
He has spent himself to beggery; and would fall so,
But that he has pernicious fire in's brain,
That raging spreads to ruine others with him.
I must beware of him,
Is she come too?
Then 'tis deereed, my Master must, from sorrow, suffer in madnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Go home Ephraim.
And have a care you suffer not my boy
To Straggle forth 'mong his unhappy play-mates,
For fear of mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: It shall be my care.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What do you lock up my brother, ha?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: H' has lock't himself up, Madam; and will suffer
None to come at him, till his sorrowful fit
Be somewhat over.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Not's own Sister, ha?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Nor his half brother neither: yet he's here.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Is he here, ha? That Strygood? Is he here?
Hang him old reprobate. And beshrew thy heart,
For a young varlet, to call him our brother.
It is no marvel, if my brother Matchil
Lock up himself, and such a wickednesse
Be in his house, as is that Strygood, ha—
Let him take heed, he comes not in my Nayl reach,
And call me Sister, or my Brother, brother,
Like a debaush'd old Villain, as he is.
O that my husband Nestlecock were alive,
But for three minutes, to send him to
Newgate, if he presume to call me Sister
But I command you in my husbands name,
Who was a Justice, when he liv'd, to thrust him
Out of your Masters doors, my brothers house.
Lest I be sick with the loath'd sight of him.
You will not disobey this, will you, ha?—
If not, why stir you not? ha.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I must remove
This fit of hers. There's but one way to do it;
And thats to talk of her white boy, she's fond on.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Will you not send him packing, ha?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash,
SP.L: First, Madam.
(By your good Ladiships leave) how does your sonne
Sweet Master Nehemiah Nestlecock?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I thank you courteous friend. In truth, last night,
One of my Coach-gueldings fell lame, and I,
By that constrain'd to come afoot,
Was forc'd to leave my boy at home; or else
He had come with me, to have been a comfort
To his sad Uncle: But I would not now
For twice my Gueldings price, my childe were here;
And that foule fiend i'th' house, whose very looks
Would fright him into sicknesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: O good Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I can't so soon forget the fright he took
At seeing the roguish Jugler once eat tow,
And blow it out of's mouth in fire and smoke,
He lay a fourtnight by't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: That's two yeares since.
And he was then but young, he's now a man.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Alack a childe; but going in's nineteenth year.
Where's my Neece Joyce?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Within there Madam; so is Gabriella
The French young Gentlewoman to attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I'll stay with them till I may see my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I hope old Strygood, who now on the sudden
Hath slipt her memory, meets her by the eares first.
SP.STAGE: Enter Matchil, an opeu letter in his hands.
SP.L: But the good minute's come, before I look't for't.
My Master now appears. He looks most sourely
Expressing more of anger then of grief.
I feare, old Strygood was so loud with me,
That he hath over-heard us, and I shall break
Before I am a Freeman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Sorrow be gone
And puleing grief away, whilest I take in
A nobler and more manly Passion;
Anger, that may instruct me to revenge.
My childe is lost by treacherous neglect
In that false Frenchman, to whose seeming care
I trusted the chief comfort of my life;
My boy. Nay, read again. 'Tis written, here,
He was grown man:

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: His man, I think, he said.
SP.STAGE: Cash listens to Match∣il, and speaks aside.
SP.L: Does your man trouble you. I do not like that

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And here he writes that in his youthful spring
And heat of spirit, he began to grow
Intemperate and wilde—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Wilde! Are you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Which drew him on to riotous expence—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: And there again, to riotous expence!
'Tis I directly that he's troubled with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And sometimes into quarrels. What o' that?
In all this he was still mine own. Oboy—

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Some slave has writ some fearful information.
Against me, and he hugs and kisses it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And had his Guardian had a feeling care
(Hang his French friendship) over my dear childe,
As I had over his, these youthful follies
Might have been temper'd into manly vertues.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I hear not that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: But I fall back agen
From my revenge to grief. Away; I will not.
Here's the death-doing point. These slight disorders.
In my young forward sonne (I finde it here)
Were, by his churlish and perfidious Guardian,
Interpreted no lesse then Reptobation,
And, by his ignorant cruelty, so punish'd.
For, here he shuts his eare and door against him:
When suddenly the loose licentious world
Soothes on his youthful, in judicious courage
To imminent destruction; so being engag'd
In a rash quarrel, he in duel fell.
Th' Opponents sword was instrument; yet I inferre.
Lafoy, his Guarcian was his murderer.
Farewel, my boy; and this is the last teare
Thou shalt wring from me. Something I'll do,
Shall shew a fathers love, and valour too.
I'm young enough to draw a sword in France, yet.
But first—Come hither, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Now it comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrt.
SP.L: I purpose streight to order my estate
Look that you forthwith perfect my Accompts;
And bring me all my books of debtor and creditor,
Receipts and payments, what you have in wares,
And what in cash, let me inform my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: 'Tis as I fear'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I'll set all right and streight,
All statutes, bonds, bills, and seal'd instruments
That do concern me, I have in my Closet
Or at my Councels, or my Scriveners.
I'll call in them my selfe. Why doest thou look so amaz'dly?
Would'st have me yield a reason? why, I'll tell thee
I mean to make a voyage; and, perhaps,
To settle and proportion out my estate
By Will, before I go. Do you as I command you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Whatever he pretends, I know his drift:
And, e'te I'll be discover'd by my stay;
Being run out, I'll choose to run away.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: My daughter in the first place must be car'd for.
I'll make her a good match. My next in blood then,
My Knave-half-brother, and my whole fool-Sister.
But the best is, her Ladiship has enough;
And all I have, in Strygoods hands, were nothing.
Therefore I'll purpose nothing to him. Oh.
The Joy and Torment of my life, at once
Appear to me. I must divide them, thus.
Hence hated issue of my mortal foe
VVhom I have foster'd with a Parents Piety
As carefully and dearly as mine own.
VVhile the inhumane cruelty of thy Sire
Has to untimely death expos'd my sonne.
Thank me I kill not thee; so leave my house.
There's French enough in town, that may befriend you.
To pack you o're to Paris; what's your own
Take w'ye, and go. VVhy cleave you to her so?
Forsake her, cast her off. Are not my words
Of force, but I must use my hands to part ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Deare, honour'd father, I beseech you hear me.
In parting us you separate life from me,
And therein act a real crueltie
On me your only childe, sharper then that,
Which you can but pretend done by her father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Durst thou speak so?

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I cannot live from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: O monstrous. Pray, your reason. Why not live?

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: You know, Sir, from our Infancie we have been,
Bred up together, by your tender care
As we had been twin-borne, and equally
Your own; and by a self-same education,
We have grown hitherto, in one affection,
We are hoth but one body, and one mind,
What Gabriella was, I was, what I, was she.
And, till this haplesse houre, you have enjoyn'd me,
Nay, charg'd me on your blessing, not to arrogate
More of your love unto my self, then her,

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: That was, 'cause I presum'd her father lov'd,
Or should have lov'd my sonne, your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I never knew brother, or sister, I;
Nor my poor self, but in my Gabrella.
Then blame me not to love her, I beseech you
—Upon me knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Th' art knee-deep in rebellion.
Unnatural Gipsie, since thou prov'st my torment
In being the same with her; and hast declar'd
Thy self no more my childe, then she, whom now
I do abhorre, avoid, with her, my sight.
Rise, and be gone, lest thou pull curfes on thee
Shall sink thee into earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: O rather, Sir.
Let me, 'gainst whom your fury first was bent
Suffer alone the sharpnesse of your vengeance:
And let it not be said, 'cause you surmise,
My father lost your son, that, therefore, you
Have cast away your daughter. Hurl me, rather,
Into the ruthless waves to seek my way;
Or do but take her, hold her in the armes
Of your paternal love, and I'll take flight
To weane her to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: She cannot, may not leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Out of my doors then, with her.—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What's the matter? ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Such as you cannot mend, deare Lady Sister.
What come you hither with your Ha—for? Ha—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: To comfort you, dear brother, if you'll heare me.
Your sonne is dead, they say; and here I finde
Your daughter is rebellious 'gainst; our will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You speak much comfort, do you not, think you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: But is it so Joyce? ha!—I thought you, Joyce,
Would have rejoyc'd your father in obedience, Joyce;
And not afflict him with your stubbornnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: O this impertinent woman!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: But my brother,
Let me advise you, rather then suffer her
To be an eye-sore to you, put her out,
Where she may learne more duty. If you please
I'll take her home, and shew her how it should be

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Yes, as you have shewen your Nestlecock, your sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I, there's a childe! Brother, you'l pardon me,
If I aspire in hope, that he shallbe
Your heire, if Joyce miscarry in rebellion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And therefore you would breed her. How the devil
Works in a covetous woman! Though a foole too.
Your sonne's an Asse; an Ideot; and your self
No better, that have bred him so. Do you tell me
Of your sweet sugar-chop't Nestle cockscombe?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: He's fit t' inherit nothing but a place
I'th' Spittle-house, Fools Colledge, yond, at Knights∣bridge.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: And did I come to bring thee consolation?
Now let me tell thee, I rejoyce in thy
Just punishment, thy scourge of crosses. Thou,
That for these six years space▪ until this day,
Hast kept continual feast and jollitie
For thy wives death, who was too good for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Right, for she was my Master, a perpel
Vexation to me, while she was above-ground
Your Ladiship could not have spoke more comfort to me
Then the remembrance of that shook-off Shackle,
Which now, in my affliction makes me smile,
And were I on her grave, I could cut capers.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: A further punishment, I prhecie
Grows in the neck of thy leud insolence

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I could e'ne finde in heart to marry again,
In spight, now, of thy witchcraft, my son dead!
My daughter disobedient! and your childe
A very chilblaine. What have I to do
But marry again: all women are not devil,
I may yet get an heire unto my minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Art thou here too—

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Stay, you forget your brother, Mr. Matchil.
You have match'd ill once already; and take heed
You match not worse, your children, though un∣toward.
And taking of the devillish Shrew, their mother,
Were likely of your own begetting; Yet
Your second wife may bring you a supply
Of heires, but who must get them, first is doubtful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Thy impudence amazes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I'm sick at sight of the leud Reprobate.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Dee cast about for heirs; and have besides
Your daughter here, a brother and a sister?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Call not thy self our brother. He appears
Unde to me, but thou insufferable,
I loath to look upon thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: He has spoke
SP.P: Against her Aunt, her Moon-calf sonne. I'll make her love me best, and presently.
SP.L: Brother, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I cannot look upon thee.
Provoke me not to eech, I charge thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.L: Give me leave to speak; Hold you your peace;
Hear but my brotherly advice; and when
Give your consent in silence.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Hear him not.

SP.SPEAKER: (Mat.)
SP.L: Nor you neither, hum—hum—hum.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I am not angry with you now; and therefore
I charge you, hear him not.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: My advice is thus, that for your daughters good.
For mine own good, and for your Sisters good.
And for her sonne, your Nephew's good.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: How's that? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: And chiefly for your own good, and the credit
A wise man would desire to hold i'th' world,
Think not of marrying, nor of buying hornes
At the whole value of your whole estate,
But match your daughter while you have the meanes
In your own hands; give her a good round portion,
Here are deserving Gentlemen i'th' house.
Next, think of me your brother, that has spent
In down-right fellowship (heaven knows what
All fraudulent purposes to make any man
A miser or a gainer by't) a faire estate.
And now do want a brotherly supply.
A hundred a year or so: but above all
Fasten your land unto yout Sisters sonne.
That hopeful Gentleman, sweet Nehemiah.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Now brother you may hear him.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: What though it straggle from the name of Matchil.
Remember yet he is your mothers Grandchilde.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Why dee not hear him, brother?—

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: As I hope
To be a landed man my self,
Had I a thousand yearly, I would leav't him.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Trulie, I thank you. Now I'll call you brother.
Y'are a good natur'd Gentleman if you had it.
Come home, and see my sonne.—VVill you not hear him? ha

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I need not, nor your selfe. I see you gape
Like monsters that would swallow me alive.
I know your mindes; and I will do mine own.
And, thus it is. Stay, let me stay a little.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Look you how wilde he looks.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: He's falling mad.
Stark staring mad,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I would he had a wife then,
For nothing else can tame him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: So it shall be.
First, I'll be Master of mine own estate.
Next—

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Take a wife to master that, and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Next, you Madamoiselle, (on whom with pa∣tience
I cannot look) forsake my house, and suddenly;
Linger not for a man to wait upon you,
But let your black bag guard you, 'tis a fashion
Begun amongst us here by your own Nation.
And if I longer must call you my daughter,
Forsake you her.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: VVhat mine own heart? dear Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: At your own choice. I can force her depar∣ture,
Though not perswade your stay, determine quickly
Either to leave her, and enjoy a father,
Or never more expect a fathers blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: Dear, mine own heart, leave me, obey your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: It must be to my death then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I'll be sudden.
Therefore be you as brief in your resolve.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Alas, poor hearts. Just so loth
To part was I and my sonne Nehemiah
Today when I came forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Neece Joyce, let me
Advise you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Pray, Sir, none of your advices.
Let her advise her self; whilest I impart
To you my next intention; which is thus.
To end your strife for shares in mine estate
I'll venter on a wife: indeed I'll marry

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Will you so? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Yes indeed La,—

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: If then
You'l estate nothing on me for my life
Give me a see to help you to a wife,
I can, a good one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I'll none, Sir, of your good ones.
Besides, Sir, I'm provided.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You are not, are you? ha

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Let it suffice, I say't, so quit my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Shall I expect then nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Pray sir, do.
'Tis all I can afford you. You have wit,
Yes, you can daunce, tread money out of rushes,
Slight and activity to live upon.
A nimble braine, quick hands and airie heels
To get a living.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Hah.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Pray fall to practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I may, sir, to your cost, if you put off
Your daughter with her Sweet-heart, her Mon Coeur
There, as she calls her. Dear, my Lady Sister;
You see how churlishly this Merchant uses us.
He has forgot, sure, he was borne a Gentleman.
Will you be pleas'd, I speak to you in your eare.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Any way, brother Strigood, Hang him, Nabal,
To warn me out o's house; and not alone,
To turne a stranger from within his gates,
But offer to cast out his childe too, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: 'Tis about that I'd speak, pray Madam heark you.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Noble Mr. Matchil, though we are your meat
Before we saw you you will give us leave
To take our leaves, and thank you ere we part.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: O Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: W'have heard your cause of sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: But I have over-past it. Heark ye Gentlemen

SP.SPEAKER: Eras.
SP.L: You'l give us leave first to salute the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Nay, if you love me, heare me first.

SP.SPEAKER: Er. Val.
SP.L: Your will, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Neece, you shall no way disobey your father
In being rul'd by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: So, so, it takes.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You and your second selfe shall home with me
Until his furious humour be blown over.
To which the first meanes is to his fight,
And then let me alone to make your peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy. Gab.
SP.L: We thank your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: So let us slip.
Home to my house together.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Hist brother, lead the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: As glad as ever Fox was of his prey
SP.STAGE: Exit. om. Pet. Mat. Er. Vab.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Tis even so, Gentlemen, sorrow findes no lodging.
In my light heart sometimes she knocks at door,
And takes a drink, but here she must not sit by't.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Y' are happy Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Yet I have heard you say
You never tasted joy for divers yeares
Till your wife died: since when, a King of mirth,
And now to marry agen is such a thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Yes sir, tis such a thing that I will marry
That I fore know can never disobey me
And I'll defie the devil to dishonest her.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Is she so ougly?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: No, he means so vertuous.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Well-said, sir, you shall drink before me. Ra∣chel, Mawdlin.
SP.L: 'Protest you shall though't be in my own house.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Now he resumes his humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Ratchel I say,
Bring me a kan o' sack.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: But how can you
Presume before the dangerous marriage-trial
That she whom y'have chosen will be obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: D' ye think he has not tried her? There's a question

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Well-said agen. I was about to say so.
Rachel, some sack, I say. Yes, I have tried her, sir,
Tri'd her, and tri'd her again; all over and over
These five yeares day and night; and still obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Then you are sure to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: No, I never us'd
A marriage-question, not a woing word,
But do all by command, she is so obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And yet she's chaste and vertuous withal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Well-said again, sir, so I was a saying.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: But we have talk't away the Gentlewomen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: No matter, let'hem go. Would they were far enough.
SP.STAGE: Enter Rachel, silver Kan and Napkin.
SP.P: Come, the sack, the sack.—Who taught you that courtesie maid.
SP.L: Pray try a better to the Gentleman.
Protest you shall begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: In your own house, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: 'll rather g' ye my house, then break my word in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Y' are Lord here, and may command me, sir. And so my service to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I'll do you reason, sir.
Be ready with your Napkin, and a lower douke maid.
I'll hang dead weight at your buttocks else. So.
Is not this obedience, Gentlemen, Mr. Erasmus?
Mus, I will call thee Mus, I love to be
Familiar, where I love; and Godamercy
For your friend here; you both shall see my daugh∣ter.
But my French Damosel and I are parted
I hope by this time. So here's to you Mus.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: To me, to me, to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Ha boy, art there? dispatch
Your court'sie quickly, and go cal my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Rach.
SP.L: She is gone forth, forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Forth, ha? when? whither?
La ye, she thinks I'm angry, and the finger
Is in the eye already. Is not this
Feare and obedience, Gentlemen? who went with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rach.
SP.P: She went with my Lady Nestlecock, to bring Gabriella on her way they said.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I would
They were all in France together.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: What, your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: She comes again, I doubt not. Dry your eyes.
And drink that sack, without a court'sie, drink it.
You do not know my meaning, Gentlemen.
Stay: now gi' me't agen.—Now go and dry
Your face within—without a court'sie? ha!
Now is not this obedience, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: But this is not the rare obedient peece
That you will marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You do not hear me say so.
But I presume, as much obedience
In her I have made choice of.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Marrie a maid.
And we will be her Hench-boyes, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: No, I'll have no such blades 'bout my wives hanches.
But come, to end this tedious Scene, in which
I ha' past the Purgatorie of my Passions
Of sorrow, anger, feare, and hope at last.
I am refin'd, sublim'd, exalted, fixt
In my true Sphere of mirth; where love's my object.
And bloodie thought of black revenge cast by.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Could your faire breast harbour a bloody thought?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: For some few minutes, in which extasie
I meant t' ha' gone, as other Gallants do.
To fight in France, forsooth, and charg'd my man
To draw up his Accompts, call in my moneys,
Thought to have made my Will—.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I saw your Cashier
Go forth e'ne now with a sttong lusty Porter
Loaden with money: I will not say my teeth
Water'd at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: But 'twas enough to make
A very true mans fingers itch.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I cannot
Think he is run away; but yet I like not
His carrying forth, when I say, fetch in money.
But this is from my purpose. Love ye mirth?
Let's in, and drink, and talk. That gives it birth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I prithee now, I prithee, prithie now
Urge me no more in this case; for I cannot,
Nor I wo' not so I wo' not, I be jealous
Os mine own wife, mine own deat flesh and blood?
That's such a thing! I pidee speak no more on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: You shew you love Rafe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: So I hope I do Nan.
My cock, my pity nittle nansie cocksie,
Do I not shew my love when I deny thee
Vnreasonable requests? I never heard
Of woman that desir'd a loving husband
To be a jealous Master over her.
Especially a City-Shopkeeper.
The best part of whose trade runs through the hands
Of his faire wife too! 'Tis unreasonable.
And thou the sirst that e're take up the humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: And you the sirst that e're I knew besotted
Into a wilful confidence, which renders
Me to a vile construction; and your selfe
By leaving me to all assaults and hazards
Have got the reputation of a Wittal.
Or one that seems contented to become so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: My Cock, my Nansie Cock, my Cocksie Nansie,
Kisse me, and use thine own conscience: I scorn
The yellow sicknesse, I, let 'hem all say what they will.
D'einty, come thou to me. I will not lose
An haires bredth o' my humour, nor retain
An ill thought o' my Cocks honestie
For all the wealth i' the Exchange, not I

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: I not desire you should, but only that
You will not seem so carelesse of my credit,
Exposing me to all temptations
Of the wilde Gallantry of the wanton time.
By whom (although my chastity remaines
Untouch't) my name and your discretion suffers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Pish, Honi soit again: Cock, I defie
Calumniation and detraction I.
When I am jealous, let the horne-curse take me;
And let me be with hornets stung to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Still you flie from the point, I would not have
You vex your self with causelesse jealousie
Over my constant love; but only seem
A little watchful o're my reputation.
Whereby you may decline mens leud attempts.
And not to throw me upon opportunities
To draw them on; as if I were a thing
S out, as in your shop, for common sale.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Cock, Thou shalt never tie me to't: not I.
I must not lose my harmlesse recreations
Abroad to snook over my wife at home.
Thought'st ha' me like the hair-brain'd Point-tagger,
That us'd to hammer his fingers at one end
O'th' shop, while's wife was bargaining at the other?
Not I; sweet Cock, pidee lets heare no more on't.
Now friend! Is your businesse to me or my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Post.
SP.L: This Superscription will inform you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.P: To my deare daughter Mrs. Hannah Camelion, at her shop or house in or near the New Ex∣change.

SP.SPEAKER: Cock.
SP.P: Take it quickly, what a Knave art thou to put a letter in my hands, that is directed to my wife. Sbobs I would not ha' open'd it for fonrty pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Post.
SP.P: If all husbands in the City were of his minde, it were a Forrest of fooles indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Cock, I must leave thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.P: Pray stay a little. This letter's from my fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I hope the good Captaine's well.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Yes, very well, pray read his Letter here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Cock, you shall pardon me. Not I.
I have a match to play at the ducking-pond.
Prithee fore-slow not my occasions, Cock,
As I forbear to pry into thy secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.P: Here's nothing but what I would have you see.
There's for your postage, friend. It needs no an∣swer.

SP.SPEAKER: Post.
SP.L: I thank you, Mystris.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: But if you will not stay to reade this Let∣ter.
You shall not deny me one thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: What is it, quickly? my sweet Nanny Cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Here, take this pen: write here a word or sentence.
What you please. But keep it well in minde,
And look that you be sure to know't agen
When I shall shew't you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.P: 'Tis done, there: I defie, and dare the de∣vil and all his Clerks to counterfeit my hand. So, my sweet Cock, a kisse and adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Well Rafe, remember that you won't be jea∣lous.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Not I, Sbobs yonder comes one of the Blades,
That thou would'st have me have an eye to; He
That lives by his wits, and yet is seldom sober:
That goes so gallantly, and has no credit,
Nor ever buyes with ready money; But
Barters commodity for commodity.
(Such as it is) with Tradesmens wives, they say.
What call you him, oh Askal; there's another
Comes with him too. Into thy shop, good Cock.
I wo' not stay, not I. So, farewel Cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: And farewel Coxscombe, some wife would say now.
I am much troubled at his sillinesse.
And would to right me, straine a womans wit,
Knew I with modesty how to answer it.
Something I'le do.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Was ever such a humour in a man, as this mad
Merchant Matchil is possest with.
To marry so, to spight his childe and kindred.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: He has made his daughter by't a match worth nothing.
And there your hope is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: And yours in me.
For as I said before, good Valentine.
I must returne you to your City wives.
By the old trade to pick your maintenance
Out of em, as you boast you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: 'Tis well, sir.
And now to let you know that I can live
Without the helps of such cool friends as you.
I'le shew you a present probability.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
