SP.L: Doest see yond pretty mumping peece i'th' shop there?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Yes, is that one—?

SP.SPEAKER: Val
SP.L: One o'th' fourty, boy,
That renders tribute in to my Exchecquer.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Didst ever lie with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: How plain you are. Not I, not I.
That▪s her fool-husbands word.
Let it sussice that I have seen her thrice.
And that I lay with, drink, and weare her money.
O 'tis the sweetest Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: How got you acquainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I'le tell you that, walking by chance as now,
Before her shop, where a young Gentleman
Was bargaining, he call'd me by my name,

SP.SPEAKER: Val Askall.
SP.L: Instantly her eye was fixt,
And streight ran over my delineaments,
Which I set to her view; and took occasion
To ask her how the object pleas'd her.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Bold-face.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I never lost by that.
She then demands, Is your name Askall, sir?
I answer, Yes. Pray of what countrey, sir?
I told her; when a sudden flaming blush
Did in her face betray the fire of love,
That was at th' instant raging in her breast,
She look't me through and through. Sigh'd, turn'd away.
Then look't again under her hat-brims thus.
And thus I nimbly catch't her with mine eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I, thou hast a devillish catch i'that same eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Sir, what I have, I have. I gave a leere
With that same eye that made her turne her whitesup.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: But to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Why do you think a woman's so quickly brought to th' point?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: VVhat follow'd then?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I saw she was struck, and thus I gave her line
To play withal. I whisper'd in her eare,
The way to finde my lodging and my service.
Next morning early comes a message to me,
Inviting me to dinner: Chear and welcome
Plenteously flowed; and sir, before we parted
Upon some private conference, twenty pieces
Were clutch't into this hand, but with a caution
To be discreet and thrifty of her purse,
And keep a friend in store. I have been modest,
And have not struck her since, but for ten more.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: And that's your last.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I le hold you ten o that
See she has spied me.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.P: VVhat lack ye, Gentlemen; faire cut-work bands, boot-hoose, or boot-hoose tops, shirts, wast-coats, night-caps, what will you buy?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I come not now to buy.
But in plain termes to borrow. Do you not know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Not on these termes.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Sure thou mistak'st the woman.
This is not she, thou talk'st fo freely on Bounce.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: She's cautious before thee. Walk off a little.
Now you may hear me, Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Give me leave
A little, first to wonder at your rashnesse,
To talk so openly before a stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: My intimate friend: I'le trust him with my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: What's that to my unblemish't reputation?
'Tis not your life can salve that, being wounded.
But thus it is, when women out of goodnesse
Hazard their fortunes to relieve the wants
Of such as you, that carry no respect,
But to your own licentious Appetites.
And think no favour's sweet, unlesse you may
Have priviledge to boast 'hem to our shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I do not boast of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Pray, boast no more
Then you have found, and much good may they do you.
'Tis not poor thirty pieces can undo me.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: No, nor ten more I hope; and that's the summe
I would entreat: all makes but fourty pound.
I'll pay thee like a Gentleman, as I am one,
Either in money; or doest hear me, Rogue,
In what shall please thee better. Come, be wise,
Thy husband's a dull ducking Gamester. And
Kennels his water-dog in Turnbull-street.
We'll answer his delights with better sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: There's your presumption.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: No, 'tis my ambition.
When shall we walk to Totnam? or crosse o're
The water, or take Coach to Kengington
Or Padington; or to some one or other
O'th' City out-leaps for an afternoon,
And hear the Cuckow sing to th' purpose? when?

SP.SPEAKER: Had.
SP.L: A woman were a wise one that would trust
Her selfe in such wilde hands as yours; to have
Her name made Tavern-talk among your blade,
And thrust i'th 'list of your loose-hilted Mystresses:

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: O no; fie no: you cannot think how close
And careful I will be. Heark in thine eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I cannot blame this fellow now so much
For using of his wits to get his living,
Though in an idle way; as for traducing
People of worth and vertue, as this woman
Who I am credibly inform'd is vertuous
And too discreet for him to shark upon.
Therefore to grace himself, he slanders her.
I have alwayes lik't his company till now,
And shall hereafter be more wary of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Well sir, upon pour faithful protestation,
And vow of secresie, liere's ten pieces more.
You have found a tender-hearted woman of me
Over your wants; and all the satisfaction
That I desire, is, that I may not suffer
Under a lavish tongue; 'tis easie payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Yes, but I'le pay thee better. Therefore tell me, when we shall meet and have a spirta∣broad.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Your friend stayes for you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Pish, let him stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.P: You slight him now, but he knows all your Councels.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: By this good tongue, no more then the un∣begotten Hans that I mean to clap into thy Kel∣der.
SP.L: Nor ever shall: doest think I am so foolish
To talk away my hopes? No, thou art my Faery,
Pinch me to death when I discover thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Han,
SP.L: Go to, avoid suspition then, besides
I have occasions that do call me hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Your stay was somewhat long.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Yet 'twas to purpose.
As here you may behold, but I must make no words on't.
She has enjoyn'd me that. O'tis a cunning Gypsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: So't seems, by trusting thee that hast no pow∣er to keep a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Troth, to tell you true.
My conscience will not beare't, I cannot be
So ungrateful to receive a courtesie,
But to acknowledge it.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Yet thou hast the conscience
To work a mans estate out of his hands
By his wives frailty, even to break his back.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: 'Tis rather to be fear'd she may break mine.
She's a tight strong dock't Tit.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: O Tradesmen, why do you marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Why? to make Tradeswomen.
For Gentlemen that want money and commodity.
You know the thing that I call father in ,
That had my mothers whole estate, and butied her,
Allowes me nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Thank your own sweet courses.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: My courses are sweet courses, they serve me to live upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: But I shall put you off
O'one of your sweet courses, or at least
I'le strain a point of friendship to be satisfied
Touching this woman, 'twill be worth discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: But why these cloudy looks? do not you like my courses? ha▪

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I cry thee mercy, Val.
I was upon our former subject Matchil.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I there's a hasty match clap't up. You ask't
Why Tradesmen marry, there's a marriage now!
A humorous Coxscombe that could never laugh
In all his last wives dayes; and since her death
Could ne're be sad. For him to marry his Malkin
For poor and course obedience. Well. I hope
To take my course in his house yet for all.
Her boasted chastity and obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Wouldest thou touch such a thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: What, not for money?
She can pay well and her uglinesse cannot fright me
I can do that work winking.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: She can be no such woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Tell not me
What any woman can or cannot be,
You'll give me leave to try my fortune with her,

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Yes, and walk with you towards it.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: No newes, no tidings of 'em, Ephraim, ha!
Was even sucg a scape?

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Not since the Rape
Of Hllon I'm perswaded. I have search't
With narrow eyes (as I may say) with care,
And diligence in most secret places.
And can no way inform my self, what is
Betide of the young Damosels, or old Squire.
Your Neece, and the French Virgin, and the man
Unworthy to be call'd your brother Strigood.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O hang him Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Doubtlesse 'twas his plot
To work upon your Ladiships good nature
To harbour them, that he might take th' advantage
Of stealing them away.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What to do, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: To do? much may be done by his seducements,
On two such tender Virgins, though he should
But plant them in our suburbs: but my feare
Is that he has transported them beyond seas
Into some Nunnery. Your Ladiship
Knows he is adverse in Religion.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I know he is of none.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Satan will work.
The stronger in him, then to their subversion.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: How shall I answer now my brother Matchil?
But he is justly serv'd to marry so.
The thought of it torments me. Where's my comfort?
Where's Nehemiah, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: He's busie, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What, at his book? or at his musick, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: That is, his Ballet, or his Jewes Trump. No,
Madam. He is busie at his exercise of Armes
With a new Casting top, a Cat and Catstick,
I bought and brought him home.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I thank you for 'hem,
My careful discreet Ephraim. I like
His harmlesse exercises well.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: I hope,
Your Ladiship can say since I have had
The Government of him under your Ladiship,
I have been careful of the Gentleman,
And have his love withal so much, that I
Dare say (I hope you'll pardon the comparison)
That had you married me (which was as likely
As that your brother would have ta'ne his Maid.
I think that Mr. Nehemiah would not
Have run away in hatred of our Match,
As Mrs. Joyce. it seems, hath done of theirs.
I hope your Ladiships pardon, I understand
My duty.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: And you speak but reason Ephraim.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: I have given her there a touch of my affection.
Who knowes how it may work?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Go call him in.
I would not have him over heat himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: 'Tis a good care. And Madam, by the way,
Let me advise, that since his riper yeares
Require, and that faire Propositions
Of marriage are tender'd for him, that
We gently by degrees, do take him off
From childish exercise, indeed plaine boyes play.
More manly would become him.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You would have him
Do worse then, would you? and be nought, you var∣let?
What! would you have him play at Mans-game, ha?
Fore he be married, ha! what, what! how now!
Is it but up and ride w'ye, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: I humbly
Beseech your Ladiships pardon, I will call
Sweet Mr. Nehemiah to your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Go, th'art an honest man. I know thou lov'st him.
Indeed he's all my comfort and my care
And I must naturally respect all those
That do partake with me my care of him.
SP.STAGE: Enter Nehemiah, looking down and eating.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: my boy Negh, Sonne Nehemiah.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: F'sooth.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: That's my good Lamb. Hold up thy head; and thou.
Shalt have a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: But mother f sooth, when I have her,
Will she play with me at peg-top?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: At any thing, my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: And she ha' not good box and steel, I shall so grull her.
And then at Mumbledepeg I will so firk her.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: But when y'are married, youll finde other pa∣stime.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Whate're I say, I have a meaning though.
But yet, I doubt, I shall not forsake all
My old fagaries in a yeare or two.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I know thy will is good to leave thy wag-tricks.
And I commend your understanding in it.
It shewes you man, and ready for a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Amardla, f'sooth, I think so; I Amardla.
For I did beat a boy as high as my selfe
Yesterday, with one hand.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Where was thy tother.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: The boy had but one hand f'sooth. I us'd both.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Well th'art too witty to live long, I feare.
But as I was saying, sonne, I do expect
Sir Swithen Whimtby to bring his Neece.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Who fsooth, the crying Knight, he that has wept
E're since his Lady di'd; and mournes in colours;
Speaks nothing but in verse, and gives me Ballats;
The old Knight Powel, that pronounces what dee call 'hem?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Odes childe and Elegies. He has been in∣spir'd.
With the infection of Poetry,
E're since his wives departure: and 'tis thought
Nothing can put him out, or cure him of it
But a new wife to kill the furious itch of't,

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: But is not his Neece too big for me? I would be loth
To be over-match'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O witty, witry, still.
But when she comes Nehemiah, What'll you say to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: I'll give her the time of the day or the night
I warrant her, come at what houre she will.
Why if I eat not all before she come.
(And she must try her, if I do'nt) I'll ask her
If she can speak with plums in her mouth; and then
I'll offer her a long one and two round ones,
And nod at her.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You will not, will you, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Mother, I know both what to say and do
I trust I am not to be taught to wooe.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Too witty still, I say, to be long-liv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: But heark you mother f'sooth; I am told that you
Beare a moneths minde to that Sir Whimlby,
And a crosse match is talk't on betwixt you
And the old Knight, and me and his young Neece.
O ho—is't so?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: This is no crafty childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Let me but see how you will handle him now
And mark how I'le come over her with small Jerks.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O th'art a witty wag. A blessing on it.
SP.STAGE: Enter Ephraim, ushering Whimlby and Blith.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Madam, Sir Swithen Whimlby and his Neece,
Mrs. Blith Tripshort.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: They are very welcome,
Noble Sir Swithen.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Noble Mrs. Blith.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Sweet Knight, y'are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Welcome, sweet Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Still weeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: O good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Still weeping for a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Mother, she puts me on't,
She laughes.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Laugh with her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Amardla, so I will, and if you laugh
At me, I'll laugh at you again, so I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Are you there with me? I'le be here with you then.
Will you eat any Sugar-plums? no, I'le eat 'em for you.
There's ha, ha, ha, ha, for you now.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Do you note, Sir Swithin, what a wag it is.
Walk into the next room Nehemiah. Did you note him?

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Madam, to tell you true.
My love to you
Springs from the joy,
I take in your sweet boy
SP.STAGE: —Eph. And that's the way to win her.
SP.L: I can take no delight
But in his sight,
Nor any pride
Since my dear Grissel di'd,
In all, I see on earth or finde in books,
But that which overcomes me in his lookes.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O sweet Sir Swithen, you have all woo'd and won me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Then all my hopes are frustrate.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: My sonne shall have your Neece, and for mine own part.
You loving him so well, of what's in me.
I can deny you nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Gentle Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: She offers up her selfe; now may the proverb
Of proffer'd service light upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Nay, Sir Swithen.
Let me entreat you to leave weeping now.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: When my dear Grissel did.

L.HI: And when your Ladiship appears in sight.
(Pardon) I cannot chuse but cry out-right.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Alas, good Knight. He weeps pure Helicon.
He has not wherewithal to quench his love,
But his own teares. A wife would cool him better.
Why sir, does sight of me renew your grief?

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.

L.HI: And till, to ease my paine,

SP.L: That in my Grissel di'd.

L.HI: So oft as she in you to me appears
My numbers cannot cease to flow in tears.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Good sir, collect your self, and be assur'd
I am your own, so Neh. may have your Neece,
With her full Dowry of foure thousand pounds.
My personal estate is full as much.
That and my self are yours on the crosse marriage,
You making me an answerable Joincture.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Is't come so near; I'le crosse it, or my star▪
Drop crosses on my head. O vain, vain woman,
To doat on Poetry in an old man.
Ladies may love it in the young and bold,
And when they are sick give gally-pots of gold,
For cordial Electuaries to chear
Their crop-sick Muses; but to an old and sere
Man that out-lives his labours, who can be
So vain to give her self away but she.
I had been sitter for her, and I'le watch
Occasion yet, perhaps, to crosse the match,
I can tun Poet too.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Dry now your eyes, and answer me in prose,
Are you content to yield to those conditions
I have propounded, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: VVhim.
SP.L: I am content.
And now for joy could weep,
Finding my Grissel in your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I hope the young ones do accord as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Protest, I cannot abide you.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Nor I you.
Amardla, that I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: They'r agreed.
Madam, it seems they both are of one minde.

SP.SPEAKER: La
SP.L: I do not like it. What's the matter Nehemiah?

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: She is no wife for me, she has broke my Jewes-trump; look you here else. And almost broke my head with one of my bounding stones.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Blesse my boy; she has not, has she, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: And yet after all that, and for all I offered to teach her to shoot in my Trunk and my Stone-bowe, do you think she would play with me at Trou, Ma∣dam? no, nor at any thing else. I'll none of her.
And yet I'le have her too. If she will promise to do as I would have her hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: There, do you note him there, Sir Swithen?
This childe has no childish meaning in't, I war∣rant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: No Madam, no, I know him inwardly
He is my joy, and she shall be conformable,
Or fare the worse.

SP.SPEAKER: La
SP.L: She will, I know she will.
Will you not have my son, sweet Mrs. Blith?

SP.SPEAKER: Bli
SP.P: Sweet Madam, what to do? ha, ha, I shall be quickly weary with laughing at him. His fooling will soon be stale and edious; and then to beat him would be as toilsome to me; and lastly, to be tied to nothing but to cuckold him, is such a common Town-trick, that I scorne to follow the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: La
SP.L: Can she talk thus? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: A merry harmlesse Girle.
Fear not, good Madam, she will come about.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: A thousand mile about rather then meet him.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I much desire she would; for now my sonne
Is set a marrying, I warrant it pure thing
It is in paine, till it be at it: ha!
Pray bring her on, Sir Swithen, let him kisse her.
Poor heart, he licks his lips; and look how arseward she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Fie Blith, be courteous, Blith.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Mother,—she has spit Amard just in my mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Amard, what's that? if you speak French you wrong me.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Gip, Mrs. Tripshort. Is this the manners your Mother left you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Speak not you of Mothers, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Sir wthen, will you se my childe abus'd so, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: I can but grieve for't, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: My mother is as good as your mother, so she is, for all she's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I, well-said Neh.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Yes, it appears in your good breeding
Your fine qualities expresse her vertues sussiciently.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: How dare you Huswife talk thus to my son, of me, and before my face too? ha! Sir Swithen, can you think well of me, and suffer this, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: Alas, good Madam, I am down again I know not what to think of living woman now.

SP.SPEAKER: La▪
SP.P: Do you bring your Neece to abuse me?

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: I am so drown'd in teares, that I cannot ee what to say to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Mother, Amardla, the more I look on her, the better I like her.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Sayest so, my boy. Besides, I have a conceit she can out-scold you▪ and that's more then ever woman did, I think f'sooth.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: For thee, I do forbear her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: By your leave, my Lady Nestlecock, I have brought a sister of yours here to salute you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Though unworthy to be of your Counsel, or at the Ceremony, I heard you were married brother. And by a Sisters name you are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I thank your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Sir Swithen Whimlby! and your pretty Neece! well met, what affairs have you in hand here? what do you cry for your old wife still or for a new one? But heark, you Lady Sister, where's my daugh∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Now for a tempest. Truly sir, I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Is shenot with you, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: No truly, sir.
She's slipt from me with her good Uncle Strigood.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: That Thief has sold her then into some Baw∣dihouse
Was this your project for her education,
To steal my childe to make a whore of her?
Are you turn'd Lady bud now for your Neece
Because you have no daughter? O the devil!
If there be Law, I'll trounce your Lady Hagship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: VVhat, what? how now? do you taunt me, sirrah, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I'll make thee an example.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Thou hast made thy self an example, and the scorne of thine own childe in marrying of thy drudge there; and thats the cause of her running away thou mayest think, because she hates to live where she must call her mother that was thy droile.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Droile, I think, she said.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Speak to her, I charge thee, on thy obedience to speak to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: The droile is now your brothers wife, Madam, and in that setting your Ladiships lavish tongue aside, as good a woman as your selfe, none disprais'd, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Well-said Rachel, hold thine own Rachel. And so to you, sir Sw then.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Mother, come away, mother.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: By and by, my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Do you presume to call me drudge and droile, that am a Ladies Sister every day in the week; and have been any time these three dayes, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: That's not every day in a whole week yet.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Thou shalt not dare to call me sister Hus∣wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P:
Cods so, and why troe? because a Lady scornes to be a huswife, ha. If you be no huswife, I scrn to call
you Sister, I; though my husband be your brother. From whence came you troe, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I know not what to say to the bold-face.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Pray f'sooth come away, I am afear'd she'l beat you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Thanks, my good childe, but do not be afraid my Lamb.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Boldface, ha! Her brothers wife▪s a bold-face, but her face is not varnish't over, yet like his Lady∣sisters face, but it may be in time when she learnes the trick on't, and have as many flies upon't, though not so troubled with 'hem, as a bald mare at Midsummer, hah.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I know not what to say to her, she has charm'd the vertue of my tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I never heard her speak so much in all her life, Sir Swithin, nor half so loud. hank heaven, she has a voice yet on a good occasion. And so farre I'll maintain her in it. Nephew Nehemiah, when saw you your Cousin Joyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: O Lud, O mother f'sooth, look you, mine Uncle holds me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Ah, naughty man, did a so gi▪me a stroke, and I'll beat it, h—.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Your wife has taught you to play the rude companion, has she? Pray take her home sir, and let her discipline your owne childe if you have one, and let mine alone. You know the way you came, sir; or if you have a minde to stay here, Come Sir Swithen, come away children; I hope I shall finde some other room in mine own house, free from your assaults, if not, I'm sure there's Law against Riots. Come Sir Swithen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Not yet good Madam Nestlecock, you shall hear me.
You have entic'd away, then lost my daughter.
And now y'are a jugling with your widow wit,
And your small worme here, to catch up for Gudge∣ons.
Sir Swithen and his Neece, I know your plot..
She's not fit match for you Sir Swithen; and her son
Much lesse for your faire Neece. Come dry your eyes,
And look upon him, and not only look,
But laugh at him, I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: I could now for him heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Mark how his mothers milk drops at his nose, while I shew you the mother and the childe.
He was her youngest sonne, and all that's left of seven, and dreaming that he needs must prove a Prophet, she has bred him up a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: F'sooth mother he mocks me, oh.—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: O prophane wretch, worse then thy brother Strigood.
SP.L: Do not cry, Nehemiah, peace, good boy, peace. So so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: A tender mother I must say she has been.
For till he was fifteen, none but her selfe
Must look his head, or wash his pretty face
For making of it cry. Laugh at her good Sir Swithen.
And before that, till he was twelve yeares old
She would dance him on her knee, and play with's Cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Whm.
SP.L: Ah ah ah ah.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: So well-said, Sir Swithen.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: Just so efac my mother would serve me, ha, ha.
Is not this better then whining.
Yes, or perhaps then wiving either.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.L: Do you say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Wh.
SP.L: Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P:
Well said, Sir Swithen, laugh on. I hope I ha' done a cure on him, by shewing him a
more ridiculous object then himselfe, to turne the tide of's tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Wh.
SP.L: Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Laugh still, defie the fiends, women, and all their works.

SP.SPEAKER: Wh.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, let the dead go, and the quick care for themselves. You buri'd your wife, and cri'd, and I buried mine.
SP.L: And laugh; which is the manlier Passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: He knows not that he is married agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: You are the merriest Merchant, ha, ha, ha.
I think I shall not marry again in haste, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Well-said, hold there. And for your Neece
Let me alone. I'le fit her with a match.
I know a Lad that's worthy of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hell laugh too much, I feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: He may at you,
For your officiousnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Ha, ha.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: To thrust your self into unthankful offices.
In things concerne you not. Will you turne Matchmaker
For others un-intreated, 'tis enough.
For you, I hope, that you have match't your selfe, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hah! Do you hab, or talk to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Who else
Should talk or give you counsel but your wife?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: VVell-said Rachel, hold thine own Rachel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I am match't again.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Pax, cry again, or burst thy self with laugh∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: La. Ha, ha, ha. Laugh son Nehemiah.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Ha, ha. ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: What am I? what do you make of me?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay, what ha' you made your self? best ask the Chimney piece that you have married there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Durst thou advance a voice against me, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: You did commend it in me against your Si∣ster.
And I may better be familiar with you;
Hah, are you not my husband? I am sure
'Tis not so long since we were married, that
You can forget it, or epent so soon.
I am not now your slave, to have my face
Wash't with your snuffes, nor to be kick't and trod on
VVithout resistance, nor to make you answers
Meerly with silent court'sies, run when you bid go
To fetch and carry like your Spaniel,
In which condition I livd long enough,
And was content until ou freed me out on't.
Now free I am, and will be a free woman,
As you are a free-man, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: O base-borne begger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: You wrong your wife in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: How she holds up the wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I never beg'd
Nor mov'd a lip to be your wife, not I,
You held my service portion good enough,
And for my blood 'tis no more base then yours,
Since both are mixt in marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Come your way.
And let me hear you speak so much at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I hope I may be bolder in mine own house.
So Madam, for the love I have found in yours,
You shall be welcome thither, when y' are sent for.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What a bold piece of Kitchin-stuffe is this?
Brothery' are match't.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: And catch't ifacla, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: He has not a word to speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Follow me home and durst.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Yes sir, I dare without more leave taking, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Was ever combe so cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: There's a new Aunt indeed! she brought me nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: I have not laught so much I know not when,
H'has made me laugh until I cry agen.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Again, you are welcom, Sir, Mrs. Blith
Now the unwelcome guests are gone, lets in
And dine, then will we after meat

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.L: Of Joinctures, Madam, and of Nuptials treat.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Right sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Love, as I shall adore thee for a deity.
Rid me of this ridiculous society.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Matchil, Rachel, between Erasmus and Valentine.

SP.SPEAKER: Eras.
SP.P: GOod Mr. Matchil.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Mystris, be not so violent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I'll rather run my Countrey, Gentlemen, then endure her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: You were best to kill her then, and then you'll have no other course to take, unlesse you stay and be∣hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I'le make thee glad to flie first.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: From my house and husband shall I? from my possessions shall I? And leave you all to spend in riot shall I? No sir, I'le stay and spend my share if you go to that, that will I. And make all flie as well as you, and you go to that, that will I, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Whoop, whow.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: Nay, fle be not so loud.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: What didst thou bring thou drudge thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: That which you were content to drudge withal, I am too sure o' that. The drudge you speak of is no worse then your own wife, I am too sure o'that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: I know not what to say to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Did you not fay for better, for worse? And if 'twere worse then 'tis, 'twere all too good for you. And that I hope I shall finde some good Friend to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: That I like well, I'le be her first man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I trust you have found the drudge to be a woman fit to content a man, and if you grant not that, some better man perhaps shall be a Judge, betwixt you and the drudge.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Better still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: She threatens hornes. I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Hornes. I think, you said. If 'twere so 'twere too good for you. Cannot your own wife content you, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: She holds up that point stoutly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: That shall be tri'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: O for an expert Chyrurgion now to cast her in a dead sleep, and geld her.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: Introth you will be both sorry, when your passion gives but least way to your understandings. Mr. Matchil, let me perswade with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Never uniesse you bring her on her knees, to crave forgivenesse at my foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: If you but yield an inch he treads upon your neck, I will not give an under spur-leather for you. But bear it out bravely, and I'll be your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: Mrs. Matchil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Mrs. Match-ill indeed, to be so match't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: So match't▪ how match't? what from the hur∣den sinock with lockram upper-bodies, and hempen sheets, to weare and sleep in Holland, and from the dripping-pan to eat in silver, ha. Do you repine at your Match, ha. Is wealth contemptible to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I was better content in my povertie. I have not been my selfe, Gentlemen, since he marri∣ed me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mas.
SP.P: You may be poor again as soon as you please, the door is open, depart at your pleasure; you know the way to your old Aunt the Apple-woman, at Hock∣ly-hole. Take your knitting Needles again, and live with her, go.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: No sir, I'll stay with you, and make you as poor before I have done wi' ye, as I was before you had me Gent. I shall not be my self till then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: The devil you shall. Was ever such a crook∣ed condition crept into a thing like woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Yet this sir, is the rare piece of obedience
You boasted of, and said you would defie
The devil to dishonest her, I am sorry
Your judgement led you into such an errour,
Already she's my Mystresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Is she so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Yes, and Ile call him servant, Gentlewomen use it.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Do so, Mystresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: If she, sir, be your Mystresse, Then am I
Your Master-in-law, out of my house I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Doest thou conspire to grieve him?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Troth, sir, I did but jest. You have my pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: All are not times for Jest, friend Valentine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat
SP.P: O my affliction!

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: Have a little patience, sir.
SP.L: While I talk calmly with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Leave me then
A while unto my thoughts. Go into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Pray servant help me here a little. Do so much
As winde up my Jack for me, my Watch I would say.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Her Jack▪ she's in the Kitchin still.
A pretty Watch this, Mystresse, what did you pay for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Nothing, my husband ga't me.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Pity the Spring is broke, but I can get it mended.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Good servant take it with you then to the Jack-makers, I would say, the Watch-makers. Come Gentlemen, shall we have a crash at cards?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.P: With all my heart. What is your game?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I can play a many old games. One and thirty bone-ace, Tickle me quicklie, and my Ladies hole, and sichie. But you shall teach me new ones, though I lose money for my learning, Gleek and Primero, Gresco saut, primofistula, I know all by hear-say. Come let us have a bout at somewhat. I have money e∣nough.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: And I'le make shift to ease you of some on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Affliction on affliction hourely findes me,
And layes me on the Rack, tearing my heart
Like greedie vultures, O my heart, this heart
That I so long suppos'd impenetrable
By all the darts of sorrow, is now transfixt,
Shot through and through with torments, and by this.
This last made sensible of all the rest.
My sons untimely death, my daughters losse.
My Sisters follies, and my Brothers vices.
My servants falshood, and the jeers of strangers
Now wound me all at once; and all through this
Predominant blow, pull'd on me by mine own
Impetuous rashnesse. Let me here consider,
While my hearts torture keeps my soule awake,
The moving cause of all these ill effects.
Mine own unbridled wilde affections.
Scorne of example, and contempt of counsel.
I cannot but observe withal, how just,
A judgement follows mine own wilful acts,
In the same kinde of doing ills for ills.
For my lost sonne, I rashly wrought revenge
Upon an innocent Girle; and with her
Have lost mine own; and for th'unmanly joy
I took in one wives death, because a Shrew.
(Though otherwise vertuous) I am in another
Trebly tormented; not alone with noise,
But with a feare of unchaste purposes,
Which if they come to act, my purse must pay for.
I see my faults, and feel the punishments.
And rather then stand out in my defence
T'enjoy some peace, I will endure some sorrow
And beare it civilly. Within there.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Go call your Mystresse, pray her to come a∣lone.
My resolution brings me yet some ease:
Men that are borne to serve, must seek to please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Rachel.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra
SP.L: Your pleasure quickly, I have left
My company, my servant, and my friend yond,
Sawing against one another at Corne the Caster; till I come to 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: And then all three to In and In, is't so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: My servant, and my friend and I are e'ne all one.
They are the goodest Gentlemen, the best com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Your servant and your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Yes, and my servant playes for me now in my absence, as farre as ten pieces go that I left him. My plow goes there, though I am here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: Your plow makes vile baulkes of my money the while.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I am not so ill a huswife as you imagine. And my friend, and my servant have promis'd to carry me abroad, to this town, and to that town, and tother town, and whow, I know not whither. And my ser∣vant will have me to Hide-Park he sayes, to see and to shew all, as well as the brave Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: This is gallant indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: And my friend will carry me to a whatdeecall, a new Academy, where I shall see the rarest musick and dancing, he sayes, and learn the finest Complements. and other courtly qualities that are to be had for mo∣ney, and such instructions for the newest fashions

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: She will flie to the devil for fashions sake. Pray stay a little, and let me talk calmely with you. You have almost broke my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: But not altogether, I hope. I would not win so great a game, without some sport in playing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hear me.
I know you put on this affected carriage,
But to try masterie, and the disease
Being so general among all women,
Is in you therefore more excusable.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: O, are you coming?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Hear what I will say to you.
And finde in that a husbands good affection.
I love my peace, and would preserve my honour,
Both which are in your breasts to save or spoil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: And can you think the way to purchase peace
Is by a war with me? hah, you are cozen'd.
Do you think your domineering looks, or noise,
Or blowes, can fright me into quietnesse,
Or that you shall have honour by abasing
Your wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You will not understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Hah.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Though I love peace, and would preserve my honour.
I'le yield in both to you, and can, (I have been
So usd to thraldome) But the world, the world
Is such a Talker.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I have found the man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: There I would save a reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: He's loth to bring it out; I'le close w'ye.
You'll be content so, I will suffer you
To bear a loud command o're me in publick,
That I shall carrie it in private. Is't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Truly wife, yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: You'll give me leave to beat you
In private then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Nay, we'll bar blowes at all times.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: But if I chance to give you a rap or two,
Or now and then a nip, and you strike me
Again, I'le strike you some way else, as you
Would not be struck. And so observe my carriage.
The Gentlemen are coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: O, here they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And not by the eares: that's wonderful.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Sir, I perceive my errour, and repent it.
Promising you in all my after life,
To be a faithful and obedient wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: He has fetch't her about, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Grammercy Rachel, binde it with a kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: And thus it should be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Gentlemen, have ye found us?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: With joy to see this reconciliation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Thus shall ye see it ever, Gentlemen.
I knew she would yield, or I should make her heart ake.
What were a husband, if he were not Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: You have wonne the sield, it seems, yet I may hope
I have not lost a Mystresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Nor I a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: In a faire way, Gentlemen, I shall
Abridge her of no courtly priviledge.
But no more haytie twaytie tricks, I charge you.
She shall not jaunt to this nor that town with you.
(I thank you for your care) nor to Hide-Park.
Nor to the Academy you tell her of, without my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And do you say so Mystresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Truly yes.
I am no such woman as you took me for,
With Mr. Matchils leave you may be welcome
Home to his house in good and seemly sort.
Put pray expect no further entertainment
Then he shall well allow of.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I have lost her.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: This change is admirable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Why do you admire it.
Is she not mine? how could you think she durst
Stand out in her rebellion? although the devil
Who soothes all Upstarts dispositions
Into an over-weening of themselves.
Possest her for a time, had not I power
And vertue do you think to conjure him out?
What have I studied for, think you, e're since
My last wife di'd, but how to rule the next?
Go get you in, there's something in the house
Worth looking after.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I be sworn, he frights her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Would I had you within to perform covenants.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: What do you grow rebellious again.
Why stir you not else, ha? prithee Sweetheart
Respect my dignity, or only seem to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Yes, I will only seem to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: He makes her tremble.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Gentlemen, I must about my house-ffaires.
So, I take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Er. Val.
SP.L: Good Mrs. Matchil.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Aha.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: And Mr. Matchil, at your own good pleasure.
Having in private something to impart to you,
I would entreat your presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Well, Anon, anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Your eare before I go good Mr. Matchil.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: H'has brought her to her servile old obedi∣ence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: O—oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: That is a private touch, sir, of the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Pox of your Lobster claws. There waanip▪

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: It will be worth consideration, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Well, Ile come to you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I humbly take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Any ill newes that you change colour so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: No, nothing, nothing but a womanish feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Well, you are a happy man that have o' recom her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.P: You know not me yet Gentlemen, I know a word in private would do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Yet she desires to have you again in pri∣vate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Tis her abundant love, and pure obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: She comes again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Since y'are not yet dispos'd to cnter, sir.
One word more, Mr. Matchil, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Oh,—I understand you. Go, I'le follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Again, I take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I must weare Lantern-hornes upon mine arms,
If she use this. Well, Gentlemen, at your own time
Lets see yee. My Rach. shall make you welcome,
And for me, you know me, I will still be Master.—
I come, I come, I come. So, farewel Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Ha, do you run?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: What doest thou think of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I'le lay all the tricks I have against his brags.
She masters him in private, and that all
This shew of her obedience is dissembled.
My hope revives again; we must abroad with her.
But tell me, what new Academy's that
You told her of, I understand not that yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Nor have I seen it, but we both will shortlie.
'Tis but of two or three dayes standing yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Where is it? who are the Professours,
And what the Arts?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I'le tell thee all know.
It carries a love-sound; but I am told
It is but private lodgings kept by
Both men and women, as I am inform'd, after the French manner.
That professe Musick, Dancing, Fashion, Comple∣ment.—

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And no drabbing?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: A little perhaps in private.
But guesse now in whose house all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Even in your City-Mystresses, that lends you
Money so freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Who Camelion?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Yes sir, I doubt, your borrowing of the wife
Has broke the husband, put'hem off their trade,
And now they seek new wayes to live by projects.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And could you keep this from me all this while,
Till I am there, each step's a tedious mile.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: But not without me, good Val. We'll finde a time.
Together, and our Mrs. Matchil with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Cock, I protest Cock, I commend thy course
Thou hast taken in brave Lodgers, gallant Guests,
Guests o'th' Game Cock; and my house is counted
A house of quality and recreation, Cock,
In civil sort and gentle fashion, Cock,
Sbobs Cock, I know thou wouldest not have it other∣wise
For all the wealth i'th' Exchange.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: But Rafe you care not
What people say, so I bring you in profit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Not I, not I, my little Cocksie Nansie,
Not I, pish, Hony soit qui maly pense.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Some do not stick to say, I know what's what,
And that our house is no better then it should be.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Pish, Hony soit agen, i'th' very teeth of 'hem,
Let 'hem all say what they will. Dainty come thou to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: But I know what I know, and that our house is
Better then it should be, if some of them
Had but the keeping of it, that speak so ill on't.
And that the Gentlewomen in our house
Are well-condition'd, and as chaste as courteous.
And if you saw, (as they desire I should
See all betwixt their great Resorts and them)
You'd be in love with their sweet way of living.
Then for their dancing, 'tis so neat and graceful.
See 'hem anon at practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Not I, Cock, I'le see nothing.
I will not leave one ducking pond, for ten dancing schooles.
Yet I can dance, and love it: you know that Cock.
And though you are a Gentlewoman borne,
You took me for my legs, not or my armes.
Is not that a good Jest, Cock. Sbobs 'twas out before
I was aware. Here comes their father.
SP.STAGE: Enter Strigood, Cash, disguiz'd in bravery.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: It seems he has brought in some new scholar.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Where are my daughters, Landlady.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Close in their chamber, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Are none of our Academicks come yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Not any, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I look for some anon
Pray bid the Girles come down
To practise.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Sir, when I was a Batchelour, I practis'd,
Dauncing sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Indeed, good Landlord?

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: And maugre wedloek, I have something left
Yet in these legs, that can expresse at least
Love to the quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: That shall not be lost,
If I can further it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I saw last night
Your new French daunce of three, what call you it?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: O the Tresboun.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I think I could make one in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: This Gentleman's another, call the Musick.
I'le try what you can do.
Cash, Thou art welcom, I am glad I met thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: But that you had foreknowledge of my habit,
And seen it in my out-leaps, as you call 'hem,
I might ha' past. But you in this disguise,
None but the devil himself that is your Inmate,
And lodges with you in it, could have known you.
Sure he devis'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: No, you are short.
I learn't it of a Jesuite.
And 'twas but easie: shaving of my old
Gray haire and beard off; clapping on this perrule
After the fashion; having but few wrinkles.
(For which I thank my Batchelourship, I passe
For a brisk youth. But for my Hannibal eye here. And by my brothers
Courteous advice I have ta'ne a course to live
Vpon my stock of wit, slight and activity,
With nimble braine, quick hands, and aery heels, as he told me, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: He could not think you would have stolne his daughter to ha' set up withal.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: But now I care not
What the wretch thinks, so he discovers nothing,
I dare trust thee Cash, partly on thy Oath
Which I have ta'ne you know: but more respectively
Upon your fourty pieces here, friend Cash,
Which I have also ta'ne: but most of all
For that I know you dare not make discovery,
For feare of Little-ease. That were a prison
Too fearful for such bravery to stoop into.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: That keeps me still in awe. 'Tis well you know it.
But it is better, he has no suspition
That I am run away.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: The Musick's ready, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Play then,—the Tresboun.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: 'Twas very well done, Landlord, I protest
I love your house the better for your quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: But if you saw me at the ducking pond,
Me and my Trull.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Your Trull?

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I mean, my bitch, sir.
O she would ravish you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Some other time.
Here comes your wife. The newes good Landlady?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Newes out of France, your fame is spread a∣broad.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: How out of France?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Two young French Gentlemen.
New come ashore, the daintiest sweetest Gentlemen
That e're I saw (now you'll be jealous Rafe)

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Are come to lodge here, having heard
It seems, that you professe French qualities.
And instantly desire to be acquainted
With you and your sweet company.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Can they speak English?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: One very well: and the tother can say
Tree Fransh crown for two English kisse already,
Now be jealous Rafe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Pish, Hony soit qui maly pense.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: You can speak French, Landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: So much as you have heard, not one word more.
I assure you but this, Adieu Monsieur and so
I leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Will you not see the Gallants Rafe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Not I, I wo'nt be jealous Cock, and so▪
By the Back-door to the ducking pond. I go.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Enter then Landlady, where be these Girles?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Here they are come.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Stand aside Cash, and be not yet discovered.
Now Ladies, how do y'like your way of living?

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I do not like it Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: Troth, nor I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: We eat and lodge well; and we weare good cloathes.
And keep our credit in the house we live in,
But what we suffer in our reputation
Abroad, is dangerously doubtful.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: So, so.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: Here we are view'd and review'd by all com∣ers.
Courted and tempted too, and though w'are safe
In our chaste thoughts, the impious world may say,
We are set out to common sale.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: So, so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: And so you are to th' utmost of his power
I dare be sworue;

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: But Uncle, for the time that you intend
To stay, I pray admit no new acquaintance,
Nor any more, lest I for my escape
Venture a leap two stories deep.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Ha! you said?
You know I have disclos'd you to no eye
That could take knowledge who or whence you are,
And for the forrein strangers, and such Townsfolks
As knew us not; what need we weigh their thoughts.
Their gold is weight; let that be all we look to.
While our deserving arts and qualities
Require it from 'hem. If they think us wicked,
And hope to get Virginities for salary,
And pay for their deluded hopes before-hand.
What is our act bnt Justice on their follies,
In taking of their prodigal coine?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: I hope,
You deal not that way for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Never fear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: But Uncle, though you have taught us courtly
Gypsie tricks.
That somewhat trench upon our modesties.
Pray let it not be thought we'll sell our honesties.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Trust to my care.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: And thats the way to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: And in that care be confidently seen,
By a deserving Gentleman, whom I
Present to kisse your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I will see none.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: You need not feare me, Lady; for I can
But tell your father, if you slight his servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: Blesse us! what Metamorphosis is this?
'Tis Cash your fathers man.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: Is this the habit of a Merchants Prentice?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Is this the lodging of a Merchants daugh∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: Has his great marriage turn'd my fathers house
Into a sumptuous Palace, that he keeps
Such costly men. Or doth the bravery
Of his late beauteous Bride require such gorgeous
Attendants? Pray what office may you fill
About her person.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Will you home and see?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: We are betray'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha. Be not afraid of Cash.
I know him, and he knows us. He is our friend
And we'll be his. As for his bravery
'Tis no new thing with him. I know him of old.
This sute's his worst of foure.
And he's one
Of the foure famous Prentices o'th' time.
None of the Cream and Cake-boyes, nor of those,
That gall their hands with stool-balls, or their Cat∣sticks,
For white-pots, pudding-pies, stew'd prunes, and Tansies.
To feast their Titts at Islington or Hogsden.
But haunts the famous Ordinaries o'th' time,
Where the best chear, best game, best company are fre∣quent.
Lords call him Cousin at the Bowling Green; And the great Tennis-Court.
Thy fathers money
Would rust else, Girle. Keep thou our Councel Cash.
And we'll keep thine, though't be to the undoing
Of him and all the wretches of his brotherhood,
That love their money, and their base desires,
Better then blood or name.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: But can you hold
It good in any servant so to hazard
His Masters livelihood.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Can you hold your peace?
He's wise, and saves by't all this while: He knows
His friends are bound in full two thousand pounds,
For's truth, and his true service, and perhaps,
He is not out above one thousand yet,
Where's your wit now?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Mystresse, I'le do you service, and be true to you.
I'd not have mist of this discovery.—

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: You see she hearkens to him. Talk aside Cash.
And touch her boldly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I would not have mist it.
For all the wealth your father has: and at
Convenient privacy. Ple give you reasons,
That shall gaine your belief to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: The French Gallants.
I had almost forgot them. They are a paire
Of delicate young Monsieurs. If they have
But crownes enough, they are the likelicst
Merchants for my new Mart that I can choose.
She said they can speak English, that's a help.
For devil of French have I to entertain 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: See mine own heart, here's more temptation still.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I'le not endure the onset.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I le defend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: Yet there are graces in their looks methinks,
That do invite my stay.

L.HI: N' entendes vous, la langue francois Mon∣sieur dittez.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I would be glad to heare you speak the lan∣guage
I better understand, and that is English.
In which you are most welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: Your faire courtesie
Merits our greatest thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Gali.
SP.L: I tanck you, sir.
I have bid Fraunce adieu to come and learn
De English very well; I speak a lietel,
But de English Mesteresse can teach de best.
I shall be glad to take my commencements,
Or my first Lessons from these Ladies lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: A fine forward spark?

SP.SPEAKER: Gali
SP.L: O sweet, O delicate.
Ladies, if you will breath into me English,
I shall, if you please, put Fransh into you.
Ʋne pour l'antre, dat is one for anoder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: So they might make a hot bargain on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: Are these your Civil Gentlemen, Landlady?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: He seems a little waggish: but the other
Is wondrous civil. He comes blushingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: You are before me in the Salutation
Of these faire Ladies, Monsieur Galiard:

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.L: Il E'vray Monsieur Papilion, I kisse before, then you mose kisse behind.
But let me pray my tardinesse be excus'd

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: You pronounce English well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: I am glad
You like it Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: I like the others as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: I have before spent many monethes in Eng∣land:
And my great love unto the Nation,
Especially to the beauties of your Sexe,
Retracts me hither, where my friend was never.
Till now that my perfwasion wonne his company;
And happily, I suppose, we are arriv'd:
That, to the sight and knowledge we have had
Of Musick, Daunces, Courtships, and Behaviour.
Through all parts of our Countrey, France, with an
Addition of all Italy affords.
Where (by all best opinions) even the choicest
Of such court qualities, and active graces,
Have had their Spring, we now, as Fame suggests,
Shall in this faire Society, discerne
More then by all our former observation.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Report, sir, speaks too loud on our behalfe,
And let me pray ye, that it not beget
Too great an expectation on our weaknesse,
By your too gentle suffrage. What we can,
We'll do.

SP.SPEAKER: Gali.
SP.L: O wee dats de best. Doe is de ting
De Fransh man loves: If all your both two daugh∣ters
Shew all; all makes but more desire to do.
Speak I no good English, Madamoiselle?

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I understand you not.

SP.SPEAKER: Gali.
SP.L: You no understand me,
Because you tinck I lie. But if you lie
With me, I make you understand me presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: This hot-rein'd Mousieur takes 'em for the same.
Strigood would have 'em be I came in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: At afternoon we'll have an exercise
Of courtship, Gentlemen. In the Interim,
If you will have to stir the appetite,
A dance before our Ordinary we are for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gali.
SP.L: And we for you Alloun al Egremant Alloun

L.HI: Monsieur Papillion pour l' honour de France.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: VVhat are your dances chiefly in request.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Good Landlady, bid the Musick be in radinesse.
And then see dinner set upon the table.
We have Sir for Corants,—La Miniard,

L.HI: La Vemimde, Le Marquesse, Le Holland,
La Brittaine, Le Roy, Le Prince, Le Montague,

SP.L: The Saraband; the Canaries, La Reverree.
For Galliards, the Sellibrand, the Dolphine,
The new Galliard, the Valette Galliard and lepees,

SP.SPEAKER: Gali.
SP.L: 'Tis all very good Monsieur Papillica Essontes

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: And heark you, Monsieur Strigood, you will be put to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I feare no French flashes. Beare up Cash. If we cannot daunce 'hem of o' their legs, our wenches can,
I warrant thee. Musick be ready.
Gallants, what are you pleased to daunce?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: tells what, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Gentlemen, your dinner stays meat will be cold.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: And we are hot, 'tis better that take cold then we.
But come, one table for us all.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Stri. Agreed, agreed, agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I say so too.
But to my self reserve what I will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: EPhraim, thou hast made me a man, both without, witnesse this sword and within, witnesse this precious book, which I have gotten al∣most by heart already.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: But sir, beware you fall not back again Into your childish follies: but go forwards In manly actions: for non progredi est regredi.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: I know the meaning of that too, Ephraim. That's once a man and twice a childe. But if I turne childe again, while I have teeth in my head, 'le give Mrs. Blithe leave to dig 'hem out with Sugar∣plums, as she almost did these two of 'hem yesterday, with her knuckles. I would they stuck both in her bum for't, till I wee married to her, and that shall be shortly, they say, I wo' not turne boy again for that trick.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: I hope you will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P:
Thou mayest be sure on't Ephraim: for if I would turne boy again, I ha' not wherewithal to set up again. Thou sawest that, assoon as I had tasted the sweetnesse of this delicous book here, I tore and burnt all my ballats, as well the godly as the ungodly. In my conscience as many as might have furnish't three Bartholomew Faires, and then for love of this sword, I broke and did away all my storehouse of tops, gigs, bls, cat and catsticks, pot-guns, key-guns, trunks, tillers, and all; and will I turne boy again canst think? ye I am half sorry, being towards a wife, that I did
not keep 'hem for my children: some money might have been sav'd by't. And that is a manly and a good husbandly consideration, I take it. But hang covetous∣nesse: There comes not a mouth into the world, but there's meat for t; and if I finde 'em not play games, their mother will finde friends, that shall, for them and her selfe too

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: I'm glad to heare such good things to come from you,
And hope that now your judgment's strong e∣nough
To manage my affair. You know my minde, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Amardla Ephraim, 'twill be hard to compasse. For the old Knight will never let me have his Neece, unlesse he have my mother. He meanes to truck for her, though, I confesse, I had rather call thee father then any man, I know, yet I know not how to bring it about, unlesse he marry her first; and then she be weary of him, and take thee afterwards to mend her match. I think it must be so, Amardla Ephraim.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: Now you flie out again, that's as impos∣sible, as 'tis unlawful.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Peace, my mother comes.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Where are you childe? Neh.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: I hear her neighing after me, I'le do all I can for thee, Amardla Ephraim.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Look you onne, what kinde Sir Swithin has sent you. A dancing frog, you would think it were a∣live, and a ballet of burning the false prophets before they be tried. And another fearful one of the new Antichrist.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Hang bawbles, burn ballets, I am a man, and defie boyes tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: A sudden change, I pray it be good.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Tell me of toyes? I have a sword: offer me ballets? I have a book. Speak to me of Sir Swithin, I'le talk to you of Ephraim that gave me these bles∣sings; and is fitter to be my father, (so he is) then the foolishest Knight of 'em all.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Blesse my sonne from too much learning. That book has done him no good, I doubt. He talks and looks so wildly o'the sudden.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: A ha!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What book is't. Let me see it.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: I'le tell you first. It is a book all of Bulls, Jests and Lies Collected by an A. S. Gent. Mother f'sooth, there be such things in it! If you never reade it, it is the rarest book that ever you read in your life. Open it where you will, and you shall learn something. As here now. One refusing to eat Cheese∣cakes, was ask't his reason. He told them he lov'd the flesh well, but was afeard of the bones. Then here's the next to't. One asking whence Lobsters were brought: his fellow repli'd, one might easily know their countrey by their coat. They are fetch't from the red sea. Now would I might never eat more of 'hem, as well as I love 'hem, if I know what Cheese-cakes were made of, or from whence Lobsters came be∣fore.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Is this your book-learning? In troth thou mak'st me laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Laugh on, good Mother. And while you are in the merry mood, let me speak a good word for E∣phraim. I have a minde f'sooth, because he has made me a man, to make him my father, f'sooth.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What, what! How now.
How durst you firrah, move my sonne in this? ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Is it but so? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Pray f'sooth hear him speak. He can speak Po∣etry (he sayes) as well as Knight Whimlbie. Speak Ephraim.

L.HI: Keeper in wedlock. These did wisely know,
Inferiour men best could their work below.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Mother f'sooth, Is it not fine?

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: Nay, Madam, more then so, I'le further go

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But you shall not, Sirrah. What, what! how now! Is't but up and ride? ha! Out of my doors thou varlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: I must out too then, mother I am afraid, oh.—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Good Neh. be pacified, I'le give him a better answer.
SP.L: But not a word on't now, sweet childe, I pray thee.
Here comes Sir Swithin.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I marry Sir Swithin. This is better then O Ma∣dam, O—, when you wash't your handkerchiefs in the suds, and then to wring hem out in Poetry.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P:
My tears with the memory of the dead are all fallen into Lethe; and nothing but joy left in me, sinc my hopes are confirm'd in your lap. And hang
Poetry: I study profit now. Therefore, look you, Madam, here is a draught of my marriage-instrument to your lap.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: His instrument being drawn, I must put up my pipe and be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: VVhi.
SP.P: And here is another draught for sweet Master Nehemiah, for my Neece Blithes Joincture.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: O but she sayes she will not have me.

SP.SPEAKER: VVhi.
SP.P: When did she say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Now, now, she spat the word out of her mouth. And I say, if she ha' not me, you shall whine both your eyes out before you have my mother; and see ne're the worse, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: A crosse marriage, or no marriage, I say still.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I say so too, sonne, Sweet boy, be content.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi. Blithe.
SP.P: You spoke well of him behinde his back: and made me think you lov'd him, and would marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: Behinde his back, I may do much to please you. But when I look upon him, he turnes my stomack worse then a fool made of soure wilk.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Marry Gip, Mrs Queasie, my sonne's as sweet as you, I hope, and as wise as you. And suck't as sweet milk as ever the good Cow your mother gave.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Patience, good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.P: I hope the crosse marriage is crost. This is untoward wooing.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Uds so! do you flirt out your unsavoury com∣parisons upon my sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: Flirt not you at me, Madam, lest I flirt your milk-sop under the snotty nose here.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Yes, and I have a sword, and you ha' got ne're a one.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You wo' not will you, ha! Do you flie at him, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Fear not, good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Ephraim, save my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.—

SP.SPEAKER: Whi
SP.P: She shall not hurt him. Leave her to me, good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I ever fear'd he was not long-liv'd he was so witty. And now I feare, she will be the death of him. I would not he should marry her for a million.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh
SP.P: Say not so, mother. I love her better and better still.
I never had play-fellow i my life, but we fell out and in agen.
And I must and will marry her, I take my death on't a∣forehand.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: O me! he is bewitch't to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Leave all to me, dear Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: As I am to you, I think, Sir Swithin.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Let me alone with her: I'le win her, and he shall wear her▪ feare not. As was saying, Madam, she speaks as well of him behinde his back, as your owne heart can wish. And told me she was content to mar∣ry him.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Behinde his back? did she so?

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Yes truly, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Loe you there, mother, Let her marry me behind my back then: And when we are marri'd, I'le make her stick to't before my face, I warrant you; or if she will make back-play. I'le play at nothing but back∣gammons with her.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Well, Heaven blesse thee, thou art but too good for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Speak gently, Neece, I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli
SP.P: Madam, I hope your Ladiship shall finde me too good for him. If e're he has me.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Ha! say you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: She meanes in well-doing, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay then, I thank you Mrs. Blithe. Assuring you that you shall be no way so good to him, but I will be as good to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Agreed again of all hands. But look how she turnes and keeps cut like my Sparrow. She will be my back Sweet-heart still I see, and love me behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: She is yet raw, and has not much been abroad to see the manners of the time. In which my melan∣choly has been her main hinderance. But Madam, there is now that is worth all our sight and observation; A new Academy, where they say, the newest and most courtly carriage and behaviour is taught and pra∣ctised both for young Gentlemen and women. Have you not heard on t?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Yes Sir Swithin; and that the French tongue is taught there with great alacrity; and my sonne is wish't thither, but soft I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: But let him see it: at least in our company it will embolden him; I mean to carry my Neece thither. I have been a Lover of Arts and Exercises; and know somewhat since my youth. Pray let us spend one houre of this afternoon there.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Pardon me good sir Swithin.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: But he shall not mother if you love me: for I mean to perfect my dancing there; and to learn French there; For I mean when I am married to travel into France. But I will first be perfect in the tongue I shall learne it the sooner when I am there you know. Pray let us go to th' Acomedy, what dee call it?

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: The Academy.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Say you so sonne? then come sir Swithin. Come Mrs. Blithe, we will all go.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: I'le wait upon you, though my heart sayes no.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: O mine own heart! how near were we both fallen
Into the Gulf of Ruine?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: Thanks for our delivery!
We were upon the brink of main destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: Was ever such a Frend as this mine Vncle?
Pretending us his children too, and call'd us daugh∣ters
To those he bargain'd with to sel our Maide head?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: 'Twas a most damnable practise sie upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: And had the Monsieurs been as capable
Of our Virginities, as he was of.
Their moneys, how had we then resisted.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: By Venus (mine own heart) my Gentleman
Came up so close to me, that if my voice
Had not been stronger then mine armes (O me!
I tremble fon it yet) I had been vanquish't,

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: But did you note the vertue of the Gentle∣men?
When they were sensible of our feares and tears,
How gently they desisted and with what humanity,
When they perceiv'd how we had heen betrayd,
They pitied our conditions; and woo'd homditly
Our loves in way of marriage. Provided that
Our births and fortunes might no way disparage
Theirs, being free and generous

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: I confesse
I love 'hem both so well, that if they prove
(As they pretend they are not) our inferiours
In blood and worth, I would take either of'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: Troth (mine own heart) 'tis just the same with me.
I care not which I have. And mark a sympathy,
How equally all our ffections strike.
We both love them, they both love us alike.
But peace. Cash, though he has done us good service,
Must not know all. How goes it within Cash?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: And why Cash pray. Ha' not you chang'd your names
From Joyce and Gabriella to Jane and Frances.
And is not your Uncle Strigood now become
Your father, by the name of Mr. Lightfoot
The nimble dancing Master? And must I still
Carry the name of Cash? and having lost
My nature too, in having no cash left?
(Pox o'the dice) call me Mr. Outlash.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: My father will fetch you home with an Inlash,
One o'these dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: But after you, faire Mistris,
Now to your question for the squares within.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I with the Frenchmen, and my Uncle Stri∣good.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Your father Lightfoot, you forget agen.
There's a drawn match made: For the Monsieurs
Have ta'ne their money again: And you have still
Your Maidenheads, I hope. But to have heard
The coie they kept, the wrangle, and the stir;
And how the young Blades put the old one to't;
Would ha perplext you more then keeping of
Your Maidenheads from men you love.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: You cannot tell that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: O how the old man chafes that you would offer
To make your mone to hem to move their pity,
And not to make his bargain good; and then
How they put home his basenesse to him; to make sale
Of his own blood and honour in his children.
(They knew they said some parents in their coun∣trey,
After their children were turn'd whores, would share
To live upon the profits, but to sell
Their soules before they were damned, fie; fie, fie, fie).
Till he confest indeed you were none of his.
But children of some friends of his deceast,
Left to his care sor breeding; which he had
Plenteously given, and thought it might seem reason∣able
To raise his money out of you agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: What an old devil is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Baser and baser still.
The Monsieurs cri'd, and swore if they could sinde
Your Parents were Gentle and vertuous,
Being their first Loves, they would marry you,
To free you from this miserable thraldome.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: Brave honest Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: Be advis'd though, Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: I hope I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Beware of Travellers, many passe abroad
For gallant fellowes that have run their countrey,
For picking pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: And some you know at home
For cozening their Masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: You are pleas'd.
But you have known my love; for Gabriella
Let'hem share her betwixt 'hem. You and I
Made one, may soon make peace with the old man
At home.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: O Rogue! I'le tell you more anon Cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Come Gentlemen, Monsieur Papillion.
And Monsieur Galliard, all friends, all friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: A greed, agreed, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gall.
SP.L: And agree for me.
Agree poor tout.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Chear up your faces Girles.
'Twas but my trial of your chastity.
And since you have stood firme, I am proud of you.
Trust me, 'twas but to try you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gall.
SP.L: Wee wee All, but for try. Trimount, tri∣mount.
No more, but all for try: no man can tinck,
But'twas too very moshe to take two hundred
Crowns for two pusillages, no, no was but
For try: but and she had not squeek and scrash too
Like to do leetel chat, I had Trimount
One, two, tree, five time, for all your try.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: VVhat's past let be forgot. According to
Agreement, Gentlemen, y'are now content
To joyne with us in Academick fellowship,
And for your pastime professe Art and Science,
As we do for our profit: y'are expert,
I finde; and shall winne wonder of our Nation,
To your own much delight out of their follies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: And then for Gamesters, Gentlemen. If youll play.
I'le bring ye those shall venture money enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: VVe are planted to our wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Gall.
SP.L: All very good.
All very good; but I would see thee first.
VVhat Ladies will come here to practise complement.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: You are still hot upon the female Monsieur Galliard
Monsieur Papillion here flies over hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, what will this world come to?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Landlady, the newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: The old will to't.
As well as the young I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: To what Landlady?
SP.STAGE: He takes her aside. And that while the young men and maids court and confer at tother side.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: To fashion following;
A Reverend Lady
Of fifty five; and a Knight of threescore
And upwards, are come hither to learn fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Do you know their names?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Yes, yes: and them; 'tis that
Begets my wonder.
'Tis the Lady Nestlecock, and one Sir Swithin VVhimlby.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: VVit be merciful unto us.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.P: The Ladies man's without: who came to know if the house were ready to entertain 'hem; do you know 'em Mr. Lightfoot?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I have heard o'th' Lady. Cash, see if it be E∣phraim.
He cannot know thee. Let him not away,
By any meanes, his not return to them may keep 'hem back.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: 'Tis he, I see him hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Landlady, is your husband come from duck∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Yes, overjoy'd with the good sport he has had.
He'll play th' good fellow then. Entreat him Cash.
To help thee, put a cup or two upon
That fellow; and hearst me, spice his cup,
I mean, grave Ephraims cup with this same powder,
'Twill lay him asleep, and quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I know the trick on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: And Landlady, when the Knight and Lady come,
Say we are ready for 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: That I shall sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.L: 'Tis then an absolute contract. I am yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: And I am yours as firme as faith can binde.

SP.SPEAKER: Gall.
SP.L: To which we are de witnesse. Be so for us,
I am her husband, And she is my wife,
Speak you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: 'Fore Heaven, I do acknowledge it,
But sir, the Church must be observ'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Gall.
SP.L: For that.
We'll send for one Minister that shall marry
Us all at once. One kisse till then shall serve.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: 'Tis well done Monsieurs, I no sooner turn
My back, but you are on the Damosels lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Gall.
SP.L: A leetel in de honest way will serve,
