But he shall know no-ting.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: On with your Masques-Maids,
And take especial heed you blush not through 'hem.
For here are some at hand will put us to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: 'Tis not my father, nor my Lady Aunt?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I cannot promise you. Be bold and safe.
Beare it out bravely, or our school breaks up
Immediately: and we are broke forever,
Besides, there is no startiug.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: That's enough
To make a coward fight, and mine own heart;
We must stand stoutly to't, we lose our loves else.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.L: Well, I am arm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Fall into complement.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I muse we lost my man thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: By your leave, sir.
Are you the Regent of this Academy?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: I am sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: And are those of your Assistants.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Yes sir, and all Professors of Court-discipline,
By the most accurate, yet more familiar
Rules, then have ever yet been taught by any,
For quick instruction both of young and old.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: You promise very fairly. For us old ones,
We know and could have done things in our youth,
Which still we have a minde to: but we leave
The practice to our young ones: Here's a paire
Would faine be at it. We'll pay their admittance.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: But I'd be glad to see first by your leave,
Some probability of what they shall learn.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: And reason good, good Madam. Pray observe there.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Fair star of courtship, my unworthy humble self, a Profest servant to the integrity of beauty, makes this
Clear testimony of your merits, that every eye that sees you,
Owes you his heart for tribute, and that unjustly your beholders live, that live not in your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Mother f'sooth, is not this French?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Peace chlde. Hear more on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.P: Noble sir, you are so exactly deserving in the opinion of all righteous judgements, that the least syl∣lable of your faire testimony, is able to re-edifie the ru∣ines of a decayed commendation.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: The best that ever I heard, since I woo'd my Grissel.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri,
SP.P: Was not that a sweet bout, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: Yes, yes, it puts me in minde of some sweet bouts I had with one before I married her.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: as he married my Sister troe?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I am forc't to give you over, Madam, you have such a preventing and preoccupying wit in all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: That goes like English Mrs. Blithe. I could learn some of that me thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: Best tell your mother so; she may rejoyce at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: There, Lady, was a taste of sweet comple∣ment between persons equally affected. May it please you now to let your sonne passe upon this demosel. Who being to her a stranger, and raw (as I imagine) in courtship, shall meet with reprehension, that may be for his instruction.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Do Neh. speak to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: Put of your hat and say—.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: What! and her masque on?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: That was well-said. Why are they mask'd, I pray sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: We are commanded it by the policy of wise authority; for feare young heires might fall in love with 'em, and sink their fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You have well satisfied me.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: What should I say to one I never saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: When I was young and bold, I would have said, Lady, you are most auspiciously encountred. And speak it boldly.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Lady, you are most suspiciously accoutred, I speak it boldly.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: Auspiciously encountred man.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Auspicously encountred woman, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I commiserate your encounter. 'Tis a most hungry, verminous, impoverish't word sir. It seems you are a stranger by't, to the Innovation of courtship.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: What should I say to that now?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: He's a weak scholar forsooth, and would be glad to learn.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: The acknowledgement of his weaknesse is the first greece of gradation to perfection, and his glad∣nesse the scaling-ladder of resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Pray f'sooth, can you teach me a complement to offer you sugar-plums, and eat 'hem my selfe: to save my manners and my plums too?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What a wag it is?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: What walking dunghil is this? made of the dust swept from the house of ignorance.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What, what! how now, ha? you are a Flapse to terme my sonne so, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: O good Madam. This is but school play.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I'le put her by her school-tricks and no only nmask, but unskin her face too, and she come over my heire apparent with such Billingsgate Comple∣ments.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Sweet Madam, no harm was meant, and no∣thing said in earnest: 'Twas meerly but school pra∣ctice, but to shew the sweet young Gentleman how he might be subject to the scorne of Court, before he be seen in Complement.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Say you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: 'Twas told your Ladiship before, that by repre∣hension he might finde instructiou.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: Right Madam; For no Fencer learnes his Science before he receive some hits and knocks too: Oh, I have had many.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay, I am satisfied, and pray, that my rash er∣rour may prove pardonable Lady

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Rather let me implore your mercy, Ma∣dam—.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P:
'Tis well, 'tis well Lets hear an Interchange or two now, of complemental acknowledgement of
courtesies past betwixt Ladies, for the edification of his faire one, who seems not yet to have ta'ne notice of us, but looks o' the ground still.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: 'Tis not to finde a fescue, sir, among the Rushes.
To pick out a lesson in your crisse-crosse-row of comple∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: Sharp and sudden. She has a good wit I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: Ob erve, good Blithe, observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Can your poor servant expresse acknowledge∣ment enough, Lady, for favonrs so incessantly heap't upon her, besides the accumulation of many secret be∣nefits?

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.P: I cannot but admire, Madam, your noble and illustrious Gratitude, that can give beauty to benefits of so low a birth and condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: O my Grissel comes to my minde agen, she was the gratefullest woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: If such favours, Madam, should passe under an humble name, Honour would grow idle, and a thankful Nature beguil'd of her emploiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.P: You'l make my zeale hereafter, too bashful to serve your most curious acknowledgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: Curious acknowledgement! There was a thrid drawn out.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I am hound by many kindnesses, Madam, to ce∣lebrate the faire memory of you; as the trouble of your Coach twice in one day, besides those inestimable Jewels, the Monkey and Dormouse your Ladiship sent me.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: I would you could lend me a sight of 'hem for∣sooth, I love such things devoutly.

SP.SPEAKER: Joy.
SP.P: You do but open a privie door to my thankful temembrance, Madam, for the bounty of your Squirrel and Paraquitoe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.P: Fagh, shut that privie-door.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: And shut in the Squirrel and the Paraquitoe to be stifled, shall she? O that I could see hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: Now Madam, and Sir Knight, Is not this neat and handsom?

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.P: Truly, truly, 'tis most admirable pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Nay, if you heard our Lectures, saw our
Daunces.
Relish't our Musick and harmonious voices,
Observ'd our Rules for fashion and attire,
Our many exact postures and dimensions,
Fit to be us'd by way of Salutation,
Of courtesie, of honour, of obeisance,
To all degrees of man or womankind,
From the low bent of vassalage, to the head
Of towring Majesty, you should admire.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But do you reade and teach all these to your scholars?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: Stand forth, Monfieur Galliard. Stay w'are interrupted.
SP.L: Up maids, and quickly; or 'tis not your Masques
Can keep you undiscover'd. Go, be ready,
With Musick and your voices, when I call to yee.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Why are we interrupted? pray proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Mother, it is my naughty Aunt, so 'tis▪

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: No matter, sonne, we'll take no notice of her.
SP.L: I wonder at the boldnesse of the drudge though.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I can turne taile too, as well as the great La∣dy. Hab.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: And do so, Mystresse, give her a broad∣side.
SP.L: Well-said, we'll make our partie good, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Sir, we have heard your Fame; and love your Arts.
pray that our ambition be excus'd,
Which drew on our Intrusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: To me and to the place you are all welcom.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And so to all I hope, chiefly to you,
Good Madam Dowager, hoping in good time
I may get good, by doing much good upon you
How likes your Lpmy complement.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Do you bring your rude companions to affront me? Are you so hot? you stir up your cinders before they be cak't.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Still in the Kitchin-dialect.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: No ruder then your self, hah.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I brought her, Madam,
SP.L: advance my suit to you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Will you see me abus'd
ir , look to your Neece, the t'other talks to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Whi.
SP.P: Kinde merry Gentlemen, Madam, when I was young I would have done the like. Their com∣ing hither, was as ours was to note th' instructi∣ons
That are taught here. Pray sir proceed. On with your exercise, that we may all be edified.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: We shall do so, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: But sir, your Gentlewomen,
SP.L: That past upon our entrance where are they?

SP.P: Sir, they were call'd in haste to private pra∣ctice
SP.L: With some great Ladies in an upper room.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Umh—private practice. Well, I shall know all.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.P: And they being absent, we shall for the pre∣sent
SP.L: Only deliver by these Gentlemen,
me heads of Sciences.
A Song, a Daunce, and then
Entreat you take a taste of a collation.
And all most fairly welcome.
The heads of our chief Arts. Your silence, pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.L: The first is the due carriage of the body,
The proper motion of the head, hand, leg,
To every several degree of person,
From the Peasant unto the Potentate;
To your nferiours how and when to use the Nod,
The Hum, the Ha, the Frown, the Smile,
Upon the fit occassion; and to your equals,
The exactest, newest, and familiar motions
Of eye, of hand, of knee, of arme and shoulder,
That are in Garbe, in Congee, Crindge, or Shrug,
In common Courtesie, or Complement,
Lastly, for your Addresses to Superiours.
The Honours, Reverence, or Obeysances,
Proper unto the quality or estate
Of person whatsoever. And so much
For carriage and behaviour. In the next place
You shall have rules for the more graceful wearing
Of your Apparel, with the natural Reasons,
Why some mans hat does better in his hand
Then on his head, and why his coat hangs neater
Upon his elbow, then upon his back,
As also Reasons for Tunes bringing up.
And marriages, together of the fashions
Of man and woman, how his Caller, and her
Black-bag, came on together; how his pocket-comb
To sprue his Perrule, and her Girdle-glasse,
To order her black pashes, came together;
How his walking in the streets without a cloak
And her, without a man came up together,
Of these, and of a hundred more the like.
We shall demonstrate reasons and instructions.
Shall render you most graceful in each fashion.
The next are skills in instruments, song and dancing

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Enough, those shall be made familiar to you
By voice and action instantly. A Song there.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: Admirable pretty still.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Are these your Gentlewomens voices, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: They are

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: What do you keep 'hem up like Nuns,
To sing and not be seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Not alwayes sir.
But may it please yee Gentlemen and Ladies,
Now to observe the practice of our feet
In active dancing.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: That came I to learn,
And to speak French, do you think sir, you can bring
My mouth to handle the French tongue handsomly.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: He's apt to learn, sir, I can tell you that.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Yes. I shall bring his Mout to it. But his Mont is yet a leetel too wide. But he shall have some of de wa∣ter datde woman use for anoderting, to bring it bet∣ter together, and he shall speak like de Fransh Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.P: Pray sir, if you can like the Ladies daughter of Paris properlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Now Val. thou knowest the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I wonder sir, 'Mongst all your Arts and Sci∣ences
You have so little judgement in a face,
Does his mouth appear wide to you? what false glasse
Are your eyes made of?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.L: What you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Nay, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Pray sir take no offence. Here was none meant.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Slander is no offence then. He has injur'd,
By breathing an aspersion on that face,
The life of beauty, and the soule of sweetnesse.
Wide mouth Y—.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.L: Begar Monsieur, you shall no point out mouth,
No, nor out-face the Frensh man with your great Bull-beef, and Mustard English looks.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Nay, gentle Val. forbear.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I'le stop.
This mouth that knowingly sayes he dares except
Against a tittle of his face or person.
But as he is an ignorant stranger, and
I must respect the company. I forbear.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: However sir, I can but thank your love in 't.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Now it works in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Pardon my plainnesse, Madam.
I never was so ta'ne with Masculine beauty.
And till I winne a woman that is like him,
Or has been like him, I can but languish.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: They told me I was like him, when I was younger.
And let me tell you y' are a comely Gentleman.
And be you but as honest as y' are handsom, you de∣serve well.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Ʋmh, 'tis a hard matter to bring those ends to∣gether.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Mother f'sooth. Here's a man now for you to make my father!
Beyond the Knight or Ephraim!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Were I free from the old Knight, I could look well upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Come servant, come away.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: By no meanes, Mystresse, I do but sooth her up to jeare her for vou.
If you out-stay her not, you lose your honour.
She'll brag she has out-look't you. If you start.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Nay, and she go to that, I hope I can,
Look as ill favouredly as her selfe, or a better
Woman then she, and stay in spight of her, hah.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: 'Tis well done, Mystris, Madam shall I tell you.
But I would pray you not to storme, but laugh at it.
She sayes you are no match for me.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And knowing I aim at none but some great wi∣dow.
Tells me she knows her husband's but short-liv'd.
I fear she means to break his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Say you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: No words, good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: et more whispering.
Pray Madam let us go. Neece come away,
For I fear Madam, as you wisely doubted,
This is no companie for us.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Sir, I hope.
I am not yet so tied, but I may safelie
Use my own reedom, I'le go when I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: O Grissel, Grissel, when would'st thou have said so?

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Loves power, I hope, hath wonne on destinie,
T' appoint this day for my delivery.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Nay, good Sir Swithin,—Ladies—we have yet
Dauncing to come, and a Collation promis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Yes Gallants, now w' are readie, we but stayed for this fourth man here.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: O Camelion.
Where is your wife? I hope your je lousie.
Locks her not up.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Pish Honi soit. I hate it.
No, she has been preparing of a banquet,
Which now is ready for you, worthy Mr. Lightfoot,
And your faire company; jealousie I defie
The bae horne A gue, Mr. Askal I.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What does he call you? Rascal?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Askal Madam.
My name is Askal. But the R in Master
Runs ino't so, that sometimes it sounds doubtful.
I must be Knighted, Euphoniae gratia.
Sir Valentine Askal will come fairly off.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Now note me Mr. Askal, and tell me if ever jealous man came so lightly off.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Sir, your collation stayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: 'Tis well, Gallants and Ladies
Wilt please you enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Agreed, agreed, of all sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: INhospitable! 'tis inhumane, past
The cruelty of infidels.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Thou speak'st
But thine own barbarous cruelty, hollow Frenchman.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Abominable hypocrite.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Cunning Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: Fie Gentlemen, forbear this unknown lan∣guage.
And either speak to others understanding,
If you speak Justice:

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Give me then my sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Thou hast thy sonne, give me my sonne and daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Pray Gentlemen, if you'll not hear each o∣ther, yet both hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I pray Captain speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: You had his sonne to foster; he your daughter.
You faithfully affirme you sent his sonne
For England a moneth since.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: And mine own with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: You have confest you put away his daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And mine own with her, through her disobe∣ence.
But 'twas upon advertisement by letter,
That he had first cast off my sonne to an
Untimely death.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: Some Villain forg'd that letter,
And let me tell you sir, though in your house,
Lafoy's an honest and a temperate man.
You are rash and unadvis'd, what Lafoy speaks
I will maintain for truth: what you have done
I wish you could make good; But I may fear
You are mark't out by your own wilfulnesse,
The subject of much woe and sad misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I know not what I am; but did you know
The number, and the weight of my afflictions,
You could not chide me thus without some pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: Indeed I pity you, and now y'are calme,
Know that Lafoy sent his sonne over with yours,
And but for some affaires he had with me,
I'th Isle of Wight he had embarqu'd himself
With them, and brought hem to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: There's hope then yet
That my boy lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: And is come over feare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You comfort me, and now Lafoy y' are wel∣come.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: But to what comfort, having lost my daugh∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Lost or lost not, mine's with her. And I
purpose now to be sad no longer. For I think
I ha' lost my wife too, there's a second comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: Take an example here Monsieur Lafoy,
And shake of sadnesse; mirth may come unlook't for.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: I ha' lost a sonne too, a wilde roaring Lad,
About this town. And if I finde not him,
I doubt not I shall finde, that he has spent me
A hundred pound since I last heard of him.
By the way sir, I sent you a bill of change
Last moneth, to pay a hundred pieces for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Twas paid. I have your bill for my discharge.
How now?
Ha' you found your Mystresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Nor tidings of her, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: She has found then some good exercise, I doubt not.
That holds her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Sir, there's a Gentleman
Craves instant speech with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Who? or whence comes he?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: He will be known to none before he sees you.
And, when you see him, he sayes he thinks you'll know him.
He's a brave gallant, one o'the Alamodes,
Nothing but French all over.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Fetch him me quickly,
It is my sonne. Grammercie mine own heart,
That wast not light so suddenlie for nothing,
Pray Gentlemen, who e're you see, name no man
To me, unlesse I ask you. He comes, he comes.
I'm grown a proper man. Heaven make me thank∣ful.
Just such a spark was I at two and twenty,
Set cloathes and fashion by. He thinks to try
If I can know him now. But there I'le fit him.
With me sir is your businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I presume
You do not know me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: As well as he that got him.
Pray Gentlemen keep your countenances. Not know you sir?
'Tis like I may have known you here to fore,
But cannot readily collect; perhaps
You are much chang'd by Travel, Time, and Bra∣very,
Since I last saw you. There he may finde.
I partly guesse, but will not know him yet.
Good Geutlemen say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: What ailes he troe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: He knowes me, I feare, too soon. If now my plot faile, and he have a Counterplot upon me. I am laid up.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Do you not know me yet sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Know you, or know you not sir, what's your businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: You sometimes had a sonne sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Now he comes to me.
I had sir. But I hear he's slain in France.
And farewel he. Mark how I handle him.
And what sir of my fonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: He's dead you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I mufe the Knave askes me not blessing though.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: But to supplie his losse you have a daugh∣ter
That may endear a sonne, sir, to your comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Whither now flies he trow! Sir, do you know her.
Or where to finde her?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: First upon my knees
Let me implore your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Now he comes home: And I can hold no longer.
My blessing boy, thou meanest. Take it, and wel∣come
To a glad father. Rise, and let my teares,
If joy confirm thy welcom.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I may not rise yet sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: No? why? what hast thou done? where's young Lafoy?
My true friends sonne here? whom I now must lock
Up in these armes, amidst a thousand welcomes.
Where's the young man?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I know not who you mean sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Distract me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: I feare you are destraught.
I know not him. How should he know my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Let me look nearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Sir, I am your Prentice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Whow—whow, whow, who—my Thiese and Runaway.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Prav sir afford me hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Sir, your cause
Requires a Judges hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: I have put me
Into your hands, and not without much hope,
To gaine your pardon, and your daughters love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Tis roundly spoken. Gentlemen, I'le tell you.
This gallant youth, has gallanted away
A thousand pound of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: For your advantage sir: For
By this way
Of Gallantry, as you call it, I have travell'd
Through the Resorts and Haunts publike and pri∣vate
Of all the Gallants in the Town. In brief
I have found your daughter, where she had been lost
For evet in your brother Strigoods hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Canst bring me thither?

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Is my daughter with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Madam Gabriella, the French Damsel's there.
And others, men and women, whom you'll know when you come there.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Good sir, lets hasten thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You'll aid me, sirs?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: Yes, with our lives and fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Be fearlesse Lady, and upon my life,
Honour, and faith; you are secure from danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Sir, I have put me in your hands you see
So liberally that I may feare to suffer,
If not a censure, yet a supposition
Of too much easinesse, in being led
So suddenly so farre towards your desire.
But my opinion of your noblenesse
Joyn'd with your Protestation, pleads my pardon
At least it may, the wretchednesse considered,
To which I was enthrall'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: It is not more my love
Unto your vertue, and your faire endowments.
Then pity in me labours your release.
Nor is it rather to enrich my self.
Then to save you from so immense a danger,
As you had fallen into by yielding under
Your Uncles weaknesse in so fond a match.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: Blesse me from being fool-clog'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Now you are free.
If you can think your self so, and but yield
Unto my present Counsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Do so Lady
Before you are mist within. Here is the Closet,
And here's the Key in your own hands, And pre∣sently I'le fetch a Priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: You see
I still deal fairlie w'ye; and give you power
To keep guard on your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Bli.
SP.L: And yet I yield
My self your prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: In: some body comes.
She will be yours. And let me tell you, sir,
I wish you as much joy with her, as I
Have with my Cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: You have befriended me
In this good enterprise: And one good turne
Requires another. And now for that I told you,
Touching your wife, your Cock you so rejoyce in.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Alas. alas, good Gentlemen, you would fain
Ha' me be jealous. Honi soit, y'are short.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Stand by and observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Do you begin to boggle,
And when I send for twenty pieces, do you
Send me but ten?

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Nay mark.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I pray,
What have I had in all by your account.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: At several times, you have had fifty pounds of my poor husbands money.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: What's that to the free pleasure of my body
Which must afford you sweet and lustie payment?
You froward Monkey. But perhaps you ha' got
Some new-found Horn-maker, that you may think,
Deserves your husbands money better, for
Doing his Journey-work, one o'the Monsieurs,
Or both perhaps i'th' house here under's Antlers,
It must be so, why else of all the town,
Must I be one o'th' last that must take notice
Of your new College here, your brazen face Col∣lege
Of feates and fine fagaries? do you grow weary of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Do you grow wilde? speak lower, do you mean to undo me?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Will tother fifty pound undo thee, I have lost
All that I had within among your Monsieurs.
And you must yield supply, or lose a friend
Of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: What a way would so much money have gone
In betts at the ducking pond?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Will no lesse serve your turn then fifty?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: No lesse. All makes (you know) but a just hun∣dred.
And there I'le stick; and stick close to thee too,
Else all flies open. What care I who knows
Your credits breach, when you respect not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: 'Tis too well known already; Alls too open.
My house, my purse, my wife, and all's too open.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: O me, undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Was ever loving husband
So much abusd?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Enquire among your neighbours.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Be patient man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: O thou close whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Take heed, sir, what you say.
Eene now you said she was too open, sir.
Y'are in two tales already.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: I feare he's mad
Or jealous, which is worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Pish, Honi soit.
He jealous, he defies it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Do you deride me?
Sir, you can witnesse with me, he confest
Receipt of fifty pounds my wife has lent him,
(False woman that she is) for Horn-making,
Job Journey-work.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: You are deceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I know.
(At least I think) I am deceiv'd in both.
My money and thy honesty, but the Lawes
In both shall do me right, or all shall flie for't.
I'le instantly to councel.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Hear me first.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: By all meanes hear her first. Pray grant her that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I dare not look on her, lest I be tempted
To yield unto my shame and my undoing.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Will you not heare your Cock, your Nansie,
Nanny Cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Time was you would not ha' denied me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Nor any thing, if my Cock had but stood upon't.
Such was my love, but now,

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: But now y'are jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Have I not cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Here's tother fifty pieces, take 'hem sir.
They are full weight, and truly told.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Brave wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: If you will law, sir, you shall law for some∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: What dost thou mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I hope she'll humble him so,
That he shall keep our chamber-door for us,
While we get boyes for him. A dainty Rogue,
She tempts me strongly now. Would she would call me
About it presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: That money sir
May serve to countenance you among the Gamesters
Within, that blew you up. The Lady widow
May think the better of your credit too,
Being so good i'th' house.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I'le streight amongst 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Councel me not sir. All my joyes are gone.
I cannot think now what a ducking pond
Can be good for, except to down me in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Alas, poor man, I was in this too busie.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Stay, you shall promise me before my hus∣band,
That you will never more attempt my chastity.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: That bargaine's yet to make. Though before him
I may say much, I will not stand to that
For all the wealth he has.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: You shall protest
Then, fairly, as you are a Gentleman
You never have enjoy'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I like that.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: No, no, I cannot safely, for in that
I shall surrender up my interest
In's house; and he may warne me out on't. No,
Take heed o' that. 'Tis not his tother hundred
Shall make me slip that hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: I am lost again.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: What a bold thief is this! Pray heare me, sir.
You may remember that I ask't you once
What Countreyman you were.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Yes, when you first cast your good liking on me, and I told you.
SP.L: O'th' Isle of Wight: And what o' that?

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: And you
Call Captain Hardyman, their father-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: You wrong me basely, to say I call him any thing; for he gives me nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: You wrong him basely. Look you, Can you reade.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I had done ill to venter (as I ha' done)
On Salisbury plain else. Hah, what's here
SP.P: That daughter, I sent you order to receive for me an hundred pounds. If you finde that your brother the Spendthrift Val. Askal, (Zookes that I) be in any want, furnish him according to your own discretion.
SP.L: I am Val. Askal, where's the money? My hundred
pound, ha' you't.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: It seems a Sister of yours had it.
Ha' you a sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Val,
SP.L: He had a daughter by my mother, but
He placd her out a childe, I know not where
Where's that young whore trow? Hannah I think
her name was. Hang me if know directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: My wives name's Hannah, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: I am that sister, brother, but no whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Now Val. your brags to make men think you lay with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: You have your hundred pound sir. Look you, husband.
This is my fathers letter which you wrote on.
That which you dar'd the devil and Clerks to coun∣terfeit, reade your own hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I must admire this woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Do'st think I did not know thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: No sir, nor would I that you should,
Till I had foil'd you in your course,
And had my will to make my husband jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: My Cock, my Cock again, my Nanny cock,
Cock-all my Cock-a-hoop, I am overjoy'd,
See, see thy father too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: This is the woman.
To whom I paid your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: 'Tis my daughter—.
My blessing on you.—What are you here too.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And ask you blessing too. Your hundred pound Has bound me to't. Heaven blesse you, Here's halfe one still, yes, and the better halfe, for tother's spent.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: O y'are a great good husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I would be one. And here's a good rich wi∣dow
Now in the house, your countenance may help me,
My Sister and my Brother both can tell you,
How orderly and civilly I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: O wag.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: 'Tis like sir, I shall prove your Furtherer.
What is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: That Merchants Sister, and a Lady sir.
I would not have him heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: Well talk aside then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: In that I'm partly satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I love you sir,
And waited on your wife but as your Spe,
For feare he might have led her to more folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat:
SP.L: But saw you not two such Damsels here?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Here are
Some in the house that would not be seen by us.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Because they thought you'd know 'hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: And if that
Old fellow be your brother Strigood, tis most strange

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You know not him here do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: No not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Tis my man Cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Most wonderful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: We shall know more anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Pray haste sir, to discovery: I would fine
Once see my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I would see a little
The fashions o'the house first.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Pray obscure
Your selves in that by room there, where you may
See and hear all that passes, nor can any
Passe out o'th' house without your notice.
The Gentlemen and I will mix again
With the Society, if they please.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Agreed.
Within Strigood. Where are you Gent'emen?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Come away Val.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Is not that the Hell-hounds voice?

SP.SPEAKER: Cash
SP.L: Yes, 'tis your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Good Captain go with us upon discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: I'le seat you to see all, and be unseen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Do so good Cock. Do so now sir, I'le fetch the Priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: O Gentlemen, you have lost such sport, the
Lady
And Merchants wife have been by th' eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash
SP.L: Could not
The old Knight part 'hem?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri
SP.L: He has done his best,
And almost lost his eyes in the adventure
Betwixt the Furies tallons▪

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: But are they friends agen?

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: And deep in complement.
Our school affords no such in act or language.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Sister, Indeed I am too much your trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Pray Madam let me serve you truly truly.
I'le be your servant for a yeare and a day

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Indeed, indeed you wrong your self, I am yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I am your servants servant, and will serve
Under your Ladiships Cook to do you service.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Indeed you may not.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: If I may not be
Accepted for your houshold servant, let me
Become your Chare-woman▪ in any office
From Cupboard to (lose-stool, I can do all
To do your Ladiship service.

SP.SPEAKER: Val,
SP.L: This now savours of Complement indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: In sooth, 'tis sooth, forsooth the tale I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Well acted mother.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Y' are too obsequious
Good gentle Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I am short of good.
Gentle I grant I am, for I bite no body,
Command me then sweet Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: And very well acted Nant.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: O you shall pardon me▪

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I am no Pope, for your sake would I were.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Your courtesie o'recomes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: O not so.
I wish it could forsooth, would it were better for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Exceeding well acted o'both sides.
Mother and Aunt f'sooth, Amardla you have done't
Better then the two School-Mystresses to dy
Could do their Whatshicomes, their Complements
I think you call 'hem. But I ha' lost my Mystresse
To complement withal. Mrs. Blihe Tripshort
Has out-strip't me, Amardla that she has.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Where's he wise Uncle should ha' look't to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: He's crying all about the house for her,
But cannot finde her. How shall I have her now?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Thou shalt not have her boy, she's naught.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Then he's
Naught too. You sha'nt have him.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Nor will, I feare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Think of the Gentleman, mother that out-fac'd
The Frenchman for me. I would you had a thousand such in France now.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: God-a-mercy boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Peace, hear a little more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.P: Sir; come away.
I have found a carelesse Curate, that has nothing but a bare Coat too loose shall chopt't up presently. And give him but a piece, he'll fear no Cannon.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I am bound to thee for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Whither goes he?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: No matter, let him go t'untrusse perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: I say she is i'th house.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: She's gone, she's gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: She's flowen out of a window, or chimney-top then.
I'm sure I wrtch't the door with epen eyes
E're since you entred, as my Lady charg'd me,
Lest her childe might slip out to play i th' street.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: And I am here you see. He cannot see
He has no more eyes then a sucking pig,
And yet he weeps like a roasted one.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: I am abus'd,
And rnder me my Neece,
You have stolne her for your sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: My sonne defies her,
As I do you, old whining wither'd fellow,
That has no moisture in him but for teares.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: That is my Cue. A young well govern'd man
Were fitter, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: Where have you been servant?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I speak to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: My Lady, I think you said.
Are you so stout sir▪ hah?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I rather think he playes the cunning hypocrite
With his false teares, and packt her hence himself

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: My Lady mindes you not, and I can learn
To give you a broad side too.

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Madam, that cannot be, for I have seen
All that went out, or came into the house▪
Since you. Here came a Church man in ere while.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: A Churchman! then I feare she's clbsely mar∣ried unto her wo and mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: Perhaps to me.
Behinde my back you said she would do so.
And before him came in your brother Matchil.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: My brother, who her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Eph.
SP.L: Yes, with others.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: My husband, I think you aid What a foule house these washing dayes make?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Nay, 'tis no Jest Now dies let me tell you,
And sad Sir Swithin; pray lend all your eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Cash, we are betray Cash if we be not nimble.
I smell a Fox. Hy thee up quickly Cash,
And hurry down the wenches We'll make bold with
My Ladies Coach to hurry us away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: But not too fast, Go sir, fetch down the wenches.
Thou shamelesse Reprobate. Doest thou hang thy head now?
I'le take a course to hang the rest o'thee.
Your Ladiships well met at the new school.
So is your Chare-woman. Ha' you profited
By the devils doctrine here? you weep sin Swithin
For the iniquity of the times.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: You mean
His Neece, pray Vncle did you meet her,
She's gone away too, after my Cousin Joyce,
And the French maid, I think, she is here agen.
Amardla, wipe your eyes, and look Sir Swithin,
The tother honest Gentleman has found her.
And let him take her for his paines for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I thank your love. But sir, 'tis your consent
We only seek.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Sir Swithin, let 'em have it,

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: This is the Gentleman I would have spoke for:
In birth, in meanes, in person every way
Deserving her. Take him upon my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: And Madam, since you stick but upon Joyn∣cture,
Having heard lately well of his husbandry.

SP.SPEAKER: Han.
SP.L: Thank a good sister, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: I will secure you
Three hundred pounds a year, your brother knows me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: With make good his word. Agree by your selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.L: Upon these termes, 'tis like we shall agree.
Sir Swithin are you pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: Pleas'd or displeas'd.
It seems they are married.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: Yes, I assure you,
I saw their hands joyn'd, and I heard 'hem both
Answer the Priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Whim.
SP.L: I will no longer whine.
Heaven give you joy, As y'are your owne, y' are mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: There are more weddings i'th' house, your daughters,
Are linck't by this time to the two young Frenchmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: His daughters? ours I fear? what French? where are they?
SP.STAGE: Enter Cash, two sonne's, Joy, Gab.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: Here sir, undone I feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat,
SP.L: What are you married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Jun: Sir, she is mine, I must and will main∣tain it.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Jun. And she is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: This is your sonne. And this
Is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: This is your daughter. And this mine. Each married to her brother.

L.HI: Jun. Mon Pere Je desire vestre Benediction Jour pour moy & ma fennue.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: You are lost children all, was ever thread
By fate so crossely spn, so crossely wed?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I know not how to Blesse you, or to look
On your incestuous eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Jun. What is dat Incest,
We have commit noting, we have no time,
Since we were marry for so much as kisse,
Begar no point so much as but one kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: Be not dismay'd. These marriages are none.
The errour of the persons nullifies
The verbal ceremony; and 'tis well
They past not unto further rites: I'le finde
A lawful way to clear all this. And then
As you and they consent, they shall exchange
And marry in due order.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: Jun. Sir I tanck you.
You'ave speak very well. And we shall make.
De exshange presently. A new exchange,
De new Exshange indeed, for de husbands
To shange the wifes before they can be wearie.

L.HI: Prenez mon frere, la voici la' une pour lautre.

SP.L: Dere, is one for anoder:

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.L: Is each party
Agreed, and so content?

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: J. Gab. We are.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: And we.

SP.SPEAKER: Laf. Ju.
SP.L: Wee wee, I ensuis tresbien contult.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat. Ja.
SP.L: Provided that we have our fathers leaves and councels.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Can you seek fathers leaves or councels now,
That have run from 'hem in your disobedience,
Into the snares of hell: too farre I fear
To be releast. O hell-bred Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Your brother o' one side.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat. Ju.
SP.L: Lend but a patient care.
And by my hopes of your desired pardon
I'le quit you of your feare. 'Tis true, my duty
At my Arrival should have wing'd me to you.
But hearing of your late, ill talk't on marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: O that root of mischief,
And of my Sisters flight as oth to appear to you,
As to presume a welcom; I was curious
First to observe the Town, and taste the newes;
When more by Providence then accident,
Here we made choice of lodging, saw and lik't
The practices of the Society,
Until this wicked man; (who still presumes
To call you brother,) finding us youthful strangers,
And (as he might suppose) wanton—

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: He made
A bargain with you for their Maiden heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash
SP.L: told me that, and how that hellish purpose
Was vertuously declin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: O counterfeit Cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: But must you therefore, knowing whose sons you were.
Marry you knew not whom.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat. Ju.
SP.L: Pardon me, sir.
Our loves were noble, and by due enquirie,
Fetch't from each others faithful breast, the knowledge
Of each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: VVhat! and marry then
Each his own Sister? Riddle me not to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat. Ju.
SP.L: Sir, I have done. And now that I have said
The worst that might have hapned by his practice,
To make his shame or his repentance greater,
VVho only was my aim. VVe are not married,
None of us all are married one to other.

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.L: No, I assure you sir. Howere I li'd
At their request, (small matter for a friend)
I saw all the hurt the Priest did here to day.
That was upon them two there.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Thank you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You shall be then: And so take hands in earnest.
Is't not a double Match Lafoy?

SP.SPEAKER: Laf.
SP.L: VVithout
All manner of condition I consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I am full of joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cash.
SP.L: O can you pardon me sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Good boy, good boy. I know not how a City
Could stand without such Prentices. And hope
This wants few such. But what canst thou now say
Brother, o' one side for thy felfe. Speak quickly▪
VVhile the good humour holds me to be friends
VVith all the world: yet yonder's one lies heavy
Athwart my stomack.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Y'are full of joy you say.
And I say had it been within my power,
To have broke your heart, I had don't. Therefore in me
Be comforted and love me; for I finde
I have no power to hurt you, and will therefore
Attempt no further.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Brotherly spoke in troth.
And worthily worth an hundred mark a month,
Shall ha't.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Know then into the bargain, that
I forg'd the letter that suggeited to you
My Nephews death, in hope of means that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Honestly said agaiu. Now what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.L: I say that I am humbled on my knees.
I beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: All's too well me thinks.
But heark, before you break up school, lets have
Oue frisk, one fling now, one cariering dance,
And then pack up.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Agreed, Agreed, Agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Stri.
SP.L: Play then Les tous ensembles.

SP.SPEAKER: Neh.
SP.L: That's the French name on't, Uncle, 'tis in Dutch
call'd All-to-mall; and I call it in English.
Omnium Gatherum, 'tis the daintiest daunce.
We had it here to day: I and my mother,
My Aunt and all can daunce in't, as well as the best.
With every one in their own footing. Now observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You have done well. Now pray lets break up school.

SP.SPEAKER: Hard.
SP.L: But yet not break up house. My sonne and daughter.
Have given me power to call their Supper mine.
To which I'le give you welcome, Ale and VVine.
SP.STAGE: Deus dedit his quoque finem, laus Deo.

LIST.HEAD: These BOOKs following are sold by Andrew Crook, at the Green Dragon in St. Pauls Church-yard.
In folio.
LIST.ITEM: A Large and compleat Concordance to the Bible, by Samuel Newman.
The Bible of a large English, or black Letter, used in Churches.
The Bible of a faire London Print.
'The Bible in Welch.
Leviathan, or the Matter, Form and Power of a Com∣mon-wealth, Ecclesiastical and Civil, by Thomas Hobbs.
Ben. Johnsons Works, in two Volumes.
The History of Don Quixote.
Doctor Kellet of the Sacrament of our Lords Sup∣per.
All Homers Works translated by George Chapman.
Orlando Furioso, by Sir John Harrington.
Psyche, or Loves Mystery, by Jo. Beaumont.

LIST.HEAD: In quarto.
LIST.ITEM: Riders Dictionary.
Doctor Gauden, of the Ministry and Ministers of the Church of England.
—His three Sermons upon several occasions.
The Fables of Esop, paraphrased in verse, and adorn'd with Scripture, by John Ogilby.
Doctor Lightfoot, his Harmony on the foure Evange∣lists.
—His Commentary on the Acts of the Apostles.
—His Description of the Temple
—His Description of the service of the Temple.
Ten godly and faithful Sermons by John Gore, late Mi∣nister at St. Peters in Cornhil.
Doctor Day his Treatise of the Resurrection, 1 Cor. 15. 16.
Burton of bowing at the Name of Jesus.
Mr. Thomas Shepherd, of Liturgies, power of the Keyes, and of the Catholick visible Church, in an∣swer to Mr. John Ball.
Dr. Twisse of Predestination, in answer to Mr. Cotton.
The Swedish Intelligencer, containing the principal pas∣sages and actions done in the best parts of Chri∣stendome.
Virgil translated Grammatically by John Brinsley.
A Phylosophical and Chymical Treatise of Fire and Salt.
Clement, (the blessed Pauls fellow-labourer in the Go∣spel) his Epistle to the Corinthians.
The Protestants Kalendar.

The Mysteries of Art and Nature in foure parts▪ the first of Waterworks, the second of Fire-works, the third of Drawing, Limming, Painting, Engraving, and Etching, the fourth of sundry experiments, by John Bate.
William Lithgow his Travels.
A Sermon preacbed at Newport in the Isle of Wight, Octob. 1648. in the time of the Treaty, on Gal. 5. 22. 23. by Robert Saunderson D. in D. and Chap∣lain to the late King.
An excellent Treatise of the interest of Princes and States of Christendome.

A Path-way to Piety, containing
1. Christs Prayer expounded.
2. A Communicant instructed.
3. A Direction to live well.
4. A Direction to die well.

Doctor Swadlin his Manuel of devotions, suiting each day with prayers and meditations suitable to the works of the Day, as also each mans calling, she Nobleman, the Souldier, the Lawyer, the Trades∣man, the Sick man, the dying man.
A Brief of the Bibles History.

DIV1.P: BY RICHARD BROME.

Q.L: Asperius nihil est Humili cum surgit in Altum.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for A. Crook, and Hen. Brome, at the Gun in Ivy Lane. 1659.

LIST.ITEM: Gonzago. King of Sicilie.
Gonzago. His Son the Prince.
Horatio. An old humorous Courtier.
Lodovico. Eulalia's faithful Counsellor.
Flavello. alias Alphonso, Alinda's Sycophant.
Four Lords, two Bishops.

ROW.CELL: Three or four Countrey-men of Palermo.

LIST.ITEM: The Scoene Sicilie.

DIV2.HEAD: The first Song, for pag. 88.
DIV2.L: VVHat if a Day, or a moneth, or a year
May not the chance of a Night or an Hour

DIV2.HEAD: The second Song, for pag. 111.
DIV2.L: HOw bless'd are they that wast their wearied Hours
In solemn Groves, and solitarie Bowers,
And false Delights of frolique earth:
Where they may sit and pant,
Where neither grief consumes, nor griping want
Away false Joys, ye Murther where ye kisse.
There is no Heaven to that, no Life to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: THe clouds of Doubts and Fears are now dispers'd,
And Joy, like the resplendent Sun, spreads forth
New life and spirit over all this Kingdom,
That lately gasp'd with Sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Now the Court
Puts on her rich Attire, and like fresh Flora,
After the blasts of winter, spreads her Mantle,
Deck'd with delightful Colours, to receive
The jocund Spring, that brings her this new life.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. II.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Flavello bare before the Prince, the Queen Eulalia, Alinda, Attendants, Hoboys,

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: The Queen comes on, Joy in that face ap∣pears
That lately was overwhelmed in her tears,

SP.SPEAKER: Lod. and Hor.
SP.L: Health and perpetual Joy unto the Queen,

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Thanks my good Lords, I am prepar'd to meet it.
How neer's the King?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: At hand, my Soveraign.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Welcome that happy word that leads the way,
But yet he is not come, he is not here:
Never so sweet an expectation
Appear'd so tedious: pray set on apace,
That I may live yet to an interview
With my lov'd honour'd Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: That your delay
May seem less grievous, hear this by the way,
A brief relation of the Kings success
In this his late well-won Battail.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Be it so.
But mention not his dangers, good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: That were to make his Conquest nothing worth:
It would make Victory upon his head,
As she had flown into his Burgonet,
To shrowd her from a storm, and not to sit
Or rather stand triumphant on a foot,
With display'd wings upon the utmost Sprigg
Of his high stourishing Pume, vaunting her safety
So perch'd and so supported by his Valour.

SP.SPEAKER: Prin.
SP.L: Pray Mother hear the dangers too; the worst
Will make the best the sweeter: I could hear
Of dangers yet to come; and Women may
Discourse of Perils past each Holy-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Well said, young Prince, right of the Kings own Metal:
And gracious Madam, let me tell you, though
You do not love to hear of blood and danger,
Y' have brought a Warrior forth, I do foresee't:
I love to speak my thoughts, I hope you trust me,
A right old Courtier I, still true to th' Crown.

SP.SPEAKER: Prin.
SP.L: How this old fellow talkes! you said, my Lord,
You would discourse the Battail.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Excellent Prince,
I was i'th' way: but the Queen put me out on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Well, well my Lord, deliver't your own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Then, humph, humh, humh, in my own way.
But by the way, no way to derogate
From the Kings matchless resolution.
A word or two of the best Soldier
In all the world (under the King I mean,
I know my limits) that's our brave General,
Lord Sforza, Madam, your stout Country-man,
Though our Kings Subject now; that bore him so
At the great marriage-Triumph in Tourneament,
Tumbling down Peers and Princes, that e'er since,
He's cal'd your Champion, and the Queens old Soul∣dier.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: But what of him now in the battail?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Marry but this, That as we have a King,
And as the King brings victory, nay life,
Home to his Queen, his Country and our comforts,
Next under Heaven we are to give the praise
To this old Souldier, to this man, the man
Indeed, another man is not to be
(Except the King) nam'd in this Victory.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: You seem my Lord to honour Sforza yet
Before the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Excuse me gracious Madam,
I know my limits: what? before the King?
I am an old Courtier I, still true to th' Crown,
But thus it is declar'd, that in the battail,
When in the heat of fight the mingled bloods
Of either Army reek'd up to the Sun,
Dimming its glorious light with goryvapour,
When slaughter had rang'd round about the field,
Searching how by advantage to lay hold upon out King.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Prithee no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Prin.
SP.L: Good mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: At last she spied and circled him about
With Spears and swords so thickly pointed on him.
That nothing but his sacred valour could
Give light for a supply to his relief,
Which shin'd so through and through his wals offoes,
As a rich Diamond 'mongst an heap of Ruines,
And so was found by the quick eye of Sforza,
When like a Deitie arm'd with wrath and Thunder,
He cut a path of horror through the Battail
Raining down blood about him as he flew,
Like a prodigious Cloud of pitch and fire,
Until he pierc'd into the straight, wherein
The Royal Person of our King was at
His last bare stake of one life to a thousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I dare not hear it, yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Then in a word, old Sforza fetcht him off,
And with his sword which never touch'd in vain,
Set him i'th' heart of's Army once again.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: That I like well.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: That did your Champion, Madam,
The Queens old Souldier, and your Father, Lady:
D'ye simple at it? such a Souldier breaths not,
Only the King except: now note the Miracle,
The King receiv'd and gave new life at once
Of and unto his Army, which new life
Was straight way multipli'd, as if the lives
Of all the slain on both sides were transfus'd
In our remaining part, who with a present fury
Made on with that advantage on the Foe,
That the whole field was won as at one blow.
I am prevented.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Captain, Drum and Colours, King and Sforza, Souldiers.
The King embraces and kisses the Queen, the Prince and Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Now cease our Drums, and furle our En∣signes up:
Dismiss the Souldiers, hostile Armes surcease,
Whiles we rejoyce, safe in these Armes of Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Go Souldiers, better never stood the shock
Of danger, or made good their Countreys cause.
Drink this to the Kings health and victory.

SP.SPEAKER: Sold.
SP.L: Heaven bless the King, and our good General Sforza.

SP.SPEAKER: Again.
SP.L: Long live the King and Sforza, Sforza and the King,

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: The King and Sforza, Sforza and the King,
Equal at least, and sometimes three notes higher,
Sound Sforza's name then doth the Kings: the voyce
Of the wild People as I pass'd along
Threw up his praises neerer unto Heaven
Ever methought then mine: but be it so,
He has deserv'd well, now let me again
Embrace the happie comforts of my life.
Through deadly dangers, yea through death it self,
I am restor'd unto my Heaven on Earth,
My wife and Son: a thousand blessings on thee.
Say, dearest life, whose prayers I know have been
Successful to me in this doubtful War,
How welcome am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: That's more than I can speak:
For should I bring comparisons of the Spring,
After a Frosty winter to the Birds,
Or rich returns of ventures to the Merchant,
After the twentieth currant news of Shipwrack,
Redemption from captivity, or the Joyes
Women conceive after most painful Childbirths,
All were but Fabulous nothings to the Bliss
Your presence brings in answer to my Prayers:
Heaven heard me at the full: when I forget
To send due praises thither, let me die
Most wretched, though my gratitude shall never
Sleep to th' inferior means, e'en to the meanest
Souldier assistant to your safe return,
Especially to you good Sforza, Noble Souldier,
I heard of your fidelitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: My duty Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Are you one of his great Admirers too?
The world will make an Idol of his Valour,
While I am but his shadow: Ile but think on't,
Indeed he's worth your favour, he has done won∣ders.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Let me now speak, I may not hear these wonders bounc'd,

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You do forget your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What says my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Nay I have done.
Gonzago, you and I have chang'd no words yet;
I have brought Victory home, which may perhaps
Be checkt at when my heat shall fall to ashes.
How will you maintain your Fathers quarrels ore his Grave?

SP.SPEAKER: Prin.
SP.L: I do not hope t' outlive you Sir, but if I must,
I sure shall hope to keep your name and right
Alive whilst I live, though I cannot hope
To have so good a Souldier at my Standard
As Warlike Sforza.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: This is more and worse
Then all the rest: the childe has spoken plainly,
I had been nothing without Warlike Sforza:
Ile make him nothing, and no longer stand
His Cypher that in number makes him ten.
My Lords, my thanks to you for your due care
In my late absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: All was Loyal Dutie,
As we are old Courtiers Sir, still true to th' Crown.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I have found you faithful.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: It befits true Statesmen
Watchful to be at home 'gainst civil harms,
When Kings expose themselves to hostile Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: There's a State-Rime now: but Horatio,
Has not Petruccio visited the Court
Since our departure?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Pox on Petruccio.
Bless me, and be good to me: how thinks your
Grace of my Allegiance, and can ask
Me that Question?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Now he is in his Fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: The Hangman take him. Petruccio King?
Peugh, peugh; I hate to name him.
How can you think your State had been secur'd
If he had breath'd amongst us? That vile wretch,
Whom in your Kingly wisdom you did banish
The Court for a most dangerous Male-content,
After his just repulse from being your General,
When he durst stand in Competition
VVith brave deserving Sforza here, the best
Most absolute Souldier of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Still Sforza!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Except your Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: There is an Exception wrung out,

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: He come at Court by my permission?
I should as soon be won to set your Court
On fire, as see him here.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Send for him speedily.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: [Starts] Your Majesty is pleas'd to have it so.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And upon your Allegiance
Which you so boast of, let me have him here,
And very speedily; Ile have your head else.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Nay since it is your Highness pleasure, and
So seriously commanded, I will send
My own head off my shoulders, but wee'l have him:
In what you can command, I dare be Loyal.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Look to it,

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: It must be so, this is one of his un-to-be-examin'd hastie Hu∣mours, one of his starts: these and a devillish gift
SP.L: He has in Venerie, are all his faults.
Well, I must go, and still be true to th' Crown.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Petruccio sent for! who for braving of
Brave Sforza here, so lately was confin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: I cannot think the Court must hold 'm both
At once, less they were reconcil'd, which is
As much unlikely: what do you think my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I know not what to think.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: She Sforza's Daughter, say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Queen.
SP.L: Yes my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: She's a right handsome one: I never knew he had a Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: He brought her o'er a Childe with me, when happily I came your Bride, bred her at home, she never saw the Court, till now I sent for her to be some comfort in your long absence.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Sforza's absence, I fear you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: And trust me Sir, Her simple Countrey In∣nocence at first
Bred such delight in me, with such affection,
That I have call'd her Daughter, to embolden her.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: O did you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: And now she has got some spirit,
A prettie lively spirit, which becomes her
Methinks so like her Fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Very good.
I like her strangely.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What was that she said
To you Conzago?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: That Heaven might ha' pleased
T' have fashion'd her out to have been a Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Comely Ambition.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Reconcile all quickly,
Or you had better never have been born,
Then disobey my last command, which was
Neve to see the Court till I induc'd you.
Do you stare at me?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: I but obey'd the Queen.
I hope shee'l answer't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: No more, Ile talk with you anon.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Come Sforza, Welcome to Court, so is your
Daughter too, I have tane notice of her: O firest, welcome.
Come you both with me this night, weel Feast:
Pray bid us welcome all, as but one Guest.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I shall in all obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: And for this,
Less then a King I shall abhor to kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Repuls'd? disgrac'd? and made the scorn o'th' Court?
Is the advancement of an upstart stranger,
Because he is the Queens dear Countrey-man?
Have I for all my many Services,
Found the reward of being made an outcast?
Could not the King be pleas'd, though he advanc'd
Sforza unto the Honour I deserv'd,
To trust me in his service? could he think
My sword could be an hinderance in the Battail,
Or have delay'd the winning of the Field!
And must his Court and presence which I have
VVith my observance dignifi'd, reject me
Now, as a dangerous and infectious person!
Tis a new way to gratifie old Souldiers.
So soon return'd? I do commend thy speed.
The news at Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: The King's come bravely home,
And every ear is fill'd with Victory,
But chiefly with the Fame of Sforza's Valour.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Sforza? Ser. Lord Sforza Sir, I cry him mercy,
The new Lord General.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Thou com'st too fast

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: So me thinks too, less 'twere to better purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: The Fame of Sforza's Valour, good if it last.
VVhat other news?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: I have told you all the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: If thou hast worse, let's have it quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: You shall, That you may flie the danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: VVhat is't, without your Preface?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Here are Messengers sent from the King to you; pray Heaven all be well. Ther's the old tutchie testie Lord, that rails, and never could abide you, since the King look'd from your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Th' hast made me amends, ther's for thy news.
Is this bad news?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: Truely my Lord, I think so:
For if the King had sent to you for good,
I think he would have sent one lov'd you better.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: VVhat? then the old Courtier? thou knowst him not.
Ile shew him thee. He is the onely man
That does the King that service, just to love
Or hate as the King does, so much and so long,
Just to a scruple or a minute, and then he has an
ignorant Loyaltie, to do as the King bids him, though
he fear immediate death by it.
Call him in.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: They come.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: My masters, come along, and close up to me: my Loyaltie defend me, I shall not dare to trust me in this devillish fellows reach else. And thus it is Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: 'Tis thus Sir, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Good friends look well to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You come with strength of armed men, to bear me
From mine own House which was my appointed Pri∣son,
Unto a stronger Hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Look every way.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: The King it seems now that his Nignion
General is Landed, cannot think him safe, and I not
Faster: which though I can prevent, I will not.
Come, what Gaol will you remove me to?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I would thou wert in Hell for me:
No Sir, I come to call you to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: What? with a Guard?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: That's for my Self. I know thou lovest not me.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Nor you me, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Nor cannot, less the King could love thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Why perhaps he does, you see he sends for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Why if he does, I do, but 'tis more then I know, or can collect yet by his Majesties affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Here's an Humour now.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I know my Loyalty, and I know the King has sent for you; But to what end I know not: and if it be to hang thee I cannot help it. Look to me now my masters. Nor do I care, that's the plain troth on't, while the King is pleas'd, and thou wert my Brother. I am an old Courtier I, still true to the Crown.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I commend your Loyaltie: Come, we are Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Look to me for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Were you afraid, you came so arm'd and guarded?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: That's because I would not be afraid: look to me still.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Indeed my Lord you are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Yes, as much as I look for.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: VVhat should the King intend by this? I fear no ill,
For I have done none; therefore I may go.
Perhaps he thinks to make me honour Sforza
Now in his time of Jollitie, and be friends:
I need not go for that; he cannot do't,
Yet I will go to tell him so: my Lord,
My joy to see the King will post me faster
Than your grave Loyaltie, or Massie Bill-men.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Yes, prethie keep afore with thy back to∣wards me, and so long I dare trust thee.
Have an eye though.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Her Father hath surpriz'd her then?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Yes, and means to hurry her away from
Court this night: I heard him threaten it.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: But he must not do't, she is too sweet Fla∣vello, and too fit for my embraces, to be snatch'd away.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Now that shee's ripe and ready for your use,
Like fruit that cryes, Come eat me. Ile not boast
The pains I took to fit her to your Appetite, before she saw you.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How, my carefull Agent?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: At first sight of her Feature, I foresaw
She was compliable to your affection.
Then by discourse I found she was ambitious,
I ply'd her then with Pills that puff'd her up
To an high longing, till she saw the hopes
She had to grow by. Pray stand close, they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Has the air of Court infected you already?
Has the Kings kisses mov'd by adulterate heat,
Swoln you into astubborn loathsomness
Of wholsom Counsel? Come your wayes; Ile try
If Countrey-Air and Diet can restore you
To your forgotten modestie and Duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: VVhat have I done amiss?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Do you capitulate?
But so much satisfaction as may make
Thee sensible of shame, I will afford thee:
Didst thou not after Banquet, when the King
Heated with wine, and lust rais'd in his eyes,
Had kiss'd thee once, twice, thrice, though I look'd on,
And all the Presence whispered their cold fears
Of the Kings wantonness and the Queens abuse;
Didst thou not then still gaze upon his Face,
As thou hadst long'd for more? O impudence!

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Impudence? Sir, pray give it the right name,
Courtship, 'twas Courtship Sir, if I have learn'd
Any since I came here.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Brave metal'd wench!

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: I am amaz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Besides Sir, the Kings kisses
Are great inestimable Honours, and
VVhat Lady would not think her self the more
Honour'd, by how much the King did kiss her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: And should he more then kiss, still more Honour'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: It might be thought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Durst thou argue thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: I know he dares not beat me here. Pray Sir
Let me but ask you this, then use your pleasure:
(Cause you stile Impudence, that which I call Court∣ship)
VVhat Courtier sits down satisfied with the first
Office or Honour is confer'd upon him?
If he does so, he leaves to be a Courtier.
And not the thing we treat of. Did your self
After the King had grac'd you once, twice, thrice,
(As he kiss'd me) expect no further from him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: She's wonderously well read in Court alreadie:
VVho i'th' Devils name has been her Lecturer?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Do but your Majesty observe that, and think
VVhat pains I took with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: How many Offices
Did you run through before you were made General?
And as the more the King confers upon us,
Is more our Honour, so 'tis more the Kings,
VVhen most his Favours shine upon Desert.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I like her better still.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Insufferable Bag∣gage.!
Dar'st thou call any thing in thee Desert?
Or mention those base Favours which the King
Maintains his Lust by, with those real Honours
Confer'd on me, who have preserv'd his life?
Is it such Dignity to be a VVhore?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Pray Sir, take heed: Kings Mistrisses must not
Be call'd so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Dar'st thou talk thus to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Yes, Sir;
If you dare think me worth the Kings embraces,
In that neer kind, howe 'er you please to stile it:
Sure I shall dare, and be allow'd to speak.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: That word makes thee a Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: The King dares not
Maintain it.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And that costs you your Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Dear Sir, take heed; Protest I dare not hear you:
Suppose I were advanc'd so far above you
To be your Queen, would you be therefore desperate,
And fall from what you are to nothing? Pray
Utter no more such words, I'd have you live.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: She vexes him handsomelie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: As I live she's mad. Do you dream of being a Queen?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: VVhy if I should, I hope that were no Treason:
Nor if I were a Queen, were that sufficient
VVarrant for you, to utter Treason by,
Because you were my Father; No dear Sir,
Let not your Passion be Master of your Tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: How she flies up with the conceit? d'yee hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: Because you were my Father.
Soveraignty you know, admits no Parentage.
Honour, poor petty Honour forgets Descent.
Let but a silly Daughter of a City
Become a Countesse, and note how squeamishly
She takes the wind of her Progenitors.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: She has swallowed an Ambition
That will burst her: I'll let the humour forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: You will not kill your Child?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Though all Posterity should perish by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Not for the Jewel in your Ear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Impudent Harlot! she has heard me value
This Jewel, which I wear for her dead Mother,
I would not part with, whilst I wore my Head;
And now she threatens that: a Kingdom shall not save thy life.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Know where you are, Sir, at Court, the Kings House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Were it a Church, and this unhallowed Room
Sanctum Sanctorum, I will bring you to your knees,
And make me such a Recantation
As never follow'd Disobedience;
I'll take thy life else, and immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: King. Flav.
SP.L: Treason! a Guard! Treason! &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Heaven save the King.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Lay hold on Sforza, the dangerous Traytor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: 'Tis Sforza is betray'd.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Away with him, see he be kept close Prisoner.
Flavello, see that his daughter have convenient Lodg∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Let me but speak; I hope your Majesty—

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Let not a word come from him: hence, away.
VVhat a most dangerous estate even Kings do live in?
VVhen those that we do lodge so neer our Breast
Study our Death, when we expect our Rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Be comforted good Queen, and I beseech
Your Grace to pardon me in this command
The King has laid upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I do, and must no less submit my self
To the Kings soveraign will then you: and though
I am committed to your house and custody,
I am his Highness Prisoner: and more,
Though I know not my crime, unless it be
My due Obedience, I am still so far
From grudging at his pleasure, as I fear
To ask you what it is suppos'd to be;
But rather wait th' Event, which though it bring
My Death, 'tis welcom from my Lord and King.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: VVas ever Vertue more abus'd then hers?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Yet thus much, good my Lord, vvithout of∣fence;
Let me demand, Is Sforza still close Prisoner?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Yes, and Petruccio his Adversarie
Governs his Place, and high in the Kings Favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I will not ask his Trespass neither, it
Sufficeth it is the Kings high pleasure. But Alinda
Sforza's fair Daughter, what becomes of her?
Poor vertuous Maid, is she thrown out of Favour
Because I lov'd her too?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Alas good Queen!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What do you weep? nay then all is not well
With her, I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Good Queen, I fear so too;
And that all ill proceeds from her to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I may not understand thee, Lodovico:
I'll still retain the duty of a wife,
Which though it be rejected, shall not throw
Me from the path a Subject ought to go.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Two such wives more might save a Nation.
But see Petruccio the now-powerful man, under tho King.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Horatio with him too, are they such Friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: None greater since the King was pleas'd to grace Petruccio.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.P: Madam, howe'er my Person, no less then my Authority, I know is most unwelcom to you; I must appear, and lay the Kings Command upon you, which you must obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I must? see, Lodovico, here's a plain-
Dealing Lord, that knows, my Love and my
Obedience to the King, and warnes me
Faithfully to observe it: good my Lord,
I will obey the Kings Command in you:
Lay't on me. What must I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You must go to the Bar, to answer to
Those Accusations that will be brought
Against your Life and Honour, as touching
Your foul Disloyaltie unto the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: He is a Traytor to the King and Me,
That dares accuse me of Disloyaltie.
Patience assist me, and controul my Passion.
The greatest Crime that ever I committed
Against my Soveraign, was, To be so neer
The Vice of Anger in the presence of
One that he lov'd so well; but pray your Pardon,
Though truly those sharp-pointed words drew Blood
From my oppressed heart: and though you love me not,
I hope you think me innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Would I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: You do.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I would I durst speak what I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: My Lord, you ever lov'd me, can you think?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Come, what I think, I think; my love to you
Was the Kings love, if it were love at all:
If he will say, he ever lov'd you, I can say so too.
But to speak truth, I know not if I did,
Or I did not; but now you're hateful to me;
That I dare speak, because he hates you soundly.
And your old Russian Sforza, that fell Traytor,
That would have kill'd the King: do you look up at it?
You may look down with sorrow enough:
Your Country-man, your brave old Champion,
He has Champion'd you sweetly it seems.
Is there no honest VVoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVhat means this unknown Language?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: VVomen are alwayes ignorant of Reproof:
I'll tell you what it means, for that loves sake
You thought I lov'd you once. Or do you know
VVhat Mars and Venus meant, when injur'd Vulcan
Had e'm in's Net? Good King, how wert thou a∣bus'd?
And this good honest, faithful, loyal Lord,
Full to the brim, of Merit, and true Valour,
By that Blade-brandishing Sforza, that meer Fencer▪
To this great Martialist: but he is fast enough,
And all's come out, howe'er you'l answer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVhat must I answer? I know not yet your meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Nor ever shall, for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You'll know too much
I fear, anon. Come, Madam, vvill you go?
The High-Court stayes your coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I must submit me to it, and its Laws;
But to a higher Judge refer my Cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Good Queen, thy wrongs are manifest, though none
Must dare to utter them, but in our Mone.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Mount, mount, my thoughts, above the earthy
Of Vassal minds, whilst strength of womans wit (pitch
Props my Ambition up, and lifts my hope
Above the flight of Envy. Let the base
And abject mindes be pleas'd with servile Bondage▪
My Breast breeds not a thought that shall not flie
The lofty height of towring Majesty.
My power upon the weakness of the King
(Whose raging Dotage to obtain my Love,
Like a devouring flame, seeks to consume
All interposed Lets) hath laid a Ground-vvork
So sure upon those Ruines, that the power
Of Fate shall not controul, or stop my building
Up to the top of Soveraignty, vvhere I'll stand
And dare the VVorld to dis-commend my Act:
It shall but say, when I the Crown have won,
The vvork was harsh in doing, but well done.
Flavello, welcom!

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Hail, my Soveraign Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
