SP.L: 'Tis a brave sound, and that vvhich my Soul thirsts for;
But do not mock mine Ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Believe it Madam,
Joyn your attention but vvith one hours patience,
And you shall hear the gen'ral Voice o'th' Kingdom
Give you that stile, vvith large and loud allowance.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Stile thy self happy then, in vvhat Reward
A Subject can receive, or a Queen give.
How moves our great proceedings?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Fairly, thus:
Eulalia, for now I must no more
Give her the Title that belongs unto
Your Execellence, of Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Advance that Harmonie.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Eulalia is brought unto the Bar, accus'd,
Convicted of that high offence, that instantlie
Shall pull that Judgement on her, that shall crush
Her into nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Appear the proofs manifest?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: That vvas my care, it behoov'd me to work the VVitnesses, vvho swore (in brief) most bravely, that they heard Lord Sforza, vvhom you also may forget now to call Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: That vvithout your instruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: They swore, I say, they heard that Sforza boast
The knovvledge of the Queen in carnal Lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: VVas that enough?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: No, but it serv'd to put
The question to her, Was it true or not?
No, cries the Queen, nor can I think that Sforza
Would lay that scandal on himself and me.
Those Witnesses were two cashier'd Lieutenants
That Sforza should have hang'd for Mutinies
In the late war, but threw 'em by, it seems,
To serve him in this Office: me they cost
Five hundred Crowns apiece, and well they got it.
But where I left: the Queen denies their Oath.
And though it had been true that Sforza had
Affirm'd as much, that had not found her guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: What Witnesses were next?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Two dainty devils
Birds, a Doctor and a Midwife, who accus'd
Themselves for Bawds i'th' Action, and depos'd
I know not how many, how many, how many times,
They saw 'em link'd in their unlawful pleasures.
These were the Queens own people, and deserv'd
A thousand Crowns apiece, and had it instantly,
Afore-hand too.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: What could the Queen say then?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: She denied all, but in such a patient way,
After her foolish fashion, that it gave strength
To th' Evidence against her; then she wept
For their iniquity, and gave them a God forgive ye.
And so attends the censure of the Court,
VVhich straightway will be given: they'l be set
Before my coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Hast, Flavello, hast,
And let thy next news be to this a Crown,
That she is not a Queen, and I am one.
This Father and this Queen I now could pity,
For being hew'd out and squar'd thus to my use,
But that they make those necessary steps
By which I must ascend to my Ambition.
They that will rise unto a supream Head,
Should not regard upon whose Necks they tread.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter four Lords, two Bishops, King, Prince: they sit; Eulalia in black, Crowned; a golden Wand in her hand, led between two Friers; she kneels to the King, he rejects her with his hand. Enter at the other door, a Doctor of Physick, a Mid∣wife, two Souldiers; the King points them to the Bishops, they each deliver Papers, kiss the Bi∣shops Books, and are dismiss'd. The Papers gi∣ven to the King, He with his Finger menaces Eulalia, and sends her the Papers: she looks meek∣ly. The Bishops take her Crown and Wand, give her a Wreath of Cypress, and a white Wand. All the Lords peruse the Papers. They shew various countenances: Some seem to applaud the King, some pity Eulalia. Musick ceases. King speaks.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: MY Lords and loyal Peers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: A new distinction
Between Spiritual and Temporal.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Good Lo∣dovico, peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: This is a Cause, the which, but for fair Order,
By which I am constrain'd to be a Judge,
Would rather drive me to a mourning Closet
Then to this Seat; to shew my equal grief
Against the Crime and Shame of the Delinquent.
I see y'are all amaz'd, and cannot marveil
At your Astonishment, who do suffer with you
In the great Change Honour compels me to,
Together with Religion, fairly urging
To an high point of Justice, which to utter
Draws faintness from my words, chilling my Blood
Like the departing Breath that separates Life.
For such I held her, and so many yeers
Retain'd her in the Closet of my Heart,
Its self-Companion: that till these proofs,
VVhich now like daggers by compulsive wounds
Have made their passage, she could ne'er have parted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Royal Hypocrisie!

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The Proofs you see are plain,
That she was found—Pray speak it for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: In Adultery.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And that she sought the Life of fair Alinda
By Sword and Poyson both: and of that Cup
'Tis like my self had tasted,
For my supposed love to that wrong'd Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: You have given her the Bed-right that be∣long'd to your wrong'd Queen, these twelve months.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Our Laws of Sicilie are so well rebated
VVith Clemencie, and Mercie, that in this Case
They cut not Life from one of Royal Blood,
Onely take off (as is on her perform'd)
All Dignities, all Titles, all Possessions,
All means to live, even to her naked hands.
And such, Eulalia, now is your condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: To work for her living? if she were as young, and no honester then she for vvhose sake this is inflicted on her, she might find something else a∣bout her, then naked hands, to help at a living shift-

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Now to this Censure, for due Orders sake,
And for vvhich end this Parliament vvas call'd;
Your Voyces are requir'd: do ye all approve it?

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: VVe do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: We must.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: VVhat say you, Lodovico?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: VVe do; Heaven knows against my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: My thanks unto you all, that do obey
So vvell vvith one consent your Soveraign Lord.
And sacred Sir, thus low, as it becomes me,
Let your poor Hand-maid beg, that you incline
A patient Ear to this my last Petition:
That as you cast me off, as an offence,
You will be pleas'd to think me not offended,
But pleas'd in all I suffer: for, Heaven knows,
I am as free from any Passion
Of Anger, Hate, Repining or Distaste,
Nay, as insensible of Grief or Sorrow,
Or whatsoever Anguish of the Minde,
As I was capable, for ought I know,
Of Joy or Bliss the first hour I was born.
Never made happy till I was your Bride,
In which blest state I cannot but remain,
While you are pleas'd, and I obey your will,
Though unto Death, to Banishment or Prison.
Poverty is Blessedness, in vvhich I'll pray
For pardon of the Sins of my Accusers,
And those that have suborn'd them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O poor Woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: So in the blest continuance of your Dayes,
I shall pray Heaven to smile on all your VVayes.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Nay, stay Eulalia, I have yet a Business
I would have pass the general Consent
Of this Assemblie, in which your Voice is useful.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Upon my life, his Marriage with that Start-up,
That Snake this good Queen cocker'd in her Bosom,
Is not this Royal cruelty?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: You wrong your Princely Dignity:
Turn to the King your Father, kneel to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: And are not you my Mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I must and can forget what I have been;
So must not you: your Mother was a Queen.
My present fortune claims no Title in you.
Hurt not your own, by looking down on me.
This I will do as warranted by safetie,
Not as a Mother, but Beadswoman, pray
For all that bliss on you a Mother may,
Good Sir, observe the King before his wrath.
Take hold upon you for regarding me.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. II.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Favello ushering Alinda like a Bride, two Virgins.
The King descends, takes her up: the Lords rise, all amazed.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Let your amazement cease, and now per∣ceive
My Lords in general, that I your King
Am Subject to this all-deserving Lady,
And do require you not alone to hear
What I can say, but without all denial
That you approve, confirm what I will say.
I am by law no less then your consent
Divorc'd, and free from all impediment
To make my second choice in Marriage,
And therefore crave Alinda for my wife,
And that immediately we solemnize
Our Marriage, and her Coronation.
I hope none rates our will or his own life
So meanly, as to give least contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: O let me lead your voyces. Long live
Gonzago and Alinda, King and Queen of Sicily.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: O gross Hyocrisie!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: My Lord the Prince, pray let your voyce be next;
The rest will follow. Why speak you not, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: She would fain seem to voyce in your be∣half,
But in a way that much perswades against you.
Do but your Highness note it.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: You Sir, come from that Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: She was my mother when she was your wife;
And that's so late, I cannot yet forget it.
But I fear to offend.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: O shew it in your Duty then, young Prince:
'Tis true, the Law of Nature-wills a Son
To be a partner in his Mothers woe;
But Laws above that lay a strong command
On Sons to obey the Edicts of their Fathers.
A Fathers frownes are Comets threatning ruine.
Let all your thoughts be free from his offence:
The most Heaven seeks, is our obedience.
In all obey the King; think not of me:
I am no more, nay not so much to you
As is the Begger whom you may relieve,
Since of all these comforts I am depos'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Faith thou hadst not mine, good woman:
I must not call thee Queen now.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Or if you needs will think I am your mother,
Let it be onely in the charge I give you,
That since Alinda bless'd by providence
Must be invested with the Regal Crown,
You shew her that obedience befits a Queen,
And your dread Fathers Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: I fear shee'l turn him
Traytor, if he give more ear to her inchantments.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Ile shew him a way to give her thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: My Royal and dread Father.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Put forth that woman:
Do it without grudge, out of the Court,
I mean to seek her way. Do you refuse?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: He does not, shall not, Royal Sir.
Onely I beg that I may take my leave.
The wishes a true Subject ought to send
From the most humble heart up to the Throne
Of sacred Majesty, I equally divide
To you my King and Queen,
Professing by the Powers you present,
I part as well content with my condition,
Since it is your command, as ere I was to sit in that Promotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Sir, I may not sit to be taunted and upbraid∣ed thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Pardon me, mighty Lady, I am as far
From daring to do so, as from a Queen.
And whilst you love the King, and he is pleas'd,
I shall no less obey you, then I lov'd you
VVhen I sent for you to the Court, and there into
this heart received you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: I am plainly jeer'd: hence that woman.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Away with her.
And let it be proclaim'd according to th' extremitie of Law our Censure be observ'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Alas, how can she live one night?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And now to your consent: have I it yet
For Marriage with Alinda? If you are pleas'd,
Then call us King and Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Long live the King and Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I mean Eulalia

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis well: on to the ceremonies then. Kings were
But common men, did not their Power get fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: It is oppression, Tyrannie indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Speak lower, good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: For fear of whom? of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: You would not that the King should hear you, would you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Faith if he did.—

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Faith then as sure as your tongue's your own now, your whole head would be his then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: If it might so excuse the Queen, I car'd not.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: It will do the Queen as much good, as the money it might be sold for in the Market; That and the Appurtenances to it, would yield little at the Shambles. Come my Lord, speak privately, and pur∣posely keep your head on your shoulders: it be∣comes the place as well as 't had been made for it. If the King have a mind to turn away his Wife, Ile give him leave to turn mine after her, to wait upon her, rather than to have my head bowl'd at her, though I were sure it should kisse the Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Oh but the ensuing danger, my Horatio! The mischiefes that of necessary course must follow, even to the ruine of the State, by the Kings dotage on his second choice, draws blood from Sub∣ject hearts: Oh that lewd Woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P:
She is a Woman of middle earth yet. But what shall we dare to say two hours hence? Come, think upon Law and Regal Authoritie. The Kings Power Warrants his Acts: I know as well as you the Queen Eulalia (Heaven bless her, I hope 'tis yet no Treason to pray for her) is as vertuous a Lady as ever
beautified a Court, or made a Kings Bed happy, For all the Articles fram'd against her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: The perfect Pattern of Meekness, Patience, Obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Of all that's good, or should be wish'd in VVoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: So obsequious a lover of her Husband, that she gave way unto his loose affections, even to this now-she-start-up that supplants her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: She consider'd she grows old: she reads in her Sons face nigh twenty years of the Kings love to her: and gives him leave to place it now elsewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: And is so far from limiting his Choice,
That she possesses it that seeks her blood.
My soul tels me the witnesses against
The Queen, are by this Concubine suborn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I will not say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: You cannot chuse but think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: My thoughts are warranted by the Proverb. But come, make up your Face, temper your voyce and looks with the rest of the most Honourable As∣sembly: shake off this discontent, 'tis a disease by which you'l perish else:now all the Court's in height; you to professe distaste! Come, be a looker on at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Upon a Court on Fire? O Horatio,
Bright Burning Troy gave not a dearer cause
Of willingness to those affrighted souls
She forc'd to leave her sinking in her ashes,
To flie for refuge to another Region;
Nor in their flight could they by looks reverted,
See danger in more horrible aspect,
Than I upon the ruines of this Kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Your stay, my Lord, may prevent danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Yes, if it could remove the Fatal cause,
The pride, the crueltie, the Ambition
Of that wild Fury, the outragious Queen,
VVho treads and tramples down the Covernment.
Consider this Horatio, and the means
To work this great effect: and I am yours,
To stay till it be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Alinda's Death.
VVho's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Is it not necessary? no body: what d' ye fear?
Or can you find how to preserve the State
At a less rate? you know too well the King,
How apt his Nature is to fell oppression.
The burden of whose crueltie long since,
If by the vertuous Clemencie of his Wife
It had not been alay'd and mitigated,
Had been a general subversion.
And now that Peerless Princesse being depos'd,
Whose vertue made her famous, and us happy;
And he re-married to this shame of women,
Whose vileness breeds her envie and our mischief,
What can we look for but destruction?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I dare me thinks a little hear you now,
(The Court being surfeited too with wine and noise)
And could almost talk to the point it self,
To your own ear.
'Tis fit somewhat were done:
I cannot say what: but if the wronged Queen
Be not restor'd, we shew ingratitude,
How much, I may not say: enough to damn us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I, now you speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: And though I will not speak it: if the Strumpet:
Be not conveniently and speedily destroy'd,
Though death dance with us in the enterprize,
We shall seem born more for our selves than Coun∣trey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Brave noble resolution!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Nay more, now I will speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: This way, good Horatio.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: That way, or any way; If Poyson, Sword,
SP.L: Policy or Strength may do it—

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Speak lower, good Horatio: see the Mig∣nion.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What for him? my Ladies Game-keeper, that understands nothing but Monkeyes, Parrots, short-nos'd Dogs and Starlings; Master of her Ma∣jesties Foisting-hounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: So, he hears you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Let him; he has no Soul to understand, nor Language to answer a Man: he knows how to dyet, disple and perfume the small Cattle he has charge of; for which rare Art, and catching Spiders for princi∣pal Pug, he is rais'd prime man in his great Mistresses favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: How the Petitioners flock to him!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Swarm rather, for they are Bees in his head; Oh! he engrosses all the Suits, and commends them to the White Hand, whose disposing will make the whole Kingdom black in Mourning, if Fate by us pre∣vent not. See how he carries it! We might talk what we would, for him. His well-ordered head is so taken up with Particular Affaires, he mindes no General talk.
SP.L: But my good Lord, ▪fore others Ears and Eyes,
Pursue we our Design as all were Spies:
You and the Common Good have won me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: O I embrace you.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P:
Oh—Oh—and Oh-ho—O and alas! O and alack for O—O—O—that ever a true Neapolitan born,
should live to see this day in Sicily! there O-again, Queen—O me—what wilt thou do? O—O—what shall I do? O—thou maist work and starve; O—and I may beg and live: O—but from thee I cannot live: O—I cannot, nor I wonnot, so I wonnot.

SP.SPEAKER: Jag.
SP.P: See, here's poore Andrea mourning as well as we,
And all the rest of the poor Queens cast-awayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: But I can tell him comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Oh—I will hear no comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: Yes, and be glad on't too.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Is my Queen Countrey-woman call'd back again?

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: No, but the Queen Alinda has enquired for thee, to entertain thee into her service, whilst we and all the rest of our late Queens servants are turn'd out o'th'Court, and now at this high dinner time too.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: She would eat me, would she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Jag.
SP.P: That would make it a Feast indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: But Ile not trust her on a fasting-night: Fools are meat then.

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: Well said Andrea, witty in thy sorrow: I know thou wilt back again for a new Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: No, no, take you your course, and serve her if you please,
I have play'd the Fool too long, to play the Knave now.
Ile after my old Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: Thou maist not serve her: that will be brought within compass of Relief, and then thou maist be hang'd for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: If I be hang'd for doing good, pray let it not grieve you: and as I am an Innocent, Ile never grieve for you though you be hang'd never so justly.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: We thank you good Andrea.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Take you your swinge, let me take mine I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Jag.
SP.P: Hark, the King drinks now to his new Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: So, having turn'd his old Wife out of door,
A man may drink and frolique with his who—
VVould have thought it? did you think to catch me?

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: Not I Andrea.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Catch me if you can: when it shall be Treason to say there is an honest woman, Ile say my Countrey-woman was justly condemn'd of Adultery: and till then, I know what to say: Catch me if ye can.

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: There again: now the Queen drinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Poore woman, at what River?

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: I mean the Queen Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: O the new thing at home here; I will not call her Queen, not I: my Countrey-woman is my Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Jag.
SP.P: Why is not she thy Countrey-woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: She was when she was Sforza's Daughter:
But she has turn'd a Father out of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: As here come some to turn us out o'th' Court.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. V.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Horatio, Flavello, Guard, two or three Gentle∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: Away with them: out of the gates, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: See, here are more of them: more of that hated womans Retinue: away with all.

SP.SPEAKER: Rug.
SP.P: Beseech you, good my Lord: I hope we are true men.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: As I am true to the Crown, not one of you pesters the Court a minute longer: go, you are trash and trumpery: and Ile sweep the Court of all of ye: follow your Mistresse: go.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: The Fool my Lord shall stay: the Queen ask'd for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Yes yes, the Fool my Lord, shall stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: The Fool my Lord will not stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Will not? how dar'st thou say so? ha, Fool, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: The Fool dare say more than the wisest Lord dares do amongst ye: you will not take my own proper goods from me, will ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: See what he caries: I heard of Plate and Jewels lost to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: Let's see, Sir, I will see.
SP.STAGE: [Opens the Box: Coxcomb, Bable, Bells, and Coat.]

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Heyday, here's stuff indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Your VVardrope cannot matcht it: pray give me all again; or if you will be the Kings and Queens Takers with that extremitie to force my goods from me, then present this to his Highness, and this to Hers; and tell them, 'tis all the poor dis∣carded Fool could spare them.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: No Sir, you shall take them with you, and a whip for advantage, unless you'l stay and serve the Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: No Sir, to you with an excusee moy,
If you be your Queens Fool-taker, you may
In Countrey, Court and City quickly find
Fools upon Fools that I shall leave behind.
New Lords (you know the Proverb) make new Laws,
New Lawyers of an old make a new cause.
New workmen are delighted with new Tooles,
And her new Majesty must have new Fools.
New fools she wants, not having you about her,
VVhile the old Fool makes shift to live without her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fla.
SP.L: Let the Fool go my Lord, 'tis but a Fool the less,
For he'll get wit by it, to wish himself here again.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P:
If I get but enough to keep me from Court,
I care not.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: Farewell Fool, take your Trinkets with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Farewell fine Lords, adieu old Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: The Court unclouded of this Factious crew,
VVill shine on us that to the Crown are true.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. VI.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sforza and Keeper, as in Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: VVas ever man so hurried into thraldom,
And lock'd up in the ignorance of the cause,
Stronger and darker than his Prison walls?
But I must not be Sepulchr'd alive,
And therefore Keeper, though thy office be
More Devillish than thy visage, yet thy heart
May be humane: let me then conjure thee
To vent the secret forth but in a whisper;
Or shouldst thou utter't in a Tempests voyce,
As loud as are my injuries, thou art safe:
I can be here no carry-Tale: I am fast
In thine own custody, thou seest:
I pray thee tell me, what's laid unto my charge?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: All I can say, 'Tis the Kings pleasure, and you must obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.P: Do you barke Sentences, Hell-hound?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: My Lord, y'are off your Command, and under mine,
You much mistake your self and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.P: 'Tis true.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: Lions may rage in toyles: but whilst they do,
They more enthral themselves: will you sit down,
And promise on your Honour not to force
My counsels from me? Ile deal fairly with you,
(My meaning is, to give him never a word)

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: I will not lift a finger up against thee,
As I am a Souldier: now prithee tell me,
VVhat say they is my crime? [shakes his head] nay speak it freely.
I can give it hearing:
Or tell me first if thou wilt, how fares the Queen?
VVhat? art thou dumb to that too? Answer me,
Is my Antagonist Petruccio
Repeal'd to Court yet? thence may spring my mischief.
VVhy dost not speak? this is dogged silence,
In scorn of me, to mock my misery.
I may not wrong the Honour of a Souldier
In my Revenge, or I would thrattle thee.
You're very civil, Hell take your courtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: I pitie him: but must not dare to shew it.
It adds to some mens misery, not to know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: It is decreed of me, that I must suffer
This Barbarous crueltie; and Ile bravely bear it:
I ha' not force these double walls to part,
Or mollifie the Jaylors harder heart.
May spirit then assist me to despise
And bear my scorn above my injuries.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Revenge has cast her self into my hands,
Strangling the Life of Sforza in these Lines:
His Head is in this grasp, but where is Honour?
Must that forsake this Brest? must the pure heat
Of heavenly Honour, yeeld unto the scorch
Of Hell-bred base Revenge? it must not, cannot:
For as the Sun puts out all baser Fires,
Where Honour shines, thought of Revenge expires.
Besides, he is below my Anger now;
And has no Life but forfeited to Law,
Or the Kings Fury, I'll not question which;
Nor was it justlie, he gave me th' Affront,
In being made Lord General, when I stood for't.
But the Kings selfe, in his Election,
He wrong'd not me no more then I did him,
When th' Honour was transfer'd from him to me.
That's answer'd cleerly, I acquit thee, Sforza.
But now my Loyaltie, how shall I discharge
That special Duty I am here commanded,
(Stand back I say) to see the Execution,
And bring the Head of Sforza to the King?
What an addition here is of Advancemet?
To make me first a General, then a Hangman:
I'll do him better Service: Loyal Horatio
Would think himself now damn'd, to leave a tittle
Of the Kings powerful pleasure unfulfil'd.
Call the Keeper.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: Here my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I am to see and speak with Sforza.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: Then I doubt not but your Honour has brought VVarrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: My Honour be your VVarrant: will not that serve?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: I will not lose the Kings Grace for all the
Honours in the Kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Do'st know me, or my place?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: Yes, I both know and honour you, as far as my own place gives me leave: but in this I must crave pardon; you may not see him my Lord, by a less VVar∣rant then the Kings own Signet, and that fetches him out, and it please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: But have you been so strict to all men else?
Has no man chang'd a vvord vvith him?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: Not since
These Keys commanded him, I can assure you,
Not even the Prince himself, who much desir'd it.
I look'd as black on him, as upon you now.
I am no white Prison-Keeper, I, to venture
Mine own Neck for a Prisoner's, at a price,
And give condemn'd men leave to run away:
No, I am the black Jaylor, I, and 'tis thought,
Lineally descended from Cerberus.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I must commend thy Care; see, there's the Signet.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: I'll fetch the Prisoner.
May it please you to come forth, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Have I then liv'd to hear Mans voice again?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: Here's the Lord Marshal, and chief Gene∣ral
Of the Kings Forces, come to speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Those Titles once were mine, but now I must
Attend his pleasure that is Master of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: All leave the Room, but be at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Guard.
SP.L: VVe shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: My first object from my long obscurity,
The man that hates me most of all the world?
It is: his news cannot be good. not good?
The better: 'tis best to know the worst; he cannot deceive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: My Lord, I do presume I am unwelcom,
Because you are possess'd I never lov'd you:

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: The Court yields me such Complement; this has
No ampler Comforts in't. But y'are deceiv'd,
For you are welcom, sowre captious Lord, y'are welcom.
Because (love me or love me not) you speak.
I have been here these two and twenty dayes,
And never heard the voice of Man till now:
Meat I have found, and Lodging; but for Language,
In what part of the world I am, I know not.
Proceed; I value your words well, you see,
That give you six for one; why do you not speak?
I have been us'd to talk with men that love me not,
And more with Enemies, I dare besworn,
Then Friends: come, speak, I pray, what is't you come for?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Alas! I pity him: his too too much vexation
Has over-tam'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Will you not speak and tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Pray let me ask you first; Have you been kept
So strictly from the Speech of all men?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: E'er since I was committed, and from the knowledge
Of vvhy I vvas committed too; nay, he that keeps me,
'Till now he call'd me forth, never spake a vvord:
If I ask'd him, what News? here he vvas vvith me:
Or when he heard from Cuurt? then there again:
Or, why I vvas committed? still the same answer.
So that I could inform my self of nothing.
Come, if thou bee'st an honest Enemy,
Tell me something:
As thou dost wish my throat cut, tell me something.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You seem to take no notice of the cause of your commitment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Further than this I cannot: 'Twas the Kings pleasure to command it.
Treason was cry'd; a Guard: away with him:
But for what cause, unless it were for drawing
My sword upon (O that Rebellions Girle!)
To save her from the danger of his lust,
(VVhich I tell you I was doubtful of) and so Sir,
Let me ask you, is she still about the Queen? (Queen.
My daughter Sir, I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Yes, much about the

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: And the Queen loves her?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: As dearly as her self.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Nay if you be a Souldier, now speak truely.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: The Queen and shee's all one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Then there's some hope,
The King yet keepes fair quarter with her.
VVomen are quickly jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: He knows no∣thing,
I'm confident, of all these great proceedings.
Poor man! I pity him: but Ile put him to it.
VVill you now answer me as y' are a Souldier
To some few Articles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: You have engag'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: 'T were shame he should die ignorant of at least
The Accusations are laid against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Come Sir, your Articles?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You are ac∣cus'd
Of an intended Treason 'gainst the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Who's my Accuser?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Even the King himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Umh, umh, umh: he should not be my Judge then.
It is some Devillish dream of his, or else
That Policie that Princes purchase Hell by,
With strong assurance without all exception;
That is, when Souldiers men of best desert
Have merited more then they have means to give,
To cut their lives by whom they onely live.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You flie now from the question: y' are en∣gag'd by the Honour of a Souldier
Unto that Accusation: guiltie or not guiltie?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: I am not guiltie, as I am a Souldier;
And in that Oath I would not be forsworn,
To save as many lives, were they within me,
As perish'd by my Sword to save his One.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: In that I am satisfied: now to the next,
If you will hear it; you shall promise me
To answer without passion I or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: I will do what I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You're next accus'd
Of fowl Adulterie with the Queen Eulalia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Hah!

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Guiltie or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: No Sir, nor dares there be
Such a suggestion in the heart of Hell.
And were he there, that thought, or could but dream
Of such a Scandal, I'ld squeeze it out on's Brains.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Then I must hold you to your promise Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: A wrestling towards; away west, away.
Nay then I am betray'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Forbear I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: He comes but to insult and to torment me.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: My Lord you much forget, is not this Passion?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Passion of heart! he hopes not for Salvation
That hears with patience but the repetition
Of such a Blasphemie. I must not die,
Until the world be vindicated from
The redamnation such an error threatens.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You see I could oppress you; but all forbear the roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Do you come to mad me?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: If you will be calm, Ile tell you what I come for.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: As setled as a Rock beneath a mountain
Here will I sit, and hear thy loudest malice.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: If this man be not innocent, vertue lives not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Now tell me what you come for; and be sure
You ask no more abominable questions,
VVhilst calmly I clear these, thus: By the Honour
And faith of a true Souldier, I am clear
Of these suggested crimes, which before Heaven
(Which knows my Innocencie) I do not urge
To save my life from the Kings violent Fury,
Nor any way to close with thee in Friendship,
Now that my fortune is at worst. So, speak:
'Tis long a coming: I begin to think
It is some good, you are so loath to utter 't.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: It is, if you can apprehend it so.
My Lord, I take you for my friend, and come
To make my moan to you; insomuch as now
I do conceive you Noble, Vertuous, Honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Foh! this is worse than all the rest, this stinks
Of the Court-putrefaction, Flatterie, grossly.
But on I prithee: talk is such a noveltie,
I will hear any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I could not see your vertue, when it shin'd
Thorow the radiant favours of the King:
It dazled me with envie then: but now,
Like the red Sun through cold and mystie va∣pours,
I can behold it at the full.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: So, so: umh, whu: so much for my vertues:
What's your business now?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I say I come to make my moan to you,
Groaning beneath a weightie Injury
The King has thrown upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Has denyed him
Something I warrant, that he would have begg'd;
The making of a Knight, or some such foolerie:
What was 't?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: In putting a base office on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Is the great Marshals and chief Generals
Office, become so base?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: No Sir, the Hangmans Office. Read that—
I am commanded there, and warranted
VVith present speed to bring your Head to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: A prayer or two, by his great leave and yours,
And you shall have it instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: My Lord, you shall not undervalue't so:
That Honour which has won me to you, shall
Work better for your preservation.
I have much more to tell you, and strong Reasons
Why you should live: of the Queens infinite wrongs
And yours, wrought by your Daughters cruel Am∣bition.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: This is a nobleness beyond Example:
Sure now you are honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: There you see my strength:
If now for truth and Honours cause I strain
A point of Loyaltie, you will engage
Your Honour to secure me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: I hold my Honour equal to the best,
And prize it still so far above my life,
That to save Kingdoms Ile not forfeit it.
Here in the sight of Heaven I do engage it,
For your securitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I ask no better. Keeper!

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Dismiss that Guard, and give us way.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep
SP.L: I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Now come my Lord, vertue may be cast by;
But never overcome by Tyrannie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: VVars Sword, Laws Axe, or Tyrannies fell Knife,
May overcome my Person, not my life.
For that is yours Petruccio.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: TUrn'd out of all, and cast into the world;
And that forbidden too to pitie me?
No sucour, no relief to be afforded?
Heaven still is where it was, and cannot lose
The Providence it ever had: let those
That think me wretched now, consider that,
And be with me converted to a Faith
That will proclaim us happy. What's my loss?
VVhat was the State and glory of a Court,
But steps and lights through dangerous Ambition,
To ends beyond our selves, in whose atchievements,
VVe make our selves but nothing to ourselves.
And all that we are then, is to the world,
VVhich renders us great Titles: which tane off,
VVe then return unto our selves again,
And all the world is ours: I was not great
Till now; nor could I confidently say
Any thing was mine own, till I had nothing.
They do but sleep, that live in highest Pompe;
And all their happiness is but a dream,
VVhen mine is reall: nay, nay, I can prove it.
Their costly fare breeds riot, mine content:
Their rich Attire is but mere Pageantry,
Made to please their eyes: mine keeps me warm,
And healthful, when a cold becomes their sickness.
They boast of Honour and Gentilitie,
For their Attendants then, when the chief Honour
Of the best woman, meek obedience,
Is my own handmaid; and my Patience
A sweeter servant than Gentilitie,
Continually my other: for Councel and defence, what have I now?
They have the helps of worldly wise mens brains,
And I the comforts of my fruitfull Prayers.
They have tall big-bon'd servants for defence:
I the strongst guard of all, mine innocence.
What Musick had the Court compar'd to this,
Or what comparison can all their sports
And Revells hold with those of Kids and Fawnes,
And frisking Lambs upon the countrey lawnes?
VVhich are my hourly pleasant entertainments
In all my wanderings: in which I have not
Hunger'd at any time, but I have found
Meat which I duely earn'd: nor ever thirsted,
But I have found a Spring that has refresh'd me.
And am no sooner weary, then I finde
A shelter or a shade to rest me in:
As now, in which a slumber 'gins to creep
Over mine Eyes, more soft then any sleep,
Could these my Senses when I lay of late
On Down, beneath the Canopy of State.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. II.
DIV3.L: Sleep in thy Sainted Innocence,
Whilst Angels watch in thy defence.
Sleep whilst I charm these bubling Streams
With Musick, to make sweet thy Dreams;
Thy Dreams which truly shall relate
The Passages of thy Estate.
DIV3.STAGE: Dumb shew. Enter Alinda, Flavello, two Lieute∣nants, Doctor, Midwife. Exeunt Lieutenants, Doctor, Midwife. Enter Sforza at the other end raging, and the Jaylor, with mute action. Enter King, Petruccio: Alinda whispers the King: he gives a Warrant and Signet to Petruccio: Exit Petruccio. King. kisses Alinda, graces Flavello. Exeunt. All this as the Genius speaks.
DIV3.L: Note, first thy Foes in Court conspire
Against thy Life, and Villains hire
To act thy Tragedy.
Loe those the perjur'd Evidence
That suggested thine offence,
Are hir'd the second time to be
Co-actors in thy Tragedie.
They have their Fee, and now are sent
Towards thee with a vile intent.
Ill thrive their purposes. Now note
The wrongs that are 'gainst Sforza wrought,
Who lives from Speech of all men still,
Pent by the Kings abused will;
Not knowing of the Treacherie
That was conspir'd 'gainst him and thee.
Nothing of all that's past knows he,
More then he must a Prisoner be;
Which doth him much impatience bring:
But the bad Queen instructs the King
How his vexation he may end,
Who strictly for his Head doth send.
What from these black intents shall grow,
Is not as yet for thee know.
Now, holy Soul, I must thee set
A course that must thy living get.
Thou must not beg, nor take for need
More then thy Merits proper meed.
First therefore, I thy Brain inspire
With a Divine Prophetick Fire;
Thou shalt be able to Fore-doom
The ends of many things to come.
Into thy Breast I next infuse
The Skill of Med'cine how to use:
Learn'd Aesculapius never knew
The use of Simples more then you.
Many diseas'd by Grief and Pain,
Of thee shall Health and Strength obtain.
Next Handy-Works and Literature,
With Education good and pure,
Thou shalt be able to bestow
Upon the Country's Youth, and show
The Elder sort how to improve
Their Wealths by Neighbour-hood and Love:
Now when thou from this Trance dost wake,
See that thou present Practice make
Of these thy Gifts, and fear not then
The Practices of Fiends or Men.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What soft? what sweet? what heavenly Trance was this?
I feel my self inspir'd with holy Flame
Above the heat of Mortals: sure I have
The Spirit of Prophecie, the Gift of Healing,
And Art of teaching hidden Mysteries.
Thanks Heaven, that first didst send me Patience
To sweeten my Afflictions, and now
Plentiful means to live, for others Good.
Who live but for themselves, are but for show,
And stand like barren Trees, where good might grow.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter to her, Lodovico and Andrea.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Farewel, thou foolish Pomp, and Pride of Court,
Whose shine is but an Ignis fatuus
That leads fond Mortals from the path of Vertue,
And Tracts of real Comforts: thus I shake
Thy wanton Dust from off my Feet, to tread
The wayes of Truth and Innocence: this Air
Breaths Health upon me, Peace, and perfect Pleasure.
VVhere the swoln Courts sophisticated Breath
Did but disease my Blood, and taint my Senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: It is good Lodovico, though disguis'd,
I can no less then know him: and the poor Fool
That was my Servant: they come to relieve me
In these disguises, that I might not know
From whom I receiv'd Comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: To this way
The most unfortunate Queen enclin'd her course:
And see, already, how her VVants and VVoes
Have worne her to the bone: Alas, she's pin'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: And look you new Master, yonder's my old Mistress;
VVhat Fools were we; that could not find her sooner!
Alas! I can see through her: there is not
So thin a Queen in the Cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Hold thee, good Woman, pray thee take it quickly.
I came now from a Feast where we had plenty,
And brought these Dainties, meant unto another;
But my dear Charity tells me thou dost want it.
I pray thee eat it; do not look, but eat it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What Traytor art thou, that presents me Poy∣son?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: By all the truth and honesty in Man,
'Tis wholesome Food: see, I will be thy Taster,
Though in good sooth, it grievs mee to beguile thee
Of the least Morsel: sure thou hast need of 't▪
Good VVoman eat, and let not Famine be
Fearful of Poyson, or false Treacherie.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Is it not Poyson to a loyal heart,
To eat contrary to the Kings Command?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: No, if it were, what a many would have been poyson'd the last Lent, that may live to be very good Subjects, very good Subjects all the yeer after, except a few Fish-Dayes?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: 'Las, we are plain poor Country Folke, and hear no such news.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVhy will ye urge so much against your con∣science?
Have you not heard of my banishment, and the Kings Edict,
Proclaiming all men Traytors that relieve me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: VVe heard indeed the King had put away his old good VVife, and tane a new one: but can we think you are she that was the Queen?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Yes good Dissembler, you do know't, and you;
As sure as I know you for Lodovico,
And you, Sir, for Andrea: Can it be,
That you that have been loyal Subjects, should
Now go about to forfeit thus your Lives?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Pray leave this fooling, Mistriss: eat your meat;
And here's good Drink to wash it down: and then
If you have a minde to hang us, let the
Gallows take his due; for my own part, I had
Rather hang like a man, while I am good
For something, then you should pine away to no∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Fear not you me, pray Sir, nor neglect the care
That's due unto your selves, to injure me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O dearest Heaven! do you think we'ld injure you,
That venture lives for you? no, gentle Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Lo, there again, that's Treason too, to call her Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: No body hears nor sees; pray eat a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Do not I hear and see you? I am not safe
In my obedience unto the King,
To hold such conference with you that would
So violate his Laws: but let it warn ye
Off of this course; for I'll appeal to Justice
If you persist in this Rebellion.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Any woman but she, now in her Case, would eat such an Husbands Brains without Butter, rather then forsake good meat; and but for this wil∣fulness in her, I should not think her a woman, I. But as she is, new Master, we shall never do good upon her: and therefore since your Grace has not the grace to eat this meat, mark with what a grace or without Grace, I will eat it my self: do you fear Poyson? [Eats] Now Bottle let me play a part with thee; can you think this Poyson, that goes down so merrily?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Much good may it do thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Stay, now perhaps she'l eat.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: 'Tis like enough; I did but eat to get her an Appetite, therefore I'll e'en eat on, till all be done, to get her the better stomack: now Bottle, to thee again.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: See, here come poor Folks, that perhaps do want
That which superfluously thou hast devour'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P:
I'll eat again, for that: I am as poor as
they; and you never knew Charity in Beggers towards one another. Bottle again for that.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter to them, Pedro, Poggio and Lollio.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: O Misery! O Desolation!

SP.SPEAKER: Pogg. Loll.
SP.L: Diseases, Sicknesses, O Calamity!

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: What Saints are those that they invoke so?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What is the Cause of these sad Cries, good People?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Go back, if you respect your safety, go;
And look not this way where the Air disperseth
Nothing but foul Infection, Pain and Sorrow.
Return, I say, for here you appear strangers,
And run not to the Ruine of your selves:
This way is fil'd with Cries: you can meet nothing
But Lamentations of a thousand Souls:
Some Lame, some Blind, some Deaf, some Lunatick,
Some struck with Palsie, some with Leprosie;
All sighing, groaning, crying, underneath
The painful weight of Sorrow and Affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What is that woful part o'th' Country call'd,
That suffers this Calamitie? and how
Did the Inhabitants there stand affected
To Goodness or Religion?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: We are all sinful▪
Yet no way to extenuate our fault,
Or murmure at the Judgement faln upon us;
We have been held obedient to the Church,
True Subjects to the King, and friendliest Neigh∣bours
Among our selves, all Sicily could boast of:
This part of it, or Province, being call'd,
The fair Talermian Fields, and is the same
Our Kings have customarily laid out
For their Queens Dowry: and has therefore been
Vulgarly call'd The Paradice of Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Stay there, old man: I have heard there is
Neither Lawyer nor Physician in all the Province.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: None could e'er get a living amongst 'um in all their Practise.
It seems they liv'd then civilly and temperately.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Nor Gentleman nor Begger in their Con∣fines.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Then sure their Wealth was all communi∣cable.
There could not but be excellent Neighbour-hood.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: And, which was worth all the rest, their Priests
Were ever the best good-Fellows in all the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Y'are now upon the Confines of that Coun∣try,
And cannot scape some dangerous ill,
If you dare tast the Aire of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: That shall be try'd; I'll have a whiff on't:
If I get a mischief by it, let the Fools harm be a war∣ning to the VVise.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: See more of those distressed Souls that flie
The foul Contagion,
Yet charitable to each others wants:
For here the Deaf conducts the Blind: the Blind
Supports the Lame: the Dumb removes the sick and feeble.
All that can make least shift for't, flie the Place,
Then do not you press torward it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: There will I.
Take up my Habitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Y'are not desperate?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Mark me, good Lodovico, note my Reasons:
This poor afflicted Province was my Dowry:
And the o'er-hasty judging world will say,
According to the Censure pass'd on me,
My Trespass drew this Evil on the Land.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Tis better that the world should judge so, and perish
For it in it's Ignorance, then you so wilfully
Be cast away: you hear that none escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: None, Old nor Young, Man, Woman Child, all
In one kinde or other, do feel Affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Do any die?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: None, though the most do wish
They might, in lieu of their sad sufferings.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: And whither now do you intend your travail with your griefs?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: VVe hope a better Air will cure us. But
VVe are advis'd by our Divines and Augurs,
By the best means we can, to make our Journey
Towards the Court, to send our sad complaint
Unto the King.

SP.SPEAKER: (Eul.
SP.L: Hear now what he will say)

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: They find by Divination, that this punish∣ment
Is falne upon this Province by the Sin
Of the Adulterous Queen, whose Dowrie 'twas.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Did not I tell you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: And that until
His justice take away Her loathed life,
This evil will not cease.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What, the Queen Eulalia's life?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Yes Sir; we hear shee's banish'd, and forbid relief:
But nothing save her polluted blood must quench this flame,
In expiation of her Sin and shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Dare you stay longer here? pray let us flie.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Why then you think me guiltie, Lodovico.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I know not what to think, but that I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Was that your Priests opinion and advice?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Yes, and thus grounded, that our pains began
Just at the hour, the Kings Indulgencie
Releas'd her forfeit Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: 'Twas everso; Priests are but Apes to Kings,
And prostitute Religion to their ends.
SP.P: Might you not judge as well, it was th' injustice and the wrongs the innocent Queen hath suffer'd, that has brought sense of her injuries upon her Pro∣vince? And that if she had died, her Dowrie here with her had also suffered Death? to make it nothing to the King, as he made her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I, mark ye that: and that your false surmise
Against the Queen has brought this evil on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.P: O now my pain increases. 1. O mine Eyes. 2. My Brain. 3. My Bones. 4. My limbs are on the Rack.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: 'Tis plain, your fowl mistrust is the infection that rages in you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Lodovico, peace: where is thy pain good man?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.P: Here in this Arm shrunk up as it were sear'd with fiery Irons.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Bless'd Providence assist me whilst with Prayers I use the gift thou gav'st me for the cure of these afflicted People. Give me thine hand: what feelst thou now?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: A precious cooling Balm that has extin∣guished
The scorching heat I felt, and has reduc'd
My Flesh, my Sinews, and my Arteries,
Into their natural temper and true use.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Joyn that hand to thy other, and thank Hea∣ven then
SP.L: That made thee whole.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: I do, I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Mira∣culous!

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: O sure you are some Heavenly Saint or Goddess.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Beware Idolatry, and onely send
All praise to th' power whose mercy hath no end.
Onely do this for me: inform the rest
How you have sped, and win them back again,
To the next village: bid them be of chear,
Whilst I make Holy Prayers for their help.
Ile come and live among you for my hire,
Which shall be cheap, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: All we have
VVill be too slight reward: first take my store.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I will but take my next competent meal.
I hope this will be thought but valuable.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: I pray take more.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Go back I say with your sad company,
And comfort them with news of your success,
And a full hope of cure to every one
That's Partner in this sad Affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: With happy feet I shall spread it through the Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O happy woman, now no more a Queen,
But Holy Saint: I see how Providence
Means to advance thy injur'd innocence.
Ile dwell here now my self, and without fear:
For perfect health I think dwells only where
Good Eulalia remains: I have enough
To buy a Farm for me and poor Andrea.
But what's become of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Ile tell you, Lodovico: the poor Fellow
Is gone to taste the Countrey Air for me,
Lest I might be infected: you shall see
Straight how he speeds.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: And that was honest love.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: A Surgeon, a Surgeon! Oh a Surgeon!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul,
SP.L: How now, Andrea?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: A Surgeon: Oh twentie Surgeons, bone∣setting Surgeons.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: What's the matter man?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: I am out of joynt. Ile taste no more of such contagious Aires, To save as many Queens as I have hairs. Oh Surgeons and Bone-setters, Bone-setters and Surgeons, all my Bones, all my Bones for a penny.
SP.L: I have not a finger nor a toe in joynt: my Leggs,
my Thighs, my Arms, my neck.
My back and Crupperbone is out of joynt.
Oh for a Sowgelder, a Surgeon I would say.
Out a joynt, out a joynt, I am all out a joynt.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Thy tongue's not out a joynt.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: No, nor a Thing
I have that has no Bone in't: All else is out a joynt.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: This came of tempting Providence: were not you
Told the danger by the many that smarted of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: I met them all dancing and frisking home.
The blind man made the way: the dumb man sung,
The deaf kept time to his Notes: the lame led on
The Dance to all the rest: whilst I can go
No further. [lies down] 'Twas for you I ventured.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: And now you repent you meant me so much good.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: And now again I do repent that ever I did repent. Oh for a Stone-cutter, a Bone-setter I would say.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVell Sir, give me your hands: stand up.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: VVith as good a will as ever I stood to wo∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Now, how do you feel your self?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: In very pretty plight, I feel I am sufficient.
SP.P: Haugh, heigh— [Capers and turns] 'twill do again: and if I durst venture into that unluckie Countrey again, I would now teach the Clowns how to Dance for joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Yes you shall venter Sir; and by the way,
Ile teach you to teach them to work and pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: To work and play I pray you,

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: If there be Heaven on earth, it is this woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Then if there be a Purgatorie on earth,
Ile venter through it for her, heigh, o, ho.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. V.
DIV3.L: 1. Health and Joy: Health and Joy.
2. O happy woman that ever she came hither!
1. Nay happy we that ere she came among us.
2. VVhat shall we render her in recompence?
All that we have is too little for this woman,
This good woman, this holy woman, this she-Saint,
If there be one above ground.
3. O do not make an If at her, neighbour, lest the ground swallow thee quick in thy Infidelitie.
2. Now doubtless, and without all adventure, she is an unknown woman.
3. And therefore a good woman: for 'tis too true,
All those that are well known are e'en bad enough:
And known she will not be for all our entreats,
No not so much as from whence she came, we see.
2. And that counsel she may keep still for me:
For doubtless, and without all peradventure
If we had need of another such, 'it were in yain to seek her.
1. Sure 'twas from Heaven she came,
Where the whole stock of good women vvere plac'd long ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.L: 'Tis she I'm confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Stroz.
SP.L: Our work lies fairly then before us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: These look like mischievous Robbers.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: What can they take from us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Your Life, I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: I have e'en din'd, let 'em take away when they please.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Their looks are murderous.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Fear not, Lodovico: why look ye Friends, so amazedly? ha'ye lost your way? or what do ye seek?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: No, we ha' found our way, 'tis to you we seek: we dare come roundly to you, for all your
SP.L: Guard, your old Fool, and your young here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O my unhappy Fears!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: You will not murder me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.L: 'Tis all the Office we are bound to doe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Just Heaven protect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.L: Call upon Heaven as you go thitherward:
VVe may not stay long Invocations.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Pray take me in your way, and run me through her, if you be honest Murderers. Help: Murder, Murder!

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. VII.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter to them, Curate, Crier, Pedro, Lollio, Poggio.

SP.SPEAKER: Crier.
SP.P: O yes! O yes! O yes!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Silence Crier, suspend the Proclamation, to preventa bomina∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Heaven has sent us ayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.L: O we are prevented!

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P:
On, on; sa, sa; down with their VVeapons, up with their heels, till we insect and rip up the in∣trails of the Cause: what an Assassinate was here at∣tempted?
O infausta Des! two swords against the naked vvomb of a VVoman! and none but weapon∣less men to assist her!

SP.SPEAKER: viz.
SP.L: Senex & Ineptus.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: That is to say, Give me their Swords un∣der my Fools Coat, I'll hurt no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Upon my facundity, an elegant construction by the Fool. So, I am cedunt arma Togae.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: For our attempt Sir, we vvill answer it: vve are for the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Then vve are for the King, Sir; & in nomine
Majestatis, we command you to attend our present
Office, and then we will examine yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Loll.
SP.P: And then if you deserve the Gallows, you shall be sure on't: a short breathing-vvhile shall be no hinderance to you. So Crier lift up your Voice, and proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Crier.
SP.P: O yes, O yes, O yes: By the Kings most Excellent Majesty, a Proclamation, prohibiting upon pain of Death, any Relief to be given unto the ba∣nish'd Eulalia.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Now say, VVhereas upon just and lawful Tryal.

SP.SPEAKER: Crier.
SP.L: VVhereas, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: The said Eulalia.

SP.SPEAKER: Crier.
SP.L: The said Eulalia.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: I am that hapless she, that for relief will not beg, nor borrow, nor take of yee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.P: 'Tis she, and at the price of Life I vvill re∣lieve her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: How? vvhat have vve done? In relieving her from killing, we are all become Traytors.

SP.SPEAKER: Loll.
SP.L: That's an idle fear: vve knew her not,
VVhich now vve do, vve may again reliver her
Into their hands, for them to kill her yet:
And then there's no harm done.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: So let us give them their swords again; and
vvhen they have done their vvork, to make all sure,
vve'll hang them for their pains, and so keep the Law
in our own hands vvhile vve have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: The woman must be sav'd á manubus istis.
They are Catilinarian Traytors.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: You Sir, have reason; you have found her Life
The King has pardon'd: and although her Doom
In this her Banishment were heavy, and
A punishment even unto Death, but that
Good soul she works and labours for her food,
You find not yet 'tis lawful any kill her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Recte dixisti Domine: therefore Sir,
You that are for the King, as you pretend,
Shew us th' Imperative mood or warrant for her death,
Or we shall put you into the Optativa mood,
By punishment to wish your selves dead oftner
Or more times than bona fide there be Tenses
In all the Moods of all my Accidences.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: For my part Ile forgive them, if they will
Deliver truely who corrupted them,
To rid the world of this weary burden; that I may pray for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Can such a goodness deserve so fowl a Cen∣sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: But first tell me: Are not you two the men that gave false evidence at my Arraignment touch∣ing injur'd Sforza?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.L: We gave no evidence, nor false nor true.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: No countrey-woman, they had no such Beards. But I will try if I can make'm like'em: O rare! what a nimble Barber am I? Lod. They are the self-same men, the two cashier'd Lieutenants that Sforza should have hang'd for mutinies in the late Wars.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: What hinders now their execution?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Digito compesce labellum: silence good Pedro.
I do commend your zeal: but Periculum est in via,
We will walk safely: for this time therefore wee'l do onely thus,
Double our guards upon 'em, and away to prison with them,

L.HI: Est locus in carcere quod Tullianum appellatur.

SP.L: We will presume to know who 'twas that set you awork, before you go,

SP.SPEAKER: Ambo.
SP.L: You will be made to answer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: A word more, wee'l hang you presently, and answer that too: Abite hinc in malam Rem: away with 'm.

SP.SPEAKER: Loll.
SP.L: Ah Rogues, wee'l hamper ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Pogg.
SP.L: Kill a woman 'cause she was a Queen?

SP.SPEAKER: Loll.
SP.P: Wee'l hamper ye, and halter ye, and do ye hear? hang ye.
SP.STAGE: Exeunt Lollio and Poggio, with Fabio and Strozza.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Abi hinc & malam rem, away with'm.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: As I am Erudite, idoneus Adolescens,
A very towardly Juvenis. Cupis at{que} doceri?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Wilt thou be a Scholar?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: After you is manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Now by mine intellect, discreetly spoken.
Be but my Pupil, I will make thee one,
And dip thy Caput in pure Helicon.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Pray what's my Caput? and what's your Helicon?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Still a desire to learn: this is no Fool.
And by the company hee's in, I do suspect,
Simile non est Idem: hee's too wise,
To be the thing he seems but in disguise:
Some Lord of Court, his outside non obstante.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: It is confess'd Sir, I am Lodovico,
Somtimes a Lord of Court when this was Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: O Oedipus! I meant this Juvenal.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: No truely Sir, your Simile non est Idem.
I am no Lord, what ere you like me to.
What I may pass for in the Country I know not,
At Court I was a Fool when she was Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: VVe dare not call her Queen now: but while we
Relieve her not, though we associate her,
VVe are the Kings true Subjects: and with your leave,
Disclaiming of all Honourable Titles,
VVe'll live amongst ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: O gracious woman, so I may safely call you,
VVho once preserv'd my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Mention not that.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: I ought not to conceal it: therefore know
That some years past being imploy'd to Court
To render the Kings Rents for this Province:
VVhich though I duely did, there was a Lord,
A strange officious one, that charg'd me deeply,
And all our Province, with detested breach
Of our Allegiance: at which my rage
Banish'd my reason, and confounded so
My senses, that without respect of Person,
Or Place, which was the Danger of the Law,
I struck him there in Court: and was adjudg'd
To suffer death for't, till you won my Pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: VVere you that man?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: And 'twas my
Cozen Lord'I warrant that you box'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.P: 'Tis he that braggs so much his truth unto the Crown; I need not name him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Sed nunc quid sequitur? Pray mark the issue of this Court quarrell. By the way,'tis well you have renounc'd all qualitie of Court.
SP.L: Here were no living for you else; for know,
Since this mans trouble, not a Gentleman,
Much less a Courtier dares breath amongst us,
But be as you pretend and write, but Yeoman:
You shall live Jovially with us and welcome,
At your own charge, your own Viaticum.

SP.SPEAKER: Loll.
SP.L: We have laid up
The murderous minded men in dungeon deep,
Clogg'd them with Ploughchains, Fetters and Horse∣locks.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: VVe'l teach 'm to kill Queens:

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: VVe mean this woman, this discarded Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: For all the Feasts, the Triumphs and the Glories
That have been spent, at price of great Estates,
In celebration of my high Advancement;
For all the King has in his present being,
His Love to boot, assur'd in highest measure;
Me-thinks there is yet wanting an Addition
To crown my Happiness: all's not safe hereafter;
I cannot safely say I am his Wife,
While th'other seems contented with a Life. Flavello!

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Most Mighty Soveraign.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: O most Coelestial sound!
Here's all your business granted.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Greatest and best of Queens! All?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: See the Kings hand to all: do you mistrust me?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: I onely look for the poor womans Pardon
That kill'd her Husband for his gelding the Priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.P: If you but manage the Profits of my Fa∣vours with a discreet Hand now, you may soon finde the difference between a Mignion, and the Son of a Dish-Maker.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: I finde it in your Gifts, my bounteous God∣dess.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: Oh Divine!

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: And would presume that
I my self were worthy
A place i'th' Kalendar, might I do you Service,
That merited the smallest of your Graces.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: Do you know the village where that woman lives?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Who, sacred Deitie?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: I'm very sick to name her or her Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: O Eulalia; yes, the very House: 'tis in your Majesties way now, as you pass to Nicosia: the King is ready, Madam, and calls away; he longs to be at the end of his journey, to perform his Duty in the three Grants belong to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: O but that Woman, and that hated Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Eulalia▪ Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: Thou art a base
Ingrateful Villain to name her to me;
Thou hear'st me say, I dare not speak her name,
Yet thou dar'st stab mine Ears again, with it.
Had some receiv'd the Favours thou hast done,
Or could but dream of half▪thou'rt like to have,
I should not fear her Ghost; but thou art dull.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: O let me take new spirit from your hand,
And say unto your self, She is sure dead.
But the King comes. I am enough inspir'd.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I will not onely have you guiltless, Sir,
But free from least suspect; let but a spark
Of Discontent appear upon your Look,
I'll rip the hollow cave that holds the fire,
And with Death quench it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: I beseech your Highness,
If any alteration in my looks
Be found, or read, let it as well be construed,
It grows but from a filial fear t'offend.
I have forgot I had another Mother:
And humbly at the Feet of this I honour,
I beg her Ayd, to win your Favour towards me.
Most gracious Madam, if you knew the Truth,
The fair sincerity I bear in Duty
Towards your Highness—

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: For what respect, young Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: The principal i'th' World: For that you have
My Fathers Love; and but to Wrong or Grieve you,
Were Stripes or Wounds to his Affection.
So much of my late Mother I remember,
To yield a Reverence to his Contentment, and shall for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: My Lord, my Love, what pretty meaning have you?
Do you bring your Son to mock me?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Ha! my Alinda, he's no Son of mine,
That with lesse Adoration dares look up
On thy Divinity, then the Aegyptians
Gave to the Sun it self: but an out-cast Bastard,
And of the daring Giants ignorant Nature,
That war'd against the Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.P: I would not move your Anger: pray let this win your Reconcilement.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: O thou art gentle, and the life of Sweetness:
Come, my Alinda, I was calling you
To our intended Journey to Nicosta,
Where solemnly I will perform my Vow,
To grant the three demands I promis'd you,
In the full view of our Nobility.
Which by the Custome of my Predecessors
Have ratified and confirm'd the Power
Of Queens, and made them absolute: have you thought
To ask things worthy of your Dignity,
Wherein I fully may declare my Bounty?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: I, Sir, shall be so reasonable, that
I doubt not upon the way, or there at very instant,
To crave past my Desert.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: O you are modest: but ask home, Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: And by the way, Sir, let it be my Suit,
We give a Visit to distrest Eulalia;
Wherein we may do Charity fitting Princes;
(We may perhaps give Order for her Burial)

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thou art all Goodness: Come, all Friends, Gonzago:
But thank her Clemency.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: An Earldome be thou sure of, wise Flavello,
To add to thy improvements: Though it be
No full Discovery, I'll make it serve,
As I will fashion it, to excellent use.
Poyson or Sword thou heardst him speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Elav.
SP.L: And in a menacing way: Now what may be
Conjectur'd by such words, from men whose looks
Shew discontent against your Mightiness,
Rests most considerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: VVrite, Flavello, write,
VVrite by that Copy in a States-Man's hand.
Alas, good men! I dare even swear for them,
How ere those words might fall in their discourse,
They had no thought of me: yet this surmise
Gives me an hint to try her Loyaltie,
Or make her once more guiltie: for my State
Stands by the King, as unto her his hate.
Read it Flavello.

Q.P: Most Royal and most wronged Soveraign Mistress, be happily assured that the time of your Restoration is at hand: and thatby no loss means then the death of that she-monster that usurps your Dignitie. All shall be determin'd at Ni∣cosia, by
Your devoted Servant unto death. Nameless.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: 'Tis well.
It needs no superscription: only seal it,
And think of your directions and disguise.
'Tis but your half days journey: and be sure
VVe are not far behind you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fla.
SP.L: I flie, my Soveraign.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Now to the King,
Of whose despight I still must sharp the sting.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No news of Lodovico yet, Horatio?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: None since he stole from Court upon the Banishment
Of that false wicked woman, whom I cannot
Name to your face or forehead, but I tremble.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Because you fear all horned Beasts.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: My Loyalty forbid,
And my infallible Truth unto the Crown,
But I were sensible of the injury.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I know thy Loyalty: but as for Lodovico,
How was my Judgement wrong'd in him!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: And mine.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I thought my self as safe in that mans Coun∣sel—

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: And so did I,
By my lov'd Loyalty, think my self safe
In his Advices—

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yet methought he had
A kinde of slyness in his Countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Yes, he had ever a kind of a slie look.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: That still methought I had a Genius
That check'd my forward love, and did inform me
That he would prove disloyal: and for that cause,
To speak plain truth, I never lov'd him truely.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: VVill your Majesty believe me? I would I might never rise
Into your Favour (and that I would not say
For all the Traytors Lands in your Kingdom,
VVhich were no small reward) if that were not
Mine very own conceit of Lodovico
That Traytor; hang him: what should I call him less?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yet 'twas given out you lov'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: So 'twas thought your Highness did.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And that he was your yoak-fellow in the State.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Yes, when he's hang'd he shall be King. How Horatio?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Your Majesty knows my thoughts: nay I thank my creation, I was ever
Just of your Majesties mind from my Nativitie,
And in that faith Ile die.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Here's a true States∣man now!
Go, send Gonzago to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: My sweet yong Prince?
I shall: but ere I go,
Let me inform your Highness in my thoughts
Of the sweet Prince Gonzago: if ever King
VVas happy in a Son, you are in him.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Go, call him to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Cherish him, good my Lord:
Hee'l be a sure staff to you in your Age,
And prove a Statesman quickly: I cannot think,
Except in him and your undoubted Queen,
Petruccio and my self, True Loyalty lives.
And here he comes: obedience in his Face
Most brightly shining.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Wait without Horatio.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: My dread Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Did you attempt
Against my strict command to visit Sforza?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonza.
SP.L: It is most true, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You are a Traytor.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: Gracious Heaven forbid it.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What was your purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonza.
SP.L: First on my knees let me implore your Royal Pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: My end was noble: as I thought, well suit∣ing
The Honour of a Prince: I would have search'd
Into the secrets of his heart by questions,
VVhether he had intended or conceived
Treason against your Highness, as it is
Presum'd he did: for which he was committed.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My self for that was his Accuser;
How durst you then make a scruple at it?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: Still relying on your Pardon, I had thought
T'have won confession of it from himself.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Suppose he had confess'd it?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonza.
SP.L: I had then
Concluded there had been a Probabilitie
Of my poor mothers falsehood: yet I would have put
That Question to him next.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: And say
He had confess'd that too?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: Then had I sav'd
Your Laws a needless labour in his death;
And with the same hand made that mother child∣less,
That by her folly forfeited her Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: VVas that your resolution? but suppose
He had denied all?

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: All had then been nothing
But a Scandal to my mother and himself:
So good a Souldier would not be a lyer
To save an abject life.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Sirrah, you are
His Bastard, not my son, in doing this.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonza.
SP.L: You are my King, would I could say, my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Within there!
Horatio, would you think it? this young stripling
Takes part against me with that Traytor Sforza.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Does your Grace think so?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Think so? I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Then I know it too: Think, did you say? I think 'twas time to think it.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I knew it not till now.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: As I am true to th' Crown, just now I knew it too.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: O do not so interpret, Royal Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: What can be said against it? has not his Grace spoke it?
What must be done with him to please your Majesty?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Convey him from my sight, and let our Marshal
Petruccio take him to safe custody,
Till our further pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: My King, and Fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Hence with him I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: Great Sir, your mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Did not I tell your Majesty there was not,
But in the Queen, Petruccio, and my self,
True Loyaltie in the Court? Away you Traytor∣ling.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: My Lord, you are too severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: What? in being true to th' Crown? O my Loyaltie!

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: No news yet? no return?

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: We shall have, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: You made not choise of men of Resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: They were the same exasperate cashier'd Souldiers
That sware so valiantly against Eulalia.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Many that pass for Souldiers dare swear va∣liantly,
That dare not fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Many that dare not fight,
Dare do a murther Madam, such a tame one too.
I am confident they have kill'd her: however, I have done my best.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Thou hast done nothing whilst that woman lives.
The work was not so course, that your own hand
Could have disdain'd it, Sir, if you had lov'd me.
So leave me, negligent Fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.L: Her first months Majesty hath wip'd out
The memorie of all her former dayes.
I must not lose her though: this hand then soon
Must do the work, be 't not already done.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How cheers my love? what ominous aspect
Hath wrought this sad Eclipse upon that Beautie,
VVhose radiancie onely is my life?
Cast by this veil of sadness: quit my fears,
And from my Browes wipe off a score of years.
No? what must then remove it? or dispell
These Clouds, that from the anguish of thy heart
Do cast this shadow ore my happiness?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: I must not, will not name it: but you said
You would do something, which it seems
Your wavering love neglects.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Can I neglect
A duty that belongs to my Alinda?
Speak it again: and by my first nights bliss
I had with thee, by this kiss, and by this,
Ile treble in performance all my promises.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Y' are dull in your performances: I will
Not name a request the second time, although my life,
Your dignitie, and your Kingdoms safetie,
Lie on the rack for 't.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: She will not name 't again:
Her last request was for the head of Sforza,
Her arrogant proud Father, whose perversness
Checq'd at her due promotion; and whose life
Swolne up with Popularitie, was my danger,
Threatning no less then ruine on my State.
She will not name 't again, poor tender soul,
Lest she might fall into th' interpretation
Of an unnatural child: yet for my safetie,
She suffers in desire to have it done.
I have prevented her desire, 'tis done:
I know Petruccio his Antagonist,
Who had my warrant and Signet for it,
VVould not be slack in th' execution.
Come, sweet, be fearless: that which your mild good∣ness
Is now so timerous to name, is done.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Is she pursu'd and put to death?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What she?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: Nay, I have said again.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Sforza, my dearest life, th' unnatural Homi∣cide
That sought thy life and mine, is put to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: VVhat, my dear Father?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: VVas it not your Desire?
Here comes sure Testimony: speak Petruccio;
