I will not ask, Is 't done? but speak the manner
How Sforza di'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: A self-wil'd obstinate man:
Such as he liv'd he di'd: and gracious Madam,
That a more bloody Spectacle should not move
Your tender nature to compunction, I brought
But this inseparate Adjunct of his malicious Head
Against you, the King, and the whole Kingdoms good.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: This is a token most infallible,
The Jewel that none but the cold hand of Death
Could ravish from him: 'Tis done:
The fear of him is like a storm blown ore:
'Tis done but this is yet but part of that full satis∣faction
That must confirm my safetie: Pray my Lord,
You fatal instrument of my Fathers blood,
Let me not look upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Nay Alinda,
You must not be so sad: your gentle sorrow
In those obsequious Tears express'd, shew nature
And Filial pietie as he was your Father:
But think upon your wrongs, my dangers, and your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Alas my Lord, think you withall, a Father
Is not so early forgot. But sorrow leave me,
And do you give me leave to think, that now
It is no less a Childs part to embrace
Revenge then sorrow for a Fathers loss.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How means my love?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: She lives that was his Ruine.
You may remember whom I mean: Eulalia.
Till now, I had no Plea against her life:
Onely my care of you might wish her Death,
For your security. Her fowl Adultery
And secret Practices against your Crown,
Were nothing unto me, compar'd with this.
Now I have lost a Father: she the cause:
He suffers, she survives: where are your Laws?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Sweet, be content.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Content your self great Sir,
With your black infamie: sit down content
On your Majestick Throne, the President
Of Capital contented Cuckolds, do,
Till all your Subjects dance the Hornpipe too.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Nay dear Alinda, do but think—

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Think what?
VVhat on a course to be reveng'd on you?
To serve you in that kind my self?

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: O torment!

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Or rather, let me think your lustful purpose
VVas but to rob me of my Virgin-Honour.
And that you put her by but for a time,
Until my youth had quench'd your Appetite;
Then to recal her home to your embraces.
She is your wife it seems then still: not I.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You have awak'd me from a Lethargie
In which I was confounded: now I see
She and mine Honour cannot live at once:
She dies, Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: And you may consider
A little further yet Sir, if you please:
You Father and maintain a Son (your own
I cannot safely say, and therefore more
Is my vexation) who demeans himself
Not towards me, like one that were your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Hee's also doom'd already, my Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: It may prevent a greater strife hereafter,
Should he but live t'inherit Lands and Titles
That must belong to yours and my succession.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thy wisdom inspir'd me: all shall be
(Be thou but my Alinda) rul'd by thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Seal you that Grant: with this kiss I Seal mine:
My glories were eclips'd, but now they shine.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Poggio, Lollio, two Countrey-men with Eulalia.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Y'Are welcome Friends, your prayers and good wishes
Are comforts to me, yet without danger of the Proclamation.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Madam, the Court in all the Braverie
It boasts and borrows, cannot so rejoyce
In the bright shining Beauty of their Queen,
As we in your enjoying in this plainness.
Their Bells, and Bonfires, Tilts and Tournaments,
Their Feasts and Banquets, Musicks and costly shews
(How ere unpaid for) shall not outpass our loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Be you as confident, I will not wrong
A man among you: therefore pray reserve
What is your own, and warrant your own safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Pogg.
SP.L: But how you'll live, we know not: we are now
In our old former Health: the Countrey's cur'd,
Your Practice at an end: unless you had
The common gift of most Physitians,
To make as many sick, as you make sound,
You will not find a Patient in seven years.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: But I have other Arts: sufficient skill
In works of several kinds, the Needle, Loome,
The Wheel, the Frame, the Net-Pin: and choice of
Fingers works are most familiar with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: And can you handle the Bobbins well, good Woman?
Make statute-Lace? you shall have my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Pogg.
SP.L: And mine, to make Tape-Purles: can you do it?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Yes, and teach all your children works to live on.
The which, together with my own labour,
May bring sufficient for my maintenance:
Without the idle help of Begging, Borrowing,
Or any way infringing the Kings Command.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: You'l have a help beyond himself, but bor∣rowing.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Something I have in Book, to help their know∣ledge,
And by practise give them literature.
Then when these serious works and studies toil us,
For Recreation, yet with equal skil,
VVee'l practice divers Instruments, Songs and mea∣sures,
That shall invite the Powers above to smile
On the content of which we them beguile.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Well Mistris, ours is the voice of the whole Countrey;
All which, or what you please of it, is yours:
Take this House: make your choice of servants.
Take our children: make your own Rates for their Education.
Our Purses and our lives are free to you:
Get what you can, that's your own: will this please you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Yes gentle Friends, and with asmuch content
As ere I found in height of Government.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Take your possession then: and let
Posteritie record, that without grieving
A Royal Queen once Traded for her living.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Eho, oh, io, where is my learned sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Why seem you so distracted?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Alas what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Sure, sure, his Scholars have over-Ma∣ster'd him, and whipt him out of his wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Corpus inane animae, hold thy peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Pray speak, what chance has happened?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P:
Non est narr andi locus: Go forth and see. Th'
enraged Rurals are in an uproar lowd, each one an Hercules furens, a formidabilis formidandus Hostis and quite against the Law
SP.L: Of nostrum est injuriam non inferre,
Are on the point of making themselves merry,
In hanging those ill destin'd men by th' neck
That sought so late to give your neck the check.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: O let us flie to rescue them.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Yet I hope
Your hast will bring you short to cut the Rope.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lollio, Poggio, and guard, with Fabio and Strozza.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Bring 'em away to present execution:
They have lien too long upon the Countreys charge.
We have given 'em bread and water a whole for∣night.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.L: You dare not do't: what Law are we con∣demn'd by?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Dare we not do't? that word's an hanging matter
Here in our Civil Government: dare not do 't Sir?
VVee'l do't; and when 'tis done, wee'l argue Law with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stroz.
SP.L: When you have tane our lives, you'l lay the
Law to us: you cannot be so Barbarous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Impudent Traytors! how dare you say we cannot? yet because we graciously are pleas'd to put the Law out of our hands, and make you hang your selves, Ile give you Reason: Silence on your lives. First, know, lewd men, y' are Traytors to the King, In offering to be wiser then his Judgement, Which was but Banishment to the good Eulalia:
SP.L: Seeking most Trayterously to take the life
Of (I do not say the Queen, but) the Kings wife
Of most happy memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.L: The good Eulalia?

SP.SPEAKER: Stroz.
SP.L: the Kings wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: That was:
You shall not catch us tripping Sir,
VVe are more than your match.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Good I do say she is, and good again
I dare pronounce he that by dayly pain
VVorks for her dayly bread: and for bare hire,
Teacheth our children so, that we admire:
The Infants who have understanding more
Then we their Parents have, or then
Our Fore-fathers before us had.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: But brother Lollio, make not your speech so long: what is 't to them? they'l carry none on 't to th' 'other world: let's do what we came to do, e'en hang 'em. Then, as I said, wee'l argle it afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: But brother Poggio, better 'tis they live
A minute two or three, then such a Speech
As I am now upon, be lost.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lodovico, Pedro, Curate, Andrea, Eulalia.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: See what y' have won by your delay! if she prevent not now
The good we meant her, I dare hang for 'm.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: In tempore venimus with a Reprieve, quod omnium Rerum est Primum.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Alas, what mean you neighbours? would you now
For all my labours and my Prayers for you,
Blast me with curses of expiring men?
What trespass have I done you, that for me
You put these men to death against my will?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab. Stroz.
SP.L: We do applaud your mercy, gracious Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: There now, there they deserve hanging for that:
They call you Queen, against the Proclamation.
Dare you maintain 'em in't, and now speak for 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: No, I condemn their faults, and blame their lives;
But have nor Power nor will to judge the men:
You have the will; but to assume the Power,
You take the Kings Right from him: you transgresse
As much his Laws in spilling of their blood,
As they had done in mine, had they prevail'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: They do not intend to spill their blood, Countrey woman, they would but strangle them: never pierce the skin, nor make 'm an hair worse men, if you consider rightly what they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: But to the point. This is the All and some: We meant you a good turn, and for your sake t' have hang'd 'em right or wrong. Now since you will needs stand in your own highway of womens wisdom, which is wilfulness

SP.SPEAKER: (Cur.
SP.P: A most Elegant Figure!) Let'em and please you come to the Gallows another day for killing you out right: who can help it?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Oraculously spoken: which of the Sages could said more?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: 'Tis not unknown to you, that I can speak like a Sage, and am one of the Sages of our Precinct here for the Laytie, though your learning lie another way among us. I am a Sage, and will be a Sage.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: And so am I, and will be: and but that wise woman, which is as much to say as a fool for her la∣bour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Another elegant Figure.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: But that, I say, she has gain-said it, we would; yet to shew our selves Sages, hang 'em up for Scarcrowes, to fright all their fellows for coming from Court to kill women in the Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: O how I love a Sage! how many Sages do you allow in your Precinct?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Some three or four main Heads: we have now only Pedro, Poggio and my self:
SP.L: But we have many Powers under us:
These now are Powers that execute our Commands.
There is as much difference between a Sage and a Power,
As between a Judge and a Hangman.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: But is not the learned Curate a Sage amongst ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: No, as I said before, their learning lies another way: we allow not our Clergie any Tem∣poral Offices, for reasons known unto our selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Pray let me have a Sages place amongst ye then: I long to be a Sage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Brother Andrea, you shall have my voice in your Election.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Sage Brother Lollio, I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: But will ye now, if misericordially
This gracious Foeminine preserve your lives
from the Gallow Tree,
Become new men indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I know they will
When they consider the most dangerous sin,
That threw them on their desperate Attempt,
And their escape from merited Punishment,
They cannot be so graceless, not to turn
To a reformed life: First know, yong men,
Your former Act 'gainst me an Innocent,
Was Perjurie by which I fell, yet flourish.
Consider there how black and fowl your Sin
Is rendred by my Chrystal innocence:
Your next Attempt against me, was blacker, Murder,
The very word sounds horrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Stroz.
SP.L: Gentle Madam,
Name it not then: but by your sacred mercy,
Acquit us of the Doom which we so justly
Have drawn upon our selves: and we will spend
Our lives in rendring satisfaction
To your abused goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: This is serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Or may the earth on which we kneel for favour,
SP.L: Forc'd by the weight of our detested Sins, open.

SP.SPEAKER: Amb.
SP.L: Quick devour us.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: So, enough:
Ile take your words.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: But now you must reveal
By whom you have been wrought to these fowl Practices.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: All, wee'l discover all, though justly then we pay our lives to Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Good neighbours, Lollio, Poggio, and Andrea, conduct them to my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: My self also will to be their securer con∣voy go,
For fear the Rusticks may presume again
To stretch these penitent necks with halter strain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: You shall do well: I thank your Charity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Well, since in these we are prevented thus,
Come more, wee'l hang 'em, or they shall hang us.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Make me but once a Sage, and then fear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pogg.
SP.P: Thou shalt be one next Sessions, without all peradventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: When we have tane these mens confessions,
Ile write at large each passage to the King,
Against the good Eulalia's will or knowledge

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Ile be your faithful Messenger, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Thanks my good Pedro: but remember Silence.
So deep in thought good Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Never enough in contemplation of my Hap∣piness.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.P: It is your Heavenly mind that sweetens all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Pogg.
SP.P: VVhat's the matter man?
Doubtless and without all peradventure, more miracles.

SP.SPEAKER: Pogg.
SP.P: The news, good neighbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: O neigbours Poggio and Lollio, such a news, such a Discoverie, such a thing is come to pass, such a business is come to light, as your hearts never heard, your Tongues never thought, nor your ears ever utter'd: you cannot hear it, but it will drown you in a Sea of Admiration, never to rise again in your right wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Now am I mad till I hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Thou shalt tell me first whether it be good or bad, or Ile not hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: It is good or bad I assure you: and there∣fore you may be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: I mean which is it? good or bad?

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: I say it is good and bad: and you may both stay and be gone, hear it or hear it not, an't' please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Nay thou art in thy Jibes now: how good or how bad is thy news?
SP.L: I pray thee neighbour, I do pray thee how good or bad is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: Nay then it is neither good nor bad, but both: the best and the worst that ever you heard in your life, and the worst shall out first: what do you think of the woman that we have got among us?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Who, the holy woman? that we are all so bound to pray for? I hope no ill's betide her.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: Come, shee's a witch: flatly and plainly said to be a witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Did not I tell you she was an unknown woman, and therefore a good one, quoth you? but say I, doubt∣lesly; and without all peradventure, all that she did was but a kind of witchcraft.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: It cannot, fie, it cannot be: how is she found so? Countr. I do not say shee's found a witch, but she's accus'd for one.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: By whom is she accus'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.L: By two brave men at Arms that came from Court
VVith purpose to have kill'd her for the same.
To be short, They found her out, and naked swords they drew:
But as they thought to have thrust her through and through,
They both dead Palsie-struck fall to the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.L: And had no strength but of their Tongues to wound
The Fame she had.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Vertue can want no Foes,

SP.SPEAKER: Count.
SP.L: VVith that they cryed she was a witch, and swore
She also was that Queen which for a whore
The King had turn'd away.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: This is indeed the best news thou couldst bring.
Now doubtlesly and without all peradventure, 'tis the Queen indeed: and if she be not a witch, I am sorry I thought so, with all my heart: where be those men? wee'l hang'm presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: No, the Queen, if she be the Queen, will not have them hurt more then they be: we wete about to execute 'em: but she would not suffer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Goodness it self!

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Nay without all peradventure, if there be goodness above ground, I said, and I say it again, 'tis in that woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P:
She would have cur'd 'em presently her self: but could not do't, because the cruel Caitifs
would not confesse their sins, as she made us, you know, before her gift could cure us: by the same token I suffered an hours torment that I might have scap'd, because I was so loath to bring out that naughtie business betwixt me and the Millers wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: 'Twas well you confess'd at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: I, and they will be glad to confess, before they be able to stir hand or foot, I warrant: and so I told 'm when I lodg'd 'em both lovingly together upon straw in my Barn, too good for 'em; and so I told 'em too, for being Traytors to her Holiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: But where's our Holy woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Our Queen wee'l call her now, without all peradventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Coming this way to her Court-Cottage here, but very slowly, though our two new neighbours make the best way they can for her through the Peo∣ple that press upon her so with thanks and offerings for their new Healths: but she takes not so much for curing of a thousand mortal People, as I have spent in Turpentine and Tarre to keep my Flocklings cleanly in a Spring time. Hark, she comes: this is her Musick where ere she goes.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Heaven bless our Holy woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Depart good neighbours, good people all de∣part: shee'l come abroad again to morrow.
Within Heaven bless our Holy woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: She thanks you all good People, pray de∣part,
To morrow you shall have the second part:
She shall appear again unto you; pray depart,
The men in Peace, the Wives in quietness,
And let your bigger children still the less.
Heaven bless our Holy woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: So, now the Hubbub's gone: I pray pass on.
I shall be as weary of the Cottage, as of the Court,
If this noise hold: here's thrusting and crowding
As much as there, onely here they have less Pride.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVas ever comfort in the Court like this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I never liv'd till now.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Here come more of our weather-headed wise neighbours.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Heaven bless our Holy woman.
Heaven bless your Holiness.
Nay then Heaven bless our Sacred Soveraign.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: This Homage fits not me.
We had not liv'd but by your sacred means;
And will no longer live then be your Subjects.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: You go about to cast away your lives:
In serving or in succouring me, you fall
Into Rebellion against the King.
We have no King nor Queen but you.
Heaven bless your Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Heaven bless your Majestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: That was pronounc'd bravely; O my brave new neighbours!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Y' are Traytors All.
In honouring our Soveraign?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: I, well said, hold her to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: How dare you call me so?
VVe dare, and can prove it good and lawful.
This Province is engag'd unto you Madam,
The King made it your Joynture: and we find
No reason but you instantly possesse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVhat, and the King alive?
He's dead to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Yes, yes, he's dead to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: VVell said again: that's a sound point, be∣sworn
These be true Blades.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I tremble but to hear you,
And will not live an hour amongst you more
But with this freedom, To use my fair obedience to the King.
You shall obey the King then, and we'll obey your Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: O let that Title die with my late Fortune:
Remember it no more, but let me be
As one of you; nay rather, an Inferior,
Or I from this abiding must remove:
Of which I first made choice in truth for love.
O Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Take heed good neighbours,
Beware how you give Dignitie or Title; therein you may transgress.
No whit good Madam. Observe the Dialect of France,
And you shall find Madam given there in Courtesie,
To women of low Fortunes, unto whom
'Tis held a poore addition, though great Queens
Do grace and make it Royal.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: 'Tis then the Greatness of
The Person dignifies the Titles, not it the Person.
And in that, Madam, you are in your content
Above all Title's proper to great Princes:
But setting this aside, how thrive your Scholars?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: We go fairly on. [Enter 1. Girl.] look you Sir,
Here's one that knew no letter in the Book
Within these ten days, can read hitherto,
And waits for a new lesson: proceed hither—
And at your hour Ile hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Girl.
SP.L: Yes for∣sooth Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P:
Good Girl, well said: nay, nay, hold up your head: so, so, 'tis very well: let's see your Samplar:
what an hearts ease is here! Lod. Right in its per∣fect Colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Nay shee'l do well: now take me out this Flower. Keep your work clean, and you shall be a good Maid. Enter 3. Girl. Now where's your writing book?

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Girl,
SP.P: 'Tis here for∣sooth. Pray shall I haye a Joyn-hand Copy next?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: No child, you must not Joyn-hand yet: you must your letters and your minums better first. Take heed, you may Joyn-hand too soon, and so mar all: still youth desires to be too forward. Go take your Lute, and let me hear you sing the last I taught you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Whither do you press? who would you speak withall?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.L: O Sir, for Charity sake give us access unto the holy woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Who are you? or from whence?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: We are poor Pilgrims man and wife, that are upon our way struck with sad pain and sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Alas poor Pilgrims! here's she must do you good.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: How divine Justice throwes my Enemies in∣to my hands? what are your griefes?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: My wife is struck with dumbness.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Hold a little,
That's the greatest grief a woman can endure:
But trouble not thy self to seek for cure.
Too many a man i'th' world will change with thee
A wife that of her Language is too free,
And give good Boot.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Pray Sir be you silent.
And where's your pain?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Here in this hand;
Which I desire to shew in some more privacie.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Because your Blow cannot be safely given here, you think.
O sinful wretch! thou hadst no pain till now;
Nor was she dumb till divine Providence
Now at this instant struck her. It is now
Just as thou saist: and justly are you punished
For treacherous counterfeits. Lodowick search his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: His hand is wither'd, and lets fall a Knife.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: As sharp to do a mischief as ere was felt on.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Now take off his false Beard: see if you know him,
And let the woman be unmuffled.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O Divels!

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: O the last couple that came out of Hell!

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: These are the other two that damn'd them∣selves
In perjurie against you at your Tryal.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: How do you master Doctor, and Mistress Midwife?
Is this the Pen your Doctorship prescribes with?
This might soon write that might cure all diseases:
And are these the Labours you go to, Mistress Mid∣night?
VVould you bring women to bed this way?

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: O damnable conspirators!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Pray take 'm hence, their time 's not come for cure yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Come away Pilgrims: we'll cure 'em for you,
If your own salves can cure you: O my sweet Pil∣grims.
Fough, they stink of Treason damnably
VVhat, shall we hang'm? drown 'em? or burn 'em?
They shall taste fortie deaths, then take their own.

SP.P: I, come away with 'em: they shall die fortie times without peradventure,

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: You shall lose me, if you do any violence to any of 'em: but let'm be lodg'd with those we took to day: Ile feed 'em all.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: They'l be a jolly com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Pray do as I intreat.
You shall in all command us.

SP.P: Ile make my Barn a spittle for your conspira∣tors till it be top full, and then set fire on't, and please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Do you no harm, and fear none: send your Children.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Omn.
SP.L: Long live our Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Your Queen? have you a mind to be hang'd?
Queen? have you a mind to be hang'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: our School-Mistress, we would say.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVe live secure in spight of Foes: and see,
Where Heaven protects, in vain is Treacherie:
VVho says out State is low, or that I fell
When I was put from Court? I did not rise
Till then, nor was advanc'd till now. I see
Heaven plants me 'bove the reach of Treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: O happie, happie Saint!
SP.STAGE: Ex. Rustici with Doct. and Midwife.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. V.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Flavello, alias Alphonso, with a Letter to Eulalia, Poggio and Lollio following.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: I would she had a Councel: she shall have a Councel,
And we will be the Heads thereof,
Though I be put to the pains to be President my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: It is most requisite for her safety: her danger may be great.
A good guard then in my opinion were more requi∣rable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: 'Tis well consider'd: she shall have a Guard too: and we will be the limbs thereof, though I be put to the trouble of Captain on't my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: You will put on all Offices, yet count 'em pain and trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Yes, and perform 'em too here in our Court of Conscience, for here's no other profit to hinder the Dutie: let them above do what they list; we will have as much care of our School-Mistress, as they of their Semiramis: I speak no Treason nor no trifles neither, if you mark it. But she must never know this care of ours, She'll urge the Statute of Relief against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: This is some Courtier sure that's with her; he smells illfavordly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: That made me dog him hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: He shall not have her out of sight, that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Nor out of reach neither: a mischief's quickly done.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: No Superscription, nor any names unto it. Most Royal and most wronged Soveraign Mistress: (that must needs be me.) Be happily assured your Restauration is at hand; And by no less means then by her Death that usurps your Dignitie: (a plain conspiracie against Alinda in my be∣half.) All shall be determined at Nicosia, by
Nameless.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: You know not the contents then, and are bound by Oath you say not to reveal the senders of this Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: It is most true: onely thus much I tell you, they are your noble and best chosen Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Heaven! can it be, that men in my respect can plunge into such danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: So Madam, this being all I had in charge,
I must crave leave (indeed I do not like this
Oportunitie, nor well the countenances of these Hobnols.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: You are no messenger of such ill Tidings
To part so slightly: indeed you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: She's honied with the newes: I have al∣ready
Madam my Reward, and will no longer stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Then I must say, you shall stay: or Ile send
A cry as loud as Treason after you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: You'l wrong yourself and Friends then.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: You wrong your self Sir, and we charge you stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: By the command of Peasants?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: How! you choplogical Rascal, Peasants!

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Down with him into utter darkness.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: No-violence good Friends: but if you will detain him
Till I give order for his libertie,
You do the State good service.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: May it do you Service?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: The State is finely serv'd already.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Me most of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Hell cannot hold him faster then.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: Madam, hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Mad Asse, hold your prating till she calls you:
Mean time you are fast: 'twas time we were a Councel or a Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I thank thee Providence, I dreamed not of such ready help.
I am struck through with wonder at this Letter:
I could not at the first but think't a Bayt
To catch my willingness to such an Act;
Or Gullerie to mock my Hopes or wishes,
In case I had such: therefore I desired
The Messengers restraint from being my Relator:
But now a strong Belief possesses me,
A oble Fury has stirr'd up some Friends
To this high enterprize: whereby I gather
My cause is weigh'd above, whence I shall see
How well my patience over-rules my wrong,
And my Foes ruin'd with mine Honours safety.
But let my better Judgement weigh those thoughts,
I do not seek revenge, why shall I suffer it?
My causeless injuries have brought me Honour,
And 'tis her shame to hear of my mis-hap.
And if by Treachery she fall, the world
Will judge me accessarie, as I were indeed
In this foreknowledge of the foul intent,
Should I conceal it.
Then here's the trembling doubt which way to take▪
Whether to rise by her Destruction,
Or sink my Friends, discovering their pretence.
Friends have no Priviledge to be treacherous:
She is my Soveraignes wife, his chief content;
Of which to rob him, were an act of horrour
Committed on himself. The question's then,
Whether it be more foul ingratitude
To unknown Friends, and for an act of Sin,
Then to be treacherous to the Prince I love?
It is resolv'd: Ile once more see the Court.
O my good Patrons, I must now intreat
Means for my Journey to attend the King,
On a discoverie for the present safetie
Of his fair Queen: she will be murder'd else.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: And let her go: we have shut up your news-bringer safe enough, will keep you by your favour, short enough from hindring such a work.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Dear Friends, a small matter will prevent this world of dangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Would you have us to become Traytors, to
Supply your wants against the Proclamation?
If you be well, remain so: your Iudustry
Can keep you here: but for a Journey, that
Requires Horses and Attendants: money must he had▪
Which we have not for such an idle purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: O hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Will you neglect your House and Trade to meddle any more with State-matters?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: And bring our necks in danger to assist you?
Let your own counsell advise you to stay.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How died the Boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Gonzago Sir, your Son?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My Son, my Son? you urge the name of Son
To work remorse within me, when I ask
How died that Bastard Boy; no Son of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: His last words that he spake to me, were these;
Go, tell the King my Father, that his frown
Hath pierc'd my heart: tell him, if all his Land
Be peopled with obedient hearts like mine,
He needs no lawes to second his displeasure,
To make a general Depopulation:
But that he may not lose so much, I pray
That in my Death his misse-plac'd anger die,
And that his wrath have double force 'gainst those
That to his Person and his Laws are Foes.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Did he say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: And then, as if the Spirit of Prayer
Had onely been habitual in his soul,
He did implore Heaven's goodness to come down,
Lifting him hence to shine upon your Crown.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: This Boy yet might be mine, though Sforza might have wrong'd me by the By.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.P: This done, he pray'd me leave the Roome. I wept: In sooth I could-not chuse.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Well, well, you wept, return'd, and found him dead in's Bed you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Yes, in so sweet a Posture, as no Statuarie
With best of skill on most immaculate Marble
Could fashion him an Image purer, slighter.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No more.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: I found his stretch'd-out fingers which so lately
Had clos'd his eyes, still moistned with his tears;
And on his either cheek a tear undryed,
Which shone like Stars.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: It seems he wept and died.
Prithee no more: I cannot though forget
My threatnings were too sharp: I must forget it.
I charge you that you leavy up our Army
Against those Rebels that we hear give succour
Unto the wretched cause of all my mischiefes,
That hated ill-liv'd woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: O my dread liege?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The matter? speaks; how does the Queen?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: O the sweet Queen! I fear, I fear, I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What fearst thou? speak the worst I charge thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I fear she has a Moonflaw in her brains:
She chides and fights that none can look upon her.
Her Fathers Ghost, in her I think: here she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Where's this King? this King of Clouts,

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Fearful effect of Pride!

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: This shadow of a King, that stands set up
As in a Press among the Raggs and Vizors
That represent his deceas'd Ancestors.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What means my love?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Your love? where is your love?
Where is the preparation that you promis'd
Of strength to tear in pieces that vile Witch
That lives my souls vexation? your love?
You are a load of torment: your delays
To my desires are Hellish cruelties.
Are these your Promises?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I have given order with all speed I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: You could cut off an old man in a Prison,
That could make no resistance, and you could
Vex a poor Boy to death, that could but cry
In his defence; that you could do; but this
That has so much shew of fear or hardness,
As a few Peasants to maintain a Strumpet
Against your Dignitie, is too much to do
For a poor coward King.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: What a tyrannous Ambition
Has the Devil puff'd up this Bladder with!

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I fear her wits are craz'd indeed. Alinda,
Hear me gentle love.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: O my torment!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: As I am true to the Crown, I know not what to say to this: she's falling mad sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: No, no, you dare not do't: your Army may
Perhaps i'th' dangerous Action break a shin,
Or get a bloody nose: it now appears
My Father (as 'twas voyc'd) was all your valour.
Y' have never a Mars or Cuckold-making General
Now left: and for your self, you'r past it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: His' tother wife would not have us'd him thus.
Quiet Cuckoldrie is better then scolding chastitie all the world over.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I see distraction in her face.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Did all your brave Commanders die in Sforza?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: By the Kings favour Madam (not to stir
The dust of your dead Father) he has Souldiers
That know to lead and execute no less
Then did victorious Sforza.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.P: Sirrah! you have stirr'd more then his dust; you have mov'd his blood in me, unto a Justice that claims, they trayterous head.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: My head? and Trayterous? I do appeal un∣to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: A King? a Cobweb.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: And she the Spider in't I fear.
My Loyaltie knowes not how to look upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: If thou beest King, thou yet art but that King
That ows me love and life, and so my subject.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Indeed Alinda;—

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Yes indeed Gon∣zago,
Life by inheritance: for my valiant Father
Whose life thou tookst, gave thine, and so 'tis mine.
And for your love, you dare not wrest it from me;
Therefore deny not now my just demand,
In that proud Traytors head.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: She's mad be∣yond all cure.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Examine his offence, my dear Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Is't not enough Alinda doth command it?
Are these the Articles you gave me grant of?
Is this the nothing that you would deny me?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Sweet, weigh but his offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: His Head is my offence: and give me that
Now, without pause, or by the strength of Hercules
Ile take thee by the Horns, and writhe thine own off.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Go from her sight Petruccio; levie up our Forces,
And let the Boy Gonzago be embowell'd,
And sent as a forerunner of our Furie
Unto that Witch, contriver of these woes.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: 'Tis done, my liege.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Was ever woman barr'd her will, as I am?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Here's a fine woman spoil'd now, by humo∣ring her at first, and cherishing her Pride.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Sure you have but mock'd me all this while:
I am no wife, no Queen, but silly Subject.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: 'Tis a disease in her that must be sooth'd:
Sweet, thou shalt have his Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: O, shall I so?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Go in, it shall be brought thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Mark what I say to bind you to your word:
Do it, or Ile not love you: I can change
Love into hate, hate into love most sweetly:
Let that man live to morrow, Ile love him,
And do fine feats with him, such as your tother wife
And Sforza did; but make much better sport on't.
They were an old dry couple.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Take this, take all.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: I leave all to your Kingly consideration:
You know your charge: look to't, and so I leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What wild Affections do in women raign!
But this a Passion past all President.
O 'tis meer Madness, mix'd with Divellish cunning,
To hurl me upon more and endless mischiefes:
It has awak'd me to the sight of those
My fury (sprung from Dotage) hath already
Laid in my Path, grim Spectacles of horror,
The blood of Sforza, and that tender Boy:
O let me think no further, yet stay there:
To plunge at first into too deep a Sense
Of soul-afflicting terrours, drowns the Reason,
And stupifies the Conscience, which delivers
Us over to an insensibilitie
Of our misdeeds, and of our selves: just Heaven!
Afford me light to see I am misled:
But let it not as lightning blast mine eyes,
Confound my Senses, make me further stray,
For ever coming back to know my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: How fares your Majesty?

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: O Horatio! shee's lost, shee's lost, Horatio.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I would my wife were with her then:
And so would any good Subject say; I think.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What dost thou think?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Marry I think (and so would any good Sub∣ject think, I think) as your Majestie thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What dost thou think of Loyaltie now?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Truly I think there's now not any warrant∣able Loyaltie left but in Petruccio and my self.
The Queen is now out of my Catalogue, and my Creed too.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: [A shout within] crying, Kill him, kill him: for Sforza, Sforza: kill him for the blood of Sforza, Sforza, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What terrible, what hideous noise is this?
Kill him for Sforza, Sforza; kill him, kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: My Loyaltie defend me! I know not what to make on't.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What art thou? speak: hadst thou the voice of Hell,
Denouncing all the Furies in't, I dare yet hear thee; speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: O mighty Sir, Petruccio.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What of Petruccio?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: O Petruccio! I tremble but to speak him.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Shall I then with the Prophetique Spirit of a King
Speaks of Petruccio? he is turn'd Traytor,
And animates the Souldiers against me,
Upon the discontent Alinda gave him
Now in her Fury: is't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: 'Tis so, 'tis so: ne'er ask him for the matter:
I thought so, just, just as your Majestie thought it;
And find withall, that now you have not left
A Loyal heart but in Horatio's bosome,
Now that Petruccio fails: I fear'd 'twould come
To that: nay knew't: O hang him, hang him,
False hearted villain! he was never right,
And so I always told your Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The cry comes neerer still: what does he mean,
To bring my Army on to Massacre
Me in my House?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: Dread Sir, vouchsafe atten∣tion:
Petruccio is Loyal: 'tis his Loyaltie,
And most sincere obedience to your will,
That brings him to the ruine of his life,
Unless your aweful Presence make prevention.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Is then his Loyaltie become his danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: As thus great Sir, in the late Execution
Of Death-doom'd Sforza, which the Souldier
(Not looking on your Justice, but the Feud
That was betwixt Petruccio and him)
Resents as if it were Petruccio's Act,
Not yours, that cut him off: and still, as madly
Bewitch'd with Sforza's love, as ignorant
Of the desert of brave Petruccio,
They all turn head upon him: and as if
'Twere in his power to new create him to them,
They cry to him for Sforza, Sforza; or if not,
Petruccio's life must answer Sforza's blood.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Left you him in that distress?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: He did prevail
With much entreatie, by some private reasons,
Upon their fury for an hours respite:
In which dear time 'tis onely you may save
Guiltless Petruccio from a timeless Grave.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thou art a Souldier, art not?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: And have commanded in your Highnesse Wars.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Me thinks I should remember, but Ile trust thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I hope you'll be advis'd, though, how you run
Into this wild-fire of Rebellion.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My Fortune is more desperate then his:
I am beset and circled in with mischiefes.
Way-laid with heaps of dangers every where:
Yet I will on: Kings were not made to fear.
Ile fetch him off, and the more readily,
For my misprision of his Loyaltie.
Could I think that man false?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: No Sir, nor I:
By all meanes fetch him off: that Loyal General
Is tenfold worth the whole Rebellious Army:
Save him, and hang them all.
SP.STAGE: Enter Petruccio with a Rabble of Souldiers, and two Captains, crying, Come, come, away with him, away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Have you no Faith, nor due obedience
Unto the King? this outrage is 'gainst him,
In me he suffers.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Capt.
SP.L: We obey the King,
And 'tis his Justice that we cut your throat,
For doing such outrage in the death of our brave General,
That had you lives more then false drops of blood,
They were not all sufficient satisfaction for his losse.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Capt.
SP.L: Your limited hour draws on apace: Prepare.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: He's come within that hour, that shall relieve me.
Where is he? is he come?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: You are betray'd:
He's fled and gone: no such man to be found.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Then Faith is fled from man: is Sforza fled?
Why should I wish to live, now Honour's dead?
Now take your bloody course, and in my fall,
Martyr the man that sav'd your General.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Capt.
SP.L: Sav'd him? how sav'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Sforza lives.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: How's that? how's that? that, that again.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: As I now live, I set him free from Prison,
Trusting unto his Honour to secure me,
In which I did abuse the Kings Authoritie
To th' forfeit of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sold.
SP.L: This sounds: this sounds.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Capt.
SP.L: But does this sound well from a Souldiers mouth?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Capt.
SP.L: He is not now worthy of death, before He be well whipt for lying.
The King, the King, the King!

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Capt.
SP.L: He could never come in a better time, to see how bravely we will do justice for him.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How comes this Fury rais'd amongst ye Souldiers?
Have you forgot my Laws and Person too?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Capt.
SP.L: We honour both thus low: now gives us leave
To look like men, and give your Highness welcome
To see a General of your Election
Die with a lie in's mouth: your Souldier here,
None of the good Queens old ones.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Dare you both judge and execute this man?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Capt.
SP.L: We dare to kill the Hangman of our General,
And think it fits our Office best: though you
Have Law enough to wave our care and pain,
And hang him up your self: for he affirms
That he let Sforza live 'gainst your command;
And that's the lie we treat of.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Ile give you all your Pardons, and him Honour,
To make that true. Sfor. Your Kingly word is taken.
Noble Petruccio, thou art disengag'd:
And if the temper of the Kings high Anger
Blow still above his Justice, let it crush
This cloud that holds a shower of innocent blood,
Willing to fall and calm his violent fury.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Our General lives: a Sforza, Sforza.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: You have outdone me in Nobilitie.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I am all wonder: now this man appears
The Mansion and habitual Seat of Honour;
Of which he seems so full, there cannot be
An Angle in his breast to lodge so base
An Inmate as disloyaltie: if so,
How was Eulalia false? or how Gonzago,
That tender Boy, the fruit of lawless lust?
There I am lost again: Great Power, that knowest
The subtletie of hearts, shew me some light
Through these Cymmerian mists of doubts and fears,
In which I am perplex'd even to distraction:
Shew me, shew me yet the face of glorious Truth; where I may read
If I have err'd, which way I was misled.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Enters. O my dread Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thy news?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: O my sweet Soveraign!

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Art thou distracted too?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: No Sir: The Queen, the Queen, the Queen's distracted,
And I am like to be, and you, and any man
That loves the King, unless some Conjurer
Be found to lay the Devil: I mean Sforza.
Sforza Sir (would you think?) that monstruous Traytor
Sforza walks in the Court without a Head;
Appear'd unto the Queen: I found her talking with him,
Kneeling and praying him to give her Pardon;
Told him indeed 'twas she that sought his Head,
And that she thought, that being now a Queen,
She might by her Prerogative take Heads,
Whose and as many as she listed: but
She promis'd she would send it him again,
Or else Petruccio's first: or if he would forgive her
This time, shee'ld do so no more.
He seem'd he would not hear her: then she beat
Her self against the walls and floor, and flies
To free her self by th' windows: calls for Poison,
Knife, Rope, or any thing, whereby to follow
Her most abused Father. What to make on't,
As I am true to th' Crown, I must refer
Onely unto your Majestie.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: O 'tis fearful!

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: My Lord, you saw not th' Apparition, did you?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Not I: I saw him not: nor has the Devil
Power in a Traytors shadow to appear
Unto a Loyal Subject. Hah! my Loyaltie
And Truth unto the Crown defend me!
See the very foresaid Devil at my Elbowe,
Head and all now: avoid, attempt me not Satan,
I do conjure thee by all the vertues of a Loyal Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: They are all too weak to charm a Devil Sir;
But me they may, your Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I defie thee Bubsebel.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: What do you see, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Look there, the Apparition, there it is;
As like the Traytor Sforza when he liv'd,
As Devil can be like a Devil—oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Fear not: he lives, and Loyal to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Does the King say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Give me your hand my Lord,
The king will say so, if this be flesh and blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I, if thou beest flesh and blood: but how to believe that I know not, when my touch makes me sweat out a whole showre of pure Loyaltie.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No more, Horatio: I find that my credulitie
Has been wrought on unto my much abuse,
And Sforza now appears an honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Who ever thought otherwise? or how
Could he in nature appear less then Loyal?
O my right noble Lord, I weep thy welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Back Souldiers, to your dutie: learn of me
Hereafter how to judge with equitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sould.
SP.L: Long live the King.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Now in the midst of my soul-frighting ob∣jects,
I cannot but applaud your mutual Friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Yes, and how equally I affect them both.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: O that mischance propitiously might be
A light to reconcile my thoughts and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: May you be pleas'd Sir then to let the cause
In which your injur'd Queen, your Son and I,
And truth it self have suffered, be review'd?
The mischievous creature that was drunk, now's mad
With brain-confounding strong Ambition:
She whom your ill-plac'd love Grac'd as a wife,
Whom now I am not fond of to call Daughter,
It seems is past Examination.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Mad, mad, most irrecoverably mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: But let those Hell-bred witnesses be call'd,
And re-examined.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: They are not to be found.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No? where is Flavello?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: Not seen in Court these ten dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Let me out-squeeze that Court-Sponge.
If I do not fetch out the poisonous corruption
Of all this Practice, let me yet be guiltie.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: From whence art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Your Pro∣vince of Palermo
Thus low submits in dutie to your Highness,
The Service and the lives of whose Inhabitants
So truely are subjected to your Power,
That needless is the Preparation
Which with much grief we hear you make against us,
By hostile Force to root up a Rebellion
Bred meerly out of Rumour.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Peace, no more:
I find the Province Loyal.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: VVho made doubt on't?
Ile undertake to find more Toads in Ireland,
Then Rebels in Palermo, were the Queen
(Queen did I call her?) that disloyal woman
And that slie Traytor Lodovico out on't.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: See Sforza, see Petruccio, what Lodovico
That trustie and true-hearted Lord has wrote me:
He has ended all my doubts, good man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Ah, ah! does not your grace come to me now?
I thought I would put your Highness to't for once,
To try what you would say: when Lodovico
Does not prove trustie, then let me be truss'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: 'Tis a most happy Information.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I, do you note the Passages?

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: 'Tis indeed worthy a Kings regard: you see your way.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yes, yes, I know now what to do,
And mean to put it presently in Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: This I foresaw would prove an hour of com∣fort.
The Stars themselves ne'er saw events more plainly.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How full of April-changes is our life?
Now a fit showre of sad distilling Rain,
And by and by the Sun breaks forth again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: FEar not good Madam, trust my care and Reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Good Lodovico, though I thank your care
And love to me, yet give me leave to doubt,
That as that cruel and Ambitious woman
Hath oversway'd the Judgement of the King,
She may pervert his Royal purposes
Of Peace and love, to your and my destruction.
Before you sent, would you had tane my Counsel.
SP.STAGE: Enter Pedro with Gonzago, and Letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: To end all doubts, see Pedro is return'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: And happily: see Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: My Gonzago;
My Prince, I should have said.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: Thrice-gracious Mother,
I thank Petruccio, who preserv'd my life,
For nothing more, then this one minutes Bliss,
In which I find your Blessing in a kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Weep not, fair Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: The Lord Petruccio Madam
Presents you these.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Welcome my sweet young Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SP.L: I thank you Lodovico.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Now I see methinks a Court again.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: We shall do shortly; for the King is coming,
And not in terror, but with Grace and Favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: 'Tis happy Heavenly news.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: See here's an Inundation
Of Joys that do like waves orecome each other.
Brave, wise, and valiant Petruccio!
That couldst so happily deceive the King
By a supposed death, to save the Life
Of my sweet Boy: all that I can be sorry for,
Is this: Alinda is Frantick.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedr.
SP.L: Can that grieve you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: He brings her with him: and I hope the change
Of Air, with wholsome Prayers and Physicks Art,
In which I am not ignorant, may restore her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Madam, the Sun shines fairly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: News, news upon news!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: The Queen is kill'd: is not that it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: No nor the King neither, God bless him: they are both alive, with all their Pomp and Train coming to see our School-Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.P: Auspicious Provi∣dence!

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: They take us in their way, for they are pas∣sing to Nicosia, where the King means to keep his word with the Queen, in giving her three what d'ye calls?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Three Boons, as the custom is.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Boons? I Boons: I warrant she'l ask no Baubles.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: O Mistress, you were careful for her, that comes
I warrant but to jeere you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Patience would die, if 'twere not exercis'd.
But now it rests, that we prepare to entertain our Guests.
We must to welcome them make Holy day,
And give our Scholars leave to Feast and Play.
The Swaines you say are perfect in the Dance;
So are my Maids: wee'l leave it for the King.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter King, Alinda, Horatio, Lodovico, Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: I cannot but applaud your mind, Alinda,
But am not much affected with the Subject
On which you purpose now to cast your Favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: More scorn upon my life, and rude vexation.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: If my fair meaning Sir shall prove mistaken,
'Tis but a loving purpose lost.
(O that wretch Flavello!)

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: If she have further purpose then to raise
More sorrow by the Kings displeasure to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Let her alone, her Raign's but short we know.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Is this the sound of want and misery?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Of wantonness I fear, and Luxurie.
(The villain had no purpose but to flatter.)
O Sir, why came we hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Mark the Came∣lion.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: 'Tis most sweet Musick.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Eulalia with three or four Girls, and work in their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Such as the rudeness of the Countrey yields Sir,
Hayl to the King and Queen, and may the thanks
Which on my knees I offer at those Feet
That beautifie and bless this humble Earth
Add many years unto your happy lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: We have e'en seen enough: 'twas all I fear'd,
To find her knee-deep in Hypocrisie.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Seem not to turn away, most gracious Madam,
Before I shew for which I hop'd you came,
The manner how I get a competence to live.
SP.STAGE: [Shews her works, and makes abrave description of Pieces: As Sale-work, Day-work, Night-work, wrought Night-caps, Coyfs, Stomachers.]

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Your work you say, though't be o'th' newest Frame,
I fear your Play is still at the old Game.
Both wayes bring money: is't not so forsooth?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Enough, Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Too much, to tread upon Affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What say you Lodovico?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I say Sir, the distresses of that Lady merit a
Kings Pity, and not such scorn
As I see cast upon her: but the best are women.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: No more.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: May it please your Highness sit, and note the Play
By which we gain when we lay work away.
The Song I taught you last.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: These wenches will be a good help to you at wassel-tide.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: We have varietie for all the Seasons,
Of such poor entertainments, mighty Queen,
To shew our much contentment in their welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Goodness speaks in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: There's for your Song () No, stay, I may transgress
The Law.

SP.SPEAKER: (Lod.
SP.L: O Devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Let her jeer on.)

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Not if you give it for her pains, Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Nay since you warrant it, let's pay and go.
Though I have heard such pains disputed Begging.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: As all Arts are, by the Rewards they find.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Nay I beseech your Majesties.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: What's the Feat now?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Sir, are you pleas'd to prosecute your jour∣ney?
Or do these Beauties and delights enchant you?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Ha? no, come, let's away.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Oh let me yet entreat your Highness stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Not a stroke more I thank you: we have heard
And seen enough: so much, as I must tell you
I cannot but commend your Parents Wisdom,
Who having Calculated your Nativitie,
By which they had the foresight of your fall,
Prevented thus the Planets by their care,
By teaching you to live by Hand and Foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Did ever Daughter of a King thus suffer?
Or has she Pride to smile on Injuries?

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: Sir, you forget Nicosia.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Plots against me?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: She dreams of Treason intended against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: No Divination against her own good, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Mighty Sir, hear me: not to implore your Bountie;
No not your thanks, nor Popular Applause;
But for I am your Subject and your servant,
Bound by your Allegiance as well to prevent
All Ills might pass against you, as to do none.
I could not think it but strict dutie in me
To hasten this discoverie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Treason, and a Letter?
We have never a false Brother amongst us, have we?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: If ever you held your peace, peace now.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: It bears a face of Horror.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Cunning and Gipsie Tricks: will you to Nicosia?

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: What we meant there, we may do here as well.
The Treason's there intended: look ye my Lords!
How careless is this woman of her safetie.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: You Sir are careless: for if there be danger,
VVhere can I fear it but in this place onely?
The world holds not an Enemy of mine,
But this enchantress you maintain against me.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Your motion and your own love drew us hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: I would fain love her, and certainly I should,
But that she still begets fresh cause of Hatred.
She has some Devillish Plot in hand this Instant:
This shew is but the straw that hides the Pit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: No enemy but she? to let her know she lies,
Even unto Prophanation against that Lady,
Ile speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I hope you will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: The King shall see his error.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: She her crueltie.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Will you, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: The world Eulalia's Pietie.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Will you? will you?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What says Lodovico?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Most mighty Sir, we here confess and say.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: We? you hear not me say any thing; do you?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What will you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: That Letter was not ours.

SP.SPEAKER: H
SP.L: That's well.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: We easily believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nor any day or place as yet set down
Among our selves, for fact against the Queen.
I mean Alinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Nor fact intended was there, of death or danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: 'Twas wish'd at least by us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: Lord, Lord,
Lord mumb.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Our Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: King she's the General grudge of all thy Kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: You do not hear me say so.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Their grudge incites my love: take e'm away.
Come my wrong'd Alinda: This place shall serve,
And this Assembly, to make a Kings word good.
Make your Demands: three things I promise you.
Ask what you will, even to my dearest blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Your Highness will excuse me, if I urge you
To bind it with an Oath?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Give me a Book.
VVhat I have promis'd to my lawful Queen,
I will perform; ask freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Great Queen, vouchsafe to take an Admoni∣tion,
My last and truest Testimonie of Love.
The rest were shadows to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Well, pray let's hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Let your Demands be for the common good.
Not for your own respects: selflove may hurt you:
Beware Ambition, Envie, and Revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: The Oracle could not pronounce more wisely.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Is this your love? 'tis fear of my just Ven∣geance.
Therefore hear my demands, my King and Husband.
First I demand the lives of these conspirators

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Bloody.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Next that your Son, mch of the Mothers Nature,
By Act of Parliament be disinherited.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: O fearful.

SP.SPEAKER: Alin.
SP.L: Last, that this woman have her eyes put out,
And be for ever banish'd your Dominions.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Crueltie and Ingratitude past all Example

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Was this your Charitie? you have now de∣clar'd it fully:
And I of both have made sufficient Tryal.
Come here Eulalia, take now thy wonted Seat and keep it ever.
Thy povertie and patience have restor'd thee
By the just Providentce: while her Excesse and Pride
Casts her before thee, to receive that Doom
She had devis'd 'gainst thy immortal Goodness.
Into perpetual Exile; hence, away with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alind.
SP.L: Remember your Oath, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: My Oath was to perform what I had pro∣mis'd unto my lawful Queen: that's my Eulalia.
And let good Lodowick and Horatio be restor'd.
SP.STAGE: Exeunt King and Attendants Alinda en∣transed carried out.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Oh! proh! proh Nef as!
Ile have no hand in blood of any man.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: More exclaimations? what distracts you now?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.

L.HI: Coram Senatures acta est: sub Judice lis est.

SP.L: Ocurvae in Terris animae: the Rusticks
Have tane again the Law into their hands.
And will you tender clemencie non justante
A Courtiet hang, his sweet Face nec invante.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVhat is his Name?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: His Name is hight Alphonso
That Treason brought in Pectore & Skonso

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: VVho are the heads of the Judicious Faction?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Andrea, Lollio, Poggio, the Drudges
Have got the Peoples voice to their Judges.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Dare they do this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Yes Judges they will be,
And kill, they say, the Snake of Treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I hope we may come yet to stay their Sen∣tence.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Pray bring us to the place: where if we can,
Let us avert their Judgement from this man.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. VI.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Andrea, Poggio, Lollio, a Typstaff before them.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: And can these turmoiles never have an end?
Unless we load our heads and shoulders thus
Our bodies eke with Justice Capa Pe.
And Pepper all our brains with Policie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: 'Twas time to have a care: I, and a piteous care.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: A pious care you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Well pious then:
You'l shew your own wit, whose clothes soever you wear
(So do the wits of the time) but as I said,
'Tis time we have a care, for though our Queen,
Our School Mistress I would say, be mercifully, idleful
It is fit that we be prejudicious in the State.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Ju-dicions Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Jew in your face.
Trip me again?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Agree upon't, Brother Sages of the Bench.
My Brother Poggio here said very well
And learnedly and as I would have said my self?
(If you will take his meaning) to wit that as
Our Shool Mistris doats upon
Clemencie, it is fit that we run mad upon crueltie
Someeting her in the midst, we shall jump into the Sadle of Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: I do say so, without all peradventure
For if the Candle of her mercy be not put out,
VVe shall shortly, see more honest men then Knaves among us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: More Knaves you mean Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: I mean no more Knaves then your self, Bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Agree again, Sage brothers of the Bench: and let no private
Itch grow to a put like Scab.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Then the point:
Do not I understand the purpose of our meeting
Here in our pettie Parliament, if I may so call it?
Is it nor for a Reformation, to pull down
The Queens mercy, and set up our Justice?
For the prevention of a superabundance of Treason
Dayly practiced against her?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Most true. And is it fit therefore that you brabble among your selves, and leave all worse then you found it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: No, we will make such a Reformation, that Treason shall not dare to peep over the Hedge of her Dominion, but we will take it by the nose and punish it indignely: most indignely will we punish it?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: All this I grant: but before we sit and bustle on the Bench, because it is, and that without all per∣adventure, the strst time that ever we play'd so wise a part, is it not fit to take advice among our selves, how to deform our selves in our office.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: De did you say? in in you should say.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: In with your Horns: how now?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Nay Brothers o'th Bench.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Does he think to control me? because he has been a Sexton, and a little more book learned then a Lay man with an Amen forsooth?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Nay Bro∣thers: this will control the business.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Or because he has been in many a mans grave before him, does he think no man so deep in grave matters as himself?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Well, I forbear.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Shall he bid me In, In? as if I were not his inserior?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: I forbear still.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: I will shew my self his inferior I, and a greater man then he; and to prove my self a great man, let him hang one, I will save two.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Still orbear.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Pray Brothers yet agree: and remember we use no mercy

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Let him that uses any mercy lack mercy, for my part.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Then let us sit, and fall to the Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Sit and fall: was that so wisely spoken of a book-learned man now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Still I forbear Passion becomes not Judges,
Now bring in the offender, the new and last offender.

SP.SPEAKER: And.
SP.P: Pray thinke on your speeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: I have made speeches that I hope shall make Traytors.

SP.SPEAKER: And.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: Asham'd to wear their own heads on their shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P:
A Traytors head is not his own head: 'tis forfeired by Law to
the King; 'tis the Kings head.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: I say a Traytors head is his own Head: and a good Subjects head is the Kings Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: I say that's Treason: and the head thou wearest is not thine own then, if thou beest a good Subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Wilt thou tell me that?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Passion becomes not Judges, Brothers o'th the Bench.
SP.L: The offender comes,
Now they are hot, he shall be sure to smoak for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: Whither do you hale me? you Pease-por∣ridge Peasants:
Is this a place for me to come to Tryal in?
If I had broke the Law, as I have not
I am a Peer, and do appeal unto
The Kings high Seat of Justice, publikely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: And will not our low stool of Justice, privily
SP.L: Serve for a Traytor? ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: Your selves are Traytors,
SP.L: In succouring 'gainst the Law, a dissolute woman
Whom I command you, in the Kings high name,
To yield into my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol. Pog. Andr.
SP.P: You shall be hang'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: By whose Authority?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: By the said wo∣mans Sir.
SP.L: She is our Queen and her Authority is in our hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: That speaks you Traytors: and the King has Law against you and her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.P: When you are hang'd he has: to the next able
SP.L: Tree with him, and hang him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: Villains: you dare not so say.

SP.SPEAKER: Omu.
SP.L: We do all say Hang him with one accord:

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.L: If on cord will not do't another shall:
So come away Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Stay: hear a speech first.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: You dare not use me thus: dare you take Justice one ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Yes Sir, we can spie
Great faults in Noble Coats, with half an eye.
What though we nod? does Treason therefore think
Justice is adle brain'd? or though she wink
In us (as thus) that she's a sleep? or say
She take a nap, d' ye think shee'l sleep for ay?
No, she but dreams a while, to circumvent,
Your vains hopes, with sharper punishment.
For if she be but jogg'd, no Mastife takes
Swifter or surer vengeance when she wakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: I, hang him, hang him.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Is he not hang'd yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Without all peradventure the Hangman means to hang for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Guard.
SP.L: Come Sir along, never hang backward, for up you must.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Stay him, my speeches will be lost else.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: Your long speeches will loose our purpose again, without all peradventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: Must I be mock'd out of my life? and have
My death by hanging made a sport to Peasants,
In this blind hole oth' Kingdom?

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.P: Why thou choplogicall Fellow, dost thou not think, there are as good men hang'd, and as good sport made of it too, in the bli holes of the Kingdom, as in the very eye or open mouth of it? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: Away with him without peradventure

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: I am a Courtier, and servant to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Lot.
SP.L: Come all the Court in all your costly Braveries.
And Treason in your Breech, we'll hang you for your Knaveries,
On tree in Hempen twine nay if you come
In open Arms, up shall you all and some.
For though for Tournament your Fames do flie
Run all at Tilt on us, wee'l draw you dry.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Tell us you are a Courtier? we find here
Fus to correct, which you perceive not there.
So, now away with him, I have spoke my best.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: And without all peradventure well said Judge Andrea:
How long must we say away with him? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: You hobnayl'd Rascals: can you think that you
Are fit to spie or corrects faults at Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Stay, a short speech for that, and turn him off.
Your shoes at Court are all too fine and thin:
To tread out snuffes and sparks of kindling Sin,
Which let alone the Rushes may take fire.
Then flame, then burn up higher still, and higher:
You warm you at such fire, 'tis we walk through't
The hobnayl'd Common wealth must tread it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: So, now away with him. Hang him first, d' ye hear
He has the bast clothes, that will encourage
The Hangman the better to turn the rest after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Enl.
SP.L: Whither away with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: So, now you see what's become of your fine seches.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Will ye, 'gainst all my Counsels and requests
Persist to pull destruction by taking others lives upon your own?
And seem to carry it as in care for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: No, 'tis in care of our selves, because we know
Not to breed our Children honestly without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Have I not often councell'd and entreated
You would forbear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Your councels and entreats
We are bound to disobey by Proclamation:
For we must grant you nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: VVell found out.

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.P: And therefore if you say, Hang not this man We are bound to hang him; we will shew our selves the Kings Subjects not yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: If you can answer't to the King, 'tis well;
His Majesty is here at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Go leave him unto me.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: The King at hand? 'tis time for us to look about us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lol.
SP.L: Must not we be hang'd now?

SP.SPEAKER: Pog.
SP.L: It will be so, without all peradventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Release your Prisoner, set him free, and go send the rest of the confederats.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: I was not bound till now
I have no power to move or stir a limb:
O sacred Queen, use mercy, in adudging me,
To present death, to quit me of the torment.
That rages all upon me, all within me.
The sight of you has shot more paines into me
Then I have drops of blood: O let me die.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: I cannot give thee death: nor will my prayers
Be prevalent for thy cure poor sinful man!
Till rhou layst ope the cause of thy disease;
(Thy hainous sin) by fair and free confession.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: I hope no cure, and therefore ask no life.
But the Kings Justice to afford me death,
That is no less deserved then desir'd;
For I confess, This my Device was but
To make my way to you, t' have murder'd you.
SP.STAGE: Enter two Lieutenants, Doctor and Midwife.
SP.L: Wrought thereunto by Alinda's Instigation.
More I confess; The Evidence against you,
Whereby you were despos'd, was false.
And all these witnesses which now do bring
Addition to my to my torment, did I hire
Both for their perjury past, and for their late
Attempt upon your life, with the Queens money.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Do you confess it?

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Heaven Pardon our misdeed: it is most true.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Heaven grant you all your cures.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: All blessings on the Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: All was confess'd before by Fabio and Strozzo.
And you do well to seem so penitent:
I do forgive you: and will plead your pardon unto the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: Your sacred mercy Madam, shall save a life then, to be spent in Praises and Prayers for your Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Go, and pray for grace to mend your lives.
So, let's now to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Now look you about you: cast your Coats, and instantly
Hast to the Curat, hee's preparing sports,
In speech and Dance, to entertain the King:
Go and assist him: that must be the way
To gain your Pardons.

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Come then, let's away,
No longer Brothers of the Bench wee'l be,
But of the Revels for his Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: These troubles over: let us, now
Surveigh this part of my Possession.
I never saw before. I could contemplate
This late neglected peece of my Estate,
To be the happiest: sure it is no less,
To those that think on earth there's happiness,
The Air disperseth pleasure and the Earth
Of fresh delight to every step gives birth.
Here plentie grows, and above it content,
Ore spreads the Face of all the Continent.
Eulalia, thou art happy, and didst rise,
Not fall from Court into this Paradise.
Thy can it move my admiration much,
Thy vertue wrought the change, and made it such.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: My Lord, the King is sad, what shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I am as sad as he, and should be dead,
If he were dead: and therefore no fit member
To make Him merry, I: try your vein with him,
Tell him your Daughters dying; that may cheer him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sfor.
SP.L: Are you so tart Court Blain-worm?

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yet can I smile in midst of grief to think
How the Court malice hath been wav'd and punished,
By Rustical simplicitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.L: The Sun
Appears again in the Kings smiles: observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: I thank your Majestie, that sweet smile re∣viv'd me,

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Who smil'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: not I, I'm sure did you: or you?
SP.P: There could be no such thing: who dares be mer∣ry, when the King's sad?

SP.SPEAKER: Petr.
SP.P: Yes, here are some now coming, I hear 'm, that are merry in hope to make the King so.

DIV3.HEAD: Scoen. IX.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Curat richly rob'd, and Crown'd with Bays, playing on a Fiddle, many School Boys with Skaerfes and Nosegays, &c. then follow Gonzago, dress'd and Crown'd as Queen of the Girles, fol∣lowing her: at last Eulalia supported by Lodovico and Andrea: Alphanso, Strozzo, Fabio, D. Mid∣wife. The former being all pass'd over the Stage: they kneel to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: O my Enlalia!

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: Still the most humble Handmaid
To your high Majestie.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thy words are sweet:
Yet to my guiltie sense they are not less
Then thunder bolts; fram'd of the wrongs I shot
Against the Heavenly Region of thy mind.
And 'tis but Justice that the repercussion
Do strike me dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: No Passion mighty Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.L: O my sweet Queen! but I am thunder struck

SP.SPEAKER: Andr.
SP.L: Old Lad, art there? still sick oth' Kings disease.

SP.SPEAKER: Eul.
SP.L: If I may presume of any favour, vouchsafe a glance on these.

SP.SPEAKER: Alphonso Stro. Fab. Doctor and Mid.
SP.L: Besech your Highness.
SP.STAGE: Enter Curat Gonzago in his hand veil'd three or four Lasses.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.L: Thus have you seen great King in best array,
Nostri Discipuli have made Holy-day,
Whilst I their Paedagogue or pettie King
Present in hand this little Royal Thing,
Yclep'd their Queen or Mistriss: certe fallor
For that's the Royal School Misttess as we call her.
And this her under Usner: vey'ld is she,
Dreading the Power of shinning Majesty.
Might dazle her Dancing: for nunc est saltandum,
And here are Lads and Lasses that at Random
Have left their works, as we the School & Templum,
To follow us; 'tis Regis ad Exemplum.
The youth's are muffled for their better graces,
Though you may like their feet, youl'd blame their Faces
But Ile not trouble you with long Oration,
